Ordinance No. 2019-4050

the “Village”) has the authority to regulate the sale, possession, and delivery of alcoholic liquor and from time to time limit the number of liquor licenses it
authorizes and issues and make other modifications to its Village Code; and

forth:

the text of this Ordinance as its findings to the same extent as if each such recital had been set forth herein in its entirety.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 7/522
ORDINANCE NO. 2019-4058
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE
VILLAGE OF BARRINGTON VILLAGE CODE
RE: Title 1, “Administration”:
Section 1-14-1, “Enumerated”, of Chapter 14,
“Fees, Charges, Deposits, and Other Amounts Payable to the Village”; and
Title 4, “Public Health and Safety”:
New Chapter 8, “Unattended Collection Boxes”
WHEREAS, many unattended collection boxes and the areas around such boxes are not properly or consistently maintained, which has resulted in blighted
conditions which can attract and harbor vermin and wild animals which can pose a public health hazard, and which can be a source of unsightly and/or offensive graffiti
and other unsightly and/or unsanitary conditions; and
WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities of the Village of Barrington (“the Village”) have determined that it is in the best interests of the residents of the Village to
amend Section 1-14-1 of Title 1 relative to fees for placement of unattended collection boxes on real property within the Village and to amend Title 4, “Public Health and
Safety”, of the Village of Barrington Village Code by adding a new Chapter 8, “Unattended Collection Boxes, in order to establish regulations relative thereto as set forth
herein:
NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Barrington, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois, as follows:
SECTION 1: The Corporate Authorities of the Village hereby find that the recitals hereinabove set forth are true and correct and are incorporated into the text of
this Ordinance as its findings of fact to the same extent as if such recitals had been set forth herein in their entirety.
SECTION 2: That portion of the chart entitled “Title 4, Public Health and Safety”, of Section 1-14-1, “Enumerated”, of Chapter 14, “Fees, Charges, Deposits, and
Other Amounts Payable to the Village”, of Title 1, “Administration”, of the Barrington Village Code, shall be and is hereby amended by the addition of a fee for the
placement of unattended collection boxes on real property within the Village, which shall read as follows (underlined language shall be added, and interlined language
shall be stricken):
Title 4, Public Health and Safety:
TYPE
VILLAGE

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 8/522
* * * *
SECTION 3: Title 4, “Public Health and Safety”, of the Village of Barrington Village Code shall be and is hereby amended by the addition of a new Chapter 8,
“Unattended Collection Boxes”, which new Chapter 8 shall read as follows:
“CHAPTER 8: UNATTENDED COLLECTION BOXES
4-8-1: INTENT OF UNATTENDED COLLECTION BOX REGULATIONS: The intent of this Chapter is to regulate and restrict the placement of unattended collection
boxes within the Village. The purpose of these regulations and restrictions is to:
A. Promote the community’s health, safety, and welfare by regulating unattended collection boxes for clothing or other salvageable personal property within the
Village;
B. Ensure that unattended collection boxes do not pose a hazard to pedestrian and vehicular traffic;
C. Ensure that material is not allowed to accumulate outside of the unattended collection boxes where it can be scattered by adverse weather conditions, animal
contacts and human activities; and
D. Establish criteria that avoid attracting vermin, unsightliness, and public health hazard.
4-8-2: DEFINITIONS: For purposes of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
OPERATOR means a person, entity, association or organization who places, maintains or operates unattended collection box(es) to invite or solicit the deposit or
donation of salvageable personal property.
PERMITTEE means the operator who is issued a permit (with written authorization of the property owner) for placement of an unattended collection box.
PROPERTY OWNER means the person, entity, association or organization who owns the real property where the unattended collection box(es) are or are
proposed to be located.
UNATTENDED COLLECTION BOX means any unattended container, receptacle, or similar device that is located on any property within the Village used for
inviting or soliciting and collecting clothing or other salvageable personal property, not including food items.
4-8-3: PERMITS:
A. Unless otherwise exempt pursuant to Section 4-8-7 of this Chapter, it shall be unlawful and a public nuisance for any property owner/operator to place,
operate, maintain or allow unattended collection boxes to be located anywhere on any real property within the Village unless the collection box operator first
obtains a permit therefor from the Village pursuant to this Chapter and the collection box is placed, operated and maintained in accordance with all
provisions in this Chapter and any other applicable provisions of this Code.
B. An application for a permit to locate an unattended collection box must be submitted to the Village for each proposed unattended collection box to be located
within the Village and shall be submitted on such form as the Village Manager, or his or her designee may prescribe and shall be accompanied by:
(1) Sample of contact information to be displayed on collection box (two (2) inches type minimum and weather-resistant) visible from front of box: name,
address, E-mail address and telephone number of operator/permittee;
(2) A site plan that shows the proposed location of the collection box and provides measurements that illustrate the location requirements set forth in this
Chapter;
(3) A recent color photo that shows the proposed location of the collection box; and
(4) Submittal to the Village Manager, or his or her designee, for prior written approval of an “Affidavit and Acknowledgement of Owner(s) of Record
Giving Permission to Locate Unattended Collection Box on Real Property” evidencing that the property owner, property manager or authorized agent
has consented to a collection box on the property through a lease agreement or notarized owner consent, which consent shall be in substantially the
form set forth below:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 9/522
AFFIDAVIT AND ACKNOWLEDGEMENT OF
OWNER(S) OF RECORD GIVING PERMISSION TO
LOCATE UNATTENDED COLLECTION BOX ON REAL PROPERTY
STATE OF ILLINOIS )
) SS.
COUNTY OF ________ )

permission to locate an unattended collection box on real property and state as follows:

Barrington, Illinois (the “real property”).

located at ______________________________________________________________,

place not more than two (2) collection boxes on the real property owned by me or the entity I
represent in the location as shown on the drawing attached hereto as Exhibit A.
3. I have been provided and have read a copy of the Village of Barrington Unattended Collection
Boxes Regulations (Chapter 8 of Title 4 of the Barrington Village Code, the “Village
Ordinance”) and understand the requirements contained therein for issuance, renewal,
revocation of such a permit and the Village’s remedies and penalties for non-compliance with
those Regulations.
4. I understand that in addition to the unattended collection box operator, the owner of the
property is also responsible for: (a) ensuring the requirements of the Village of Barrington are
met; (b) the maintenance of each such unattended collection box and that the area surrounding
each such collection box are free from any junk, debris or other material, (c) violation(s) of any
provision(s) of the Village’s Ordinances, and (d) payment of any fines and costs of abatement.
5. As owner of the property described above or as an officer, director, member or manager
thereof, I give permission to place an unattended collection box on the property by the operator
named above.
Name of Entity Owning
the Real Property

an individual):

County, personally appeared ________________________________________________

the within instrument, who acknowledged the same to be his/her free act and/or the free act of the
Entity who is the owner of the real property.

Notary Public
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 10/522
My commission expires: ____________________
C. Each new application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in the amount as set forth in Section 1-14-1 of this Code. This fee is not pro-ratable and
shall be in addition to any other fee imposed by the Village pursuant to any other provision of the Barrington Village Code.
D. A permit holder may renew a valid current permit by submitting to the Village Manager, or his or her designee, a timely renewal application and paying a
renewal fee in the amount as set forth in Section 1-14-1 of this Code. Timely renewal shall mean the submittal of an application not less than thirty (30) days
before the expiration of the current permit. Non-renewal within this timeframe shall require submittal of a new application and payment of the required
application fee.
E. Applications shall be filed with the Village Manager, or his or her designee.
F. A completed application shall be reviewed within thirty (30) days of receipt or such application shall be deemed to be denied.
G. A permit shall not be issued unless:
(1) The applicant has submitted a complete and accurate application accompanied by the applicable fee(s); and
(2) The proposed location and placement of the proposed unattended collection box on the subject real property is in compliance with all applicable laws
and requirements of this Chapter and any other applicable provisions of this Village Code and the Village’s Zoning Ordinance.
H. If an application is denied, the applicant shall receive written notice thereof, including the specific reasons for such denial.
I. A separate permit issued by the Village is required for each unattended collection box with a maximum of two (2) collection boxes operated by the same
permittee/operator, per each lot or parcel.
J. The term of a permit for placement of an unattended collection box shall be from January 1st through December 31st.
K. No person or operator to whom a permit has been issued shall transfer, assign or convey such permit to another person or operator.
L. A permit holder may surrender the permit by notifying the Village Manager, or his or her designee in writing of the intent to surrender said permit. The
permit shall be null and void upon the Village’s receipt of a written notice of intent to surrender.
4-8-4: REQUIREMENTS AND MAINTENANCE:
A. A permittee/operator shall operate and maintain or cause to be operated and maintained all unattended collection boxes located in the Village as follows:
(1) Collection boxes shall be comprised of metal, resin or other wind-resistant and weather-proof material only.
(2) The size of collection boxes shall not exceed the following dimensions: four (4) feet in width by five (5) feet in length by six and one-half (6 ½) feet in
height.
(3) Unattended collection boxes shall be maintained in good condition and appearance with no structural damage, holes, or visible rust, and shall be free of
graffiti.
(4) Unattended collection boxes shall be locked or otherwise secured.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 11/522
(5) Unattended collection boxes shall contain the following contact information in two (2) inch type visible from the front of each unattended collection
box: The name, address, e-mail, and phone number of both the permittee/operator and the property owner.
(6) Unattended collection boxes shall be serviced and emptied as needed, but at least once per month, or within forty-eight (48) hours after a request by the
Village for same.
B. The permittee/operator shall maintain or cause to be maintained the area surrounding the unattended collection boxes free of any junk, garbage, trash, debris
or other refuse material.
C. The permittee/operator shall be individually and severally responsible for abating and removing all junk, garbage, trash, debris and other refuse material in
the area surrounding the unattended collection boxes within twenty-four (24) hours of written or verbal notice from the Village.
D. The permittee/operator shall be individually and severally responsible to the extent provided by law for all the Village’s costs to abate and remove any
nuisance including junk, garbage, trash, debris and other refuse material from the area surrounding the unattended collection boxes.
E. Unattended collection boxes are only allowed to be located in the following zoning districts, which are described in the Zoning Ordinance and depicted on
the Zoning Map which is part thereof: B-1, B-3, M-1, M-A, A-1, and O-R Zoning Districts.
F. The unattended collection box must be accessory to a principal structure located on the lot or parcel on which such collection box is located.
G. No unattended collection box shall be placed on parking spaces which are required by the Zoning Ordinance and/or by any special use ordinance or zoning
variation ordinance applicable to the property and shall not be placed on a property so as to block any sight line(s) required for the safety of pedestrians or
bicycles or vehicles.
H. Up to two (2) unattended collection boxes may be placed and maintained by the same permittee/operator on a single lot or parcel, or on any group of lots or
parcels, if the two (2) collection boxes are side by side, are no more than one (1) foot apart, and are operated by the same permittee/operator. Unattended
collection boxes located on any lot(s) or parcel(s) must be at least 1,000 feet from the nearest unattended collection box(es) on any other lot(s) or parcel(s),
but this separation requirement shall not be applicable to any unattended collection box(es) which is or are entirely enclosed within a secure principal
structure.
I. No unattended collection box shall be permitted on any unimproved lot or parcel of land, or on any lot or parcel where the principal use of the land has been
closed or unoccupied for more than thirty (30) days.
J. No unattended collection box shall be placed closer than ten (10) feet from:
(1) A public sidewalk;
(2) A public right-of-way and/or any other Village property;
(3) A driveway; or
(4) A side or rear property line of adjacent property used for residential purposes.
K. No unattended collection box shall:
(1) Encroach upon or obstruct a designated fire lane or building exit;
(2) Interfere with an access drive, off-street parking lot maneuvering lane and/or required off-street parking space to an extent which would cause safety
hazards and/or unnecessary inconvenience to vehicular or pedestrian traffic;
(3) Encroach upon an access drive, off-street parking lot maneuvering lane and/or off-street parking space required by the Zoning Ordinance or by any
special use ordinance or zoning variation ordinance which is applicable to the property;
(4) Impede access to or block required accessibility routes for persons with disabilities;
(5) Impede access to or block trash enclosure or trash bin area(s); or
(6) Impede access to or block building ingress and egress.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 12/522
L. Any unattended collection box may be placed on a private sidewalk as long as the remaining unobstructed area of the private sidewalk is still available to
meet all applicable clearances as required by the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Illinois Accessibility Code.
M. Collection boxes shall not be placed on any grass or landscaped area but shall be placed on a level, hard, paved (asphalt or concrete), dust-free surface and
shall be secured in a manner so as to prevent them from being moved or blown over by the wind.
4-8-5: SUSPENSION AND/OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT, REMOVAL OF UNATTENDED COLLECTION BOXES AND LIABILITY:
The Village Manager, or his or her designee, shall have the right to suspend and/or revoke any permit issued hereunder if the unattended collection box(es) is or
are in violation of this Chapter and/or any other provision of this Village Code after the permittee/operator is given written notice thereof and an opportunity to be
heard. Upon revocation of any such permit, a permittee shall be prohibited from applying for a permit under this Chapter for a period of one (1) year. Any
violation of the provisions of this Chapter is and constitutes a public nuisance subject to abatement pursuant to this Village Code or as otherwise permitted by law.
4-8-6: ENFORCEMENT:
A. In addition to all other remedies, including revocation of a permit pursuant to Section 4-8-5, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to
comply with any provision of this Chapter shall be subject to the penalties as provided in Section 1-4-1 of this Village Code for each offense.
B. Any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of the provisions of this Chapter shall be deemed a new and separate offense for each day that each
such condition exists and/or continues.
C. Nothing in this Chapter shall prevent the Village from pursuing any other remedy provided by law in conjunction with or in lieu of prosecuting persons under
this Chapter for violation of this Chapter.
D. The owner(s) of the real property upon which an unattended collection box is located and the permittee shall be jointly and severally liable for each violation
and for payment of any and all applicable fines and any costs of abatement.
4-8-7: EXEMPTION:
Unattended collection boxes located entirely within the interior of a building are exempt from the requirements of this Chapter.”
SECTION 4: The Corporate Authorities of the Village intend that this Ordinance will be made part of the Village Code and that sections of this Ordinance can be
renumbered or relettered and the word “Ordinance” can be changed to “Section”, “Article”, “Chapter”, or some other appropriate word or phrase to accomplish
codification, and regardless of whether this Ordinance is ever codified, the Ordinance can be renumbered or relettered and typographical errors can be corrected with the
authorization of the Village Attorney, or his or her designee.
SECTION 5: If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Ordinance or any part thereof is, for any reason, held to be unconstitutional or
invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of this Ordinance, or any
part thereof. The Corporate Authorities hereby declare that they would have passed each section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof
irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or
ineffective.
SECTION 6: This Ordinance shall not affect any prosecution pending or any penalty, punishment, forfeiture incurred, cause of action, or rights, powers, or
remedies accrued under any ordinance in effect immediately prior to the effective date hereof.
SECTION 7: This Ordinance shall be published in pamphlet form and shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage, approval, and publication.
SECTION 8: The Village Clerk is directed to immedi ately publish this Ordinance in pamphlet form.

SECTION 3: Section 6-3A-2, “Method of Parking”, of Article A, “Village Parking Lots”, of Chapter 3, “Parking Regulations”, of Title 6, “Motor
Vehicles and Traffic”, is hereby amended to read as follows:
“SECTION 6-3A-2: METHOD OF PARKING:
The particular method or methods of parking regulation required and/or allowed in and applicable to each separate municipal parking lot, and other areas
where Village parking permits are required, and each of the parking spaces within such lot or other area, shall be as designated from time to time by
Ordinance or Resolution of the Board of Trustees this Village Code or by the Village Manager, or his/her designee.”
SECTION 4: Section 6-3A-3, “Fees and Hours”, of Article A, “Village Parking Lots”, of Chapter 3, “Parking Regulations”, of Title 6, “Motor Vehicles
and Traffic”, is hereby amended to read as follows:
“SECTION 6-3A-3: FEES AND HOURS:
Fees for utilizing municipal off street parking lots, and other areas where Village parking permits are required, shall be as follows set forth below and are
required to be paid for use of any space controlled or covered by a daily fee automated fare box or similar device (hereinafter referred to as a “fare box”),
by the use of such a fare box or by the use of the Passport Parking Application, or by a current and valid parking permit, or combination thereof as
designated by posted signs.
A. Daily Fee Automated Fare Box or Passport Parking Application:
1. Fee Established; Payment: When a municipal parking lot is controlled by one or more daily fee automated fare boxes, a fee per designated
parking space per day as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code is required to be paid by depositing in such fare box U.S.
currency, by making a payment by credit or debit card, or by utilizing prepaid electronic cards as authorized by the Village or by the use of the
Passport Parking Application. Said Fare boxes shall be placed within the parking lot or within the immediate vicinity thereof at one or more
locations. Immediately after parking the vehicle, said fee shall be deposited or paid via credit/debit card into such a fare box for the number
corresponding with the number of the parking space in which said vehicle has been parked or paid by the use of the Passport Parking
Application.
2. Parking Regulated: Vehicles may only be parked in numbered parking spaces so designated and/or so marked.
3. Hours: Said fee shall be for a Except as otherwise provided herein, parking in all Village parking lots shall be limited to that period from five
o’clock (5:00) A.M. on any day to two o’clock (2:00) A.M. the following day, or any portion of such period and any fee paid shall be applicable to
said period, or any portion thereof.
4. Prepaid Parking Tags are a type of parking permit as described in this Chapter and may be used for daily fee parking areas.
B. Parking Permits:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 19/522
1. Parking Regulations: When a municipal parking lot, or any other area where Village parking permits or prepaid parking tags are required, is
regulated by a parking permit, only those vehicles displaying a current and valid permit or parking tag issued by the Village shall be permitted to
park in designated parking spaces in the municipal parking lot, or in such other areas where Village parking permits or prepaid parking tags are
required, corresponding with the type of parking permit or prepaid parking tag issued by the Village. Notice that parking is by permit or prepaid
parking tag only shall be posted at the entrance to such lots or in proximity to other areas where Village parking permits or prepaid parking tags
are required.
2. Hours: Parking shall only be allowed by such permit or prepaid parking tag for the period from five o’clock (5:00) A.M. on any day to two o’clock
(2:00) A.M. the following day, or any portion of such period, except in designated overnight parking areas after paying the corresponding fee for
a temporary overnight parking permit, or except as otherwise authorized by another appropriate Village parking permit.
3. Fees Established:
a. Fees Established: A daily fee is required to be paid for at a daily fee automated fare box or via the Passport Parking Application or by
payment of the annual or quarterly fees which shall be paid for each parking permit and/or prepaid parking tag issued by the Village. The
fees for a both daily fee parking and parking permit permits and/or prepaid parking tags shall be as follows, which fees may be modified
from time to time by the corporate authorities of the Village: specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code.
(1) That amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code, per quarter, for a permit for commuter lots on the south
side of the Union Pacific Railroad tracks.
(2) That amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code per quarter, for a permit for commuter lots on the north side
of the Union Pacific right of way.
(3) That amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code, per quarter, or that fee as specified from time to time in
Section 1-14-1 of this Code, annually, for a “premium” parking permit which may be used for any lot or other parking area designated
by the Village for employer/employee parking.
(4) That amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code, per year, for a “discount” parking permit, which may be
used as a discounted employer/employee parking permit for any lot or other parking area designated by the Village for such
discounted employer/employee parking.
(5) That amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code for a special parking permit for commuter parking Lot 22 as
described in subsection 6-3A-7B of this Article.
(6) That amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code for an “employer/employee seasonal permit” parking permit
for Lots 10, 13, and 7, and at other designated locations, as described in subsection 6-3A-7A of this Article.
(7) That amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code for a “temporary guest parking” permit available for
purchase by Cook Street Plaza condominium owners, for parking in the Cook Street Plaza underground garage, as described in
subsection 6-3A-7A of this Article.
(8) That amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code for a “temporary (yellow) overnight parking permit,
commuter lot” to permit overnight parking in the commuter lot for a period not to exceed three (3) consecutive days and nights, as
described in subsection 6-3A-7A of this Article.
b. Proration Of Fees; Refunds: The effective date for a All annual or quarterly parking permits and/or prepaid parking tags shall be June 1 of
each year sold annually or quarterly as designated in Section 1-14-1 of this Code and with an effective beginning date as designated by the
Village Manager. These permits Any such parking permit and/or prepaid parking tag may, however, be purchased throughout the year
when available, and in such event, the fee shall be prorated. , but tThe annual or quarterly fee for such parking permits and/or any such
prepaid parking tag refund(s) when turned in and cancelled may, in such cases, shall not be prorated, with the exception of annual
premium permits and permits for the commuter lots on the south side of the Union Pacific right of way (hereinafter, “south lot commuter
parking”). The fee for an annual premium permit shall be prorated based upon the number of full or partial months remaining to the end
expiration date of the calendar applicable permit or prepaid tag year, but in no case shall the fee be less than fifty percent (50%) of the full
annual fee for such permit. The fee for a any quarterly south lot commuter parking permit and/or quarterly prepaid parking tag, and any
refund(s) for a quarterly parking permit or quarterly prepaid parking tag, shall may be prorated on the basis of the weeks which have
already expired in the quarter period based upon thirteen (13) weeks per quarter. Once a permit is issued, no refund shall be provided upon
its return, provided, however, refunds may be made on a pro rata basis as to parking permits for the south lot commuter parking, but only if
the permit for which a refund is sought is resold by the Village for the balance of the period for which it was issued.
c. Lost Permits: The fee for the replacement of a lost permit shall be that amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this
Code.
4. Permit Does Permits or Prepaid Tags Do Not Guarantee Parking: Such Parking permits and prepaid parking tags are shall be issued as a
convenience to users, and the issuance thereof shall does not guarantee the availability of a parking space, which spaces shall be utilized on a
first come, first served priority basis, except as otherwise described in this Chapter.

5. Designated Areas: Permits and prepaid parking tags may only be used in those areas designated by this Chapter, or otherwise as designated

6. Display Required: All parking permits and/or prepaid parking tags shall be hung displayed by hanging same on the rearview mirror at all times
while the vehicle is parked in a designated parking space or the vehicle may be ticketed for failure to display the required permit or tag.”
SECTION 5: Section 6-3A-4, “Parking Without Paying Fee or Displaying Permit or Tag”, of Chapter 3, “Parking Regulations”, of Title 6, “Motor
Vehicles and Traffic”, is hereby amended to read as follows:
“SECTION 6-3A-4: PARKING WITHOUT PAYING FEE OR DISPLAYING PERMIT OR TAG:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in any parking space owned or operated by the Village without paying the applicable daily fee required for such
parking, if any, or without displaying a current, valid permit or prepaid parking tag, as required or allowed by the posted regulations applicable for such
parking space or as allowed by an applicable parking permit.”
SECTION 6: Subparagraph A, “Definitions and Regulations”, of Section 6-3A-6, “Parking Lots, Parking Areas, and Permits Designated”, of
Chapter 3, “Parking Regulations”, of Title 6, “Motor Vehicles and Traffic”, is hereby amended by amending the definition of “Commuter Lots” and by
adding, in alphabetical order, definitions for “Premium Commuter Parking Permit”, “Prepaid Parking Tag”, and “Reverse Commuter Lots”, which shall
respectively read as follows:
“A. Definitions and Regulations:
COMMUTER LOTS: Any parking lots designated by the Board of Trustees where parking is restricted to vehicles displaying commuter lot parking permits
or prepaid parking tags, unless the posted notice in the lot permits parking of vehicles for which a daily fee is paid at a fare box or by the
Passport Parking Application or other permit parking is allowed. Certain commuter lots or portions thereof may be restricted to use by residents
of the communities that are members of the Barrington Area Council of Governments (“BACOG”), and such restriction shall be duly posted.
Certain Commuter lots may be specifically designated for reverse commuters who depart from the Village in the evening after five o’clock (5:00)
P.M. and return to the Village not later than ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. on the next day.
* * * *
PREMIUM COMMUTER PARKING PERMIT: A Premium Commuter Parking Permit authorizes a permit holder to park in a specific parking space in a
specific Village commuter lot as designated by the Village Manager, or his/her designee, and so posted before or until nine thirty o’clock
(9:009:30) A.M. each weekday, after which time any such unused premium commuter parking space(s) shall, after 9:00 9:30 a.m., be available
for general use as daily fee parking. A Premium Commuter Parking Permit may be purchased only on an annual basis for parking in a specific
assigned parking space in a Village commuter parking lot on either the North or South side of the Union Pacific right-of-way. Premium
Commuter Parking Permits shall be offered for sale by the Village from time to time in the following order: first by lot to Village residents, then by
lot to BACOG residents, and then by lot to others.
* * * *
PREPAID PARKING TAG: A prepaid parking tag allows the user to prepay for daily parking and may be used in any daily fee parking area, (except where
signs provide otherwise), on a quarterly basis or on an annual basis at that amount as specified from time to time in Section 1-14-1 of this Code
to avoid the need for daily fare box or Passport Parking Application payments.
* * * *
REVERSE COMMUTER LOTS: Commuter lots which are specifically designated and posted for reverse commuters who depart from the Village in the
evening after five o’clock (5:00) P.M. and return to the Village not later than ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. on the next day.
* * * *”

SECTION 8: Section 6-3-5, “General Parking Restrictions”, of Chapter 3, “Parking Regulations”, of Title 6, “Motor Vehicles and Traffic”, is hereby
amended to read as follows:
“SECTION 6-3-5: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
A. Not To Obstruct Traffic: No person shall park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than
fifteen feet (15’) of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic, except on a one-way street.
B. Fire Lanes: No person owning, controlling, driving or operating any vehicle shall cause or permit such vehicle to park in any area designated as a “fire
lane”, as vehicle parking in such designated areas interferes with access by fire vehicles. Appropriate signs indicating fire lanes and no parking shall
be installed on any area so designated as a fire lane.
C. All Night Parking: In addition to any other restrictions now or hereafter imposed, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any portion of any
dedicated right of way, including, but not limited to, any street, any parkway or tree bank in the Village, between the hours of one o’clock (1:00) A.M.
and six o’clock (6:00) A.M., with the exception of the following portions of dedicated rights of way where it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle
thereon between the hours of two o’clock (2:00) A.M. and six o’clock (6:00) A.M.:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 22/522
Cook Street between Main Street and Station Franklin Street.
Klingenberg Drive from the Village Commuter Parking Lot 11 to Route 14.
Park Avenue between Main Street and Grove Avenue.
Station Street between Hough Street the West boundary of the Village Center Resubdivision along Station Street and Grove Avenue.
Wool Street between Main Street and Klingenberg Drive.
However, notwithstanding the foregoing, the parking prohibitions provided by Section 6-3-6, “Parking During Snow Removal Operations”, of this
Chapter shall be and remain applicable to all of the streets specifically designated in this Paragraph C as provided by such Section.
D. Near Theaters: The operator of a vehicle shall not park such vehicle on the same side of the street in front of any entrance or exit of any theater
building during the hours such theater is open to the public for the uses permitted therein.
E. Use Of Bus And Taxicab Stands: No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle, other than a bus in a bus stop, bus stand or bus terminal, or other
than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated by appropriate signs; except, that the driver of a
passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such
stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone.
F. Vehicles With Expired Registration: No person may stop, park, or leave standing upon a public street, highway, or roadway a vehicle upon which is
displayed an Illinois registration plate or plates or registration sticker after the termination of the registration period for which the registration plate or
plates or registration sticker was issued or after the expiration date set under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-414 or 5/3-414.1. Any person
violating this subsection shall be fined as specified from time to time in Section 1-41-4 of this Code for each offense. Each day on which a violation
occurs or continues shall be considered a separate offense.”
SECTION 9: Section 6-3-6, “Parking During Snow Removal Operations”, of Chapter 3, “Parking Regulations”, of Title 6, “Motor Vehicles and
Traffic”, is hereby amended to read as follows:
“SECTION 6-3-6: PARKING DURING SNOW REMOVAL OPERATIONS:
A. Parking Prohibitions:
1. No person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any portion of any dedicated right of way, including, but not limited to, any street,
any parkway or any tree bank within the Village, at any time after snow begins to fall, and said snow exceeds two inches (2”) in depth as
determined by the meteorological service then utilized by the Village Department of Public Works, until snow removal operations are completed,
except in the Village Center Business District as depicted on the Official Zoning Map which is a part of the Village Zoning Ordinance.
2. No person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any portion of any dedicated right of way, including, but not limited to, any street,
any parkway or any tree bank, within the Village Center Business District after one o’clock (1:00) A.M. after a snowfall exceeds four inches (4”)
as determined by the meteorological service then utilized by the Village Department of Public Works, until snow removal operations are
completed.
B. Violations; Citations; Vehicles Towed: The Chief of the Police Department and all members thereof assigned to traffic duty are hereby authorized to
issue citations to the owner and/or operator of any car or other vehicle illegally parked in violation of this Section and to remove and tow away, or
have removed or towed away by a commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in violation of this Section which is impeding
snow removal operations. Vehicles so towed away shall be stored at a location designated by such commercial towing service and shall be restored
to the owner or operator thereof after payment of the expense incurred by the Village in removing and storing such vehicles.”
SECTION 10: The Corporate Authorities of the Village intend that this Ordinance will be made part of the Village Code and that sections of this
Ordinance can be renumbered or relettered and the word “Ordinance” can be changed to “Section”, “Article”, “Chapter”, or some other appropriate word or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 23/522
phrase to accomplish codification, and regardless of whether this Ordinance is ever codified, the Ordinance can be renumbered or relettered and
typographical and/or scrivener’s errors can be corrected with the authorization of the Village Attorney, or his or her designee.
SECTION 11: All parts of the Barrington Village Code in conflict with the terms or provisions of this Ordinance shall be and the same are hereby
amended or repealed to the extent of such conflict, and said Village Code and all other existing ordinances shall otherwise remain in full force and effect.
SECTION 12: This Ordinance shall not affect any punishment, discipline, infraction, or penalty or any action based on any other Ordinance of this
Village incurred before the effective date of this Ordinance, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the effective date of this
Ordinance, for an offense or violation committed or cause of action arising before this Ordinance, and said other ordinances as heretofore existing shall
continue in full force and effect for said limited purpose.
SECTION 13: If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Ordinance or any part thereof is, for any reason, held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining
portions of this Ordinance, or any part thereof. The Corporate Authorities hereby declare that they would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs,
sentence, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective.
SECTION 14: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect immediately from and after its passage, approval and publication as provided by law.
SECTION 15: The Village Clerk is directed to immedi ately publish this Ordinance in pamphlet form.

PREFACE
This Village Code of the Village of Barrington, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including ordinance 19-4047, passed February 25, 2019.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this Village Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent
therewith. Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the Code has been amended, superseded or repealed.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING
THE 2004 BARRINGTON VILLAGE CODE
WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Barrington, Cook and Lakes Counties, Illinois, deem it in the best interests of the Village
of Barrington to re-codify the permanent and general ordinances of the Village as specified herein as a new and original comprehensive ordinance; and
WHEREAS, three (3) copies each of the Illinois Plumbing Code December 1993 Edition, the International Code Council International Property
Maintenance Code 2000 Edition, the International Code Council International Fire Code 2000 Edition, the International Code Council International Building
Code 2000 Edition, the International Code Council International Mechanical Code 2000 Edition, the International Code Council International Residential
Code 2000 Edition, the International Code Council International Energy Conservation Code 2000 Edition, and the International Code Council International
Fuel Gas Code 2000 Edition have all been on file with the Village Clerk for thirty (30) days prior to the date of adoption of this Ordinance; and
WHEREAS, the Illinois Building Commission has been duly notified of the proposed adoption and amendments of codes regulating construction within the
Village of Barrington and such notification has been given in the form prescribed not less than thirty (30) days prior to the proposed date of adoption of the
codes and amendments, in compliance with Public Act 92-489:
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Barrington, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois, as follows:
SECTION 1: This Ordinance, consisting of Titles 1 through 11, inclusive, in the form attached hereto and made a part hereof, is hereby adopted and
enacted as the "2004 Barrington Village Code" (hereinafter sometimes also referred to as "said 2004 Code") and shall be treated and considered as a new
and original comprehensive ordinance which shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances of the Village passed on or before July 15, 2002,
as specified in said 2004 Code, except such as by reference thereto in this Ordinance or in said 2004 Code are expressly saved from repeal or continued
in force and effect for any purpose.
SECTION 2: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES.
A. All general and permanent ordinances of the Village passed prior to the adoption of the 2004 Barrington Village Code are hereby repealed, except such
as are included in said 2004 Code, or which are reserved and saved from repeal by necessary implication herein reserved and saved from repeal (subject
to the saving clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: (1) tax levy ordinances;
(2) appropriation and/or budget ordinances; (3) ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations; (4) franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting
special rights to persons or corporations; (5) contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; (6)
salary ordinances; (7) ordinances establishing, naming, or vacating streets, alleys or other public places; (8) improvement ordinances; (9) bond
ordinances; (10) ordinances relating to elections; (11) ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate (including but not limited to real
estate purchases, sales, easements and leases) by or from the Village; (12) zoning ordinances; (13) subdivision ordinances; (14) comprehensive plan;
(15) Barrington Watershed Development Ordinance, Ordinance No. 02-2989; (16) Ordinance Nos. 02-3024, 02-3041, 03-0350, 03-3052, 03-3055, 03-
3056, 03-3060, 03-3061, 03-3079, 03-3085, 03-3099, 03-3103, 03-3104, 03-3106, 04-3119, 04-3120, 04-3124, and 04-3125, which ordinances were all
passed after July 15, 2002, but which shall hereafter be included in the 2004 Code as amendments and/or additions thereto; (17) and all other special
ordinances. To the extent that any other general and permanent ordinance(s) of the Village have not been included in said 2004 Code, by oversight, or
otherwise, said omitted other general, permanent ordinance(s) are hereby reserved and saved from repeal and shall continue in full force and effect until
their inclusion herein.

Board of Trustees to make the same a part thereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated into said 2004 Code so that reference to "the Barrington Village
Code" or "the 2004 Code" shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments thereto.

express duty of the Village Clerk, or someone authorized by him or her, to insert in at least one copy in their designated places all amendments or
ordinances which indicate the intention of the President and Board of Trustees to make the same a part of said 2004 Code when the same have been
printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from said 2004 Code all provisions which may from time to time be repealed by the President and Board of
Trustees. This amended copy of said 2004 Code shall be available for all persons desiring to examine the same and shall be considered the official 2004
Barrington Village Code.

Chapter 4 of Title 1 of said 2004 Code shall apply to the section or the section as amended or in case such section or amendment contains provisions for
which a specific penalty other than the aforementioned general penalty is provided in another section in the same chapter as such section or amendment
thereto, the specific penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section, or amendment thereto, unless such penalty is
specifically repealed therein.
SECTION 6: This Ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty or any action based on any general and permanent ordinance of the Village
superseded by this Ordinance incurred before the effective date of this Ordinance, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the
effective date of this Ordinance for any offense committed or cause of action arising before the effective date of this Ordinance and said prior general and
permanent ordinances as heretofore existing shall continue in full force and effect for said limited purpose.
SECTION 7: When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive
such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly provided.
SECTION 8: The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Ordinance and the 2004 Barrington Village Code hereby adopted are
severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Ordinance shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid, ineffective, or
unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of any of the
remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Ordinance or the 2004 Barrington Village Code hereby adopted. The President
and Board of Trustees hereby declare that it would have passed each phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph and section hereof irrespective of the fact that
any one or more other phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections be declared unconstitutional, invalid, or ineffective.
SECTION 9: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect on April 1, 2004, which date shall be not less than ten (10) days from and after its passage,
approval and publication in pamphlet form pursuant to law.
SECTION 10: The Village Clerk is hereby authorized and directed to publish this Ordinance and the 2004 Barrington Village Code hereby adopted in book
or pamphlet form.
