21. The document(s) requested relate to information that would disclose or might lead to the disclosure of secret or confidential information, codes,
algorithms, programs, or private keys intended to be used to create electronic or digital signatures under the electronic commerce security act26.
22. The document(s) requested relate to vulnerability assessments, security measures, and response policies or plans that are designed to identify,
prevent, or respond to potential attacks upon a community's population or systems, facilities, or installations, the destruction or contamination of
which would constitute a clear and present danger to the health or safety of the community, but only to the extent that disclosure could reasonably be
expected to jeopardize the effectiveness of the measures or the safety of the personnel who implement them or the public. Information under this
exemption may include such things as details pertaining to the mobilization or deployment of personnel or equipment, to the operation of
communication systems or protocols, or to tactical operations27.
23. The document(s) requested relate to maps and other records regarding the location or security of generation, transmission, distribution, storage,
gathering, treatment, or switching facilities owned by a utility, by a power generator, or by the Illinois power agency28.
24. The document(s) requested relate to information contained in or related to proposals, bids, or negotiations related to electric power procurement
under section 1-75 of the Illinois power agency act and section 16-111.5 of the public utilities act that is determined to be confidential and proprietary
by the Illinois power agency or by the Illinois commerce commission29.
25. The document(s) requested relate to the names, addresses, or other personal information of persons who are minors and are also participants and
registrants in programs of park districts, forest preserve districts, conservation districts, recreation agencies, and special recreation associations30
(P.A. 97-0385).
26. The document(s) requested relate to the names, addresses, or other personal information of participants and registrants in programs of park
districts, forest preserve districts, conservation districts, recreation agencies, and special recreation associations where such programs are targeted
primarily to minors31 (P.A. 97-0385).
27. The document(s) requested relate to one or more of the following statutory exemptions to the extent provided for by such specific statute(s)32:
a. Firm performance evaluations under section 55 of the architectural, engineering, and land surveying qualifications based selection act;
b. Information contained in a local emergency energy plan submitted to a municipality in accordance with a local emergency energy plan ordinance
that is adopted under section 11-21.5-5 of the Illinois municipal code;
c. Information and data concerning the distribution of surcharge monies collected and remitted by wireless carriers under the wireless emergency
telephone safety act;
d. Law enforcement officer identification information or driver identification information compiled by a law enforcement agency or the department of
transportation under section 11-212 of the Illinois vehicle code;
e. Records and information provided to a residential healthcare facility resident sexual assault and death review team or the executive council under
the abuse prevention review team act;
f. Information that is prohibited from being disclosed under section 4 of the Illinois health and hazardous substances registry act;
g. Security portions of system safety program plans, investigation reports, surveys, schedules, lists, data, or information compiled, collected, or
prepared by or for the regional transportation authority under section 2.11 of the regional transportation authority act or the St. Clair County transit
district under the bi-state transit safety act;
h. Information prohibited from being disclosed by the personnel records review act;
i. Information prohibited from being disclosed by the Illinois school student records act;
j. Information the disclosure of which is restricted under section 5-108 of the public utilities act.
k. Names and information of people who have applied for or received firearm owner's identification ("FOID") cards under the firearm owner's
identification card act (P.A. 097-0080).
l. Personally identifiable information which is exempted from disclosure under subsection (g) of section 19.1 of the Illinois toll highway act (P.A. 97-
0342). (Ord. 11-3655, 10-24-2011)
1-17-9: DENIAL OF RECORDS; REQUEST FOR REVIEW:
A. If information is requested for a commercial purpose, and the request is denied by the village, the requester may not file a request for review with the
public access counselor ("PAC").
B. If a request for information is treated by the village as a request for a commercial purpose and the request is denied by the village, the requester may
file a request for review with the PAC for the limited purpose of reviewing whether the village properly determined that the request was made for a
commercial purpose. (Ord. 11-3655, 10-24-2011)
1-17-10: DENIAL OF RECORDS; EXEMPTION(S):
If requested information cannot be released due to its exempt nature, or if a request is unduly burdensome, the FOIA officer, or his or her designee, shall
complete a "denial of request for records" form and mail same to the requester along with a blank "notice of appeal" form. The denial of request for records
form shall include: a) the decision to deny the request; b) the reasons for the denial, including a detailed factual basis for the application of any exemption
claimed; c) the names and titles or positions of each person responsible for the denial; d) the right to review by the public access counselor, if applicable,
and the address and phone number for the public access counselor; and e) the right to judicial review. If an exemption is claimed, then the denial shall
include the specific reason(s) for the denial, including a detailed factual basis and a citation to support legal authority.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 99/522
A copy of each such denial letter and the completed request form shall also be provided to the village president and the village attorney. Copies of all
notices of denial shall be retained by the FOIA officer, or his or her designee, in a central file that is publicly accessible and indexed by type of exemption.
(Ord. 11-3655, 10-24-2011)
1-17-11: APPEAL TO DENIAL OF REQUEST:
If a request for records is denied, and the requester has a right to seek judicial review of such denial pursuant to 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/11, or has
a right to seek judicial review of the village's determination that the request was made for commercial purposes, the requester may, within sixty (60) days
from receipt of such denial, pursuant to 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/9.5, file an appeal to the denial of production of records directed to the Illinois
public access counselor, whose address is:
Public Access Counselor
Office Of The Attorney General
100 West Randolph, 12th Floor
Chicago, IL 60601
Tel.: (312) 814-5526
Public Access Counselor
Office Of The Attorney General
500 S. 2nd Street
Springfield, IL 62706
Tel.: (877) 299-3642
Fax: (217) 782-1396
E-mail: publicaccess@atg.state.il.us
The Illinois public access counselor will respond to such appeal and issue a binding opinion within sixty (60) days after the request for review (appeal)
unless a request for extension of thirty (30) business days is given by the PAC. The PAC's binding opinion must make findings of fact and conclusions of
law and shall be issued to the requester and public body. The PAC's binding opinion is subject to administrative review by either party. (Ord. 11-3655, 10-
24-2011)
1-17-12: BINDING OPINION:
A binding opinion issued by the attorney general shall be considered final for the purpose of administrative review. Any action for administrative review of a
binding opinion must be commenced in Cook or Sangamon County. (Ord. 11-3655, 10-24-2011)
Chapter 18
VILLAGE COMMUNITY EVENTS SIGN POLICY
1-18-1: MISSION STATEMENT:
The goal of the village of Barrington (hereinafter referred to as the "village of Barrington", the "village" or "Barrington") for use of its community events sign
is to provide village residents, local businesses and the public with information about the village of Barrington, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois, other units
of local government, the community and special programs and events, and services that strengthen Barrington's identity as a great place to live, work and
play. This chapter may be referred to as the VILLAGE COMMUNITY EVENTS SIGN POLICY. (Ord. 10-3596, 9-27-2010)
1-18-2: REGULATIONS:
A. Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to provide guidelines for the operation, maintenance, and utilization of the village community events sign as a
form of "governmental speech", and to describe its purpose and use by the village. The purpose of the village community events sign is to provide a
source of information for village residents, local businesses, and the public to learn more about events, programs and services offered by the village
and other units of local government. The village community events sign is not intended or required to provide information about events that are not
directly or indirectly sponsored by the village or another unit of government.
B. Objectives:
1. To serve as a source of emergency information, providing notice and updated information on local emergency situations related to such matters as
weather, hazardous spills, water system status, crime, etc.
2. To serve as a source of village information to promote awareness of community events, programs, and services provided by the village and/or other
units of government.
3. To strengthen community identity and involvement by informing village residents, businesses, and the community at large of: a) village meetings and
other news of interest; b) village sponsored and village endorsed community events; c) community events sponsored by other units of government,
such as the township, school district, library district, and park district; d) special events and community events sponsored by charitable,
eleemosynary, civic, or governmental organizations which seek to strengthen and enhance aspects of the community in accordance with the mission
statement (hereinafter referred to as "qualifying organizations"); and e) by providing information of general interest to village residents, businesses,
and the general public relative to village events, programs, services, activities, initiatives and/or areas of responsibility.
C. Community Events Sign Administration:
1. The village community events sign is owned, operated and regulated by the village. The village manager, or his designee, shall act as the village
community events sign coordinator ("the community events sign coordinator") and shall be responsible for the display of information on the village
community events sign based on direction from the corporate authorities of the village and/or the village manager from time to time and implemented
in accordance with this chapter. It is the responsibility of the community events sign coordinator to coordinate and manage the use of the village
community events sign, exercising professional judgment in administering policies set forth by the corporate authorities and determining what
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 100/522
information shall be displayed on the village community events sign, how many seconds each "page" shall be displayed, and how many "pages"
shall be displayed on the community events sign at any given time. However, decisions on matters of policy and parameters as to use of the village
community events sign shall be reserved to the corporate authorities.
2. It shall be the responsibility of the community events sign coordinator to review requests to use the community events sign and to determine the
appropriateness of the content of all information displayed on the village community events sign, based on the policies and procedures established
herein or as directed from time to time by the corporate authorities and/or the village manager. If the request for display of information is denied or
limited by the community events sign coordinator, the applicant may appeal the denial to the village board within seven (7) business days of the
denial. Denial or limitation of an application for display of information on the village community events sign shall be in writing, shall be sent to the
applicant by regular mail, shall state the reason for the denial, and may, if appropriate, offer recommendation(s) for modifying the content of the text
in order to be approved for posting on the village community events sign. The appeal of such denial by the applicant shall also be in writing and shall
state the basis for the appeal, and shall be submitted to the village manager. The village manager shall present said appeal to the village board who
shall consider the appeal at its next regularly scheduled meeting which is at least seven (7) business days after the appeal is filed, or at a special
meeting, if the village president determines that this is required by the nature of the matter being appealed. The party appealing may appear before
the board to present its appeal and the community events sign coordinator or other applicable village representatives may be given the opportunity at
that same time to respond to the appeal in person or in writing. The basis for such appeal shall be limited to those issues that have been raised in the
applicant's written notice of appeal.
3. The village manager is directly responsible to the corporate authorities for the efficient, effective, and responsive operation of the village community
events sign. As the elected officials of the village, the corporate authorities retain final authority for establishing the overall policies and procedures
related to the operation and use of the village community events sign and the final determination on all appeals as aforesaid.
D. Community Events Sign Display Content And Content Restrictions:
1. Criteria Applicable To All Requests For Display Of Information: The following criteria shall be applicable to all requests for display of information on
the village community events sign and shall be used by the village's community events sign coordinator, the village manager, and the corporate
authorities, to determine whether or not information shall be displayed and/or is eligible for display on the community events sign and to prioritize
requests for display of information:
a. The display of village and/or emergency information shall have priority over all other requests;
b. Advertisement of community events shall meet the following criteria:
(1) The event will draw people to the village;
(2) The event will foster community spirit and identity;
(3) The event will provide economic benefit(s) to the village.
c. Information displayed on the community events sign shall be pertinent to the public, the village and to the community as a whole.
d. The village reserves the right to reject any and all requests, and/or to require editing or modification(s) of text before display thereof.
2. Inappropriate Content Prohibited: Content and/or other material that is deemed by the community events sign coordinator, in his or her sole
discretion, as inappropriate for display on the community events sign shall be prohibited and shall include, but not be limited to:
a. Personal commentary or personal opinions.
b. Promotions, endorsements, or advertisements for any private business, commercial service or product or any paid advertising materials in which
commercial appeals for funds are made.
c. Advertising by, on behalf of, or in opposition to candidate(s) for public office or for or against any public policy referendum question.
d. Any display of material or language which constitutes libel, slander, pornography, obscenity or violence.
e. Display of content which is prohibited by applicable federal, state or local laws.
E. Procedures For Request(s) To Display Information On The Village Community Events Sign: Procedures for request(s) to display information on the
village community events sign shall include, but may not be limited to, the following:
1. All requests for display of information on the village community events sign shall be submitted in writing to the community events sign coordinator on
a village community events sign application, which application may be obtained from the office of the village clerk or online on the village's website,
and shall include the name of the person or organization making the request, as well as the name, address and phone number of the contact person
and should be submitted at least seven (7) calendar days prior to the requested start date for display.
2. Displays are permitted to run for up to two (2) weeks prior to, and on the day of, the event.
3. Displays will be limited to four (4) lines of text, with a maximum of twenty (20) characters per line (also referred to herein as a "page"). Each "page"
of text will display for a limited number of seconds, as determined by the community events sign administrator, in his or her sole discretion. Displays
are limited to one "page" of text. Displays will be cycled on and off with other displays.
4. Content of text should be concise, and should contain basic information such as what, when, and where. If necessary, the village community events
sign coordinator, or his designee, may edit the content to meet space requirements, to improve readability of the content, and to ensure that the
content is grammatically correct.
5. All applications received will be reviewed by the community events sign coordinator, or his designee, and, after approval thereof by the community
events sign coordinator or his designee, may then be displayed on the village community events sign, only at the sole discretion of the community
events sign coordinator. The community events sign coordinator is responsible for determining the appropriateness of the proposed content and/or
its eligibility for display on the community events sign, the number of seconds each "page" shall be displayed, as well as the number of "pages" to be
displayed during any given period of time. The community events sign coordinator will use the purpose, objectives, regulations, and further limitations
outlined in this chapter, and/or the direction by the corporate authorities, in making this determination. The determinations of the community events
sign coordinator may be appealed as provided herein.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 101/522
6. If the community events sign coordinator determines that the proposed content must be denied and/or is unsuitable for display on the village
community events sign the community events sign coordinator will provide to the applicant a written statement giving the reason for the denial and
advising the applicant that he, she, or it may appeal the denial to the village board in writing as provided in this chapter. When appropriate, the
community events sign coordinator's written statement may also offer recommendation(s) for modifying the request in order to be approved for
display on the village community events sign.
7. The community events sign coordinator, and/or his designee, will endeavor to give timely consideration to all applications for display on the
community events sign, subject to priority, budgetary and staff time constraints.
8. Each applicant for use of the community events sign shall acknowledge in writing in their respective application that the village, in its sole discretion,
may edit, reject, or require changes to any proposed display of text submitted, and that the village is not responsible for failing to post or for any error
in posting any proposed display of text, and neither the accuracy of the display of text nor the display dates are guaranteed. (Ord. 10-3596, 9-27-
2010)
Chapter 19
CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT/ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM
1-19-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
Pursuant to the authority granted to the village by the Illinois municipal code and the Illinois vehicle code, including, but not limited to, 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., and 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., and 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3, there is hereby established a "Barrington code hearing
department" as an administrative adjudication system for the village of Barrington ("the village") (hereinafter, "the Barrington code hearing department").
The code hearing department and administrative adjudication system shall be a separate agency within the village government. For purposes of this and
related sections of this code, the terms herein shall have the same meaning as ascribed by the Illinois municipal code. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-2012)
1-19-2: JURISDICTION:
The administrative adjudication system shall have jurisdiction to adjudicate matters arising out of any provisions of this code or other municipal ordinance,
including, but not limited to, building code violations that must be adjudicated, pursuant to division 31.1 of article 11 and/or pursuant to other provisions of
the Illinois municipal code1, and any offense under the Illinois vehicle code2 or similar local ordinance, except any offense that is a traffic regulation
governing the movement of vehicles and except for any offense or similar local ordinance which is a reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois
vehicle code. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-2012)
1-19-3: APPOINTMENT OF HEARING OFFICER:
The village president shall appoint a qualified attorney as the village administrative hearing officer ("the hearing officer"), in accordance with 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., and 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., of the Illinois municipal code. Pursuant to an intergovernmental agreement, an administrative
hearing officer appointed by another municipality may also be appointed by the village president as the hearing officer for the village. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-
2012)
1-19-4: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION:
The hearing officer shall administer the administrative adjudication system, and the village of Barrington code hearing department in accordance with 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., and 5/11-31.1-1 et seq. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-2012)
1-19-5: FINES AND PENALTIES:
A. The fines and penalties applicable to notices of violations issued through the code hearing department/administrative adjudication system and matters
heard by the hearing officer shall be as set forth in sections 1-4-1 and 1-14-1 of this title. Unless waived by the hearing officer, at his or her sole
discretion for good cause shown, a late charge as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this title shall be added to any fine(s) and/or other
applicable charge(s) imposed by the hearing officer which are not paid within forty five (45) days after a copy of the hearing officer's order, decision and
a notice of liability has been served in person or by regular U.S. mail on the defendant, but such late payment charge shall not be applicable in the
event that: 1) the defendant files a timely complaint for administrative review in the circuit court, or 2) if the notice of liability against the defendant is
vacated by the hearing officer or the circuit court.
B. As part of the disposition of any notice of violation, the hearing officer shall be authorized to enter an order of supervision and, in addition to other
applicable penalties and charges, may order the defendant to perform community service and/or to participate in remedial classes or counseling.
C. Except with respect to the applicable minimum fines specified for code violation(s), for parking and compliance violation(s), and/or for certain animal
control violation(s) as specified in section 1-14-1 of this title, the hearing officer shall have the authority to suspend the minimum fines otherwise
applicable to any violation of this code or of any other village ordinance. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-2012)
1-19-6: REMEDIAL HEARING DATE MAY BE REQUIRED:
Notwithstanding any provisions of this code to the contrary by which the prehearing settlement of a citation or notice to appear or a notice of violation
("initial charging document") is authorized, any enforcement officer or agent of the village may provide on the initial charging document that the
appearance of the defendant at an administrative hearing or in court shall be required if such enforcement officer or agent of the village reasonably
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 102/522
believes, based upon one or more prior offenses of the same or similar nature or other circumstances, that the defendant's appearance is necessary and
should be required to assure that the defendant thereafter takes appropriate remedial measures to comply with the applicable provisions of this code or of
any other applicable ordinance(s) of the village. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-2012)
Title 2
BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES
Chapter 1
PLAN COMMISSION
2-1-1: COMMISSION CREATED; COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created a plan commission for the village which shall consist of a member of the architectural review commission who shall be an ex
officio member, and seven (7) additional members who shall be appointed by the president, subject to confirmation by the board of trustees. (1973 Code
§ 16-1; amd. 2003 Code)
2-1-2: TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES:
Each appointed member of the plan commission shall serve for a term of three (3) years expiring on December 31, or until his successor is appointed and
qualifies, but terms shall be staggered in order that at least two (2) members shall be appointed or reappointed each year. An appointment to fill a vacancy
shall be for the unexpired portion of the term. (1973 Code § 16-3)
2-1-3: ORGANIZATION AND PROCEDURES:
A. Chairman And Vice Chairman: The president shall designate one member as the chairman of the plan commission and one member as the vice
chairman to serve as chairman in the absence of the chairman. (Ord. 96-2614, 8-26-1996)
B. Meetings:
1. The plan commission shall meet at such time as it may determine.
2. Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by any two (2) members of the commission.
3. Meetings shall be in compliance with the state open meetings act1. (1973 Code § 16-6; amd. 2003 Code)
C. Quorum; Vote Requirements: A majority of the plan commission shall constitute a quorum, but no final action shall be taken on any measure before it
except with the concurrence of four (4) members. The chairman shall vote with the other members of the commission. (1973 Code § 16-5)
D. Rules: The plan commission may adopt rules regulating the procedure of all meetings of the plan commission. Such rules shall be filed in the office of
the village clerk and may be amended at any meeting, such rules to be effective upon filing in the office of the clerk. (1973 Code § 16-8)
2-1-4: POWERS GENERALLY:
The plan commission shall have power:
A. To prepare and recommend to the village board a comprehensive plan of public improvements looking to the present and future development of the
village, and to provide reasonable requirements in reference to streets, alleys, public grounds and other improvements pursuant to law in unsubdivided
lands within the corporate limits and in contiguous territory outside and distant not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles from the corporate limits of
the village, insofar as the same are not included in any city, village or incorporated towns. After its adoption by the village board, this shall be known as
the official comprehensive plan.
B. To recommend from time to time changes in the official comprehensive plan.
C. To prepare and recommend to the village board from time to time plans for specific improvements in pursuance of such official comprehensive plan.
D. To aid the municipal officials charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official comprehensive plan, to further these
projects, and generally, to promote the objectives of the official comprehensive plan.
E. To exercise such other powers as may be provided by statute or ordinance. (1973 Code § 16-7)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 103/522
Chapter 2
ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS
2-2-1: BOARD CREATED; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created a zoning board of appeals for zoning matters which shall consist of seven (7) members to be appointed by the village president
with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. (1973 Code § 16-24)
2-2-2: TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES:
Each member of the zoning board of appeals shall serve for five (5) years as provided by statute, each such term to expire on December 31, or until a
successor is appointed and qualifies. Terms shall be staggered in order that not more than two (2) members shall be appointed or reappointed each year.
An appointment to fill a vacancy shall be for the unexpired portion of the term. (1973 Code § 16-26)
2-2-3: ORGANIZATION:
A. Chairman: One member of the zoning board of appeals shall be designated chairman at the time of his appointment. (1973 Code § 16-25)
B. Meetings; Records Kept: The zoning board of appeals shall meet at such times as it may determine upon call of the chairman, and it shall keep records
of its official actions. (1973 Code § 16-28)
2-2-4: DUTIES:
The zoning board of appeals shall pass upon all appeals from the director of development services, or his or her designee, on questions of zoning, and
shall have such other powers and duties as may be delegated to it by statute or ordinance. Provided, that a concurring vote of four (4) members shall be
necessary to reverse any decision of the director of development services, or his or her designee, or to recommend a variation. (Ord. 15-3837, 6-8-2015)
Chapter 3
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
2-3-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT AND TERMS OF OFFICE:
There shall be a board of fire and police commissioners, as provided by law, which shall consist of three (3) members whose terms shall be for three (3)
years. Such members shall be appointed by the president with the consent of the board of trustees. (1973 Code § 2-156)
2-3-2: DUTIES OF THE BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall have charge of all appointments of full time members of both the fire department and the police
department, with the exception of the chief of police and deputy chief of police as provided in section 1-7B-2 of this code, and with the exception of the
chief of fire/EMS and deputy chief of fire/EMS as provided in section 1-7C-2 of this code, and shall conduct and hold all entrance and promotional
examinations in the manner required by its rules and regulations as they may be established from time to time and as required by law. The board of fire
and police commissioners may utilize an intergovernmental cooperative as its agent for the purpose of administering such examinations if authorized to do
so by the corporate authorities. Notwithstanding any of the provisions contained herein, the board of fire and police commissioners may provide by rule for
procedures by which it will evaluate applicants, using applicant profiles prepared by qualified third party preapplication testing services, to supplement or in
lieu of examinations administered by the board. (Ord. 07-3380, 8-20-2007)

There is hereby established the board of local improvements for the village, which shall consist of the president and all the members of the board of

2-4-2: SECRETARY AND ASSISTANT SECRETARY:
The village clerk shall be the secretary of the board of local improvements and the deputy village clerk shall be the assistant secretary. (1973 Code § 2-
169)

EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD
