including contemporaneous books and records denoting the transactions that gave rise, or may have given rise, to any tax liability under this article. The
books and records shall be subject to and available for inspection at all times during business hours of the day. (Ord. 09-3507, 4-13-2009, eff. 7-1-2009)
3-2D-10: CREDITS AND REFUNDS:
A. Notwithstanding any other provision in this article, in order to permit sound fiscal planning and budgeting by the village, no person shall be entitled to a
refund of, or credit for, a tax imposed under this article unless such person files a claim for refund or credit within one year after the date on which the
tax was paid.
B. If a taxpayer under article C of this chapter is unable to use a credit authorized under said article C of this chapter solely because the tax originally
imposed under article C of this chapter has been replaced by the tax imposed under this article, then the taxpayer may apply such credit against any
tax due under this article. (Ord. 09-3507, 4-13-2009, eff. 7-1-2009)
3-2D-11: PENALTIES:
Every person convicted of a violation of this article for failing to make a return, or for making a fraudulent return, or for wilfully violating any other provision
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 119/522
of this article shall be punished by a fine as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. In addition to the fine herein set forth, such person
shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of tax due and unpaid. (Ord. 09-3507, 4-13-2009, eff. 7-1-2009)
ARTICLE E. FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX
3-2E-1: TAX IMPOSED; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
A. Any corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of the state of Illinois, and which is engaged in the village of Barrington in
effecting or soliciting fire insurance, shall pay to the village treasurer annually on July 15 of each year, a sum equal to two percent (2%) of the gross
receipts of premiums received by such corporation, company, or association for insurance on property located in the village of Barrington. Such
payments shall be made for the year ending July 1 of each year.
B. No corporation, company, or association, not incorporated under the laws of the state of Illinois, shall engage in effecting fire insurance or transact any
business of fire insurance in the village until the requirements of this article shall have been fully complied with.
C. Nothing in this article shall relieve any company, corporation or association from the payment of any risk that may be undertaken in violation of this
article. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-2: AGENT'S REPORTS:
Every person acting as agent or otherwise, for or on behalf of any such corporation, company, or association, shall on July 15 of each year render to the
village clerk and to the village treasurer a full, true and just account verified by oath, of all the premiums which during the year ending on July 1 preceding
such report shall have been received by him or any other person for him in behalf of such corporation, company, or association and shall fully and
specifically set out in such report the amount or amounts received as premiums for fire insurance. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-3: PAYMENT OF TAX; RECOVERY BY SUIT:
A. The agent shall at the time of making the report pay to the village treasurer the said sum of two percent (2%) upon the gross receipts of such
corporation, company or association, obtained as premiums for effecting fire insurance in the village.
B. The sum of money for which any company, corporation or association is chargeable, under this article, may be recovered from it and/or from its agents,
by an action in the name of and for the use of the village, as for money had and received. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-4: WRITING BUSINESS UNLAWFUL:
If such account is not rendered on or before the day herein designated for that purpose, or if the above mentioned tax or license shall remain unpaid after
that day, it shall be unlawful for any such corporation, company or association or agent thereof, to transact any business of fire insurance in the village until
the requirements of this article shall have been fully complied with. No insurance broker in the village shall place any insurance with any company,
association or corporation, not incorporated under the laws of the state of Illinois, which shall be in default for not reporting or making payment as herein
provided, until it shall have complied with all the requirements of this article. This provision shall in no way affect the validity of any risk that shall be taken
in violation hereof between such corporation, company or association and the person so insured. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-5: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX BOARD ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a village of Barrington foreign fire insurance tax board. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-6: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions are established for purposes of this article:
BOARD: The foreign fire insurance tax board of the village of Barrington.
DEPARTMENT: The Barrington fire department.
FUND: The foreign fire insurance tax fund of the village of Barrington.
MEMBERS OF THE DEPARTMENT: Any person currently employed full time in the Barrington fire department in any full time permanent position
assigned to the department as authorized and approved by the corporate authorities of the village. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-7: COMPOSITION; ELECTION OF MEMBERS:
A. The foreign fire insurance tax board ("the board") shall be comprised of five (5) members of the department. The members of the department shall elect
the following five (5) officers who shall serve as the members of the board:
1. Chairman;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 120/522
2. Vice chairman;
3. Secretary;
4. Treasurer of the board; and
5. Trustee.
B. Members of the board shall be elected annually during the first week of each July, provided that upon the initial adoption of this article, members shall
be elected as soon as practicable to serve until the next regular election in July.
C. Members of the board shall serve one year terms until their successors are elected and installed.
D. Vacancies shall be filled by election of the members of the department for the balance of the unexpired term. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-8: MEETINGS; DUTIES OF OFFICERS; QUORUM:
The foreign fire insurance board shall, in accordance with the open meetings act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1.01 et seq., establish a regular time and
place for its meetings, and not less than annually during the first week of July of each year. The chairman shall preside at the meetings. The secretary
shall keep a record of all resolutions, proceedings and actions of the board, and these records shall be open to the public, except as permitted to be closed
by the aforesaid open meetings act. Three (3) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The affirmative vote of three
(3) members of the board shall constitute approval of business before it. Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by no less than three (3)
members of the board. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-9: POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE BOARD:
The powers and duties of the board shall be as follows:
A. The board shall abide by the policies and procedures established by this article.
B. The board shall have the power to approve the expenditures of monies from the fund for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department in
accordance with the policies and procedures set forth in this article.
C. The board may otherwise establish, amend or revoke rules and regulations governing the activities and procedures of the board not inconsistent with
the policies and procedures in this article.
D. The board shall include in its proposed budget and pay for from the fund an annual independent audit of the fund, to be conducted by the village auditor
and coordinated by the village treasurer. The board shall provide, in a timely manner any and all documents and information requested by the auditor.
(Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-2006)
3-2E-10: FUND ESTABLISHED; USE OF FUNDS:
A. The money received by the village treasurer in payment of the foreign fire insurance tax shall be collected and paid to the treasurer of the board or
deposited into a separate fund entitled "foreign fire insurance tax fund of the village of Barrington foreign fire insurance tax board" ("the fund") and shall
be utilized for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Barrington fire department and said fund shall be administered in the manner hereafter
described.
B. The fund shall be established and administered as follows:
1. All funds received by the village treasurer from the collection of the foreign fire insurance tax imposed shall be deposited into the fund or paid to the
treasurer of the board and shall be separately accounted for by the treasurer of the board.
2. The treasurer of the board shall provide to the board and to the village treasurer a monthly accounting of receipts and expenditures of the fund.
3. No expenditure shall be made from the fund without prior written approval of the board and the treasurer of the board.
4. All expenditures made from the fund shall be for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department. When making such expenditures from the
fund for the purchase of capital equipment and similar assets, due consideration shall be given to the maintenance requirements of such capital
assets and the attendant cost of such maintenance. No expenditures shall be made from the fund for purposes which serve the pecuniary benefit or
amusement of individual members of the department.
5. Any checks drawn on the fund shall be processed and executed according to the then current village procedures, and any expenditures approved by
the board shall be made in compliance with then current village purchasing policies and procedures.
6. The board shall prepare a biennial budget, in accordance with the village's then current budget process and procedures. The proposed budget shall
provide specifically how funds will be spent in the following two (2) fiscal years. The proposed budget may include a contingency to be reserved for
unexpected expenditures during the next two (2) fiscal years and/or to be reserved for future fiscal years. The proposed budget shall be submitted to
the village treasurer for review and submission to the corporate authorities for action in accordance with the village's established budget process.
The board shall provide for any supplemental budget information required by the village treasurer or the corporate authorities. (Ord. 06-3293, 2-27-
2006)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 121/522
ARTICLE F. LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX RIGHTS AND
RESPONSIBILITIES
3-2F-1: SHORT TITLE:
The title of this article shall be LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-2: SCOPE:
The provisions of this article shall apply to the village's procedures in connection with all of the village's locally imposed and administered taxes. (Ord. 07-
3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-3: DEFINITIONS:
Certain words or terms in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
ACT: The "local government taxpayers' bill of rights act".
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The president and board of trustees of the village of Barrington.
LOCAL TAX ADMINISTRATOR: The village treasurer is charged with the administration and collection of the locally imposed and administered taxes,
including staff, employees or agents to the extent they are authorized by the local tax administrator to act in the local tax administrator's stead. The local
tax administrator shall have the authority to implement the terms of this article to give full effect to this article. The exercise of such authority by the local
tax administrator shall not be inconsistent with this article and the act.
LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX OR TAX: Each tax imposed by the village that is collected or administered by the village, not an agency
or department of the state. It does not include any taxes imposed upon real property under the property tax code or fees collected by the village other than
infrastructure maintenance fees.
NOTICE: Each audit notice, collection notice, or other similar notice or communication in connection with each of the village's locally imposed and
administered taxes.
TAX ORDINANCE: Each ordinance and/or any paragraph, section, chapter, or title of this code that imposes any locally imposed and administered tax.
TAXPAYER: Any person required to pay any locally imposed and administered tax and generally includes the person upon whom the legal incidence of
such tax is placed and with respect to consumer taxes includes the business or entity required to collect and pay the locally imposed and administered tax
to the village.
VILLAGE: The village of Barrington, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-4: NOTICES:
Unless otherwise provided, whenever notice is required to be given, the notice is to be in writing mailed not less than seven (7) calendar days prior to the
day fixed for any applicable hearing, audit or other scheduled act of the local tax administrator. The notice shall be sent by the local tax administrator as
follows:
A. First class or express mail, or overnight mail, addressed to the persons concerned at the persons' last known address, or
B. Personal service or delivery. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-5: LATE PAYMENT:
Any notice, payment, remittance or other filing required to be made to the village pursuant to any tax ordinance shall be considered late unless it is
physically received by the village on or before the due date, or received in an envelope or other container displaying a valid, readable U.S. postmark dated
on or before the due date, properly addressed to the village with adequate postage prepaid. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-6: PAYMENT:
Any payment or remittance received for a tax period shall be applied in the following order: first, to the tax due for the applicable period; second, to the
interest due for the applicable period; and third, to the penalty for the applicable period. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-7: CERTAIN CREDITS AND REFUNDS:
A. The village shall not refund or credit any taxes voluntarily paid without written protest at the time of payment in the event that a locally imposed and
administered tax is declared invalidly enacted or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction. However, a taxpayer shall not be deemed to have
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 122/522
paid the tax voluntarily if the taxpayer lacked knowledge of the facts upon which to protest the taxes at the time of payment or if the taxpayer paid the
taxes under duress.
B. The statute of limitations on a claim for credit or refund shall be four (4) or less years after the end of the calendar year in which payment in error was
made. The village shall not grant a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered taxes, interest, or penalties to a person who has not paid the
amounts directly to the village.
C. The procedure for claiming a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered taxes, interest or penalties paid in error shall be as follows:
1. The taxpayer shall submit to the local tax administrator in writing a claim for credit or refund together with a statement specifying:
a. The name of the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim;
b. The tax period for the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim;
c. The date of the tax payment subject to the claim and the canceled check or receipt for the payment;
d. The taxpayer's recalculation, accompanied by an amended or revised tax return, in connection with the claim; and
e. A request for either a refund or a credit in connection with the claim to be applied to the amount of tax, interest and penalties overpaid, and, as
applicable, related interest on the amount overpaid; provided, however, that there shall be no refund and only a credit given in the event the
taxpayer owes any monies to the village.
2. Within ten (10) days of the receipt by the local tax administrator of any claim for a refund or credit, the local tax administrator shall either:
a. Grant the claim; or
b. Deny the claim, in whole or in part, together with a statement as to the reason for the denial or the partial grant and denial.
3. In the event the local tax administrator grants, in whole or in part, a claim for refund or credit, the amount of the grant for refund or credit shall bear
interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum, based on a year of three hundred sixty five (365) days and the number of days elapsed, from the
date of the overpayment to the date of mailing of a refund check or the grant of a credit. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-8: AUDIT PROCEDURE:
Any requests for proposed audit pursuant to any local administered tax shall comply with the notice requirements of this article.
A. Each notice of audit shall contain the following information:
1. The tax;
2. The time period of the audit; and
3. A brief description of the books and records to be made available for the auditor.
B. Any audit shall be conducted during normal business hours and if the date and time selected by the local tax administrator is not agreeable to the
taxpayer, another date and time may be requested by the taxpayer within thirty (30) days after the originally designated audit and during normal
business hours.
C. The taxpayer may request an extension of time to have an audit conducted. The audit shall be conducted not less than seven (7) days, nor more than
thirty (30) days, from the date the notice is given, unless the taxpayer and the local tax administrator agreed to some other convenient time. In the
event the taxpayer is unable to comply with the audit on the date in question, the taxpayer may request another date within the thirty (30) days,
approved in writing, that is convenient to the taxpayer and the local tax administrator.
D. Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records of the taxpayer's business or activities, including original source documents and books of entry
denoting the transactions which had given rise or may have given rise to any tax liability, exemption or deduction. All books shall be kept in the English
language and shall be subject to and available for inspection by the village.
E. It is the duty and responsibility of every taxpayer to make available its books and records for inspection by the village. If the taxpayer, or tax collector,
fails to provide the documents necessary for audit within the time provided, the local tax administrator may issue a tax determination and assessment
based on the tax administrator's determination of the best estimate of the taxpayer's tax liability.
F. If an audit determines there has been an overpayment of a locally imposed and administered tax as a result of the audit, written notice of the amount of
overpayment shall be given to the taxpayer within thirty (30) days of the village's determination of the amount of overpayment.
G. In the event a tax payment was submitted to the incorrect local governmental entity, the local tax administrator shall notify the local governmental entity
imposing such tax. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-9: APPEAL:
A. The local tax administrator shall send written notice to a taxpayer upon the local tax administrator's issuance of a protestable notice of tax due, a bill, a
claim denial, or a notice of claim reduction regarding any tax. The notice shall include the following information:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 123/522
1. The reason for the assessment;
2. The amount of the tax liability proposed;
3. The procedure for appealing the assessment; and
4. The obligations of the village during the audit, appeal, refund and collection process.
B. A taxpayer who receives written notice from the local tax administrator of a determination of tax due or assessment may file with the local tax
administrator a written protest and petition for hearing, setting forth the basis of the taxpayer's request for a hearing. The written protest and petition for
hearing must be filed with the local tax administrator within forty five (45) days of receipt of the written notice of the tax determination and assessment.
C. If a timely written notice and petition for hearing is filed, the local tax administrator shall fix the time and place for hearing and shall give written notice to
the taxpayer. The hearing shall be scheduled for a date within fourteen (14) days of receipt of the written protest and petition for hearing, unless the
taxpayer requests a later date convenient to all parties.
D. If a written protest and petition for hearing is not filed within the forty five (45) day period, the tax determination, audit or assessment shall become a
final bill due and owing without further notice.
E. Upon the showing of reasonable cause by the taxpayer and the full payment of the contested tax liability along with interest accrued as of the due date
of the tax, the local tax administrator may reopen or extend the time for filing a written protest and petition for hearing. In no event shall the time for
filing a written protest and petition for hearing be reopened or extended for more than ninety (90) days after the expiration of the forty five (45) day
period. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-10: HEARING:
A. Whenever a taxpayer or a tax collector has filed a timely written protest and petition for hearing under section 3-2F-9 of this article, the local tax
administrator shall conduct a hearing regarding any appeal.
B. No continuances shall be granted except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the taxpayer. Lack of preparation
shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance granted shall not exceed fourteen (14) days.
C. At the hearing the local tax administrator shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the tax determination, audit or
assessment. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply.
D. At the conclusion of the hearing, the local tax administrator shall make a written determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing.
The taxpayer or tax collector shall be provided with a copy of the written decision. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-11: INTEREST AND PENALTIES:
In the event a determination has been made that a tax is due and owing, through audit, assessment or other bill sent, the tax must be paid within the time
frame otherwise indicated.
A. Interest: The village hereby provides for the amount of interest to be assessed on a late payment, underpayment, or nonpayment of the tax, to be six
percent (6%) per annum, based on a year of three hundred sixty five (365) days and the number of days elapsed.
B. Late Filing And Payment Penalties: If a tax return is not filed within the time and manner provided by the controlling tax ordinance, a late filing penalty of
five percent (5%) of the amount of tax required to be shown as due on a return shall be imposed; and a late payment penalty of five percent (5%) of the
tax due shall be imposed. If no return is filed within the time or manner provided by the controlling tax ordinance and prior to the village issuing a notice
of tax delinquency or notice of tax liability, then a failure to file penalty shall be assessed equal to twenty five percent (25%) of the total tax due for the
applicable reporting period for which the return was required to be filed. A late filing or payment penalty shall not apply if a failure to file penalty is
imposed by the controlling ordinance. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-12: ABATEMENT:
The local tax administrator shall have the authority to waive or abate any late filing penalty, late payment penalty or failure to file penalty if the local tax
administrator shall determine reasonable cause exists for delay or failure to make a filing. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-13: INSTALLMENT CONTRACTS:
The village may enter into an installment contract with the taxpayer for the payment of taxes under the controlling tax ordinance. The local tax
administrator may not cancel any installment contract so entered unless the taxpayer fails to pay any amount due and owing. Upon written notice by the
local tax administrator that the payment is thirty (30) days delinquent, the taxpayer shall have fourteen (14) working days to cure any delinquency. If the
taxpayer fails to cure the delinquency within the fourteen (14) day period or fails to demonstrate good faith in restructuring the installment contract with the
local administrator, the installment contract shall be canceled without further notice to the taxpayer. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 124/522
3-2F-14: STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS:
The village, through the local tax administrator, shall review all tax returns in a prompt and timely manner and inform taxpayers of any amounts due and
owing. The taxpayer shall have forty five (45) days after receiving notice of the reviewed tax returns to make any request for refund or provide any tax still
due and owing.
A. No determination of tax due and owing may be issued more than four (4) years after the end of the calendar year for which the return for the applicable
period was filed or for the calendar year in which the return for the applicable period was due, whichever occurs later.
B. If any tax return is not filed or if during any four (4) year period for which a notice of tax determination or assessment may be issued by the village, the
tax paid was less than seventy five percent (75%) of the tax due, the statute of limitations shall be six (6) years maximum after the end of the calendar
year in which the return for the applicable period was due or end of the calendar year in which the return for the applicable period was filed.
C. No statute of limitations shall apply if a fraudulent tax return was filed by the taxpayer. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-15: VOLUNTARY DISCLOSURE:
For any locally imposed and administered tax for which a taxpayer has not received a written notice of an audit, investigation, or assessment from the local
tax administrator, a taxpayer is entitled to file an application with the local tax administrator for a voluntary disclosure of the tax due. A taxpayer filing a
voluntary disclosure application must agree to pay the amount of tax due, along with interest of one percent (1%) per month, for all periods prior to the
filing of the application but not more than four (4) years before the date of filing the application. A taxpayer filing a valid voluntary disclosure application
may not be liable for any additional tax, interest, or penalty for any period before the date the application was filed. However, if the taxpayer incorrectly
determined and underpaid the amount of tax due, the taxpayer is liable for the underpaid tax along with applicable interest on the underpaid tax, unless
the underpayment was the result of fraud on the part of the taxpayer, in which case the application shall be deemed invalid and void. The payment of tax
and interest must be made by no later than ninety (90) days after the filing of the voluntary disclosure application or the date agreed to by the local tax
administrator. However, any additional amounts owed as a result of an underpayment of tax and interest previously paid under this section must be paid
within ninety (90) days after a final determination and the exhaustion of all appeals of the additional amount owed or the date agreed to by the local tax
administrator, whichever is longer. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-16: PUBLICATION OF TAX ORDINANCES:
Any locally administered tax ordinance shall be published via normal or standard publishing requirements. The posting of a tax ordinance on the internet
shall satisfy the publication requirements. Copies of all tax ordinances shall be made available to the public upon request at the village clerk's office. (Ord.
07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-17: INTERNAL REVIEW OF LIENS:
The local tax administrator shall establish an internal review procedure regarding any liens filed against any taxpayers for unpaid taxes. Upon a
determination by the local tax administrator that the lien is valid, the lien shall remain in full force and effect. If the lien is determined to be improper, the
local tax administrator shall:
A. Timely remove the lien at the village's expense;
B. Correct the taxpayer's credit record; and
C. Correct any public disclosure of the improperly imposed lien. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
3-2F-18: APPLICATION:
This article shall be liberally construed and administered to supplement all of the village's tax ordinances. To the extent that any tax ordinance or any tax
provision of this code is in conflict with or inconsistent with this article, this article shall be controlling. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
Chapter 3
LIQUOR CONTROL
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Except as otherwise defined in this section, the words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in the Illinois
Liquor Control Act, as amended from time to time, and the following terms as used in this chapter shall be construed according to the definitions given
below:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, capable
of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to alcohol used in the manufacture of denatured
alcohol produced in accordance with Acts of Congress and regulations promulgated thereunder, nor to any liquid or solid containing one-half of one
percent (0.5%), or less, of alcohol by volume. No license fee provided for in this chapter shall apply to wine intended for use and used by any church or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 125/522
religious organization for sacramental purposes; provided, that such wine shall be purchased from a licensed manufacturer or importing distributor under
State law.
BEER: A beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or concoction of barley, or other grain, malt and hops in water, and includes,
among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like.
CATERER: A person who serves alcoholic liquors for consumption, either on-site or off-site, whether the location is licensed or unlicensed, as an incidental
part of food service. Prepared meals and alcoholic liquors are sold at a package price agreed upon under a catering contract.
CLUB: A corporation organized under the laws of this State, not for pecuniary profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale
and consumption of alcoholic liquors, kept, used, and maintained by its members, through the payment of annual dues, and owning or hiring or leasing a
building or space in a building, of such extent and character as may be suitable and adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation
of its members and their guests and provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining a sufficient
number of servants and employees for cooking, preparing and serving food and meals for its members and guests; provided, that such club files with the
Village President at the time of its application for a license under this chapter, two (2) copies of a list of names and residences of its members, and
similarly files within ten (10) days of the election of any additional member of his name and address; and provided, that its affairs and management are
conducted by a board of directors, executive committee or similar body chosen by the members at their annual meeting, and that no member or any
officer, agent, or employee of the club is paid, or directly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the distribution or sale of
alcoholic liquor to the club or its members or its guests introduced by members beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed and voted at any annual
meeting of the members or by its board of directors or other governing body out of the general revenue of the club.
HOTEL: Every building or other structure, kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and
consumed and sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to the travelers and guests, whether transient, permanent, or residential, in which
twenty five (25) or more rooms are used for the sleeping accommodations of such guests and having one (1) or more public dining rooms where meals are
served to such guests, such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted in the same building or buildings in connection therewith and
such building or buildings, structure or structures being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity.
INITIAL LICENSE: The first license of a specific class applied for by and/or issued to an applicant pursuant to this chapter.
INITIAL LICENSE FEE: Or any other term of similar import, means and refers to the license fee specified in section 3-3-7 of this chapter for the class of
license for which an application has been filed and/or for which a license has been issued.
LIQUOR LICENSES DEFINED BY CLASS:
Class 1-A: Sale and/or serving of alcoholic liquor for consumption on licensed premises.
Class 1-B: Sale and/or serving of beer and/or wine for consumption on licensed premises.
Class 2-A: Sale of alcoholic liquor in original package for consumption off the premises.
Class 2-B: Sale of beer and/or wine in original package for consumption off the premises.
Class 3: Caterer license, not held in combination with any other Village liquor license.
Class 4: Mail order, other remote ordering, and/or broker sales of alcoholic liquor in original package, not held in combination with any other Village
liquor license.
Class 5: The serving and/or sale of beer and/or wine for consumption only on the licensed premises of a full service personal services establishment.
Class 6: The sale and/or serving of alcoholic liquor for consumption only on the licensed premises, i.e., Barrington's White House.
Class 7: A special temporary license issued to a not-for-profit organization or such other "qualifying organization" as defined in subsection 3-3-7G of
this chapter which authorizes the sale and serving of alcoholic liquor by officers, members, volunteers, employees, and/or agents of the specified
qualifying organization or by a caterer holding a current and valid catering liquor license for such purpose for a period of not to exceed five (5)
consecutive days (or for such longer period of time as otherwise approved by the Corporate Authorities of the Village) for consumption on the
premises or within the area of a special event such as a picnic, outing, festival, fundraiser, or other similar occasion.
POSSESS OR POSSESSION: To be within the physical control of a person or within the area of a person's reasonably expected physical control (i.e., in
their constructive possession), but for the purposes of this chapter, "possession" shall not include the act of lawfully serving of alcoholic liquor to one (1) or
more customers at tables on the licensed premises by an employee or agent of a licensee of a Class 1-A, Class 1-B, Class 5, Class 6, or Class 7 license
issued pursuant to this chapter in the course of their employment if such employee meets the age, employee training, and supervision requirements of this
chapter.
POWDERED ALCOHOL: For purposes of this chapter, "powdered alcohol" (also sometimes referred to as "alcohol without liquid") means any powder or
crystalline substance containing alcohol, as defined in section 1-3.01 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act, produced for human consumption.
POWDERED ALCOHOL DEVICES: A device designed, manufactured, marketed or used for the purpose of mixing powdered alcohol with oxygen, air or
another gas to produce a mist or vapor for inhalation or snorting for other than therapeutic purposes. It shall not include medical devices such as inhalers,
nebulizers, atomizers or other devices being used to dispense a prescribed medication to the holder of such prescription for therapeutic purposes.
RENEWAL LICENSE: Each subsequent license after the initial license applied for by and/or issued to an applicant for a specific class of license pursuant
to this chapter.
RENEWAL LICENSE FEE: Or any other term of similar import, means and refers to the license fee specified in section 1-14-1 of this Code for the class of
license for which an application has been filed and/or for which a license has been issued.
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals
actually are served and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining
room equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook, and serve suitable food for its
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 126/522
guests. A "meal" for this purpose means any food and/or beverage that is or may be served for or as part of breakfast, lunch, brunch, or dinner. A coffee
shop may be considered a "restaurant" if it serves meals.
RETAIL SALE: The sale for use or consumption and not for resale in any form.
SPIRITS: Any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with water or other substance in solution, which includes brandy, rum,
whiskey, gin, or other spirituous liquors, and such liquors when rectified, blended or otherwise mixed with alcohol or other substances.
THERAPEUTIC PURPOSES: Where prescribed or recommended by a physician or other healthcare provider.
VILLAGE: The Village of Barrington, an Illinois Municipal Corporation in Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois.
WINE: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural contents of fruits, or vegetables, containing sugar, including such beverages
when fortified by the addition of alcohol or spirits. (Ord. 17-3937, 3-20-2017)
3-3-2: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail in the Village any alcoholic liquor without having a retail liquor dealer's license or in violation of the terms
of such license. (1973 Code § 3-2)
3-3-3: PERSONS INELIGIBLE FOR LICENSE:
No licenses required by this chapter shall be issued to:
A. A person who is not a resident of the Village.
B. A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides.
C. A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
D. A person who has been convicted of a felony under any Federal or State law, unless the Village President determines that such person has been
sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust after considering matters set forth in such person's application and the commission's investigation.
The burden of proof of sufficient rehabilitation shall be on the applicant.
E. A person who has been convicted of being the keeper of or is keeping a house of ill fame.
F. A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
G. A person whose license issued under this chapter and/or the State Act has been revoked for cause.
H. A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a first application.
(1973 Code § 3-6; amd. 2003 Code)
I. A partnership, if any general or limited partner thereof owning more than five percent (5%) of the aggregate interest in such partnership would not be
eligible to receive a license hereunder.
J. A corporation, or limited liability company ("LLC"), if any officer, manager, director, or member thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the
aggregate five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, or more than five percent (5%) of such LLC, would not be eligible to receive a license
hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the Village. Notwithstanding anything contained in this chapter to the contrary, if
the stock of the applicant corporation is traded on a nationally recognized securities market, the Village may elect to forego the background check(s)
and fingerprinting of the officers, directors, and stockholders owning more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, or more than five
percent (5%) of such LLC, if the manager of the proposed licensee and the premises to be licensed would otherwise qualify for a license issued
pursuant to this chapter.
K. A corporation or an LLC, unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois Business Corporate
Act1 to transact business in Illinois. (Ord. 16-3892, 6-13-2016)
L. A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
M. A person who has been convicted of a violation of any State or Federal law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor or who
shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer to charges for such violation.
N. A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a license is sought or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the
license is issued.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 127/522
O. Any law enforcing public official, including the Village President or any member of the Village Board of Trustees; and no such official shall be interested
directly in the manufacture, sale, or distribution of alcoholic liquor, except that a license may be granted to any member of the Village Board of Trustees
in relation to premises that are located within the Village subject to the jurisdiction of that official if: 1) the sale of alcoholic liquor pursuant to the license
is incidental to the selling of food; 2) the issuance of the license is approved by the State commission; 3) the issuance of the license is in accordance
with all applicable Village ordinances in effect where the premises are located; and 4) the official granted a license does not vote on alcoholic liquor
issues pending before the Board of Trustees.
P. A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense as proscribed by any of subsections (a)(3) through (a)(11) of section 28-1 of, or as proscribed
by section 28-1.1 or 28-3 of the Criminal Code of 19612, or as proscribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory provisions. (1973
Code § 3-6; amd. 2003 Code)
Q. A person who at the time of the original application and/or any application for the renewal of any license (other than a Class 4 license) issued hereunder
has not either completed the BASSET Program as required in section 3-3-19 of this chapter or has not employed a manager who has completed the
BASSET Training Program as required in said section 3-3-19 of this chapter. (Ord. 17-3937, 3-20-2017)
3-3-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; APPLICATION FEES:
Applications for licenses required by this chapter shall be made to the Village President and filed with the Village Clerk, in writing, signed by the applicant,
if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, limited partnership, or other entity, verified by
oath or affidavit. Applications for licenses may be submitted to the Village by e-mail, but such applications shall nonetheless contain all required
information, including, but not limited to, an e-mail address of the respective applicant(s), and in any event, each applicant shall be required to supplement
their respective application(s) from time to time whenever their respective e-mail address changes during the application process and throughout the
license year. Each application for an initial license shall be accompanied by the payment of a nonrefundable application fee of the amount as specified
from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this Code. Each application for a renewal license shall be accompanied by the payment of a nonrefundable
application fee of the amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this Code. Each application shall contain the following statements and
information:
A. The name, age, and address of the applicant in the case of an individual, in the case of a partnership, the names, ages and addresses of the persons
entitled to a share in the profits thereof, and in the case of a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or limited partnership, the objects for
which organized, the names and addresses of the officers and directors, manager, and registered agent, and of any stockholder or stockholders
owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or limited partnership.
Notwithstanding anything contained in this chapter to the contrary, if the stock of the applicant corporation is traded on a nationally recognized
securities market, the Village may elect to forgo the background check(s) and fingerprinting of the officers, directors, stockholders, managers,
members, and/or partners owning more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or limited
partnership, if the manager of the proposed licensee and the premises to be licensed would otherwise qualify for a license issued pursuant to this
chapter. (Ord. 16-3892, 6-13-2016)
B. The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and, if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
C. The character of business of the applicant and, in case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed; the articles of incorporation and any
amendments thereto.
D. The length of time said applicant has been in the business of that character or, in the case of a corporation, the date when the charter was issued.
E. The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time the application is made.
F. The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license.
G. A statement whether the applicant has made an application for a similar or other license on the premises other than those described in the application
and the disposition of such application.
H. A statement that neither the applicant nor any other person identified in the application has ever been convicted of a felony or is disqualified to receive a
license by reason of any matter or thing contained in this Code, laws of the State or the other ordinances of the Village.
I. Whether a previous license by a State or subdivision thereof, or by the Federal Government, has been revoked and the reason therefor.
J. A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the State or of the United States or any ordinance of the Village in the conduct of his
place of business.
K. A statement listing each and every occupation or business with which the applicant and any other person identified in the application has been
associated in any capacity for fifteen (15) years prior to the filing of said application.
L. A statement listing each and every arrest of the applicant and any other person identified in the application, other than arrests for traffic offenses, giving
the place and date of arrest, the charge and the final disposition of the charge.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 128/522
M. Fingerprints of all the fingers of each hand of the applicant and of any other person identified in the application, taken by personnel of the Village.
N. A statement of whether the applicant has ever filed bankruptcy proceedings and, if so, the date and place of said filing.
O. A statement of whether there has ever been issued to the applicant a stamp relative to a Federal tax on wages and, if so, the date and places where
said stamp was held by the applicant and a statement of the purposes for which held. (1973 Code § 3-3)
3-3-5: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; PROCEDURE:
A. Referral Of Application; Investigation; Recommendation: The Village President shall cause a copy of the license application to be forwarded promptly to
each Village Trustee and to the Chief of Police of the Village. The Chief of Police shall investigate the applicant to determine the accuracy of the
information provided in the application and shall provide to the Corporate Authorities a report of such investigation, which shall include a
recommendation of whether he finds the applicant qualified to hold a license pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. (1973 Code § 3-5; amd. 2003
Code)
B. Waiting Period Before License Issuance: No license shall be issued until at least thirty (30) days from the date of filing of the application; provided,
however, the waiting period shall not apply to an amended application filed pursuant to section 3-3-11 of this chapter. (1973 Code § 3-4)
3-3-6: TERMINATION OF LICENSE:
Each license required by this chapter shall terminate on April 30 next following the date of issuance. (Ord. 97-2662, 5-27-1997)
3-3-7: CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES; FEES:
The following classifications of licenses may be issued if and when authorized by this chapter or by an amendment thereto:
A. Class 1 Licenses:
1. Class 1-A License: A Class 1-A license allows the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption only on the licensed premises where sold, except as
otherwise permitted by section 6-33 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934. Notwithstanding anything contained in this chapter to the contrary:
a. If the holder of a Class 1-A license is a golf club, the sale and serving of alcoholic beverages on the golf course of such club from one (1) or more
drink carts by person(s) at least twenty one (21) years of age with BASSET training as required by this chapter shall also be authorized by such
Class 1-A license.
b. A Class 1-A license also allows the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption off the premises if such sales are provided by the licensee acting as a
caterer and are limited to invited guests at catered functions or at an event which receives a special event license from the Village, but a separate
State-issued caterer license shall also be required.
c. A Class 1-A license also allows within the area specifically designated in the Class 1-A license as the premises, the immediate consumption of
table wine that was not purchased on the premises, subject to the following conditions, but only during the times when alcoholic liquor may be
served and consumed pursuant to the terms and limitations of a Class 1-A license and on the condition that a BASSET qualified person shall open
the customer's table wine, shall provide the initial service of the contents thereof and at the conclusion of the meal if there is any wine remaining,
shall at the direction of the customer, either properly dispose of the leftover contents of the bottle(s) or cap the bottle(s) and return the leftover
contents to the customer who shall transport same only as permitted by law.
d. A licensee holding a Village Class 1-A license may also, with the prior written approval of the Local Liquor Commissioner, utilize a State special
use permit license to transfer a portion of its alcoholic liquor inventory from its licensed premises to the location of a special event approved by the
Village and sell and serve alcoholic liquor on such special event premises for consumption at and as part of such special event on the condition
that such licensee secures a special use permit license specifically issued by the Illinois Liquor Control Commission for such special event.
e. A Class 1-A license also allows the sale of alcoholic liquor by a licensee for consumption on the premises (except as otherwise permitted by
section 6-33 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934), on that portion of the licensed premises where the customers are seated other than within a
wholly-enclosed building (herein sometimes referred to as the "outdoor premises" or an "outdoor cafe"), subject to timely and continued
compliance with all of the following conditions:
(1) Outdoor Premises Accessory: The outdoor premises must be accessory to the balance of the licensed premises and such outdoor premises
must have a current valid special license for an outdoor cafe as required by chapter 6 of this title and a current valid food establishment permit,
license, and/or certificate pursuant to chapter 6, article A of this title.
(2) Village President Approval Required: An outdoor cafe may only be approved by and at the discretion of the Village President acting as the
Village's Local Liquor Control Commissioner, or by his or her designee, for a licensee to whom a special approval to operate an outdoor cafe has
been issued pursuant to the provisions of chapter 6 of this title; provided, that such special approval is still valid and in effect.
(3) Food Establishment: All necessary permits, licenses and/or certificates have been issued to authorize such outdoor cafe to operate a food
establishment as required by sections 3-6A-3 and 3-6A-4 of this title, and such permits, licenses and/or certificates are and must remain valid
and in effect.
(4) Licensed Area: The outdoor premises upon which alcoholic liquor may be sold and served pursuant to a Class 1-A license shall be the same
area as the "licensed area" as that term is defined in section 3-6A-1-1 of this title.
(5) Compliance With Outdoor Cafe Regulations: All of the regulations related to an outdoor cafe as set forth in chapter 6 of this title, including, but
not limited to, the days and hours of operation, shall apply to the outdoor premises upon which alcoholic liquor may be sold and served pursuant
to a Class 1-A license.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 129/522
(6) Music And Entertainment: Neither live entertainment, dancing nor any recorded music broadcast from any sound system shall be permitted on
the outdoor premises except when specifically approved in advance by the Corporate Authorities.
(7) Lighting: The artificial lighting of the outdoor premises shall be sufficient to provide for the safety of all persons using such area but shall not be
such as to create a nuisance or to inhibit the normal use and enjoyment of surrounding property. Notwithstanding the foregoing, as measured
from any point, the artificial lighting shall not exceed one-tenth (0.1) foot-candle either within or without the outdoor premises.
(8) Conduct Of Operation: The entire operation and use of the outdoor premises shall be carried on so as not to create a health or safety hazard or
to create a nuisance or to interfere with the use and enjoyment of surrounding property.
2. Class 1-B License: A Class 1-B license allows the sale of beer and/or wine for consumption on the licensed premises where sold, except as
otherwise permitted by section 6-33 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934.
a. A Class 1-B license also allows the sale and serving of beer and/or wine for consumption off the premises if such sales and service are provided
by the licensee acting as a caterer and are limited to invited guests at catered functions or at an event which receives a special event license from
the Village, but a separate State-issued caterer license shall also be required.
b. A Class 1-B license also allows within the area specifically designated in the Class 1-B license as the premises, the immediate consumption of
table wine that was not purchased on the premises, subject to the following conditions, but only during the times when beer and/or wine may be
served and consumed pursuant to the terms and limitations of a Class 1-B license and on the condition that a BASSET qualified person shall open
the customer's table wine, shall provide the initial service of the contents thereof and at the conclusion of the meal if there is any wine remaining,
shall at the direction of the customer, either properly dispose of the leftover contents of the bottle(s) or cap the bottle(s) and return the leftover
contents to the customer who shall transport same only as permitted by law.
c. A licensee holding a Village Class 1-B license may also, with the prior written approval of the Local Liquor Commissioner, utilize a State special
use permit license to transfer a portion of its alcoholic liquor inventory from its licensed premises to the location of a special event approved by the
Village and sell and serve alcoholic liquor on such special event premises for consumption at and as part of such special event on the condition
that such licensee secures a special use permit license specifically issued by the Illinois Liquor Control Commission for such special event.
d. A Class 1-B license also allows the sale of beer and/or wine by a licensee for consumption on the premises (except as otherwise permitted by
section 6-33 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934), on that portion of the licensed premises where the customers are seated other than within a
wholly-enclosed building (herein sometimes referred to as the "outdoor premises"), subject to timely and continued compliance with all of the
following conditions:
(1) Outdoor Premises Accessory: The outdoor portion of the licensed premises must be accessory to the balance of the licensed premises and
such outdoor premises must have a current valid special license for an outdoor cafe as required by chapter 6 of this title and a current valid food
establishment permit, license, and/or certificate pursuant to chapter 6, article A of this title.
(2) Village President Approval Required: An outdoor cafe may only be approved by and at the discretion of the Village President acting as the
Village's Local Liquor Control Commissioner to a licensee to whom a special approval to operate an outdoor cafe has been issued pursuant to
the provisions of chapter 6 of this title; provided, that such special approval is still valid and in effect.
(3) Food Establishment: All necessary permits, licenses and/or certificates have been issued to authorize such outdoor cafe to operate a food
establishment as required in sections 3-6A-3 and 3-6A-4 of this title, and such permits, licenses and/or certificates are still valid and in effect.
(4) Licensed Area: The outdoor premises upon which beer and/or wine may be sold and served pursuant to a Class 1-B license shall be the same
area as the "licensed area" as that term is defined in section 3-6A-1-1 of this title.
(5) Compliance With Outdoor Cafe Regulations: All of the regulations related to an outdoor cafe as set forth in chapter 6 of this title, including, but
not limited to, the days and hours of operation, shall apply to the outdoor premises upon which beer and/or wine may be sold and served
pursuant to a Class 1-B license.
(6) Music And Entertainment: Neither live entertainment, dancing nor any recorded music broadcast from any sound system shall be permitted on
the outdoor premises except when specifically approved in advance by the Corporate Authorities of the Village.
(7) Lighting: The artificial lighting of the outdoor premises shall be sufficient to provide for the safety of all persons using such area but shall not be
such as to create a nuisance or to inhibit the normal use and enjoyment of surrounding property. Notwithstanding the foregoing, as measured
from any point, the artificial lighting shall not exceed one-tenth (0.1) foot-candle either within or without the outdoor premises.
(8) Conduct Of Operation: The entire operation and use of the outdoor premises shall be carried on so as not to create a health or safety hazard or
to create a nuisance or to interfere with the use and enjoyment of surrounding property. (Ord. 17-3937, 3-20-2017)
B. Class 2 Licenses:
1. Class 2-A License: A Class 2-A license allows the sale of alcoholic liquor in the unopened original package or original container, provided that such
sales shall only be for consumption off the licensed premises.
a. Any such Class 2-A license shall meet the following additional requirements:
(1) Sales Area: A sales area for all sales of alcoholic liquor, which sales area shall be separate from all other sales areas. Notwithstanding the
requirement set out herein that sales of alcoholic liquor be confined to a sales area, a holder of a Class 2-A license may maintain an aggregate
of fifteen (15) separate display areas for beer and/or wine which are not located within the separate sales area for the sale of alcoholic
beverages; provided, that each such separate display has an area at its base (or at any point on a horizontal plane above its base) that does not
exceed sixteen (16) square feet and is stacked to a height that does not exceed five feet (5'). For the purposes of a Class 2-A license, "sales
area" shall mean that separate portion of the licensed premises within which alcoholic liquor is displayed by the licensee for purposes of sale on
the licensed premises.
(2) Separate Storage: A separate secure storage area for all alcoholic liquor inventory which is not displayed in the sales area.
(3) Open And Clear Aisles: Aisles in the alcoholic liquor sales area must be open and clear and shall not be used to store or display the product
which may only be displayed on shelves.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 130/522
(4) No Separate Point Of Sale: The separation of such sales area shall not, however, require the licensee to maintain a separate point of sale (i.e.,
a cash register) for such sales area, and all such alcoholic liquor sold in its original packages for consumption off the premises may be
purchased at any point of sale on the licensed premises.
b. A Class 2-A license also allows the sale of alcoholic liquor in the unopened original package or original container provided that such sales shall be
for future delivery as mail orders, other remote ordering, and/or broker sales only where delivery to the customer is by any mail or delivery service
which is restricted to delivery to a customer only upon proof presented by the customer that such customer is twenty one (21) years of age or
older, and pursuant to orders placed by telephone (including telefax), electronic mail, or regular mail order.
2. Class 2-B License: A Class 2-B license allows the sale of beer and/or wine only in the unopened original package or the original container, provided
that such sale shall be only for consumption off the licensed premises.
a. Any such Class 2-B license shall meet the following additional requirements:
(1) Sales Area: A sales area for all sales of beer and/or wine, which sales area shall be separate from all other sales areas. Notwithstanding the
requirement set out herein that sales of beer and/or wine be confined to a sales area, a holder of a class 2-B license may maintain an aggregate
of fifteen (15) separate display areas for beer and/or wine which are not located within the separate sales area for the sale of alcoholic
beverages; provided, that each such separate display has an area at its base (or at any point on a horizontal plane above its base) that does not
exceed sixteen (16) square feet and is stacked to a height that does not exceed five feet (5'). For the purposes of a class 2-B license, "sales
area" shall mean that separate portion of the licensed premises within which alcoholic liquor is displayed by the licensee for purposes of sale on
the licensed premises.
(2) Separate Storage: A separate secure storage area for all beer and/or wine inventory which is not displayed in the sales area.
(3) Open And Clear Aisles: Aisles in the beer and/or wine sales area must be open and clear and shall not be used to store or display the product
which may only be displayed on shelves.
(4) No Separate Point Of Sale: The separation of such sales area shall not, however, require the licensee to maintain a separate point of sale (i.e.,
a cash register) for such sales area, and all such beer and/or wine sold in its original packages for consumption off the premises may be
purchased at any point of sale on the licensed premises.
b. A class 2-B license also allows the sale of beer and/or wine only in the unopened original package or original container for consumption only off
the licensed premises where sold, provided that such sales shall be for future delivery as mail orders, other remote ordering, and/or broker sales of
beer and/or wine but only where delivery to the customer is by any mail or delivery service which is restricted to delivery to a customer only upon
proof presented by the customer that such customer is twenty one (21) years of age or older, and pursuant to orders placed by telephone
(including telefax), electronic mail, or regular mail order.
C. Class 3 License: A class 3 license allows the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption off the premises by a licensee who holds no other liquor license
issued pursuant to this chapter; provided, that such sales are provided by a caterer and are limited to invited guests at catered functions. A class 3
license shall only be issued to a caterer who conducts business from a location established within the boundaries of the village and shall only be valid
for catered functions located within the boundaries of the village. For purposes of a class 3 license, a "caterer" or terms of similar import shall mean
and refer to a business or activity, the purpose of which is the processing, preparing and serving of food and/or drink items for immediate consumption
off the premises. At all times, the class 3 license holder shall comply with all of the provisions of this chapter governing licenses and license holders,
including, but not limited to, BASSET regulations (beverage alcohol sellers and servers education and training program).
D. Class 4 License: A class 4 license allows the sale of alcoholic liquor in the unopened original package or original container by a licensee who holds no
other license issued pursuant to this chapter; provided, that such sales shall be only for consumption off the licensed premises, for future delivery as
mail order, other remote ordering, and/or broker sales but only where delivery to the customer is by any mail or delivery service which is restricted to
delivery to a customer only upon proof presented by the customer that such customer is twenty one (21) years of age or older; and pursuant to orders
placed by telephone (including telefax), electronic mail, or regular mail order.
E. Class 5 License: A class 5 license allows the sale and/or serving of beer and/or wine only for consumption on the licensed premises as an incidental
part of a full service personal care services establishment such as a hair salon or barbershop. A class 5 license shall be subject to the following
conditions and limitations:
1. Full Service Personal Care Establishment: The sale and/or serving of beer and/or wine for consumption on the licensed premises shall be permitted
only in connection with a full service personal care services establishment. For the purpose of this requirement, a "full service personal care services
establishment" shall mean a business establishment that offers multiple personal care services (at least 4 different services in addition to the sale
and/or serving of beer and/or wine) which may include, but not be limited to, hair treatments, haircuts, nail treatments, body packs and wraps,
exfoliation, waxing, aromatherapy, and facials, but to qualify for such a class 5 license, the personal care services shall not include any massage
therapy services as defined in section 3-5-1 of this title or any reflexology services as defined in the massage licensing act.
2. Limited Individual Servings: The sale and/or serving of beer and/or wine intended for consumption on the licensed premises shall be limited to the
sale of individual servings of beer and/or wine or the sale of beer and wine as part of a package of personal care services. No more than two (2)
servings of beer (each not to exceed 12 ounces) or wine (each not to exceed 4 ounces) per customer shall be permitted on the licensed premises
per calendar day.
3. Incidental To Business Operation: The sale and/or serving of beer and/or wine for consumption on the licensed premises shall be merely incidental
to the primary business operation of the licensed premises of a full service personal care services establishment, and the licensed premises shall not
be advertised or otherwise held out to be a drinking establishment.
4. Permitted Hours For Sale; Serving And/Or Consumption Of Beer And/Or Wine: In no case shall the sale, serving, and/or consumption on the
licensed premises of beer and/or wine take place outside of the normal business hours of the licensed premises and, in any event, not outside of the
hours for liquor service as otherwise permitted by this chapter.
5. Live Entertainment Prohibited: No live entertainment of any nature shall be permitted on the licensed premises.
6. No Signs: No sign or any other external indicia shall be permitted on the licensed premises or surrounding property that indicates that alcoholic liquor
is available for sale and/or serving at the licensed premises.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 131/522
F. Class 6 License:
1. A class 6 license allows any of the following on any portion or portions of the premises of Barrington's White House ("BWH"), located at 145 W. Main
Street, Barrington, Illinois, which is owned and operated by the village, including, but not limited to, the garden, front yard and/or porch of said
property, when the use of such space(s) is authorized by the corporate authorities of the village or by the BWH facility manager, or his or her
designee: a) the sale and serving of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises; b) catered events on the premises which include the serving of
alcoholic liquor; c) the serving free of charge of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises, when such sale, catered serving, or serving free of
charge of alcoholic liquor is incidental to any public or private scheduled event held at Barrington's White House and/or on the property at 145 W.
Main Street in the village (collectively, "the premises") and approved by and scheduled with the BWH facility manager ("scheduled event"), and such
alcoholic liquor is provided by the village through Barrington's White House.
2. The following conditions shall apply to a class 6 license and the Barrington's White House premises:
a. All pouring and/or serving of alcoholic liquor shall be by persons who are at least twenty one (21) years of age;
b. Alcoholic liquor shall only be served to and consumed by persons who are at least twenty one (21) years of age; and
c. Alcoholic liquor served and consumed at events at Barrington's White House, and/or anywhere on the property at 145 W. Main Street, shall only
be served and consumed on the premises at scheduled events in those room or rooms and/or such outside spaces (i.e., the garden, the front yard,
or the porch) of Barrington's White House as reserved with the BWH facility manager for the scheduled event, and nowhere else in Barrington's
White House or on the Barrington's White House property.
G. Class 7 License:
1. A class 7 license is a special temporary license, for a period of not to exceed five (5) consecutive days except as otherwise approved by the
corporate authorities of the village, which temporary license may be issued by the village president acting as local liquor control commissioner only to
a not for profit corporation, club, organization or governmental entity whose purpose and function is providing benefit, assistance or support to
charitable, athletic, religious, youth service, or any civic or community service programs located within and/or serving the village for an event where
alcoholic liquor is to be sold; or where the serving of such alcoholic liquor at such event requires or may require a special event license from the state
of Illinois liquor control commission (the organizations described above are for convenience sometimes hereinafter collectively referred to as
"qualifying organizations"). Such a qualifying organization shall also obtain such a special event license from the state of Illinois liquor control
commission where so required. However, notwithstanding the foregoing, no such special temporary license shall be required to be obtained from the
village if alcoholic liquor is being served on behalf of the qualifying organization by the BASSET trained employees of a caterer holding a current and
valid catering liquor license, which caterer has been hired by such qualifying organization for such event.
2. Each application by a qualifying organization for such a special temporary license shall contain the same information required as defined in section
3-3-1 of this chapter. Each application by a not for profit corporation shall contain a copy of the applicant's recorded articles of incorporation and a
copy of the applicant's most recent annual report filed with the Secretary of State of the State of Illinois. Notwithstanding the foregoing, each
application submitted by a qualifying organization shall include reasonable evidence of the purpose and function that such qualifying organization is
providing. All applications shall state the time period for which the license shall be applicable and shall state whether the license is for solely an
outdoor or an indoor location.
3. Such a special license shall allow: a) the sale of alcoholic liquor at a picnic, outing, festival, fundraiser, or other such similar special occasion or event
by BASSET trained officers, members, volunteers, employees, and/or agents of the specified qualifying organization, for consumption on the
premises or within the area and for the days and hours of sale, all as specifically designated in such special license. A Class 7 license is exempt from
the separation requirements provided for in subsection 3-3-13B of this chapter. The fee for such special license shall be as specified from time to
time in section 1-14-1 of this Code, but no separate application fee shall be charged. A qualifying organization shall be required to obtain such a
Class 7 license for each and every such event it holds within the Village, and the number of events held by any such qualifying organization shall not
exceed five (5) such events in any calendar year, unless specifically authorized by the Board of Trustees. No such special license shall be issued to
any applicant other than the Village until the Village President, or his or her designee, has received evidence that such applicant shall have
satisfactory dramshop liability insurance coverage in effect during the period for which each such special license shall be issued. (Ord. 16-3908, 11-
28-2016, eff. 5-1-2017)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 4050 - LIQUOR CONTROL. Go to new ordinance.
