(1) Any offense involving sexual misconduct with children or other sex offenses as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1 et seq.
(2) Any felony based upon conduct or involvement in such related business activity or similar business activity, within the past ten (10) years.
(3) Any felony unrelated to conduct or involvement in such related business activity or similar business activity, but which felony involved the use of
a deadly weapon, traffic in narcotic drugs or controlled substances, or violence against another person, including rape or other sexual
misconduct, within the past five (5) years.
(4) Any misdemeanor ordinance violation based upon conduct or involvement in such related business activity or similar business activity within
the past five (5) years of the date of the application including, but not limited to, the denial, suspension or revocation of such a similar license by
any state or other unit of local government within five (5) years of the date of the application.
b. An applicant whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for cause or the applicant has pled guilty to or has been found guilty of
any violation of any provision of this chapter.
c. An applicant who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
d. An applicant under the age of eighteen (18) years of age.
e. An applicant who has failed to submit a complete application and who has failed to cure the defect(s) within ten (10) days after written notice of
any such failure to cure.
f. An applicant who has been convicted of any other criminal offense involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or moral turpitude within five (5) years of the
date of the application.
2. In addition to the provisions in subsection D1 of this section, no massage establishment license shall be issued to or renewed for:
a. An applicant whose place of business is conducted by a manager unless the manager possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee.
b. An applicant who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee.
c. A partnership, if any general partners thereof, or any limited partner owning any interest in such partnership, or an LLC, if any member or manager
has pled guilty to, or liable for, or has been found guilty of, or liable by a court or by an administrative tribunal for any one or more of the offenses
listed in this chapter.
d. A corporation, if any officer or director or any stockholder(s) owning any of the stock of such corporation has pled guilty to, or liable for, or has
been found guilty of, or liable by a court or an administrative tribunal for any one or more of the offenses listed in this chapter.
e. A corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois business corporation act,
805 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1.01 et seq., to transact business in Illinois.
f. An applicant if the premises in which the massage establishment is to be operated shall not be in compliance with all applicable codes and
ordinances of the village, including, but not limited to, zoning, building, and life safety codes. (Ord. 15-3839, 6-8-2015)
3-5-5: REVIEW BY VILLAGE MANAGER OF DENIAL OF LICENSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 148/522
The denial by the village clerk, or a village employee designated by him, to issue a license pursuant to an application made therefor shall be subject to
review by the village manager; provided, that a request for such review is made in writing by the applicant to the village manager within ten (10) days of
the issuance of the written denial of the application. The village manager shall conduct a hearing to review the application submitted to the village by the
applicant, the report of the chief of police and/or any other reports of inspections made and of any other relevant facts and evidence determined. The
applicant may present any relevant evidence in support of his request that the denial of the application be reviewed and reversed. The village manager
shall determine whether the denial of the application shall be affirmed or whether the denial shall be reversed and the application approved. If the village
manager reverses the decision and approves the application, the license applied for shall be issued. The decision of the village manager to affirm the
denial of the application shall be final and subject to judicial review only by a court of competent jurisdiction to the extent otherwise provided by law. (Ord.
05-3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-6: LICENSE FEE AND TERM:
A. Fees: The fee for the original application for a massage establishment license shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code and
as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each renewal application. All fees shall be paid at the time each application is submitted
to the village. No application shall be processed without the payment in full of the applicable fees even if the application is made for a period of less
than a full license term.
B. Terms: Commencing with the license term beginning on May 1, 2011, such license term shall commence on May 1, 2011, and shall expire on December
31, 2012, after which expiration such extended license term shall not be repeated. Commencing on January 1, 2013, and thereafter, each license term
shall commence on January 1 of each year and shall expire on December 31 of the same year, unless an application is submitted after January 1 for
any year (but before December 31 in the same year), in which case, the license term shall commence when issued but shall, in any event, expire on
December 31 following the date of issuance. (Ord. 11-3626, 4-25-2011)
3-5-7: FACILITY REQUIREMENTS:
No license to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an inspection by the village reveals that the establishment complies with each of
the following minimum requirements:
A. Premises Generally: The massage establishment premises shall be in compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances of the village, including, but
not limited to, zoning, building and life safety codes.
B. Electrical Requirements: All electrical equipment shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the village electrical code.
C. Waterproof Construction; Plumbing Requirements:
1. Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths and showers shall be made waterproof with approved waterproof materials and shall be
installed in accordance with the village building code. Plumbing fixtures shall be installed in accordance with the village plumbing code.
2. Steam rooms and shower compartments shall have waterproof floors, walls and ceilings approved by the village.
3. Floors of wet and dry heat rooms shall be adequately pitched to one or more floor drains properly connected to the sewer. (Exception: Dry heat
rooms with wooden floors need not be provided with pitched floors and floor drains.)
4. A source of hot water must be available within the immediate vicinity of dry and wet heat rooms to facilitate cleaning.
D. Disinfection And Sterilization Equipment: The premises shall have adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing nondisposable instruments and
materials used in administering massages. Such nondisposable instruments and materials shall be disinfected after use on each patron.
E. Storage Of Linens:
1. Closed cabinets shall be provided and used for the storage of clean linen, towels, and other materials used in connection with administering
massages.
2. All soiled linens, towels, and other materials shall be kept in properly covered containers or cabinets, which containers or cabinets shall be kept
separate from the clean storage areas.
F. Toilet Facilities: Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. At a minimum, a single unisex water closet shall be provided in an
establishment when less than twenty (20) (in the aggregate) employees and patrons of different sexes are reasonably calculated to be on the premises
at the same time. When twenty (20) or more (in the aggregate) employees and patrons of different sexes are reasonably calculated to be on the
premises at the same time, the following shall be applicable: Separate toilet facilities shall be provided for each sex. A single water closet per sex shall
be provided for each twenty (20) or more employees or patrons of that sex on the premises at any one time. Urinals may be substituted for water
closets after one water closet has been provided. Toilets shall be designated as to the sex accommodated therein.
G. Lavatories Or Washbasins: Lavatories or washbasins provided with both hot and cold running water shall be installed in either the toilet room or a
vestibule. Lavatories or washbasins shall be provided with soap and a dispenser and with sanitary towels.
H. Dressing Or Locker Facilities: Adequate dressing or locker facilities shall be provided for the patrons to be served at any given time. In the event male
and female patrons are to be served simultaneously, segregated dressing, locker and massage room facilities shall be provided. (Ord. 05-3213, 2-14-
2005)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 149/522
3-5-8: OPERATING REQUIREMENTS:
A. Rates Posted: Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted in the reception area in a location available to all prospective patrons.
B. False Advertising: No massage establishment granted a license under the provisions of this chapter shall place, publish or distribute or cause to be
placed, published, or distributed any advertisement, picture, or statement which is known or through the exercise of reasonable care should be known
to be false, deceptive or misleading in order to induce any person to purchase or utilize any massage services.
C. Sanitary Conditions:
1. Every portion of the massage establishment, including appliances and apparatus, shall be kept clean and operated in a sanitary condition.
2. All employees, including massage therapists, shall be clean and shall be fully covered by wearing clean, nontransparent outer garments, completely
covering the sexual and genital areas.
3. All massage establishments shall be provided with clean, laundered sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use
thereof and stored in a sanitary manner.
4. Each massage therapist shall wash his or her hands in hot running water with proper disinfectant before administering a massage to each patron.
5. Oils, creams, lotions or other preparations used in administering massages shall be kept in clean, closed containers or cabinets and shall be
dispensed in unit doses so that bulk containers are not contaminated between clients.
6. Eating in the massage work areas shall not be permitted. Animals, except guide dogs, shall not be permitted in the massage work areas.
D. Patrons To Be Covered: The sexual or genital areas of patrons shall be completely covered at all times when in the presence of an employee of the
massage establishment or any massage therapist.
E. Massaging Infected Areas: No massage therapist or massage establishment employee or agent shall administer a massage to any part of a patron's
body which exhibits skin fungus, skin infection, skin inflammation or skin eruption, unless a physician duly licensed in the state has certified in writing
that such patron may safely be massaged on that area and prescribing the conditions thereof.
F. Indecent, Obscene Conduct: No massage establishment licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall knowingly permit any person to remain in or
upon the licensed premises who commits any act of public indecency or obscenity as provided in this code or as provided in the Illinois criminal code2.
G. Compliance With Other Laws: Each massage establishment shall operate in compliance with all applicable local, state and federal laws and
regulations, including, but not limited to, any such laws and regulations relating to discrimination based on race, color, religion, national origin, gender,
disability or age. (Ord. 05-3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-9: ADDITIONAL CONDITIONS OF ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE:
A. Manager And Licensed Massage Therapist On Premises: At all times during the hours of operation of a massage establishment, there shall be present
a manager or other employee of the licensee, and a licensed massage therapist, each of whom shall not be less than eighteen (18) years of age. A
licensed massage therapist may also serve as a manager.
B. Hours Of Operation: No massage establishment shall be open for business or in operation between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M.
C. Name And Place Of Business: No person granted a license hereunder shall operate the massage establishment under a name not specified in the
license, nor shall the business be conducted under any different designation or at any location not specified in the massage establishment license.
D. Liquor Prohibited: No person shall sell, give, dispense, provide or keep, or cause to be sold, given, dispensed, provided or kept, any alcoholic beverage
on the premises of any massage establishment, and no massage establishment shall be located on any premises for which a license to sell alcoholic
liquor has been issued. (Ord. 05-3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-10: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
The massage establishment license required by this chapter and the massage therapist license issued by the state of Illinois of each and every licensed
massage therapist employed in the massage establishment shall be displayed in an open and conspicuous place in the premises to be licensed. (Ord. 05-
3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-11: CHANGE OF LOCATION OR MANAGER; TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A. Change Of Location: Any license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be applicable only to the specific licensee and location designated, and may not
be sold, transferred, or otherwise assigned. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the licensee remains the same and a request is made to designate and
substitute a different location, the village clerk, or a village employee designated by him, may approve such new location upon submission of proof that
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 150/522
such location is in compliance with all of the provisions of this chapter. A fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code shall be
required for processing a request to change the location of the massage establishment. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
B. Change Of Licensee; Nontransferability: A transfer in the ownership or control of a massage establishment shall constitute a change in the licensee,
and the existing license shall be deemed surrendered and extinguished. A new application and license shall be filed and processed as provided in this
chapter prior to such transfer taking effect. Any transfer in the ownership or control of a massage establishment in violation of this chapter shall
constitute the operation of an unlicensed massage establishment.
C. Change Of Manager: Notice shall be provided prior to any change of the designated manager conducting business for the massage establishment
licensee. The new manager must be qualified to operate the massage establishment as provided in this chapter. The licensee shall, not less than ten
(10) business days before such change is to take effect, give the village clerk, or a village employee designated by him, notice of such change. The
notice shall include any information concerning the new manager which is required in this chapter. (Ord. 05-3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-12: EMPLOYMENT OF MASSAGE THERAPIST REQUIRED:
A. No person shall employ as a massage therapist any person unless said person is a licensed massage therapist.
B. No person shall perform any massage on another person in a massage establishment unless the person performing such massage is a licensed
massage therapist.
C. No person shall perform any massage on another person in a massage establishment unless a copy of the current, valid massage therapist license
issued by the state of Illinois to the person performing the massage is on file with the village clerk, or with a village employee designated by the village
clerk. (Ord. 15-3839, 6-8-2015)
3-5-13: UNLAWFUL ACTS:
It shall be unlawful:
A. For any individual, in a massage establishment, to knowingly place his or her hand or hands upon, to touch with any part of his or her body, to fondle in
any manner, or to massage a sexual or genital area or part of any other person.
B. For any individual, in a massage establishment, to expose his or her sexual or genital parts, or any portion thereof, to any other individual. It shall also
be unlawful for any individual, in a massage establishment, to expose the sexual or genital parts, or any portions thereof, of any other individual.
C. For any individual, while in the presence of any other individual in a massage establishment, to fail to conceal with a fully opaque covering, the sexual
or genital parts of his or her body.
D. For any individual owning, operating, or managing a massage establishment, knowingly to cause, allow or permit in or about such massage
establishment any agent, employee, or any other individual under his control or supervision to perform any such acts deemed to be unlawful by the
provisions in subsection A, B, or C of this section.
E. For any massage therapist, employee or operator to perform, offer to perform, or agree to perform any act which would require a touching of a patron's
genital or sexual area.
F. For any person who holds a license to operate a massage establishment within the village, or any employee of such establishment, to fail to comply with
any of the conditions and regulations set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 05-3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-14: INSPECTION OF ESTABLISHMENTS:
Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the operation of a licensed massage establishment are provided for or required by
this chapter, or any ordinance of the village, or are reasonably necessary to assure compliance with the provisions of any ordinance or regulation of the
village, or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee or the person in charge of the premises to admit thereto for the purpose of making
the inspection any officer or employee of the village who is duly authorized to make such inspection at any reasonable time that such admission or entry is
requested. Each such inspection shall be made at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to allow such
inspection officer access to the premises or to hinder such officer in any manner. (Ord. 05-3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-15: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
A. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply and no license shall be required for any units of government, hospitals, nursing homes, and sanatoriums
or for any individual while engaged in the personal performance of their respective professions, provided such individual is holding a current, valid (i.e.,
not suspended or revoked) license or certificate to practice certain of the healing arts under the laws of the state of Illinois (i.e., physicians, surgeons,
dentists, chiropractors, naprapaths, osteopaths, physical therapists, nurses, and athletic trainer licensees who administer athletic related massages in
the normal course of training duties and who are registered with the state of Illinois) ("a licensed professional in the healing arts") or to any massage
therapist(s) holding a current, valid massage therapy license from the state of Illinois working under the direction of any such licensed professional in
the healing arts if such licensed professional in the healing arts executes and files with the village an affidavit stating that the person(s) employed by
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 151/522
them to provide massage therapy on their premises are and will remain duly licensed by the state of Illinois as a massage therapist and will work only
under the direct supervision of such a licensed professional in the healing arts and only while such a licensed professional in the healing arts is and
remains present on the premises. (Ord. 15-3839, 6-8-2015)
B. No license shall be required for any barber, beautician or cosmetologist lawfully carrying on their respective businesses to the extent authorized under a
valid unrevoked license or certificate of registration issued by the state. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this exemption is only intended to permit normal
and customary barber, beautician or cosmetologist services which involve incidental physical contact, such as hair, scalp and neck rubs and facials,
which would otherwise qualify as a massage. This exemption is not intended to, and does not permit massage activities as part of any barber,
beautician or cosmetologist business beyond that authorized by their respective state license or certification. (Ord. 05-3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-16: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE:
A. Suspension Of License:
1. Procedures: Any license issued for a massage establishment may be suspended for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days by the village manager
upon written notice to the license holder, which notice shall state a basis or charge. The notice shall be served by mailing a copy thereof by regular
U.S. mail, addressed to the licensee at the address of the licensed premises, and shall be deemed served on the date of mailing (the "service date")
and by delivering a copy of the notice to the manager of the licensed premises or to any other employee on the licensed premises. The license
holder may request in writing a hearing before the village manager within ten (10) days of the service date. If a written request for a hearing is not
made within ten (10) days of the service date, the village manager may suspend any license for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days for any of the
reasons hereinafter set forth in the provision of this subsection. Upon receiving a timely written request therefor, the village manager shall conduct
the hearing and may suspend a license for a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days if any of the provisions of this chapter are violated or any
employee of the licensee is engaged in any conduct at licensee's place of business which violates any of the provisions of this chapter or any other
ordinances of the village relating to the license, the licensed premises, or any state law, or where any applicant has committed any fraud,
misrepresentation or made a false statement on an application for a license under this chapter, or in any case where the licensee refuses to permit
any duly authorized police officer or inspector of the village to inspect the premises or the operations therein, or the failure or refusal of the licensee
to pay any fine, penalty or charge owed to the village, or in the event that the licensee would not now qualify for the issuance of a license or the
renewal thereof. The licensee shall be deemed to have actual or constructive knowledge of any violations hereinabove set forth if they occur on the
licensed premises by any person acting as an agent or otherwise receiving compensation. Such license may also be suspended by the village
manager upon the recommendations of the health official that such business is being managed, conducted, or maintained without regard for the
public health or health of patrons or without due regard to proper sanitation or hygiene. The licensee shall be permitted to present any relevant
evidence bearing on the alleged violations set forth in this notice. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
2. Appeals: Any decision of the village manager to suspend a license may be appealed to the village president within ten (10) days of the issuance by
the village manager of any order of suspension. The village president shall review the record of the hearing held before the village manager, if any
was held, or if no hearing was held, the basis for such order of suspension, and based upon such review, shall make a decision to either affirm or
reverse the decision of the village manager to suspend the license. If the village president decides to affirm the decision to suspend the license, he
may also modify the term of the suspension; provided that in no event shall the suspension exceed thirty (30) days. Any suspension ordered by the
provisions hereof shall be stayed until all administrative appeals made to officials of the village as provided herein (and not including any appeal of a
decision of a village official made to any court of competent jurisdiction) have been concluded. The decision of the village president shall be final and
subject to judicial review only by a court of competent jurisdiction to the extent otherwise provided by law.
B. Revocation Of License:
1. Procedures: Any license issued for a massage establishment may be revoked by the village manager for any of the reasons set forth in subsection A
of this section upon written notice to the license holder, which notice shall state a basis or charge. The notice shall be served by mailing a copy
thereof by regular U.S. mail, addressed to the licensee at the address of the licensed premises and shall be deemed served on the date of mailing
(the "service date") and by delivering a copy of the notice to the manager of the licensed premises or to any other employee on the licensed
premises. Within ten (10) days of the service date, the licensee may request a hearing before the village manager. If a written request for a hearing is
not made within ten (10) days of the service date, the village manager shall determine whether or not to revoke any license as hereinafter provided.
Upon receiving a timely request made therefor, the village manager shall conduct a hearing. The licensee shall be permitted to present any relevant
evidence bearing on the alleged violations set forth in the notice. After the hearing, the village manager shall render a decision whether or not to
revoke the license holder's license.
2. Reasons For Revocation: The village manager may revoke a license for any of the reasons set forth in subsection A of this section and shall revoke
a license if he determines that any one or more of the following have occurred:
a. A licensee has violated or is not in compliance with the provisions of this chapter and the license has been suspended within the preceding twenty
four (24) months.
b. A licensee has knowingly allowed prostitution on the premises.
c. A licensee knowingly conducted massage activities in the village during a period of time when the licensee's license was suspended.
d. On two (2) or more occasions within a twenty four (24) month period, a person committed a violation of the provisions of this chapter which
substantially occurred in or on a licensed premises, and the person was an employee of the licensee at the time the violations were committed.
e. A licensee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation, bestiality, prostitution, or flagellation to
occur in or on the licensed premises.
f. There is no licensed massage therapist employed by the licensee or otherwise engaged or committed to provide massage services on the licensed
premises.
g. A licensee does not now qualify for the issuance of a license or the renewal thereof.
3. Appeals: Any decision of the village manager to revoke a license may be appealed to the village president by the licensee by a request in writing
therefor made to the village president within ten (10) days of the issuance by the village manager of any order to revoke a license. The village
president shall review the record of the hearing held before the village manager, if any was held, or if no hearing was held, the basis for such order to
revoke, and based upon such review, shall make a decision to either affirm or reverse the decision of the village manager to revoke the license. Any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 152/522
order to revoke a license shall be stayed until all administrative appeals made to officials of the village as provided herein (and not including any
appeal of a decision of a village official made to any court of competent jurisdiction) have been concluded. The decision of the village president shall
be final and subject to judicial review only by a court of competent jurisdiction to the extent otherwise provided by law.
4. Period Of Revocation: Any licensee whose license has been revoked is barred from applying for a new license for a minimum period of one year
from the date of revocation.
C. Other Penalties Applicable: Any suspension or revocation of the license, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of any other penalties
provided for the violation of other applicable provisions of this chapter or other ordinances of the village. (Ord. 05-3213, 2-14-2005)
3-5-17: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Public Nuisance: Any location used as a massage establishment in violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
B. Misdemeanor; Penalties: Every person, except those persons who are specifically exempted by this chapter, whether acting as an individual owner,
employee of the owner, operator or employee of the operator, or whether acting as a mere agent or independent contractor for the owner, employee or
operator, or acting as a participant or worker in any way directly or indirectly who gives massages or operates a massage establishment or provides
any of the services defined in this chapter without first obtaining a license and paying a fee to do so from the village or who violates any provision of
this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon a finding of guilty, such person shall be punished by a fine as specified from time to time in
section 1-14-1 of this code or by imprisonment for a period which shall not exceed six (6) months or by both such fine and imprisonment. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or upon which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
Chapter 6
FOOD AND BEVERAGES
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
3-6A-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish regulations relative to the operation of food service establishments, including, but not limited to, food dealers,
food service establishments, and temporary food establishments, outdoor cafes, retail food stores, and mobile food vendors; to regulate the inspection of
such establishments and/or operations; to provide for compliance procedures; to provide for the incorporation by reference of the current edition of the
Illinois department of public health publication titled, "food service sanitation code" (77 Ill. adm. code 750), that is on file with the office of Illinois secretary
of state; to provide for the incorporation by reference of the current edition of the Illinois department of public health publication titled, "retail food store
sanitation code" (77 Ill. adm. code 760), that is on file with the office of Illinois secretary of state; and to provide for the enforcement of this chapter,
including the filing of actions for injunctive relief, and to fix penalties for violations hereof. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
ADULTERATED FOOD: A food is adulterated:
A. If it bears or contains any poisonous or deleterious substance which may be injurious to health.
B. If it bears or contains any added poisonous or deleterious substance for which no safe tolerance has been established by regulation, or in excess of
such tolerance if one has been established.
C. If it consists in whole or in part of any filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance, or if it is otherwise unfit for human consumption.
D. If it has been prepared, packed or stored under unsanitary conditions whereby it may have become contaminated with filth, or rendered injurious to
health.
E. If the container is composed of, in whole or in part, a poisonous or deleterious substance which may render the contents injurious to health.
APPROVED: Approved by the health official.
BEVERAGE: A liquid for drinking, including water.
CART: See definition of Pushcart.
EMPLOYEE: Any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving, or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils, or who is
working, either voluntarily or for pay, in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served.
EQUIPMENT: Items other than utensils used in the storage, preparation, display, and transportation of food, such as stoves, ovens, hoods, slicers,
grinders, mixers, scales, meat blocks, tables, food shelving, reach in refrigerators and freezers, sinks, ice makers, and similar items used in the operation
of a retail food store. This item does not include forklift trucks or dollies.
FOOD: Any raw, cooked, or processed edible substance, ice, beverage or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale in whole or in part for human
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 153/522
consumption.
FOOD DEALER: Every person engaged in conducting or operating any of the following businesses: Any establishment for the sale of food, and/or
nonalcoholic beverages at retail for human consumption, other than a food service establishment, including, but not limited to, the sale of any food or
beverage by means of a vending machine or by mobile food vendor.
FOOD ESTABLISHMENT: A food dealer or a food service establishment.
FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT: Any place where food is prepared and intended for consumption by persons, though not limited to, preparation, sale
and/or consumption of individual portions service, and includes the site and/or premises at which individual portions are provided and also includes, but is
not limited to, mobile food vendors. This term includes any such food service establishment regardless of whether consumption is on or off the premises
and regardless of whether there is a charge for the food. The term also includes delicatessen type operations that prepare foods intended for individual
portion service. The term does not include lodging facilities serving only a continental breakfast (a continental breakfast is one limited to only coffee, tea,
and/or juice and commercially prepared sweet baked goods), private homes or a closed family function where food is prepared or served for individual
family consumption, retail food stores or the location of food vending machines. A restaurant is a type of food service establishment.
HEALTH OFFICIAL: That person so appointed by the village manager, pursuant to section 4-1A-1 of this code, and any person so appointed pursuant to
the terms of any intergovernmental agreement pertaining to the regulation of restaurants, which may be entered into by the village of Barrington.
ICE CREAM VENDOR: A mobile food vendor which sells, as part of its operations, ice cream, frozen yogurt, and/or other frozen confectionery as food.
LICENSED AREA: The area in which an outdoor cafe is permitted to operate pursuant to the issuance of a special license therefor. The "licensed area"
shall consist of property which is adjacent to and abuts the property used as a food service establishment. The "licensed area" shall be designated in a site
plan submitted with the application.
LICENSEE: The person to whom a permit, license, or certificate is issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
MOBILE FOOD VENDOR: A food service establishment or food dealer designed to be readily movable, including, but not limited to, by use of a vehicle,
pushcart, or similar equipment, or by use of a pack, tray, or any similar method of delivery transported by a person or animal.
OUTDOOR CAFE: That portion of a food service establishment where the customers are seated other than within a wholly enclosed building.
PACKAGED: Bottled, canned, cartoned, or securely wrapped. The term "packaged" does not include a wrapper, carryout box, or other nondurable
container used to containerize food for the purpose of facilitating food protection during service and receipt of the food by the consumer.
PERMITTED TIMES OF OPERATION: The time in which a food establishment, including, but not limited to, a temporary food establishment, a mobile food
vendor and/or an outdoor cafe may conduct its business, provided, however, the setup for the conduct of the business and the shutdown of the conduct of
the business may respectively commence fifteen (15) minutes before and after the permitted times of operation set forth in this chapter. Notwithstanding
the foregoing to the contrary, with respect solely to any portion of a food establishment that operates on any portion of a public right of way, setup for the
conduct of the business and shutdown for the conduct of the business on any such portion of the public right of way may only respectively commence and
continue for fifteen (15) minutes before and after the actual time of the conduct of the business if the conduct of the business commences at such times
which are after the earliest permitted commencement time and/or shutdown occurs before the latest permitted termination time.
PERSON: A natural person, firm, club, corporation, association, partnership, company, organization, or political subdivision.
POTENTIALLY HAZARDOUS FOOD: Any food that consists in whole or in part of milk or milk products, eggs, meat, poultry, fish, shellfish, edible
crustacea, or other ingredients, including synthetic ingredients, and which is in a form capable of supporting rapid and progressive growth of infectious or
toxigenic microorganisms. The term does not include foods that have a pH level of 4.6 or below or a water activity (a(w)) value of 0.85 or less under
standard conditions; food products in hermetically sealed containers processed to prevent spoilage.
PUSHCART: A vehicle propelled by human power limited to serving nonpotentially hazardous foods or commissary wrapped food maintained at proper
temperatures.
READILY PERISHABLE FOODS: Any food or beverage or ingredients consisting, in whole or in part, of milk, milk products, eggs, meat, fish, poultry, or
other food, in a state capable of supporting rapid and progressive growth of microorganisms which can cause food infection or poisoning.
REGULATORY AUTHORITY: The state, county and/or village enforcement authority or authorities having responsibility for enforcing this chapter and/or
title.
RETAIL FOOD ESTABLISHMENT: A food service establishment or a retail food store.
RETAIL FOOD STORE: Any food establishment or section of a food establishment where food and food products are offered to the consumer and
intended for, though not limited to, off premises consumption. The term includes delicatessens that offer prepared food in bulk quantities only. The term
does not include establishments which handle only prepackaged spirits; roadside markets that offer only fresh fruits and fresh vegetables for sale; food
service establishments; or food and beverage vending machines.
TEMPORARY FOOD ESTABLISHMENT: A temporary retail food store (also referred to herein as a "temporary food dealer" or as a "temporary food
establishment").
TEMPORARY FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT: A food service establishment that operates at a fixed location for a period of time of not more than
fourteen (14) consecutive days in conjunction with a single event or celebration.
TEMPORARY RETAIL FOOD STORE: A retail food store (also known as a "temporary food dealer") that operates at a fixed location for a period of time of
not more than fourteen (14) consecutive days in conjunction with a single event or celebration. The term does not include establishments that handle only
fresh fruits and fresh vegetables, or temporary food service establishments.
UNWHOLESOME FOOD: Food that is adulterated or otherwise unfit for human consumption.
UTENSIL: Any food contact implement used in the storage, preparation, transportation, or dispensing of food.
VILLAGE: The village of Barrington, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois, a municipal corporation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 154/522
WHOLESOME FOOD: Food that is safe for human consumption and free from adulteration. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-2: REGULATION OF FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS; REGULATING BODIES:
A. Areas Regulated By Village: The issuance, suspension, and revocation of permits, licenses, or certificates to operate retail food establishments; the
prohibiting of the sale of unsound or mislabeled food or drink; and the enforcement of this chapter shall be regulated in accordance with this chapter
concerning the compliance procedures.
B. Inspections Regulated By Sanitation Codes:
1. The inspection of food service establishments shall be regulated in accordance with the current edition of the Illinois department of public health
publication titled, "food service sanitation code" (77 Ill. adm. code 750), that is on file with the secretary of state, which food service sanitation code is
hereby incorporated by reference and thereby made a part hereof.
2. The inspection of retail food stores shall be regulated in accordance with the current edition of the Illinois department of public health publication
titled, "retail food store sanitation code" (77 Ill. adm. code 760), that is on file with the secretary of state, which retail food store sanitation code is
hereby incorporated by reference and thereby made a part hereof.
3. Three (3) copies of each of the Illinois department of public health's publications titled, "food service sanitation code", and "retail food store sanitation
code", as aforesaid have been on file at the office of the village clerk for use and examination by the public for not less than thirty (30) days prior to
the adoption of this chapter. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-3: PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate a food establishment, including, but not limited to, any mobile food vendor, or any temporary food establishment, who does not
have a valid permit, license and/or certificate of registration issued to him by the health official. Only a person who complies with the requirements of this
chapter shall be entitled to receive or retain such a permit, license, and/or certificate. The license year for all food establishments shall be from July 1 to
June 30, inclusive. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE; ISSUANCE:
A. Application For Permit, License Or Certificate: Any person desiring to operate a food establishment shall make written application for a permit, license,
and/or certificate on forms provided by the health official. Such application shall include the name and address of each applicant, the location and type
of the proposed food establishment, and the signature of each applicant.
B. Inspection Of Premises: Prior to approval of an application for a permit, license, and/or certificate, the health official and/or the applicable county health
department shall inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
C. Issuance Upon Compliance: The health official shall issue a permit, license, and/or certificate to the applicant if the inspection described above reveals
that the proposed food establishment complies with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-5: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE; POSTING REQUIRED:
Permits, licenses, or certificates are not transferable. A valid permit, license, and/or certificate shall be posted in a location visible to the public in every
food establishment. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-6: CONDITIONAL PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE:
When structural, plumbing, electrical, ventilation, or similar such defects are identified and/or exist in an established food establishment that may require
significant expenditures to correct, but are not considered to be imminent health hazards, a conditional permit, license, and/or certificate for the food
establishment to continue to operate may be granted at the discretion of the village's health official in order to permit the food establishment to diligently
pursue remediation of any such defect and/or violation of this code within an agreed upon period of time. Under no circumstances will a conditional permit,
license, or certificate for the food establishment to continue to operate be issued for more than two (2) consecutive twelve (12) month periods. The
purpose of the conditional license, permit, and/or certificate is to permit the food establishment a reasonable period of time for correction of any identified
defects and/or village code violations in order to bring the subject property into compliance with this code. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-7: INSPECTIONS:
A. Frequency Of Inspection: An inspection of a food establishment shall be performed at a frequency prescribed by the health official or by the applicable
county health department. Additional inspections of the food establishment may be performed as often as necessary for the enforcement of this
chapter.
B. Right Of Access: Duly authorized representatives of the health official and/or the applicable county health department, after proper identification, shall
be permitted to enter any food establishment at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this chapter.
Such representatives shall be permitted to examine the records of the food establishment to obtain information pertaining to food and supplies
purchased, received, or used.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 155/522
C. Report Of Inspections: Whenever an inspection of a food establishment is made, the findings shall be recorded on the inspection report form on file in
the office of the village clerk. The inspection report form shall summarize the requirements of this chapter and shall set forth a weighted point value for
each requirement. Inspection remarks should be written to reference, by item number, the item violated and should state the correction to be made.
The rating score of the food establishment shall be the total of the weighted point values for all violations, subtracted from one hundred (100). A copy of
the completed inspection report form shall be furnished to the person in charge of the food establishment at the conclusion of the inspection. The
completed inspection report form shall be a public document that shall be made available for public disclosure to any person who requests it according
to law. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-8: CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS:
A. The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of the violations found; and correction of the violations
shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance with the following provisions:
1. If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of refrigeration or sewage backup into the food establishment, the establishment shall
immediately cease food operations. Operations shall not be resumed until authorized by the applicable county health department and the health
official.
2. All violations of four (4) or five (5) point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, within ten (10) days following
inspection. A follow up inspection to confirm correction may be conducted at the discretion of the applicable county health department and/or the
health official.
3. All one or two (2) point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, by the time of the next routine inspection.
4. When the inspection rating score of the food establishment is less than sixty (60), the establishment shall initiate corrective action on all identified
violations within forty eight (48) hours. One or more reinspections may be conducted at reasonable time intervals to assure correction.
5. In the case of temporary food establishments and/or mobile food vendors, all violations shall be corrected within twenty four (24) hours. If violations
are not corrected within twenty four (24) hours, the food establishment shall immediately cease food operations until authorized to resume by the
applicable county health department and the health official.
B. The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any time limits for corrections may result in cessation of food operations. An opportunity for
hearing before the village manager on the inspection findings or the time limitations or both will be provided if a written request is filed with the health
official within ten (10) days following cessation of operations. If a request for hearing is received, a hearing shall be held within twenty one (21) days of
receipt of the request.
C. Whenever a food establishment is required under any of the provisions of this chapter to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is
shown on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease operations no longer exist. An opportunity for reinspection shall be offered
within a reasonable time. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-9: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF FOOD:
A. Authority: Food may be examined or sampled by the applicable county health department and/or the health official as often as necessary for
enforcement of this chapter.
B. Hold Order:
1. The applicable county health department or the health official may, upon written notice to the owner or person in charge, specifying with particularity
the reasons therefor, place a hold order on any food which it believes is in violation of section 750.100, 750.110, 760.100, or 760.110 of the Illinois
department of public health's "food service sanitation code", or the "retail food store sanitation code", respectively, or any other section of this
chapter.
2. The applicable county health department and/or the health official shall tag, label, or otherwise identify any food subject to the hold order.
3. No food subject to a hold order shall be used, served, or moved from the food establishment. The applicable county health department or the health
official may permit storage of the food under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health, in
which case, immediate destruction of such food shall be ordered and accomplished.
4. The hold order shall state that a request for hearing may be filed within ten (10) days and that if no hearing is requested, the food shall be destroyed.
C. Hearing; Decisions: If a request for hearing is received, the hearing shall be held by the village manager, or his or her designee within twenty one (21)
days after receipt of the request. On the basis of evidence produced at that hearing, the hold order may be vacated, or the owner or person in charge
of the food may be directed by written order to denature or destroy such food or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 12-
3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-10: BUILDING CONSTRUCTION PLANS:
A. Plans And Specifications Required: Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled and whenever an existing structure is
converted to use as a food establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling, or conversion shall be
submitted to the health official, to the applicable county health department, to the village's development services department, and to the village
manager, or his or her designee, for review and approval before construction, remodeling, or conversion is begun. The plans and specifications shall
indicate the proposed layout, arrangement, mechanical plans, and construction materials of work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed
equipment and facilities. The health official and the applicable health department shall approve the plans and specifications if they meet the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 156/522
requirements of this chapter, but such approval shall not relieve the applicant from complying with all other applicable provisions of this code. No food
establishment shall be constructed, extensively remodeled, or converted except in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the health
official, the applicable county health department, and the village manager, or his or her designee. All submittals to the village's development services
department as required by this code shall comply with the village's digital data standards set forth in title 1, chapter 16, "Digital Data Standards", of this
code. The applicant is required to apply to the village for any required permits and/or approvals and pay to the village any fees and/or deposits as set
forth from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code prior to the commencement of any construction. (Ord. 15-3837, 6-8-2015)
B. Inspection Prior To Opening: Whenever plans and specifications are required by subsection A of this section to be submitted to the health official, the
applicable county health department, and the village manager, or his or her designee, the health official, the applicable county health department, and
the village manager, or his or her designee, may inspect the food establishment prior to the start of operations, to determine compliance with the
approved plans and specifications and with the requirements of this chapter and the other applicable provisions of this code. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-11: PROCEDURE WHEN INFECTION SUSPECTED:
When the applicable county health department and/or the village's health official has reasonable cause to suspect possible disease transmission by an
employee of a food establishment, it may secure a morbidity history of the suspected employee or make any other investigation as indicated and shall take
appropriate action. The applicable county health department and/or the village's health official may require any or all of the following measures:
A. The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in a food establishment.
B. The immediate closing of a food establishment until, in the opinion of the applicable county health department and the village's health official, no further
danger of disease outbreak exists.
C. Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the establishment where there would be no danger of transmitting disease.
D. Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee and of other employees and of his and their body discharges. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-12: FEES AND INSPECTION COSTS:
In addition to the requirements of this article, the permit, license or certificate required by sections 3-6A-3 and 3-6A-4 of this article shall be subject to all of
the provisions and the payment of all applicable fees and costs set forth in this chapter, including, but not limited to, payment of all of the applicable fees,
costs, and deposits set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code. Applicants and holders of permits, licenses and/or certificates required by the provisions of this
chapter shall bear the cost of any and all reinspections required by this code, at the rates set forth in this chapter, including, but not limited to, payment of
all of the applicable fees, costs, and deposits set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-13: SUSPENSION OF PERMIT, LICENSE AND/OR CERTIFICATE:
A. Summary Suspension: The health official may, without warning, notice, or hearing, suspend any permit, license, and/or certificate to operate a food
establishment if the holder of the permit, license, and/or certificate does not comply with the requirements of this chapter or does not comply with any
other applicable provisions of this code, or if the operation of the food establishment does not comply with the requirements of this chapter or does not
comply with any of the applicable provisions of this code, or if the operation of the food establishment otherwise constitutes a substantial hazard to
public health. Such suspension shall be effective upon service of the notice required by subsection B of this section. When a permit, license, and/or
certificate is suspended, the respective food establishment shall immediately cease all food operations. Whenever a permit, license, and/or certificate is
suspended, the holder of the permit, license, and/or certificate shall be afforded an opportunity for hearing before the village manager, or his or her
designee, within twenty one (21) days of receipt of a request for hearing.
B. Notice Of Suspension; Right To Hearing; Time Limit: Whenever a permit, license, or certificate is suspended, the holder of the permit, license, and/or
certificate, or the person in charge shall be notified in writing by the health official or the applicable county health department that the permit, license,
and/or certificate is, upon service of the notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity for hearing before the village manager, or his or her
designee, will be provided if a written request for hearing is filed with the health official by the holder of the permit, license, and/or certificate within ten
(10) days. If no written request for hearing is filed within ten (10) days, the suspension shall be considered sustained by the village manager and in full
force and effect.
C. Termination Of Suspension: The health official may end the suspension at any time if reasons for suspension no longer exist. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-14: REVOCATION OF PERMIT, LICENSE AND/OR CERTIFICATE:
A. Authority: The health official may, after providing to the respective holder of the permit, license, and/or certificate, opportunity for a hearing before the
village manager, or his or her designee, revoke the permit, license, and/or certificate for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this
chapter, or any applicable provisions of this code, or for the interference with the representatives of the village, the health official, or the applicable
county health department in the performance of their respective duties, including inspection of the respective premises of operation.
B. Notice Of Revocation; Right To Hearing; Time Limit: Prior to revocation, the health official, or his or her designee, shall notify, in writing, the holder of the
permit, license, or certificate, or the person in charge of the premises, of the specific reasons for which the permit, license, or certificate is to be
revoked and that the permit, license, and/or certificate shall be revoked at the end of the ten (10) days following service of such notice unless a written
request for hearing before the village manager, or his or her designee, is filed with the health official by the holder of the permit, license, and/or
certificate within such ten (10) day period. If no request for hearing is filed within the ten (10) day period, the revocation of the permit, license, and/or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 157/522
certificate shall become final. If a request for hearing is received, a hearing before the village manager, or his or her designee, shall be held within
twenty one (21) days of receipt of the request. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-15: SERVICE OF NOTICES:
A notice provided for in this chapter is properly served when it is delivered to the holder of the permit, license, and/or certificate, or the person in charge, or
when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the holder of the permit, license, or certificate. A copy
of the notice shall be filed in the records of the health official. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-16: HEARINGS:
The hearings provided for in this chapter shall be conducted by the village manager at a time and place designated by the village manager, or his or her
designee. Any oral testimony given at a hearing shall be reported verbatim, and the village manager, or his or her designee, shall make provision for
sufficient copies of the transcript for all parties. The village manager, or his or her designee, shall make a final finding based upon the complete hearing
record and shall sustain, modify, or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing decision shall be furnished to the
holder of the permit, license, and/or certificate by the village manager, or his or her designee. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-17: APPLICATION AFTER REVOCATION:
Whenever the revocation of any permit, license, or certificate has become final, the holder of the revoked permit, license, and/or certificate may make
written application for a new permit, license, or certificate. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6A-18: PENALTY; INJUNCTIVE RELIEF:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation continues. The village shall have the right to seek and obtain an injunction against any person or
establishment in the event violations occur or are likely to occur on a continuing basis without such relief. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
ARTICLE B. FOOD DEALERS
3-6B-1: INTERPRETATION:
The provisions of this article shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals, comfort and general
welfare. It is not intended by this article or by this chapter to interfere with, abrogate, annul or repeal any ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation heretofore
adopted which does not conflict with the provisions of this article or chapter. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-2: SCOPE:
Nothing in this article shall be deemed to limit the other provisions of this chapter applicable to food establishments, including, but not limited to, those
provisions applicable to food establishments and mobile food vendors as defined therein, and in the retail food store sanitation code and the food service
sanitation code adopted by reference in this chapter. It is the express intention of the village that the licensing provisions set forth in this article apply to
food dealers in addition to those included in the definitions set forth in the aforesaid sanitation codes adopted by reference in this chapter. (Ord. 12-3693,
6-25-2012)
3-6B-3: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEES:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or conduct business in the village without having first secured a food
establishment license therefor.
B. Application For License; Fees: Applications by any food dealer, including any mobile food vendor or temporary retail food store, for a food establishment
license shall be made in compliance with the village ordinance provisions relating thereto, and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or
handled. In order to obtain any permit, license and/or certificate required by the provisions of this article or the other provisions of this chapter, the
applicant for such permit, license or certificate shall pay to the village clerk (or in the case of applicants regulated under article A of this chapter, to the
health department of the inspecting county, as appropriate) the actual cost of the minimum number of required inspections, all as specified from time to
time in section 1-14-1 of this code. In addition, the applicant shall pay application fee(s), license fee(s) and administrative fee(s) to the village clerk as
specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. If the inspection is performed by the health official of the village, the inspection cost shall be
an amount equal to the amount that would have been charged by the county in which the premises upon which the food establishment is located as if
the county had performed the inspection in addition to the administrative fee(s) as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each
inspection.
C. Reinspection Fees: In the event that a reinspection is deemed necessary in either county by the applicable county health department and/or by the
health official of the village, the payment of reinspection fees shall be a condition of issuance or continuance of the permit, license and/or certificate
required. The cost of any and all reinspections shall be paid by the applicant or holder of the permit, license and/or certificate. For each reinspection
required, the applicant or holder of the permit, license and/or certificate shall pay to the village clerk the amount as specified from time to time in section
1-14-1 of this code, plus an administrative fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each reinspection. If the reinspection is
performed by the health official of the village, the applicant or holder of the permit, license or certificate shall pay to the village clerk an amount equal to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 158/522
the amount that would have been charged by the county in which the premises upon which the food establishment is located as if the county had
performed the reinspection in addition to the administrative fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each reinspection. (Ord.
12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
All applications for a license to conduct a business connected with the storage, handling, sale or preparation of food or drink intended for human
consumption shall be referred to the health official who shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the premises to be used, and he shall report his
findings thereon, recommending or advising against the issuance of the license. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-5: LICENSE YEAR:
The license year or term for any food establishment's permit, license, and/or certificate, including, but not limited to, those of any food dealer or of any
temporary retail food store, shall begin on July 1 of each year and end on June 30 of the following year. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-6: REDUCED FEE FOR INCIDENTAL VENDING MACHINES:
Where food or beverages are served through a vending machine in connection with an establishment whose main business is not the sale of food or
beverages, the license fee for selling food or beverages through such machine shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for not
more than three (3) such machines maintained on the premises, and as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each additional
machine over three (3), in lieu of the annual license fee for other food dealers. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-7: CONDUCTING ANOTHER BUSINESS ON PREMISES:
Any person licensed to sell any of the foods or beverages for the sale of which a license is required by the terms of this article or chapter may conduct on
the same premises and in connection with the licensed business any other business mentioned in this article or chapter without paying any additional fee
therefor; provided, that the fee paid for the licensed business is at least as great in amount as the fee required for the other business so conducted; but
this section shall not be so construed as to relieve any such applicant from the regulatory requirements of such other business. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-8: ADULTERATED FOOD:
A. No person shall offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human consumption which is
adulterated and unfit for human consumption, for any reason.
B. All adulterated food intended for human consumption may be condemned by the health official, and shall thereupon be seized and destroyed by the
health official or any police officer.
C. It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, or keep for such purpose, any food or drink intended for human consumption which has been adulterated by
any material harmful in any way, or which does not comply with the statutes governing the same. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-9: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
A. Clean Premises Generally: Premises used for the sale or storage of food intended for human consumption must be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition. It shall be unlawful to permit any accumulation of refuse or waste of any kind to remain thereon for more than twenty four (24) hours, and it
shall be unlawful to permit any decaying animal or plant material to remain on such premises.
B. Flies And Vermin: Premises used for the storage, preparation or sale of food intended for human consumption shall be kept free from flies, vermin and
rodents.
C. Utensils: Utensils for personal use in all places serving food or drink to the public shall be thoroughly cleaned and sterilized after each such usage.
D. Employees:
1. All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food intended for sale for human consumption shall keep themselves clean both as to
person and clothing.
2. It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with, or a carrier of, any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in the care or
preparation of any such food, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored,
prepared or sold, or to deliver such food. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-10: ENFORCEMENT; INSPECTIONS:
A. Enforcement Officer: The village's health official, as identified in section 4-1A-1 of this code, is charged with the enforcement of the provisions of this
article and of this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 159/522
B. Entry Powers:
1. The health official may at all reasonable times inspect any food establishment, including, but not limited to, any food dealer, or any place or operation
suspected of conducting any of such businesses to determine compliance with this article and/or chapter.
2. The person operating any business governed by this article and/or by this chapter shall, upon request of the health official, permit access to all parts
of the establishment and shall furnish a list of suppliers of food.
C. Regular Inspections: Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the health official shall, at least once every six (6) months, inspect every food
establishment, including, but not limited to, any food dealer(s) or any place or operation suspected of conducting any of such businesses located within
the village.
D. Reinspections; Suspension Of Permit, License Or Certificate; Fees:
1. In case the health official discovers the violation of this article and/or of this chapter or any other violation of this code, he or she shall make a
reinspection after the lapse of such time as he or she deems reasonably necessary for the violation to be remedied, in order to determine compliance
with the requirements of this article and/or of this chapter and/or with the other relevant provisions of this code.
2. If such violation or a violation of the same type still exists at the time of such reinspection, the health official shall be authorized to immediately
suspend the permit, license or certificate for such premises.
3. Whenever a reinspection of the premises of any business governed by this article and/or this chapter is necessitated by the discovery of or
continued presence of any violation of this article and/or of this chapter, the applicant or holder of the permit, license and/or certificate shall pay the
applicable reinspection fee(s) and administrative fee(s) in the amounts set forth in this article and/or this chapter, whichever is applicable. No such
permit, license and/or certificate shall be issued or reinstated until all such inspection fees have been paid.
E. Inspection Report Posted And On File: One copy of each inspection report shall be posted by the health official upon an inside wall of the premises
inspected, and said inspection report shall not be defaced or removed by any person except the health official. Another copy of the inspection report
shall be filed with the records of the village's health department. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-11: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The village health official, with the approval of the village manager or his or her designee, is authorized to adopt reasonable rules and regulations as may
be necessary for the proper enforcement and interpretation of the provisions of this article and/or of this chapter in order to protect the health of the people
of the village. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6B-12: REVOCATION OF PERMITS, LICENSES, AND/OR CERTIFICATES:
Any permit, license, and/or certificate of any food establishment, including any permit, license, and/or certificate of any food dealer(s) or of any temporary
retail food store, may be revoked by the village manager or his or her designee, for repeated violation of the provisions of this chapter, or for any violations
of any other provisions of this code related to the conduct and/or condition of the premises, the articles sold, or related to the permit, license, and/or
certificate required. Due process regarding said revocation is as provided in sections 3-6A-14, 3-6A-15 and 3-6A-16 of this chapter. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-
2012)
ARTICLE C. FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS
3-6C-1: RESERVED:
(Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6C-2: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS; INSPECTIONS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any food service establishment, including, but not limited to, any temporary food
establishment, in the village without having first secured a current and valid food establishment license therefor. A valid license is one that is current
and is not suspended, revoked or expired.
B. Application For License: Applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with the applicable provisions of this code relating thereto, on forms
provided by the village, and shall state the nature of the food service establishment business the applicant intends to operate, including the kind of food
intended to be sold or handled.
C. Issuance Of License; Posting And Filing Required; Contents: If, upon examination, the premises and the equipment therein are found to be in
accordance with the requirements of this chapter and the sanitation codes adopted by reference in section 3-6A-2 of this chapter, as applicable, a food
establishment license shall be issued to the applicant. The license shall state the type of food service establishment for which it is issued and shall be
posted in a place conspicuous to the patrons.
D. Fees:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 160/522
1. In order to obtain the license required by the provisions of this article and/or by the provisions of this chapter, the applicant for such license shall pay
to the village clerk (or in the case of applicants regulated under article A of this chapter, to the health department of the inspecting county, as
appropriate) the actual cost of the minimum number of required inspections based on the schedule of fees and of inspections adopted by the
appropriate county or the village as the case may be. In addition, the applicant shall pay applicable application fee(s), license fee(s), and
administrative fee(s) to the village clerk as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. If the inspection is performed by the health
official of the village, the inspection cost shall be an amount equal to the amount that would have been charged by the county in which the premises
upon which the applicant's food service establishment is located as if the county had performed the inspection in addition to the administrative fee(s)
as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. The license year shall be from July 1 to June 30 inclusive, and all license fees payable
hereunder are due on July 1 annually. New establishments opening after July 1 of any year shall pay a fee for the entire year.
2. In the event that a reinspection is deemed necessary in either county by the applicable county health department and/or by the health official of the
village, the payment of reinspection fees shall be a condition of issuance or continuance of the license required. The cost of any and all reinspections
shall be paid by the applicant or holder of the license. For each reinspection required, the applicant or holder of the license shall pay to the village
clerk the amount charged by the appropriate county health department according to the schedule of fees established by that department, plus an
administrative fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. If the reinspection is performed by the health official of the village, the
applicant or holder of the license shall pay to the village clerk an amount equal to the amount that would have been charged by the county in which
the premises upon which the applicant's restaurant is located, as if the county had performed the reinspection, in addition to the administrative fee as
specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each reinspection.
E. Temporary Food Establishments:
1. License Year: The license year for a temporary food establishment shall begin on July 1 of each year and end on June 30 of the following year, and
the annual license fee(s) shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. The license shall state "Temporary Food
Establishment" and the period of time for which it is valid. The license shall be issued to the person named in the application and shall not be
transferable.
2. Location Restricted: Temporary food establishments are only permitted in conjunction with a special event authorized pursuant to a current and valid
special event permit issued pursuant to this code.
F. Suspension Of License: The health official of the village may suspend any license authorized by this article upon violation by the holder of any of the
provisions of this article and/or of this chapter including, but not limited to, the food service sanitation code adopted by reference in section 3-6A-2 of
this chapter.
G. Revocation Of License: The health official of the village may revoke any such license, after an opportunity for a hearing before him upon finding that the
food service establishment or temporary food establishment for which such permit was issued is in violation of any of the provisions of this article
and/or of this chapter and the food service sanitation code adopted by reference therein. With respect to any violations of this chapter and the food
