service sanitation code adopted by reference therein, the revocation shall proceed according to the procedures specified in section 3-6A-14 of this
chapter.
H. Reinstatement Of License: The holder of a license for food establishment, including, but not limited to, any food service establishment or temporary
food establishment, which has been suspended, may at any time make application for the reinstatement of such license. Within one week after the
receipt of a statement signed by the person to whom the license was issued, to the effect that the violated provisions of this article and/or of this
chapter have been conformed with, the health official shall make a reinspection, and in the case that the findings indicate compliance, he or she shall
reinstate the license. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6C-3: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF ADULTERATED FOOD OR BEVERAGE:
Samples of food and drink and other substances may be taken and examined by the health official as often as may be necessary for the detection of
adulteration. The health official may condemn and forbid the sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink which is adulterated. (Ord. 12-
3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6C-4: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. All Food Service Establishments: All food service establishments, including, but not limited to, mobile food vendors or temporary food establishments,
shall fully comply with the sanitation codes, adopted by reference in this chapter.
B. Temporary Food Establishments And Mobile Food Vendors: The health official shall approve an inspection of temporary food establishments or a
mobile food vendor only if it complies with the following sanitation requirements:
1. Clean Premises Generally: It shall be located in clean surroundings and kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
2. Construction Generally: It shall be so constructed, equipped, and arranged that food and drink, utensils, and equipment will not be unduly exposed to
insects or to dust or other contamination.
3. Quality Of Food And Beverage: Only food and drink which is clean and free from adulteration shall be sold or served.
4. Water Supply: An adequate supply of water of safe, sanitary quality shall be easily available and used for drinking and for cleaning utensils and
equipment.
5. Utensils:
a. Only single service eating and drinking utensils shall be used by customers.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 161/522
b. If multiuse utensils are used in the preparation or serving of food or drink, they shall be thoroughly washed with hot water and a satisfactory
detergent and subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each day's use and so handled and stored as to be protected from
contamination.
6. Refrigeration: Adequate provisions shall be made for refrigeration of perishable food and drink, and all perishable food and drink shall be maintained
at the appropriate recommended temperature for said item(s).
7. Ice: Ice used in or with food or drink shall be from a source approved by the health official and so handled as to avoid contamination.
8. Garbage And Wastes: Garbage and refuse shall be kept in tightly covered, watertight containers until removed and shall be disposed of in a place
and manner approved by the health official. Dishwasher and other liquid wastes shall be disposed of so as not to create a nuisance.
9. Toilet And Lavatory Facilities: Adequate and satisfactory toilet and hand washing facilities shall be readily accessible to employees. No person
engaged in the handling or serving of food and drink shall return to his work, after using the toilet, without first thoroughly washing his or her hands.
(Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6C-5: DISEASE CONTROL:
A. Diseased Employees Prohibited: No person who is infected with any disease in a communicable form or is a carrier of such disease shall work in any
food service establishment, including, but not limited to, any mobile food vendor or temporary food establishment, and no food service establishment,
including, but not limited to, any mobile food vendor or temporary food establishment, shall employ any such person or person suspected of being
infected with any disease in a communicable form or of being a carrier of such disease. It shall be the duty of the manager of a food service
establishment having knowledge of a known or suspected case or carrier of communicable disease among his employees to notify the health official
promptly. A placard containing this subsection shall be posted in all employee toilet rooms.
B. X-Rays And Tests Required: The health official may require that all food service establishment employees have an annual chest X-ray or tuberculin or
other test as may be reasonably required. All new employees shall have a preemployment chest X-ray or tuberculin or other test as may be reasonably
required by the health official within the twelve (12) months prior to the beginning of work in a food service establishment.
C. Training In Food Handling Required: In compliance with the regulations adopted by reference in this chapter, the operator of any food service
establishment or an employee representative of the operator shall complete a course in food handling conducted by an approved agency.
D. Procedure When Infection Suspected: When suspicion arises as to the possibility of transmission of disease from any operator or employee of any food
service establishment, the health official is authorized to require any or all of the following measures:
1. The immediate exclusion of the operator or employee from all food service establishments or temporary food establishments.
2. The immediate closing of the food service establishment or temporary food establishment concerned until no further danger of disease outbreak
exists in the opinion of the health official.
3. Adequate medical examination of the operator or employee and associates with such laboratory examinations as may be indicated. (Ord. 12-3693,
6-25-2012)
3-6C-6: NEW FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS:
A. Conformance With Provisions; Submittal Of Plans: All food service establishments located in the village which are hereafter constructed, reconstructed,
or extensively altered shall conform in their construction to the requirements of this article, chapter, and code, and properly prepared plans, including
equipment specifications and installation layouts for such construction, reconstruction, or extensive alterations, shall be submitted to the health official
for approval before work is begun.
B. Digital Data Standards: All submittals to the village and/or to any engineer, architect, surveyor, or other consultant retained by the village as required by
this title shall comply with the village's digital data standards set forth in title 1, chapter 16, "Digital Data Standards", of this code. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-
2012)
ARTICLE D. OUTDOOR CAFES
3-6D-1: RESERVED:
(Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6D-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an outdoor cafe in the village without a valid outdoor cafe license issued by the village for such purpose,
except as otherwise provided by the corporate authorities pursuant to a current and valid special event permit or pursuant to a temporary use approved by
the village. A current and valid license is one that is currently in effect and not suspended, revoked or expired. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6D-3: OTHER PERMITS, LICENSES AND/OR CERTIFICATES REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 162/522
A. A license to operate an outdoor cafe may only be issued for the period and to a person who has a valid permit to operate a food establishment that also
has a valid permit, license and/or certificate issued by the health official to operate a food establishment as provided in sections 3-6A-3 and 3-6A-4 of
this chapter.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an outdoor cafe in the village without a valid license and/or certificate to operate a food establishment. The
suspension, revocation or termination of a permit, license and/or certificate issued to operate a food establishment as provided in this chapter shall be
deemed to constitute an immediate suspension, revocation or termination, as the case may be, of the license issued to operate an outdoor cafe. (Ord.
12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6D-4: LICENSE FEES:
The fee for each license for an outdoor cafe shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code which fee, if any is applicable, shall be
paid at the time the application is submitted. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6D-5: TERM OF LICENSE; DAYS AND HOURS OF OPERATION:
Each such license shall be operative for a twelve (12) month license year commencing on May 1 of each year; provided, however, an outdoor cafe may,
pursuant to each such license, only be operated during the times hereinafter set forth:
Sunday through Thursday, 7:00 A.M. until 10:00 P.M.
Friday and Saturday, 7:00 A.M. until 11:00 P.M.
Further provided, notwithstanding anything in the foregoing regulations to the contrary, no outdoor cafe may be operated, and no chairs, tables, or other
related equipment relative to such an outdoor cafe shall be allowed to remain on any public sidewalk during the time any of the parking prohibitions related
to snow removal operations as provided by this code are in effect. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6D-6: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
Except as otherwise provided, each license may be renewed upon proper application and payment of the proper fee, if any. The requirements, procedures,
and applicable fees for granting and issuing a license renewal shall be the same as the requirements and procedures for granting a new license, except as
provided by section 1-14-1 of this code. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6D-7: ENCROACHMENTS ONTO PUBLIC WAYS:
A. If any portion of the licensed area encroaches upon and uses portions of any public right-of-way, then the license pertaining to such portion of the
licensed area shall be deemed to constitute a nonexclusive license to temporarily encroach upon and use portions of such public right-of-way,
revocable at will by the Village.
B. If any portion of the proposed licensed area encroaches upon or uses any portion of any public right-of-way under the jurisdiction of any government,
governmental agency or political subdivision other than the Village, then the issuance of a license for an outdoor cafe shall be subject to the consent of
or satisfaction of any requirement of such other government, governmental agency or political subdivision. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6D-8: REGULATIONS:
A. Regulations Applicable To All Outdoor Cafes: Every outdoor cafe operated under a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall comply
with each of the following regulations: (Ord. 17-3937, 3-20-2017)
1. The licensed area shall fully comply with all applicable ingress and egress regulations and all other ordinances and regulations of the Village and the
State.
2. No access shall be obstructed to any parking area which is required to be maintained in connection with the conduct and operation of any food
establishment or any outdoor cafe.
3. The licensed area must be designated by physical barriers consisting of or distinguished by natural materials, a rope barrier with stanchions or other
appropriate facilities, subject to Village approval.
4. The tables and chairs used in the licensed area must be placed on paved surfaces and constructed of durable materials that can withstand
inclement weather including high winds.
5. If umbrellas are used in the licensed area, the same shall be placed in locations within the licensed area in such a manner that clear, safe and
unobstructed site distances shall be maintained for all vehicular and pedestrian traffic on all adjacent and/or abutting public rights-of-way. (Ord. 12-
3693, 6-25-2012)
6. No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, dispensed, consumed or otherwise served in any manner on the licensed area, unless authorized pursuant to
and in compliance with this article. (Ord. 17-3937, 3-20-2017)
7. All trash and debris must be removed from time to time and at the end of each day so that at all times the licensed area and all adjacent land is
maintained in a safe, neat, clean, orderly and sanitary condition. If the licensee does not perform the foregoing in a timely manner, the Village is
authorized to remove or cause to be removed any trash, debris or other property which is not removed from the licensed area as and when the same
is required, and the licensee shall be charged for and shall pay for the cost of such removal. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 163/522
B. Additional Regulations For Outdoor Cafes On Public Ways: In addition to the regulations set forth in subsection A of this section, every outdoor cafe
operating or applying for a license to operate on a portion of any public right-of-way pursuant to the provisions of this article shall comply with the
following additional regulations: (Ord. 17-3937, 3-20-2017)
1. Each application shall include a detailed site plan illustrating a proposed licensed area (including physical barriers), the size and location of the
principal building(s) such as parking area(s), property lines and the location and area of the proposed licensed area. The application must also
include a detailed management plan for the operation of the outdoor cafe. The management plan shall include, but shall not be limited to, provisions
relating to cleanup of the licensed area, location of trash receptacles, control of individuals loitering in and around the licensed area and a procedure
for the nightly removal and storage of the dining tables and chairs from the licensed areas. The outdoor cafe shall be operated in accordance with
the management plan as approved.
2. All property permitted or required by the terms of this article to be placed and maintained on the public right-of-way shall be maintained at the sole
cost of the licensee in a good and workmanlike manner pursuant to the approved plans and specifications.
3. During the conduct of business, the licensee shall establish a temporary barrier at the perimeter and around the licensed area to prevent the moving
of tables and/or chairs within the dining area farther into the public right-of-way, and to limit access to the licensed area from within an adjacent
building or through one (1) passageway controlled by the licensee and/or its employees.
4. The licensed area shall not block pedestrian or vehicular ingress, egress or access over, upon or along any public sidewalk, alley, street or other
public right-of-way and shall be designed and maintained in such a manner that an unobstructed path at least five feet (5') in width exists along the
public right-of-way for the entire length of the licensed area; provided, however, such path shall be measured from the curb, if any, or other similar
point and shall exclude the curb measurement, if any.
5. All of the tables and chairs used in the licensed area and the barriers erected to designate the same must be removed each night and stored in a
secured area outside of the public right-of-way at the termination of the conduct of business for the day. At the termination of the license, whether by
expiration or otherwise, the tables and chairs shall be stored in a permanently constructed building.
6. By applying for a license and operating an outdoor cafe on a portion of a public right-of-way pursuant to this chapter, the licensee shall and does
agree that it shall at all times and under all circumstances, indemnify, protect, defend and save harmless the Village, its employees, officials,
grantees, licensees, agents, lessees and invitees from and against any and all damages, losses, claims, demands, actions and causes of action
whatsoever (including any reasonable costs, expenses and attorney fees which may be incurred in connection therewith) whether or not the claim,
demand, or action asserted be meritorious, and which results from or is alleged to arise out of or in connection with, the installation, construction,
reconstruction, operation, maintenance, alteration, repair, replacement, removal or existence of the encroachment upon the licensed area, or the
existence of the license granted to the licensee herein; provided, however, in the event, if any such claim, damage, loss, demand, action, or cause of
action is asserted against the Village, or its agents, the Village shall furnish written notification thereof, and the licensee, at its sole cost and expense,
shall employ the services of an attorney reasonably satisfactory to the Village and shall conduct the defense thereof before any court, board,
commission or other governmental body exercising jurisdiction therein. No settlement or compromise of any such claim, damage, loss, demand,
action or cause of action against the Village or its agents shall be made unless agreed to by the Village.
7. By applying for a license and operating an outdoor cafe on a portion of a public right-of-way pursuant thereto, the licensee agrees to pay the Village,
its grantees, licensees, agents, lessees and invitees for any and all damage or injury (including death) to persons or property or any expense which
they, or any of them, may sustain resulting from or arising out of or in connection with the installation, construction, reconstruction, operation,
maintenance, alteration, repair, replacement, removal, or existence of the encroachment upon the licensed area, or the existence of the license
granted to such licensee hereunder. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
8. For the entire time that the license is in effect, the licensee shall, at its sole cost and expense, obtain commercial general liability insurance issued by
a company authorized to do business in Illinois, providing coverage in the event of bodily injury or death, or property damage, or both, as a result of
any one accident or occurrence on the licensed area. The limits of such coverage shall be not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined
single limit per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) general aggregate. Such insurance
coverage shall also include liquor liability coverage in the same limits as the aforesaid commercial general liability coverage in the event that an
outdoor cafe license has been issued pursuant to this article for the licensed area. The Village and its elected and appointed officers and officials,
employees, grantees, licensees, agents, lessees and invitees shall be listed as additional insureds. The policy shall provide that the Village shall be
notified in writing of any changes to the policy including, but not limited to, any revocation or termination thereof, prior to the effective date of any
change. The licensee shall also deliver to the Village a certificate of such insurance in a form satisfactory to the Village and, if requested by the
Village Manager, or his designee, a true and correct copy of the insurance policy including the additional insured endorsements. (Ord. 17-3937, 3-20-
2017)
9. Upon termination of the license as a result of any reason whatsoever including, but not limited to, the passage of time or revocation, the licensee, at
its sole cost and expense, shall remove the encroachment and leave the licensed area and adjacent land in a condition substantially similar to the
condition in which it was received and in a neat, clean fashion. The licensee, at its sole cost and expense, shall repair, replace or correct any
damage to the licensed area arising out of or consequent upon or occurring during the term of such license.
10. Notwithstanding anything contained in this Code to the contrary, the license on any part of any public right-of-way may be terminated by the Village
at any time without notice. Upon such termination, at the sole option of the Village but at the sole cost and expense of the licensee within ten (10)
days of the licensee's receipt of written notice from the Village to do so, the licensee shall remove the encroachment from the public right-of-way and
cease the use granted hereby; and upon the failure of the licensee to remove such encroachment, the Village may undertake or cause the removal
of such encroachment and charge the cost of such removal to the licensee. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6D-9: APPROVAL AUTHORITY:
A. The Village Manager, or his designee, shall have the authority to grant written approval or disapproval of any application for a license for an outdoor
cafe which he or she determines substantially complies with all of the terms, conditions, and requirements of this article.
B. In the event the Village Manager, or his designee, determines that an application for a license for an outdoor cafe fails to substantially comply with one
(1) or more provisions of this article, the Corporate Authorities of the Village shall make the final determination of such application for a license based
upon the Corporate Authorities' determination of whether or not approval of such license would, in such circumstances, still be in the best interests of
the Village and its residents and whether or not the approval of such a license would, under such circumstances, present any substantial risk to or
potential negative impact upon the public health, safety, and/or welfare. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 164/522
ARTICLE E. MOBILE FOOD VENDORS
3-6E-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; INSPECTIONS; FEES:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct mobile food vendor operations or to operate as a mobile food vendor in the village,
whether as a food dealer or as a food service establishment, without having a current and valid license therefor. A valid license is one that is not
suspended, revoked or expired. No person shall operate as a mobile food vendor or use or cause the operation or use in the village of any food vehicle
without first having obtained a mobile food vendor license, provided, however, that no license shall be issued to authorize any mobile food vendor to
operate in the village which does not have a permanent food establishment within the village which permanent food establishment has a current and
valid license under this code: 1) unless such mobile food vendor is an ice cream vendor having a current and valid license as a mobile food vendor
under this code; or 2) unless it has a current and valid license as a temporary retail food establishment as part of a special event having a current and
valid special event permit issued pursuant to this code. Notwithstanding the foregoing, food dealers and/or food service establishments that operate
exclusively and temporarily by invitation only on private property and do not sell food to the general public shall not be required to obtain a mobile food
vendor license, and deliveries of preordered food shall not be considered mobile food vendor operations; provided, however, that such food dealers or
food service establishments shall obtain all other applicable village, county, and state license(s), permit(s), certificate(s) and approval(s) and shall be
subject to all village, county, and state laws as may be applicable to such operations.
B. Application For License: Applications for such mobile vendor licenses shall be made in compliance with the general ordinance provisions relating
thereto, on forms provided by the village, and shall state the nature of the mobile food vendor business which the applicant intends to operate,
including the kind of food intended to be sold or handled.
C. Issuance Of License; Posting And Filing Required; Contents: If, upon examination, the premises and the equipment therein are found to be in
compliance with the requirements of this chapter and the applicable codes adopted by reference in this chapter, a license shall be issued to the
applicant. The license shall state the type of mobile food vendor operation for which it is issued and shall be posted in a place conspicuous to the
patrons on any truck, cart, or other vehicle used in such mobile food vendor operation.
D. Persons Prohibited From Securing A Mobile Food Vendor License: It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a mobile food vendor or for any
organization to use any person as a mobile food vendor if such person has been convicted of a violation of other ordinances of the village (except for
minor traffic violations), or any misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving moral turpitude, or any felony of the laws of any municipality, state, or U.S.
government, within the last ten (10) years, and no mobile food vendor license shall be issued to any such person. Applicants for such a mobile food
vendor license and each of their employees shall submit to a fingerprinting and criminal history background check to determine compliance with the
restriction of this subsection.
E. Fees:
1. The fee for a mobile food vendor license shall be as provided from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code.
2. In order to obtain the license required by the provisions of this article and/or by the provisions of this chapter, the applicant for such license shall pay
to the village clerk and to the health department of each inspecting county in which the applicant will operate the actual cost of the minimum number
of required inspections based on the schedule of fees and of inspections adopted by each county or the village as the case may be. In addition, the
applicant shall pay such license fee(s) and administrative fee(s) to the village clerk as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. If the
inspection is performed by the health official of the village, the inspection cost shall be an amount equal to the amount that would have been charged
by each county in which the applicant will operate as if such county or counties had performed the inspection(s) in addition to the administrative fee
as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. The license year shall be from July 1 to June 30 inclusive, and all license fees payable
hereunder are due on July 1 annually. New establishments opening after July 1 of any year shall pay a fee for the entire year.
3. In the event that a reinspection is deemed necessary in either county by the applicable county health department and/or by the health official of the
village, the payment of reinspection fees shall be a condition of issuance or continuance of any permit, license or certificate required. The cost of any
and all reinspections shall be paid by the applicant or holder of the permit, license or certificate. For each reinspection required, the applicant or
holder of the permit, license or certificate shall pay to the village clerk the amount charged by each county health department according to the
schedule of fees established by each department, plus such administrative fee(s) as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. If the
reinspection is performed by the health official of the village, the applicant or holder of the permit, license or certificate shall pay to the village clerk an
amount equal to the amount that would have been charged by each county in which the mobile food vendor will operate, as if such county or
counties had performed the reinspection(s), in addition to the administrative fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each
reinspection. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6E-2: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
A. Vehicle Identification: No person shall operate or cause to be operated any vehicle or pushcart used in the village by a mobile food vendor that does not
prominently display on such vehicle, in letters not less than four inches (4") high, the name of the owner or the assumed name under which the owner
operates, the address of the owner and the kind of goods for sale, and a distinct identifying number assigned to the vehicle. Such lettering or approved
alternative shall be permanently affixed to the vehicle by painting, decal or other method approved by the health official.
B. Vehicle Inspection, Maintenance, Appearance:
1. Mobile food vendor vehicles shall be subject to inspection by the village at any time during operation.
2. Mobile food vendor vehicles shall be maintained in a neat, clean and sanitary condition at all times during operation or in public view.
C. Restrictions On Location, Parking And Stopping:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 165/522
1. No person shall stop, park, and/or operate a mobile food vendor vehicle or pushcart and/or operate as a mobile food vendor on any public way for
the purpose of selling, giving away, displaying, or offering for sale any items, except for a period of time sufficient to consummate an immediate sale
or sales.
2. When stopped or parked, mobile food vendor vehicles shall maintain sufficient room for other vehicles to safely pass on such public way and a
minimum five foot (5') clear pedestrian path on any public walk utilized by such mobile food vendor.
3. Any vehicle(s) used by a mobile food vendor in the village shall not be permitted to park or stand in any location on any public ways except where
the parking of motor vehicles is permitted under the provisions of this code, and the parking or standing of such vehicle(s) on the public ways, except
in a lawful parking place, is prohibited and shall be subject to the parking regulations of the village applicable to such parking space.
4. No person shall stop, park, and/or operate as a mobile food vendor on any public place or public property other than a public way for the purpose of
selling, giving away, displaying, or offering for sale any items, unless authorized in advance in writing by the village board or the village manager, or
his or her designee, by a special event permit.
5. No person shall stop, park, or operate a mobile food vendor vehicle or pushcart and/or operate as a mobile food vendor within five hundred feet
(500') of any lot, parcel, or tract of land utilized for a public or private school, a train station, or a commuter parking lot, and for the purpose of
interpreting this subsection, the distance from property shall be measured from the property line of any lot, parcel, or tract of land used for any of
such purposes. The restriction set forth in this subsection relative to the required separation from school property shall be applicable only between
the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on any day when such school is in session.
D. Noise Limitations: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation operating as a mobile and/or temporary vendor upon the public places of the
village to emit noise of any kind (other than by voice) distinctly and loudly audible upon such public places by sound amplifier, bells, chimes, or other
similar mechanical or electrical device calculated to draw attention to such mobile and/or temporary vending activities.
E. Hours Of Operation Limited: Except as otherwise provided in this code for mobile food vendors, mobile food vendor operations conducted within the
village shall be limited to a period of time commencing at nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and ending at eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. or dusk, whichever is earlier.
However, mobile and temporary vendor operations associated with a special event may be conducted within the hours specified by the approved
special event permit.
F. Insurance Required: During the entire period of time that the mobile food vendor's license is in effect, the licensee shall, at its sole cost and expense,
obtain commercial general liability insurance issued by a company approved by the village and authorized to do business in Illinois, providing coverage
in the event of bodily injury or death, or property damage, or both, as a result of any one accident or occurrence on the licensed area. The limits of such
coverage shall be not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage and two
million dollars ($2,000,000.00) general aggregate. The village and its trustees, officers, employees, and agents shall be listed as additional insureds.
The policy shall provide that the village shall be notified in writing of any changes to the policy including, but not limited to, any revocation or termination
thereof prior to the effective date of any change. The licensee shall also deliver to the village a certificate of such insurance in a form satisfactory to the
village and including a true and correct copy of the insurance policy including the additional insured endorsements. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6E-3: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF UNWHOLESOME OR ADULTERATED FOOD OR BEVERAGE:
Samples of food and drink and other substances may be taken from a mobile food vendor and examined by the health official as often as he or she may
deem necessary for the detection of unwholesome or adulterated food. The health official may condemn and forbid the sale of, or cause to be removed or
destroyed, any food or drink which is unwholesome or adulterated. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6E-4: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
All mobile food vendors shall comply with the requirements for sanitation for food establishments, as applicable, set forth in the Illinois department of
health food service and retail food store sanitation codes, adopted by reference in this chapter. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-6E-5: DISEASE CONTROL:
A. Diseased Operator(s) And/Or Employees Prohibited: No person who is infected with any disease in a communicable form or is a carrier of such disease
shall work as a mobile food vendor or in mobile food vendor operations, and no mobile food vendor operation shall employ any such person or person
suspected of being infected with any disease in a communicable form or of being a carrier of such disease. It shall be the duty of the owner, operator,
and/or manager of a mobile food vendor operation having knowledge of a known or suspected case or carrier of communicable disease among his or
her employees to promptly notify the health official of such facts.
B. X-Rays And Tests Required: The health official may require that all mobile food vendor operator(s) and/or employees have an annual chest X-ray or
tuberculin or other test as may be reasonably required. All new employees shall have a preemployment chest X-ray or tuberculin or other test as may
be reasonably required by the health official within the twelve (12) months prior to the beginning of work as or with a mobile food vendor.
C. Training In Food Handling Required: As often as may be required by state law, the operator and all employees of any mobile food vendor shall
complete a course in food handling conducted by an approved agency.
D. Procedure When Infection Suspected: When suspicion arises as to the possibility of transmission of disease from any operator and/or employee of any
mobile food vendor, the health official is authorized to require any or all of the following measures:
1. The immediate exclusion of the operator(s) and/or employee from all mobile food vendors.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 166/522
2. The immediate closing of the mobile food vendor operation concerned until no further danger of disease outbreak exists in the opinion of the health
official.
3. Adequate medical examination of the operator and/or employee and any associates with such laboratory examinations as may be indicated. (Ord.
12-3693, 6-25-2012)
Chapter 7
TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT SALES
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings:
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT: A product, substance, or device not consisting of or containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body
of nicotine, whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting, sniffing, or by any other means. "Alternative nicotine product" excludes
cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, or other tobacco products as these terms are defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 675/1 et seq., and any
product approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration as a non-tobacco product for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco
dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is being marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose.
LICENSEE: A person who has or is required to have a license issued pursuant to this chapter. This term includes but is not limited to any officer, director,
manager, employee or agent of such a licensee.
SMOKE OR SMOKING: The carrying, smoking, burning, inhaling or exhaling of any kind of lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, weed, herbs, and/or any
other lighted tobacco product or accessory and/or the inhaling, exhaling, vaporizing, vaping, and/or otherwise using, any alternative nicotine products,
and/or the carrying of any activated alternative nicotine accessory.
SMOKELESS TOBACCO: Any tobacco products that are suitable for dipping or chewing.
SMOKING HERBS: All substances of plant origin and their derivatives, including, but not limited to, broom, calea, California poppy, damiana, hops,
ginseng, lobelia, jimsonweed and other members of the Datura genus, passionflower and wild lettuce, which are processed or sold primarily for use as
smoking materials.
TOBACCO AND ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT ACCESSORIES: Any items designed primarily for the smoking, the ingestion of, the inhaling of,
the vaporizing of, or for otherwise using tobacco products, and/or alternative nicotine products, and/or of substances made illegal under any statute or of
substances whose sale, gift, barter or exchange is made unlawful under this chapter.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, or smokeless
tobacco.
VAPE OR VAPING: The inhaling, exhaling, vaporizing, or otherwise using alternative nicotine products.
VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electric or electronic self-service device which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment,
dispenses tobacco products or alternative nicotine products. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail by any means, including but not limited to by means of the internet or other remote sales methods, or in
vending machines, to give away, deliver or keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away or delivering any tobacco products and/or alternative
nicotine products within the Village without having first obtained from the Village a dealer's license which authorizes the sale of tobacco products and/or
alternative nicotine products. Applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring a license under this chapter shall file in writing an application therefor with the Village Clerk upon a form provided by the Clerk, setting
forth the name and the address of the applicant, the name of the owner of the premises or establishment and such other information as may be
prescribed. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-4: LICENSE FEES:
A. Annual License: The annual fee for such license shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this Code.
B. Vending Machines: In lieu of the annual license fee for a dealer in tobacco and/or alternative nicotine products as provided for in subsection A of this
section, where tobacco products and/or alternative nicotine products are served through a vending machine in connection with an establishment whose
principal business is not the sale of tobacco products and/or alternative nicotine products at retail, the annual fee for such license which authorizes the
sale of tobacco products, and/or alternative nicotine products through such vending machines shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1
of this Code. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-5: LICENSE YEAR:
The license year for a dealer's license which authorizes the sale of tobacco product(s) and/or alternative nicotine product(s) shall begin on July 1 of each
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 167/522
year and end on June 30 of the following year. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-6: UNDERAGE PERSONS:
A. Tobacco Products, Alternative Nicotine Products, And Smoking Herbs And Accessories:
1. No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall buy, possess, smoke, vape, inhale, ingest, and/or otherwise use any tobacco product(s),
alternative nicotine product(s), and/or smoking herbs in any of their respective forms or any tobacco and/or alternative nicotine product accessories,
or any part thereof.
2. No person under twenty one (21) years of age shall buy any tobacco product(s), alternative nicotine product(s), and/or smoking herbs in any of their
respective forms or any tobacco and/or alternative nicotine product accessories, or any part thereof.
3. No person, including but not limited to any licensee, shall sell to, buy for, deliver to, distribute samples of, and/or otherwise furnish to any person
under twenty one (21) years of age any tobacco product(s), alternative nicotine product(s), and/or smoking herbs in any of their respective forms or
any tobacco and/or alternative nicotine product accessories, or any part thereof.
4. It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any employee or agent of such licensee to engage, employ or permit any person under twenty one (21) years
of age to sell tobacco products, tobacco accessories, alternative nicotine product(s), and/or smoking herbs in any of their respective forms or any
tobacco and/or alternative nicotine product accessories, or any part thereof.
B. Sale(s) To Persons Under The Age Of Twenty One Prohibited: Before selling, offering for sale, giving, or furnishing any tobacco product(s), tobacco
accessory(ies), alternative nicotine product(s), and/or smoking herbs, or any tobacco and/or alternative nicotine product accessories, or any part
thereof, to another person, any licensee, or any employee(s) or agent(s) of such licensee, selling, offering for sale, giving, and/or otherwise furnishing
any such product(s) and/or accessory(ies) shall verify that the person receiving any such product(s) and/or accessory(ies) is at least twenty one (21)
years of age by:
1. Obtaining from any person who appears to be under thirty (30) years of age and examining such person's government-issued photographic
identification that establishes that such person is at least twenty one (21) years of age, or
2. For sales made through the internet or other remote sales methods, performing an age verification through an independent, third-party age
verification service that compares information available from public records to the personal information entered by the person placing such order
during the ordering process that establishes the person is twenty one (21) years of age or older.
C. False Identification Cards: It shall be unlawful for any person to display or use a false or forged form of identification or to transfer, alter or deface any
government-issued form of identification for the purpose of obtaining any tobacco product(s), tobacco accessory(ies), alternative nicotine product(s),
and/or smoking herbs in any of their respective forms.
D. Warning To Underage Persons:
1. Any licensee hereunder and/or any person, firm, partnership, company or corporation operating a place of business wherein tobacco products,
tobacco accessories, alternative nicotine products and/or smoking herbs in any of their respective forms are sold or offered for sale shall post in a
conspicuous place upon the licensed premises near every display of tobacco products, tobacco accessories, alternative nicotine products and/or
smoking herbs a sign upon which there shall be imprinted the following statement:
SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, TOBACCO ACCESSORIES, ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS, AND/OR SMOKING HERBS TO
PERSONS UNDER TWENTY-ONE (21) YEARS OF AGE OR THE MISREPRESENTATION OF ONE'S AGE FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROCURING
ANY OF SUCH ITEMS IS PROHIBITED BY LAW. THE POSSESSION AND/OR USE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, TOBACCO ACCESSORIES,
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS, AND/OR SMOKING HERBS BY ANY PERSON UNDER EIGHTEEN (18) YEARS OF AGE IS ALSO
PROHIBITED BY LAW.
2. Such a sign shall be printed on a white card in red letters at least one-half inch (1/2") in height. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-7: DISTRIBUTION LOCATIONS RESTRICTED:
A. Sales In Proximity To Certain Institutions:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, deliver as part of any sale, or give away or deliver for promotional or marketing purposes,
tobacco products and/or alternative nicotine product(s) to any person within one hundred feet (100') of any day care center, nursery school, private
primary school, public primary school, private secondary school, public secondary school, public library, or any public park or playground.
2. For purposes of the application of this subsection A, the one hundred foot (100') separation shall be measured from the building in which the sale of
tobacco products and/or alternative nicotine products are proposed to be located to the property line of any day care center, nursery school, private
primary school, public primary school, private secondary school, public secondary school, public library, or of any public park or playground,
provided, however, that any lawful business location used for the sale of tobacco products and/or alternative nicotine product(s) which existed prior to
the effective date of this section shall not be prohibited by the subsequent establishment and/or the existing location of any of those certain
institutions identified in subsection A1 of this section.
B. Free Distributions Prohibited In Certain Places: It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of selling or otherwise distributing,
promoting or advertising tobacco products and/or alternative nicotine products or any employee or agent of any such licensee or person in the course
of such licensee's or person's business to offer, distribute, give away or deliver tobacco products and/or alternative nicotine products free of charge to
any person on any right-of-way, park, playground or other public property owned by the Village, by any school district, by any park district, or by any
public library.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 168/522
C. Sample Distributions: No person shall distribute without charge sample(s) of any tobacco product(s) or of any alternative nicotine product(s) to any
other person, regardless of age:
1. Within a retail establishment selling tobacco product(s) and/or alternative nicotine product(s), unless the retailer, or an employee or agent of the
retailer, has verified that the recipient is twenty one (21) years of age or older by the recipient's presentation of a government-issued form of
photographic identification;
2. From any mobile vehicle;
3. On a public way as a promotion or advertisement of a distributor and/or manufacturer of tobacco, tobacco product(s), and/or alternative nicotine
product(s).
This subsection C shall not apply to the distribution of a tobacco product sample in any adult-only retail facility. For the purpose of this section, "adult
only retail facility" means an enclosed retail facility or retail area where the operator ensures or has a reasonable basis to believe (such as by
checking identification as required under State law, or by checking the identification of any person appearing to be under the age of 30) that no
person under legal age is present in such a restricted facility and persons under the age of twenty one (21) shall be permanently prohibited from
such restricted facility.
D. Definitions: For purposes of this section, the terms "day care center", "nursery school", "private primary school", "public primary school", "private
secondary school", "public secondary school", shall each have the respective meaning set forth in chapter 2 of the Village of Barrington zoning
ordinance, as amended from time to time, but such school shall not include training studios, professional or vocational schools, or independent student
learning centers. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-8: DISPLAY AND SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCT(S), TOBACCO ACCESSORIES, ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT(S),
AND SMOKING HERBS:
Each licensee hereunder shall be required to comply with the following provisions and restrictions relative to the sale and display of tobacco product(s),
tobacco accessory(ies), alternative nicotine product(s), and smoking herbs:
A. Any licensed premises that derives less than eighty percent (80%) of its revenue from the sale of tobacco product(s), tobacco accessory(ies),
alternative nicotine product(s) and/or smoking herbs must display and sell all such product(s) on the licensed premises from behind the counter or in an
age-restricted area and/or such product(s) shall be kept in a sealed display case, except as otherwise provided below.
B. The restrictions contained in subsection A of this section do not apply to a licensed premises that: 1) derives at least eighty percent (80%) of its revenue
from the sale of tobacco product(s), tobacco accessory(ies), alternative nicotine product(s), and/or smoking herbs; 2) does not permit persons under
the age of twenty one (21) to enter the premises unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian; and 3) posts a sign on or in close proximity to the
main entranceway of the licensed premises stating that persons under the age of twenty one (21) are prohibited from entering unless accompanied by
a parent or legal guardian.
C. Any licensed premises that derives at least eighty percent (80%) of its revenue from the sale of tobacco, tobacco product(s), alternative nicotine
product(s), and/or smoking herbs: 1) shall not permit persons under the age of twenty one (21) to enter the premises unless accompanied by a parent
or legal guardian, and 2) shall post a sign on or in close proximity to the main entranceway of the licensed premises stating that persons under the age
of twenty one (21) are prohibited from entering unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-9: VENDING MACHINES; LOCKING DEVICES:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling, giving away or delivering tobacco
products and/or alternative nicotine products by use of a vending machine unless such vending machine is equipped with a manual, electric or electronic
locking device controlled by the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons under the age of twenty one (21) years. Any premises where access by
persons under the age of twenty one (21) years is prohibited by law or premises where the public is generally not permitted and where vending machines
are strictly for the use of employees of a business located at such premises shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-
2018)
3-7-10: LIABILITY OF LICENSEE FOR AGENTS AND EMPLOYEES:
Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent
or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if
such act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
3-7-11: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE AND COSTS:
A. Suspension Or Revocation; License Surcharge In Lieu Thereof: The Village President may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provisions
of this chapter if he or she determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this chapter. In lieu of suspension or revocation of a
license, the Village President may instead levy a license surcharge which shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this Code for each
violation. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation.
B. Hearing: No such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing by the Village President, with a
seven (7) day written notice to the licensee, affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such notice.
The seven (7) day notice provisions shall begin the day following delivery by certified mail or by personal service.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 169/522
C. Decisions: The Village President shall, within seven (7) days after such hearing, if he or she determines after such hearing that the license should be
revoked or suspended or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such determination in a written order and either the amount of the fine,
the period of suspension or that the license has been revoked and serve a copy of such order upon the licensee within the seven (7) days.
D. Costs:
1. Any licensee determined by the Village President to have violated any of the provisions of this chapter shall pay to the Village the costs of the
hearing before the Village President on such violation. The Village President shall determine the costs incurred by the Village for said hearing,
including, but not limited to: court reporter fees, the cost of transcripts or records, attorney fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders
and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the Village or such lesser sum as the Village President may allow.
2. The licensee shall pay said costs to the Village within thirty (30) days of notification of the amount of such costs by the Village President. Failure to
pay said costs within thirty (30) days of notification is a violation of this chapter and may be cause for license suspension or revocation or the
imposition of the license surcharge as aforesaid. (Ord. 18-4024, 10-22-2018)
Chapter 8
ALARM SYSTEMS
3-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
ALARM: Includes and means any device known as a burglar, holdup, panic, smoke or fire alarm.
Burglar Alarm: A security system designed to protect a building or area.
Holdup Or Panic Alarm: A security system designed to allow notification to the police department during normal business hours of occupancy by
authorized persons.
Smoke Or Fire Alarm: A security system designed to allow notification to the fire department.
FALSE ALARM: Transmission of any alarm signal caused by human error or mechanical malfunction, whether or not the exact cause of the error or
malfunction is identified, or any other activation of the signal when no actual emergency or threat to persons or property exists, other than during testing
and/or repair procedures if prior notice has been given to the police department.
FALSE FIRE ALARM: An alarm signal which indicates the existence of an emergency situation when, in fact, no such emergency exists. "False fire alarm"
shall include any alarm signal generated by any fire protection system by whatever means, but shall not include alarms resulting from any of the following
causes:
A. Fire, causing structural damage to the protected premises, as verified by the fire department.
B. Earthquake, causing structural damage to the protected premises.
C. Tornado or hurricane winds, causing structural damage to the protected premises.
D. Flooding of the protected premises due to overflow of natural drainage.
E. Lightning, causing physical damage to the protected premises.
F. Telephone line malfunction, verified to the fire department by an authorized telephone company supervisor within seven (7) days of the occurrence.
G. Electrical service interruption, verified to the fire department by the local power company manager within seven (7) days of the occurrence.
H. Plumbing or electrical malfunctions, unrelated to the fire protection system.
FIRE ALARM USER: The person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind in control of any building, structure or
facility or portion thereof wherein a fire protection system is maintained.
FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM: Any fire alarm device or system, or their combination, which is designed and installed for detecting, controlling or
extinguishing a fire or otherwise alerting occupants, the Barrington fire department, or both, that a fire has occurred.
TYPES OF ALARM SYSTEMS:
Direct Dial System: Customer's alarm system triggers a telephone call to the police or fire department stating the type of alarm and the location.
Local Alarm System: The local alarm system has no direct connection to the police or fire department. When triggered, the alarm activates an
audible signal device or visual warning mechanism on the premises. The type of alarm is usually reported to the police by a passerby, neighbor or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 170/522
person on the premises.
Monitoring Station Alarms: A system monitored by a private contractor wherein when the alarm is triggered, it is received initially at the private
contractor's location and is then telephoned to the police/fire department.
Receiving Station Alarms: The system installed by a private contractor in a police or fire department headquarters. The system constantly scans its
customers' alarms and provides the police or fire department with a coded tape if an alarm is triggered. The tape states the type of alarm, location
and alarm status. (1973 Code § 13-335; amd. Ord. 98-2713, 3-16-1998)
3-8-2: RECEIVING STATION ALARMS:
A. Permit Requirements:
1. Permit Required: No person, firm or corporation shall be allowed to have a direct burglar, holdup, smoke or fire alarm connection to the police or fire
department for the purposes of a receiving station alarm from any building, place or premises within the village without having first obtained a permit
from the village chief of police.
2. Application For Permit: Permits shall be issued only after receipt of a written application by the village chief of police. The application shall contain a
provision that the village shall not be liable for any failure of service or any damages that might result from the installation or operation of the alarm
system. All applicants must agree to indemnify the village for all claims, demands, judgments, liability costs and expenses that may arise in any way
as a result of the alarm connection and service. All applicants must certify that alarm system maintenance will be provided twenty four (24) hours per
day, seven (7) days per week.
3. Nontransferability Of Permit: The permits are not transferrable, and a change of ownership or occupancy of the premises shall be cause for a new
permit application to be filed with the village.
B. Signal Required: Applicants asking to connect to the police alarm panel shall be required to furnish a suitable signal to the receiving station located in
the communications center. (1973 Code § 13-336)
3-8-3: AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICES AND MONITORING ALARM SYSTEMS:
A. Special Trunk Line Required: Automatic dialing devices and monitoring alarm systems designed to transmit a prerecorded message directly to the
police or fire department or any type of message or signal to a private monitoring location may be programmed to dial a special trunk line designated
by the village chief of police. No automatic dialing device or monitoring alarm systems shall be programmed to dial a primary trunk line of the police or
fire department of the village. Before such a device or system is programmed to dial a special trunk line, the person or company performing this
operation shall first obtain instructions from the village chief of police or his designee concerning the procedure to be followed.
B. Permit Requirements:
1. Application For Permit: Permits shall be issued only after receipt of a written application by the village chief of police. The application shall contain a
provision that the village shall not be liable for any failure of service or any damages that might result from the installation or operation of the alarm
system. All applicants must agree to indemnify the village for all claims, demands, judgments, liability costs and expenses that may arise in any way
as a result of the alarm connection and service. All applicants must certify that alarm system maintenance will be provided twenty four (24) hours per
day, seven (7) days per week.
2. Nontransferability Of Permit: The permits are not transferrable, and a change of ownership or occupancy of the premises shall be cause for a new
permit application to be filed with the village.
C. List Of Trunk Line Installations: Every alarm business which has installed any automatic dialing device or monitoring alarm system in the village
programmed to dial special trunk lines in the communications center of the police and fire departments shall maintain a current list of such installations
for inspection by the chief of police during the course of his official duties and include in such lists:
1. The name, address and telephone number of the owner, occupant or lessor of the premises served by such device.
2. The address served by such device or system installed and the telephone number of that location.
D. Standards: Such automatic dialing devices and monitoring alarm systems installed on any premises within the village shall meet the following minimum
standards:
1. The contents of any recorded message to be transmitted by such device or system must be intelligible and in a format approved by the chief of
police as appropriate for the type of emergency being reported.
2. Upon a single stimulus of the alarm device, any such device or system may place only two (2) separate calls for the same alarm to the police
department via the special trunk lines.
3. Sensory apparatus comprising such devices or systems shall be maintained by the owner, occupant or lessee in such physical condition that false
alarms will be minimized. (1973 Code § 13-337)
3-8-4: LOCAL ALARM SYSTEMS:
A. Permit Requirements:
1. Permit Required: No person, firm or corporation shall be allowed to maintain or operate a local alarm on any building, place or premises within the
village without first obtaining a permit from the village chief of police.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 171/522
2. Application For Permit: Permits shall be issued only after receipt of a written application by the village chief of police. The application shall contain a
provision that the village shall not be liable for any failure of service or any damages that might result from the installation or operation of the alarm
system. All applicants must agree to indemnify the village for all claims, demands, judgments, liability costs and expenses that may arise in any way
as a result of the alarm connection and service. All applicants must certify that alarm system maintenance will be provided twenty four (24) hours per
day, seven (7) days per week.
3. Nontransferability Of Permit: The permits are not transferrable, and a change of ownership or occupancy of the premises shall be cause for a new
permit application to be filed with the village.
B. Requirements:
1. Local alarms may be in addition to a central receiving station alarm.
2. Local alarms shall not make a sound similar to that of sirens or emergency vehicles or civil defense warning systems.
3. Owners of said local alarms will be responsible for maintenance of these alarms and for turning off the audible signals at the request of the police
department or an officer. (1973 Code § 13-338)
3-8-5: ADDITIONAL PERMIT PROVISIONS:
A. Terms Of Permits: All alarm permits shall be effective for a twelve (12) month period beginning on January 1 of each year, subject to the provisions of
subsection 3-8-6A of this chapter. (Ord. 98-2713, 3-16-1998)
B. Additional Application Requirements; Liability And Indemnification: The application to the village chief of police shall contain a provision that the village
shall not be liable for any failure of service or damages, including damages resulting from break in to gain entrance, that might result from the
installation or operation of any receiving station alarm, automatic dialing device, or local alarm. All applicants must agree to indemnify the village for all
claims, demands, judgments, liability costs and expenses that may arise in any way as a result of the alarm systems. (1973 Code § 13-342)
3-8-6: FEES AND CHARGES:
A. Permit Fee Surcharge:
1. Charges Established: Any applicant for a police alarm whose system had in excess of two (2) false alarms during any twelve (12) month period
beginning after December 31, 1996, shall pay permit fee surcharges as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code.
2. Payment Of Surcharge: All permit fee surcharges assessed pursuant to this subsection A or to section 3-8-1 of this chapter, and as specified from
time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, shall be paid by the applicant-permittee within thirty (30) days after billing. No permits shall be renewed or
reissued for police or for fire alarms unless and until all prior permit fee surcharges have been paid.
B. False Fire Alarm Service Charge: For any "false fire alarm", as defined in section 3-8-1 of this chapter (that is, a fire alarm other than those described in
the definition of "false fire alarm" in section 3-8-1 of this chapter), charges shall be assessed based on the type of false fire alarm identified, as follows:
1. Type I False Fire Alarm:
a. A type I false fire alarm is any false fire alarm that is:
(1) Given intentionally;
(2) Due to or caused by a lack of required maintenance; or
(3) Resulting from any test, repair, alteration or addition to the fire protection system without prior notification thereof to the fire department.
b. For any type I false fire alarm, a fire alarm user shall be charged a service charge as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code.
2. Type II False Fire Alarm: A type II false fire alarm is any false fire alarm other than a type I false fire alarm. For any type II false fire alarms in excess
of the first three (3) false alarms in any twelve (12) month period between January 1 and December 31, the fire alarm user shall be charged a service
charge for each such false fire alarm as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-2009)
3-8-7: INSPECTIONS:
A. Entry Powers: For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, the chief of police shall have the authority, at reasonable times and upon
reasonable oral notice, to enter any premises in the village in or upon which the alarm systems subject to this chapter are located, to inspect the
operation of such alarm systems.
B. Report Of Violations: If such inspection reveals any violations of provisions of this chapter, a written report detailing such violations shall be promptly
sent to the village president and to the owner, occupant or lessee responsible for the alarm system. Such report shall require the correction within thirty
(30) days after receipt of a notice of the violation discovered, and shall state that a failure to comply may result in the revocation of the annual permit to
operate. The responsible owner, occupant or lessee shall be granted a reasonable extension of time to correct such violations, upon good cause
shown. (1973 Code § 13-340)
3-8-8: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMITS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 172/522
The village chief of police shall have the authority to revoke or suspend the operation of an alarm system if an inspection, as provided in section 3-8-7 of
this chapter, reveals violations of this chapter, which violations are not corrected. The chief of police may also suspend the permit of any person whose
system transmits more than four (4) false alarms within a twelve (12) month period. (1973 Code § 13-341)
Chapter 9
CANVASSERS, MOBILE AND TEMPORARY VENDORS, AND SOLICITORS
3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words, as used herein, shall be construed to have the meanings herein ascribed thereto below:
CANVASSER: A person who conducts any manner of door to door advocacy, including, but not limited to, conducting any type of survey and/or the
distribution of any literature, handbills or pamphlets, excluding the following:
A. Those present as a result of a prior invitation from an owner or occupant of the premises; and
B. Persons employed and on official business for the United States census bureau; and
C. Persons rendering assistance or providing information of a bona fide emergency nature.
MOBILE VENDOR: A person who offers for sale, barter or exchange at retail any goods or services of any kind, including, but not limited to, food, utilizing
a vehicle designed to be readily movable. The term includes "peddlers" but does not include "solicitors" or "canvassers", nor does the term include
persons who deliver goods or services, who are fulfilling an order for such goods or services which was solicited or placed by mail or other means.
PEDDLER: See definition of Mobile Vendor.
PERSON: A natural person, firm, club, corporation, association, partnership, company, organization, or political subdivision.
RESIDENCE: Shall mean and include every separate living unit, occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of
building or structure.
SOLICITOR: A person who is engaged in any of the following activities:
A. Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, food, beverages, or services of any kind, for any kind of consideration whatever, all for future
delivery; or
B. Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable, religious or
nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project, provided, however, seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and other publications shall not be deemed "soliciting".
TEMPORARY VENDOR: A person who operates a retail sales or service establishment that operates at a fixed location in the village for a period of time
of not more than fourteen (14) consecutive days in conjunction with a single special event and pursuant to a current and valid special event permit. (Ord.
12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-9-2: MOBILE AND TEMPORARY VENDORS PROHIBITED:
Mobile vendors and temporary vendors are hereby prohibited, except where and when otherwise permitted by this code pursuant to a current and valid
mobile food vendor license, pursuant to a current and valid temporary food establishment license issued in conjunction with a current and valid special
event permit, or pursuant to a current and valid special event permit issued pursuant to this code. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-9-3: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED; RESTRICTIONS:
All mobile vendors and temporary vendors not otherwise prohibited by this code shall obtain a certificate of registration as hereinafter described. (Ord. 12-
3693, 6-25-2012)
3-9-4: APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE; FEES; ISSUANCE:
A. Applications For Certificates Generally; Contents Of Certificate:
1. Information Required: The application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form provided by the chief of police and filed with and
retained by such chief. No certificate of registration will be issued to any applicant until and unless the application therefor has been completed in full
and all requested submittals have been provided to the chief of police. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the following information, among
other things, requested on the application:
a. Name and present residence address and length of residence at such address; applicable business address, if other than residence address,
which must include street address; social security number; driver's license number, if any;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 173/522
b. Residence addresses, if any, during the past three (3) years, if other than the present address;
c. Age of the applicant and marital status; and if married, the name of spouse;
d. Physical description of the applicant, including height, weight, color of hair and color of eyes;
e. Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association whom the applicant is employed by or represents; the length of time of such
employment or representation; the residence address of corporate officers and principal;
f. Location at which applicant intends to do business; nature of the business; whether a certificate of registration under the retailers' occupation tax
act has been issued; a list of inventory the applicant intends to offer for sale;
g. Name and address of all employers during the past three (3) years, if other than the present employer;
h. Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of the vending which the applicant will engage in;
i. Period of time for which the certificate is applied for;
j. A list of all certificates of registration or licenses to conduct business as a "mobile vendor" or "temporary vendor" received or applied for within the
state for the preceding twelve (12) months;
k. The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for certificate or license in the village, if any;
l. Whether or not a certificate of registration or license issued to the applicant under this code has ever been revoked;
m. Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this code or the ordinances of any other Illinois
municipality regulating mobile vendors, or temporary vendors.
n. Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state or federal law
of the United States.
2. Statements In Application Made Under Oath: All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under
oath.
3. Identification Required: In connection with the application for a certificate, the applicant shall submit to identification photographing and fingerprinting
for the purpose of allowing the police department to conduct a criminal history background investigation.
4. Records Of Applications And Certificates: The chief of police shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received and
acted upon, together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of registration or licenses issued under the provisions of
this code and of the denial of applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order, as filed; and every certificate issued
and any renewal thereof shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued.
5. Issuance Or Denial Of Certificate:
a. Upon the filing of a complete and accurate application, as provided herein, a certificate of registration shall be issued by the chief of police or his
designee within thirty (30) days of application, except that no certificate shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission
of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois, or any other state or federal law of the United States, within five (5) years of the date of the
application; nor to any person who has committed a violation of any of the provisions of this code; nor to any person whose certificate of
registration or license issued hereunder has previously been revoked as herein provided; nor to any person or entity that fails to meet the
requirements set forth in this chapter.
b. Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted or enforced to deprive any person of any rights guaranteed under the constitution of the state of Illinois
or the United States.
B. Fees:
1. Payment Due At Application: The applicant for a mobile vendor or temporary vendor certificate of registration shall pay a fee as specified from time
to time in section 1-14-1 of this code upon application for a certificate of registration.
2. Expiration Of Certificate: A certificate of registration issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire on December 31 of the year it was issued.
3. Violations: It is a violation of this chapter for any person, firm or corporation, either as principal or agent, to conduct business as a mobile vendor or
temporary vendor in the village without first complying with the applicable requirements of the retailers' occupation tax act and by obtaining a
certificate of registration as required under this chapter. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-9-5: REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the chief of police if the holder of the certificate has committed a violation of any of the
provisions of this code, or has made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of
registration under the terms of this code. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police to the holder of the
certificate in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his or her residence address set forth in the application. Immediately upon the giving of such
notice, the certificate of registration shall become null and void. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-9-6: TRESPASSING:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon any property of another in the village after receiving, immediately prior to such entry, notice from the
owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden, or to remain upon the property of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 174/522
B. A person shall be deemed to have received notice from the owner or occupant within the meaning of this section if he has been notified personally,
either orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry has been conspicuously posted at the main entrance to said property or
the forbidden part thereof.
C. The owner or occupant of any residence who desires to forbid trespasses by canvassers, solicitors, mobile vendors or peddlers, may attach or exhibit
upon or near the main front door, and the main rear or side door (if any and if to be protected), a card or plaque stating such of the following as may be
