appropriate, in letters at least one-third inch (1/3") in height:
Canvassers, Solicitors and Peddlers Forbidden
D. The form of notice provided for in this section shall not be deemed to be an exclusive form of notice. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-9-7: VIOLATIONS:
Any person canvassing, soliciting, peddling, or operating as a mobile vendor who is forbidden entry by a notice given in compliance with this chapter shall
be deemed guilty of remaining on the property after receiving notice to depart if he shall ring the doorbell or knock or create any sound calculated to attract
the attention of the occupant. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
3-9-8: EXEMPTIONS:
Notices exhibited pursuant to this chapter shall not be deemed applicable to and shall not prevent access to residential property by a canvasser, solicitor,
peddler, or mobile vendor who has received prior invitation, written or oral, from an owner or occupant thereof. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
Chapter 10
GARAGE, RUMMAGE AND SIMILAR OCCASIONAL SALES
3-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used herein:
OCCASIONAL SALES: Those sales of goods, wares and merchandise owned by the occupier of the premises or owned by a group of persons having a
common sale commonly known as, among other things, a garage sale, an estate sale, a basement sale, a house sale, a yard sale and/or a rummage sale,
which sale is conducted on an infrequent basis on premises zoned or used for residential purposes. Bulk sales and/or offers to sell items in bulk, the sale
and/or offering for sale of multiple new or reconditioned items of the same description, the sale and/or the offering for sale of new or reconditioned
merchandise brought to the premises for the purpose of sale or resale (except as above permitted by a group of persons having a common sale) and the
sale and/or offering for sale of any new items are all hereby prohibited.
PERSON: Any individual, firm or profit or not for profit corporation or organization. (1973 Code § 13-344)
3-10-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or allow the conducting of an "occasional sale", as defined herein, on premises zoned or used for residential
purposes without having applied for and received from the village manager or his designate a permit to conduct such sale. Permits shall be obtained by
the applicant from the village manager or his designate by appearing in person or by mail, but no permit fee shall be charged. Each permit shall be readily
available on the premises covered by the permit upon request of the village manager or his designate. (1973 Code § 13-345)
3-10-3: DAYS, HOURS AND FREQUENCY OF SALES:
Occasional sales shall be permitted only on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays for not more than three (3) consecutive days and only between nine o'clock
(9:00) A.M. and sunset each day. Not more than three (3) such occasional sales shall be conducted on the same premises within any calendar year, and
not more than one such sale shall be conducted on the same premises within any one thirty (30) day period. In the event of rain, an occasional sale may
be held in the three (3) day period immediately following the permitted period; however, no such sale shall exceed three (3) total days. (1973 Code § 13-
346)
3-10-4: ADVERTISING SIGNS:
All signs giving notice of the sale shall be removed no later than nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. on the day the permit expires and shall otherwise conform to all
applicable provisions of this code, including, but not limited to, the provisions of title 11, chapter 2 of this code. (1973 Code § 13-347)
Chapter 11
ADVERTISING DISTRIBUTORS
3-11-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 175/522
It shall be unlawful to distribute indiscriminately to the public, by leaving at stores, offices, houses or residences in the village, any cards, circulars,
samples of merchandise, handbills or any advertising matter whatsoever without having first secured a permit therefor. Provided, that this section shall not
be construed to apply to the sale of articles by licensed peddlers. (1973 Code § 13-265)
3-11-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be made to the clerk, and shall contain a statement of the nature of the article, cards or
advertisement to be distributed and the name of the applicant and the name of the manufacturer or distributor of such article or service advertised. (1973
Code § 13-266)
3-11-3: PERMIT FEE:
The annual fee for a permit required by this chapter shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-2009)
3-11-4: CHARACTER OF PERMITTEE:
No permit required shall be issued to any but a person of good character. The chief of police shall make or cause to be made an investigation into the
character of each applicant and shall report the results thereof to the clerk before any such permit shall be issued. (1973 Code § 13-268; amd. 2003 Code)
3-11-5: DISTRIBUTING IN PUBLIC PLACES PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute indiscriminately to the public any cards, circulars, handbills, samples of merchandise, or any advertisement
or advertising matter whatsoever on any public street or sidewalk or other public place in the village; provided, that this section shall not be construed to
prohibit the peddling or sale of any article or publication that may carry or be accompanied by advertising matter where a charge is made or a price is paid
for such article or publication. (1973 Code § 13-264)
Chapter 12
NUISANCE NOISES
3-12-1: NUISANCE NOISE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person within the village to make, continue or cause to be made or continued, any loud, unnecessary or
unusual noise which annoys, disturbs, injures and/or endangers the comfort, repose, convenience, health, peace and/or safety of others, within the limits
of the village. Without any limitation on the foregoing, the following acts, among others, are declared to be nuisance noise and in violation of this section,
unless a license authorizing same has been obtained from the village in accordance with this chapter, and then only in compliance with the terms of such
license:
A. Vehicular Noise:
1. Engine Exhausts: Permitting and/or allowing the discharge into the open air within the village of the exhaust of any steam engine, gasoline engine,
stationary internal combustion engine, or other kind or type of engine, motorboat, or motor vehicle is prohibited, except through a muffler or other
device which will effectively prevent loud, explosive, and/or unnecessary noises therefrom.
2. Defect In Vehicle Or Load: The use and/or operation, or permitting and/or allowing the use and/or operation within the village of any wagon, cart,
automobile, truck, motorcycle, or other vehicle, so out of repair or loaded in such manner or with material of such nature as to create loud and/or
unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noises is prohibited.
3. Motor Vehicle Alarms: The use and/or operation, or permitting and/or allowing the use and/or operation of a continuous, audible signal device which
acts as a vehicle security alarm, when such device is not limited in operation to four (4) minutes after activation, is prohibited.
4. Horns, Signaling Devices: The sounding, permitting and/or allowing the sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, or
other vehicle on any street or public place in the village, except as a warning of any actual or reasonably perceived danger, is prohibited; without any
limitation on the foregoing, the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud and/or harsh sound is also prohibited, and
the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and/or unreasonable period of time is prohibited; the use of any horn, whistle, or other device
operated by engine exhaust is prohibited, and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up is prohibited.
5. Audio Systems: No person shall play, use, and/or operate or permit and/or allow to be played, used and/or operated, any radio, tape player, cassette
player, boombox, or other device for receiving broadcast of, producing sound, and/or reproducing sound if such device is located in any vehicle on a
public street or highway, and if the sound generated by such device is audible to any person, including, but not limited to, a peace officer, at a
distance of seventy five feet (75') or greater.
6. Police Authority To Abate: In addition to the general penalty provided in section 1-4-1 of this code, the chief of police, or his designee, shall have the
authority to take reasonable measures to abate noise in violation of this subsection A by causing the vehicle which is the source of such violation to
be towed, and impose towing charges which shall be paid by the registered owner of the vehicle. The owner(s) of any vehicle which violates this
subsection A shall assume the risk of any damage which may be caused by efforts of the village to abate such nuisance.
B. Drums; Pyrotechnic(s); Power Equipment; Other Engines Or Motors:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 176/522
1. Drums; Pyrotechnic(s): No person shall use and/or operate, or permit and/or allow the use and/or operation within the village of any drum,
pyrotechnic(s) or explosive device or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention or for the creation of noise for some other
purpose.
2. Power Equipment; Other Engines, Or Motors: No person shall use and/or operate or permit and/or allow to be used and/or operated within the
village any noise-creating blower, fan, power equipment, compressor, and/or any other engine or motor, the use and/or operation of which causes
noise, unless the noise from such device is muffled and equipped with a muffler device to deaden such noise, and unless such operation occurs
between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
C. Construction Activity; Hours Of Work: No construction, demolition, alteration and/or site development operations shall be carried on or permitted and/or
allowed to be carried on other than during the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. on Monday through Friday, and during the
hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on Saturday and Sunday, if such operations generate and/or are accompanied by sound that
is audible beyond the boundaries of the property on which such operations are located.
D. Loudspeakers, Amplifiers, Paging Systems:
1. The playing, using, and/or operating or permitting and/or allowing the playing, use, and/or operation of any radio, MP3 player, IPOD, cellular
telephone, computer, television, musical instrument, tape player, cassette player, boombox, phonograph, television or other device designed,
intended, and/or used for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of any person on or
within any neighboring property or with louder volume than is necessary for the convenient hearing of the persons who are in the room, chamber,
vehicle or outdoor area within the village where such device is played, used and/or operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto, is prohibited.
2. Without any limitation on the foregoing restrictions of subsection D1 of this section, the following shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this
subsection D:
a. The operation of any device listed in subsection D1 of this section between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. in
such a manner as to be audible to any person on or within any neighboring property; or
b. The operation of any device as listed in subsection D1 of this section in such a manner so as to be audible to any person at a distance of seventy
five feet (75') from the location of such device; or
c. The operation of any such device as listed in subsection D1 of this section for the purpose of commercial advertising and/or of attracting the
attention of the public to any building, structure, and/or event, if such sound is audible to any person on or within any neighboring property.
E. Hawkers, Peddlers: The shouting and crying within the village of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which is audible from any property within the village
used for residential purposes is prohibited.
F. Yelling, Shouting: Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling and/or singing on or within any public way within the village, particularly between the hours of ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any
office, in any residence, and/or of persons in the vicinity, within the village, is prohibited.
G. Animals, Birds: The keeping of any animal or bird shut up or tied up in any yard, enclosure, stable, house or other place within the village which, by
barking, howling, crying, singing or causing frequent or long continued noise, annoys and/or disturbs the comfort and/or repose of persons in the
vicinity, is prohibited.
H. Exemptions From Chapter: The use and/or operation or permitting and/or allowing the following are exempt from and not included within the aforesaid
noise prohibition(s) of this chapter:
1. Authorized law enforcement, fire/EMS, and/or other emergency vehicles.
2. The operations of any unit of local government and/or the operations of any contractor authorized by a unit of local government, but this exemption
shall not extend to any other private activity occurring on the property of any such unit of local government, unless otherwise exempt from the
provisions of this chapter.
3. Any private snow removal and/or ice control operations.
4. Any construction, maintenance, power generator, and/or repair activities of an emergency nature performed pursuant to the written approval of the
village manager, or one of his or her designees.
5. The operation of heating, ventilation, and air conditioning equipment which are in sound and satisfactory working condition and were installed in
conformance with the applicable ordinances and regulations of the village.
6. Activity, operations, and/or the use of a device or equipment for which a license has been obtained from the village pursuant to this chapter, but only
when used in compliance with the terms of such license. (Ord. 09-3515, 5-26-2009)
3-12-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to use and/or operate, or permit and/or allow the use and/or operation of any device designed, intended, and/or used for producing or
reproducing of sound, or any other activities or operations, which would otherwise be in violation of this chapter, unless a license authorizing same has first
been obtained from the village in accordance with this chapter, and then only in compliance with the terms of such license. (Ord. 09-3515, 5-26-2009)
3-12-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring a license under this chapter shall file an application therefor with the village manager, or his or her designee, setting forth the name
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 177/522
and address of the applicant, the name of the owner of such device, the date(s) upon which it is intended to be used, and such other information as may
be prescribed. (Ord. 09-3515, 5-26-2009)
3-12-4: LICENSE FEES:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the daily fees for each day, or part of a day, for which a license is issued pursuant to this chapter shall be as
specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. (Ord. 09-3515, 5-26-2009)
3-12-5: ISSUANCE AND SCOPE OF LICENSE:
A license under this chapter shall be issued upon the approval of the application therefor by the village manager, or his or her designee, and the payment
of the license fee(s), as herein provided, to the village treasurer, or his or her designee, and shall permit the use and/or operation of any such device or
other activity or operations, subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter, only upon the date(s) specified in such license and on no other. (Ord. 09-
3515, 5-26-2009)
3-12-6: DAYS AND HOURS OF OPERATION:
Except as otherwise specified in this chapter, no licensee under this chapter shall use, and/or operate or permit and/or allow the use and/or operation of
any such device within the village limits between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M., except on Saturdays, Sundays and
holidays when such device shall only be used or operated between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M., and the term of any
license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be for not more than two (2) days in any given calendar year, except as otherwise provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 09-3515, 5-26-2009)
3-12-7: WAIVER OF FEES, HOURS AND DAYS OF OPERATION:
The village manager, or his or her designee, may waive: a) the license fees applicable under this chapter; and/or b) the limitations as to days and hours of
operation required under this chapter; provided, that such waiver(s) may be granted to a unit of local government and/or to a not for profit entity ("a
qualified entity") and shall only be granted upon good cause shown, which good cause may include, but shall not be limited to, the status of the applicant
as a qualified entity. Qualified entities seeking such fee waiver(s) shall submit the form required in section 3-12-3 of this chapter and shall attach to it a
request for a waiver of the fee(s) and/or the time and day limitations hereof. Within fifteen (15) days of receipt by the village of the license application, the
village manager, or his or her designee, shall notify the qualified entity in writing whether the waiver has been approved or denied in whole or in part. The
village manager, or his or her designee, shall also have the authority to grant one or more waiver(s) to a licensee which is not a qualified entity, for good
cause shown, relative to the time and day limitations of this chapter. (Ord. 09-3515, 5-26-2009)
3-12-8: INDECENCY, FALSE REPRESENTATIONS PROHIBITED:
No licensee shall cause or permit to be emanated or emitted from any such device any lewd, obscene, profane, or indecent language or sounds, or any
false representation of any matter, product or project advertised thereby, the sale of which is prohibited by any law, ordinance or statute. (Ord. 09-3515, 5-
26-2009)
3-12-9: EXEMPTIONS FROM CHAPTER:
This chapter shall not apply to the use and/or operation of any device designed, intended and/or used for producing or reproducing sound when being
used in any public parade, or procession, in any fireworks display or as part of any special event which is operated under a license or permit issued by the
village in accordance with the applicable provisions of this code. (Ord. 09-3515, 5-26-2009)
3-12-10: APPROVAL AUTHORITY:
Any licensee or applicant for a license, the village manager, or his or her designee hereunder, and/or any other interested person, shall have the right to
have any decision of the village manager, or his or her designee, made pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, reviewed, reconsidered, and a final
decision thereon made by the corporate authorities of the village. (Ord. 09-3515, 5-26-2009)
Chapter 13
TAXICABS
(Rep. by Ord. 05-3264, 10-24-2005)
Chapter 14
JUNK DEALERS
3-14-1: DEFINITION:
For purposes of this chapter, a "junk dealer" shall be defined as any person, firm or corporation who collects, procures, obtains and/or sells items which
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 178/522
have been discarded, thrown away or set out for collection by the village garbage collection contractor, or any other garbage collection service. (1973
Code § 13-184)
3-14-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Every junk dealer shall obtain all licenses required of such junk dealer and pay such fees for said licenses as are set forth herein. It shall be unlawful to
operate or carry on the business of junk dealer without having obtained a license therefor as is herein provided. (1973 Code § 13-184)
3-14-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for junk dealers' licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of the ordinances relating to licenses. (1973 Code § 13-185)
3-14-4: LICENSE FEE:
The fee to be paid for a junk dealer's license for an annual license shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-
23-2009)
3-14-5: LOST OR STOLEN GOODS:
Every junk dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things which may have been lost or stolen shall, upon demand, produce
such article or thing to any member of the police department asking to examine the same. (1973 Code § 13-188)
3-14-6: PICKING UP RECYCLABLES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to collect, obtain, possess or pick up any recyclable item placed for collection in front of a residence as part of the
village recycling program. All junk dealer licenses issued within the village shall contain a statement in regard to this restriction. (1973 Code § 13-187)
3-14-7: INFORMATION REQUIRED ON VEHICLES:
Each vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible characters the name and address of the owner and
proprietor thereof. (1973 Code § 13-189)
Chapter 15
GOING OUT OF BUSINESS SALES
3-15-1: FINDINGS AND DECLARATION:
Sales to be licensed and regulated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter are on occasion conducted and advertised in such a manner as to mislead
the public and otherwise to result in harm to the public interest. Such imposition on the public has included, by way of partial enumeration only: the
misrepresentation of the condition or necessity which is the occasion of such sale; the misrepresentation of the identity of the person conducting such sale
and/or the name and style in which such sale is to be conducted; and the excessive valuation and misrepresentation of the quality and ownership of goods
to be sold at such a sale. In order to prevent such fraud and imposition, the public interest requires the regulation of such sales and of the duration and
conduct thereof, and the public interest, therefore, requires that no such sale should be conducted without a license or otherwise than in accordance with
this chapter. (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-2004)
3-15-2: DEFINITIONS:
In this chapter, unless the context or subject matter otherwise requires:
BUSINESS: The activity of selling goods.
GOING OUT OF BUSINESS SALE: Any sale, whether described by such name or by any other name (such as, but not limited to, "closing out sale",
"liquidation sale", "lost our lease sale", "forced to vacate sale"), held in such a manner as to induce a belief that upon disposal of the stock of goods on
hand, the business will cease and be discontinued at the premises where the sale is conducted.
GOODS: Includes all goods, wares, merchandise, commodities, and other personal property, excepting choses in action and money.
PERSON: Includes a person, firm, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, association, or any other entity, or two (2) or more persons having a
joint or common interest.
REMOVAL SALE: Any sale held in such a manner as to induce a belief that upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease and be
discontinued at the premises where the sale is conducted, and thereafter will be moved to and occupy another location. (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-2004)
3-15-3: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 179/522
No person shall directly or indirectly advertise or cause to be advertised, represent or cause to be represented, or hold out to the public in any manner that
any sale of goods is an insurance, salvage, removal, going out of business, insolvent's, assignee's, or creditor's sale of goods, or that it is a sale of goods
which have been damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, unless such person shall first have obtained a license to conduct such sale under one of
such descriptive names from the village clerk if such sale is to be conducted in the village provided, however, that this chapter shall not apply to any sales
directly ordered by any court or referee in bankruptcy, or to any person acting under the direction and supervision of state or federal courts in the course of
their official duties; and further provided that this chapter shall not apply to any sales by a person regularly engaged in insurance or salvage sales of
goods, or sale of goods which have been damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, who acquired the goods for the account of others as a result of fire
or other casualty. (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-2004)
3-15-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; CONTENTS; INVENTORY:
Any applicant for a license under this chapter shall file an application in writing and under oath with the village clerk setting out the following facts and
information regarding such a proposed sale:
A. The name and address of the applicant for the license, who must be the owner of the goods to be sold, and in addition, if the applicant is a partnership,
corporation, firm or association, the name and position of the individual filing such application.
B. The name and style in which such sale is to be conducted, and the address where such sale is to be conducted.
C. The dates and period of time during which the sale is to be conducted.
D. The name and address of the person or persons who will be in charge of and responsible for the conduct of such sale.
E. A full explanation with regard to the condition or necessity which is the occasion for such sale, including a statement of the descriptive name of the sale
and the reasons why such name is truthfully descriptive of the sale. If the application is for a license to conduct a going out of business sale, it shall
also contain a statement that the business will be discontinued at the premises where the sale is to be conducted upon termination of the sale. If the
application is for a license to conduct a removal sale, it shall also contain a statement that the business will be discontinued at the premises where the
sale is to be conducted upon termination of the sale, in addition to the location of the premises to which the business is to be moved. If the application
is for a license to conduct a sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, it shall also contain a statement as to the time, location and
cause of such damage.
F. A full, detailed and complete inventory of the goods that are to be sold, which inventory shall:
1. Itemize the goods to be sold and contain sufficient information concerning each item, including make and brand name, if any, to clearly identify it;
2. List separately any goods which were purchased during a sixty (60) day period immediately prior to the date of making application for the license;
and
3. Show the cost price of each item in the inventory together with the name and address of the seller of the item to the applicant, the date of the
purchase, the date of the delivery of each item to the applicant and the total value of the inventory at cost.
G. A statement that no goods will be added to the inventory after the application is made or during the sale and that the inventory contains no goods
received on consignment.
H. A statement that the applicant has in the past maintained a place of business within the village of Barrington for not less than four (4) months prior to
the time of making application for such license. However this subsection shall not apply to any applicant who acquired a right, title or interest in the
goods as:
1. An heir, legatee or surviving joint tenant, or
2. An executor, administrator, trustee, or guardian, or
3. Pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction.
I. The application for license shall be subscribed and sworn to under oath by the applicant and shall, directly above the space reserved for the signature of
the applicant, contain the following legend in at least 10 point bold type: "Warning to applicant. This application must be fully and accurately completed.
False or misleading statements may subject applicant to the penalties of perjury in addition to other penalties provided by law." (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-
2004)
3-15-5: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; RESTRICTIONS:
A. The village clerk, upon receipt of an application giving fully and completely the information under oath as required by section 3-15-4 of this chapter and
upon receipt of the fee hereinafter provided for, shall issue a license to the applicant therefor, authorizing such applicant to advertise, represent, and to
sell the particular goods so inventoried at the time and place stated in the application and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The license
shall be issued in duplicate and shall bear a number and date of its expiration. A license issued under this chapter shall be granted and valid only for
the sale of the inventoried goods which are the property of the licensee. Such license shall apply only to the premises specified in the application, and it
may not be transferred or assigned. If a licensee under this chapter is engaged in business in other locations, advertising or offering of goods on behalf
of such locations shall not represent or imply any participation in or cooperation with the sale on the premises specified in the license, nor shall any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 180/522
advertising or any other offering of goods on behalf of the premises where the licensed sale is being conducted represent or imply any participation in
or cooperation with such sale at other locations;
B. No license under this chapter shall be issued to any person to conduct a sale in the trade name or style of a person in whose goods the applicant for the
license has acquired a right or title thereto within six (6) months prior to the time of making application for such a license, and no person shall conduct a
sale in the trade name or style of a person in whose goods the person has acquired a right or title thereto within six (6) months prior to such sale;
C. No license under this chapter shall be issued to any person to continue a sale in the name of a licensee under this chapter, in whose goods such
person acquired a right or title while such a sale is in progress, and no person shall continue a sale in the name of a licensee under this chapter, in
whose goods such person acquired a right or title while such a sale is in progress; or
D. No license under this chapter shall be issued to any person to conduct a sale, other than an insurance sale, a salvage sale or a sale of damaged goods,
on the same premises or anywhere within the village within one year from the conclusion of a prior sale of the nature covered by this chapter, and no
person shall conduct a sale, other than an insurance sale, a salvage sale or a sale of damaged goods, on the same premises or anywhere within the
village within one year from the conclusion of a prior sale of the nature covered by this chapter.
Subsections B, C and D of this section as set forth shall not apply to any person who acquired a right, title or interest in goods as an heir, legatee or
pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-2004)
3-15-6: RECORD OF APPLICATION:
The village clerk, when issuing a license under this chapter, shall endorse upon each such application the date of its filing and shall preserve it, and the
inventory attached to it, as a public record of his office, and shall make a notation of it in a book to be kept for that purpose, properly indexed, showing the
name of the applicant, the date of the application, the descriptive name of the proposed sale, the place where such sale is to be conducted, its duration,
the date of the license issued thereon, and the total value of the goods thus to be sold. A copy of the inventory shall be available for public inspection in
the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-2004)
3-15-7: SALES AS BANKRUPT, ETC.:
It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise, or otherwise to represent, for sale, or to sell, any goods at a bankruptcy, executor's, administrator's,
receiver's or trustee's sale, except pursuant to, and in compliance with, federal or state statutory authority or judicial process, or as an assignee's or
insolvent's sale except when there is a bona fide assignment for the benefit of creditors. (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-2004)
3-15-8: DURATION OF SALE; LICENSE FEE; RESTRICTIONS ON FURTHER SALES:
A. A license to conduct a sale issued pursuant to this chapter shall not be issued or valid for a period of more than sixty (60) days from the start of such
sale, and such sale may be conducted only during the period set forth in such license; provided, however, that such license may be renewed once only
for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days upon affidavit of the licensee that the goods listed in the inventory have not been disposed of and that no new
goods have been or will be added to the inventory previously filed pursuant to this chapter, by purchase, acquisition on consignment or otherwise. The
application for renewal of the license shall be made not more than fourteen (14) days prior to the time of the expiration of the license and shall contain
a new inventory of the goods remaining on hand at the time the application for renewal is made, which new inventory shall be prepared and furnished
in the same manner and form as the original inventory. No renewal shall be granted if any goods have been added to the stock listed in the inventory
since the date of the issuance of the license. A fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code shall accompany an application for a
license and for the renewal of a license.
B. Upon expiration of a license to conduct a sale pursuant to this chapter and after any approved renewal thereof as authorized by this chapter, the
business shall not be reopened anywhere within the village in the same name or by any person that directly or indirectly owned or operated that
business, for a period of at least one year thereafter, and neither the person who held such license, nor any person who directly or indirectly had an
interest in any entity which held such license, shall again transact business within the village, directly or indirectly, under the same ownership and/or
under the same name for a period of at least one year from the date of the final expiration of said license. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-2009)
3-15-9: COPY OF APPLICATION, INVENTORY AND LICENSE TO BE POSTED; LICENSE TO BE REFERRED TO IN
ADVERTISEMENTS:
A copy of the application for a license to conduct a sale under this chapter, including the inventory filed therewith, shall be posted in a conspicuous place in
the sale room or place where the inventoried goods are to be sold, so that the public may be informed of the facts relating to the goods before purchasing
same; provided, however, that such copy need not show the purchase price of the goods. The duplicate copy of a license issued hereunder shall be
attached to the front door of the premises where the sale is conducted in such a manner that it be clearly visible from the street. Any advertisement or
announcement published in connection with the sale shall conspicuously show on its face the number of the license and the date of its expiration. (Ord.
04-3148, 4-26-2004)
3-15-10: SUBSTITUTION, ADDITION AND COMMINGLING OF GOODS; LICENSE VOID; CERTAIN PURCHASES PROHIBITED:
Any substitution for or addition to goods described in an inventory filed pursuant to this chapter, or any change in the time or place for a sale conducted
pursuant to this chapter, shall be unlawful and shall void any license issued to conduct a sale pursuant to this chapter, and such license shall cease to
apply to such sale. In the case of a sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, or in the case of an insurance sale or a salvage sale, the
goods to be sold at such sale shall be clearly and distinctly segregated, marked or identified, and advertised, if at all, so that both on display and in
advertising such goods may be readily distinguished from other stocks, and their identity readily ascertained. Any commingling of such goods with other
stocks of the licensee in such a manner to cause the goods to lose their separate identity, either on display or in advertising, shall be unlawful and shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 181/522
void any license issued to conduct such a sale pursuant to this chapter, and such license shall cease to apply to such sale.
No person in contemplation of conducting any going out of business, removal, assignee's or creditor's sale, or during the continuance of such a sale, shall
order or purchase any goods for the purpose of selling them at such sale, and any unusual purchase, or additions to the stock of such goods within sixty
(60) days before the filing of such application for a license to conduct such a sale, shall be presumptive evidence that such purchases or additions were
made in contemplation of such sale and for the purpose of selling them at such sale. (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-2004)
3-15-11: VIOLATIONS:
A. The village may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enjoin a sale subject to this chapter when the sale is being conducted without a
license issued under this chapter.
B. Any person, including both the applicant and an individual filing on behalf of an applicant, who shall procure from the village clerk a license to conduct a
sale under the description of one of the names set out in section 3-15-3 of this chapter, which name shall be a misrepresentation of the true description
or character of such sale or of the kind or condition of goods to be sold under such license, or any such person violating any of the other provisions of
this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code, and every day such violation continues shall constitute a separate and
distinct offense. Each false statement of fact in an application or inventory required to be filed hereunder shall constitute a separate offense under this
chapter. (Ord. 04-3148, 4-26-2004)
Chapter 16
AUTOMATIC DRY CLEANING MACHINES
3-16-1: DEFINITION:
An "automatic dry cleaning machine", as the term is used herein, shall be construed to include and mean any device or apparatus for the cleaning of
clothes or fabrics, and designed to be used or operated by any person other than the owner, or an employee of the owner, which machine or device makes
use of or contains perchlorethylene or any other chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to human beings by reason of inhalation or contact.
(1973 Code § 13-223)
3-16-2: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
It shall be unlawful to install, operate or maintain any "automatic dry cleaning machine", as herein defined, except in compliance with the provisions of this
chapter, or without complying with all of the provisions pertaining to the installation and operation of such machine herein contained, or in violation of any
laws, rules, or regulations of the Illinois department of public health relating thereto. (1973 Code § 13-224)
3-16-3: INSTALLATION PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to install any automatic dry cleaning machine without first having secured a permit therefor.
B. Application For Permit: Applications for such permits shall contain full information as to the mechanical equipment of such machine and provisions for
ventilation for both the machine and the room in which the machine will be located.
C. Permit Fee: The fee for such permit shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each unit or machine. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-
2009)
D. Digital Data Standards: All submittals to the village and/or to any engineer, architect, surveyor, or other consultant retained by the village as required by
this title shall comply with the village's digital data standards set forth in title 1, chapter 16, "Digital Data Standards", of this code. (Ord. 09-3536, 8-17-
2009)
3-16-4: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of maintaining any automatic dry cleaning machine for use by the public upon payment
of a fee, without having first secured a license therefor.
B. License Fees: The annual fee for such license shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-2009)
3-16-5: OPERATION REGULATIONS:
A. Equipment Requirements: No automatic dry cleaning machine shall be operated unless all the equipment is properly installed and in good operating
condition.
B. Waste Disposal: It shall be unlawful to permit any residue containing solvent to flow into the sewerage system of the village; tightly covered approved
containers may be used for temporary storage of such waste outside the building. Such containers shall bear labels indicating the contents and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 182/522
dangers involved in handling, and shall be locked if in an unenclosed place. (1973 Code § 13-228; amd. 2003 Code)
C. Signs Posted:
1. There shall be warning signs posted in places of easy observation warning of the dangers in the event leakage of liquids, gas or vapor occurs.
2. At least one legible sign shall be maintained in a place available to customers giving the name, address and phone number of the owner of the
establishment, and of the service department or agency responsible for the proper maintenance of the machines.
D. Attendant On Duty: No establishment for which a license is required under this chapter shall be open for business, and it shall be unlawful to admit the
public or customers into the room where such machines are located, unless there is on duty in the establishment at all times a competent person in
charge of the establishment and in charge of the operation of such machines. (1973 Code § 13-228)
3-16-6: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the village manager to cause such inspections to be made as are necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter. (1973 Code § 13-229)
Chapter 17
MOTELS
3-17-1: DEFINITION:
The term "motel", as used in this chapter, shall be construed to mean any parking lot or garage for the accommodation of motor vehicles where transient
sleeping accommodations are afforded or provided on the same premises for the public or for the occupants of such automobiles. Provided, that a hotel
which furnishes parking space or has a garage in connection with the hotel shall not be construed as a "motel". (1973 Code § 13-236)
3-17-2: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a motel in the village without having first obtained a license therefor or without complying with all of the provisions
of this chapter. (1973 Code § 13-237)
3-17-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; PLANS:
Each applicant for a license to operate or maintain a motel shall file an application with the clerk, and shall state thereon the name and address of the
applicant, name and address of the owner or manager thereof, location of the motel, and the maximum number of persons and vehicles to be
accommodated. This application shall be accompanied by plans of the toilet, bath and washbasin facilities, slop sinks, water faucets, sewer connections,
driveways and other improvements. (1973 Code § 13-238)
3-17-4: LICENSE FEE AND TERM:
The annual license fee for any motel license shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, and the license year shall be the same
as that provided for general business licenses in the village1. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-2009)
3-17-5: BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
A. Firewalls Near Parking Areas: No parking space shall be provided for motor vehicles within ten feet (10') of any building or structure used for housing
accommodations in a motel unless the wall facing such parking space is constructed of fireproof materials and unless the windows in such wall, if any,
are equipped with reinforced fire resistant glass. (1973 Code § 13-239)
B. Sanitary Facilities: No premises shall be operated as a motel unless it is equipped with adequate toilet and other sanitary facilities to serve the total
number of persons accommodated therein. All such sanitary facilities shall be properly connected with the sanitary sewerage system of the village if the
premises are located on a street served by such sewer. (1973 Code § 13-241)
C. Cleanliness Of Premises: A motel premises must be kept clean and sanitary at all times, and all waste material must be removed therefrom at least
once every twenty four (24) hours. (1973 Code § 13-243)
D. Lighting: Any area or premises of a motel open to use by the public or by all persons staying in or being accommodated in the motel shall be kept
adequately lighted at nighttime; provided, that such lights must be so shaded or otherwise regulated so as to prevent them from shining upon any
adjacent premises. (1973 Code § 13-246)
3-17-6: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 183/522
It shall be unlawful to permit any violation of any ordinance or law on or in any motel, and it shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any motel or any
portion thereof for immoral purposes. (1973 Code §§ 13-242, 13-245)
3-17-7: INSPECTIONS:
The chief of police shall inspect or cause to be inspected each motel to see to the compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (1973 Code § 13-244)
Chapter 18
PARKING LOTS
3-18-1: LOCATION:
No parking lot shall be established or operated in any place where such establishment or operation would be in violation of a zoning or any other
ordinance. (1973 Code § 13-276)
3-18-2: DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Vehicle To Square Footage Ratio: Not more than one car for each two hundred (200) square feet of area shall be accepted for parking in any parking
lot. (1973 Code § 13-277)
B. Marking Of Spaces; Entrances, Exits And Wheel Barriers Provided: Each parking lot shall be marked so as to show the parking place allotted for each
car, and shall have sufficient entrances and exits to permit the entrance and egress of cars without obstructions to traffic. Where parking places abut on
or exist so near public sidewalks that motor vehicles can extend over or be driven on or over such sidewalk, the owner or operator of the lot shall place
or erect wheel stops or other suitable barriers to prevent motor vehicles from extending over sidewalks when parked or being driven on or over public
sidewalks at points other than designated driveways. (1973 Code § 13-278)
C. Surface Of Lot: It shall be unlawful to operate a parking lot unless the surface thereof is covered with concrete, asphalt, macadam or similar paving, and
such parking lot shall at all times be kept clean and free from dust or refuse, and adequately drained. (1973 Code § 13-285)
D. Driveways: No driveway to a parking lot shall be constructed except in full compliance with the ordinances relative to the issuance of permits for
driveways, and it shall be the duty of the operator of each parking lot to maintain the sidewalk and parkway over which such driveway passes in good
condition. (1973 Code § 13-279)
3-18-3: BUILDINGS ON LOTS:
Any buildings constructed on a parking lot shall be constructed in full compliance with the ordinances pertaining thereto, and shall have exterior walls of
nonflammable material; provided, that any structure used or to be used for office purposes only may have less than the minimum area requirements
prescribed for residences or commercial buildings. (1973 Code § 13-286)
3-18-4: OPERATION REGULATIONS:
A. Attendant Required: There shall be at least one attendant on the premises of all public parking lots charging hourly rates for parking, except those
operated by the village, at all times during which the parking lot is open for business. (1973 Code § 13-282)
B. Rates And Hours Posted: At the entrance of each public parking lot charging an hourly rate for parking, except those operated by the village, there shall
be posted in words and figures large enough to be read by prospective patrons a statement of the rates to be charged and of the closing hours. (1973
Code § 13-281)
3-18-5: DRIVE IN RESTAURANT LOTS; CLEANLINESS REQUIRED:
If a parking lot is maintained in connection with a licensed establishment serving food for consumption on the premises, and food or drinks are served to
the occupants of cars, sufficient adequate containers must be maintained for all trash and refuse, and the premises must be kept thoroughly clean by the
proprietor. (1973 Code § 13-283)
3-18-6: CERTAIN VEHICLES AND USES PROHIBITED:
A. Inoperable, Junked Vehicles; Display For Sale; Repair Shops: It shall be unlawful to park or store, in any parking lot, any vehicle which is not in a
condition ready for use, or to permit the parking of any abandoned, junked or partially disabled vehicle in any such lot, and it shall be unlawful to use
any parking lot for storage or parking of any vehicle for the purpose of displaying the same for sale, or to use any parking lot or portion thereof as an
automobile repair shop. (1973 Code § 13-287)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 184/522
B. Intoxicating Liquors: It shall be unlawful to serve intoxicating liquor for consumption in any car parked in a parking lot, and it shall be unlawful for any
person in a car parked in a parking lot to drink any intoxicating liquor while therein. (1973 Code § 13-284)
3-18-7: OTHER BUSINESSES ON PREMISES:
If any business other than that of operating a parking lot is conducted on the same premises with a parking lot, such business shall be conducted in full
compliance with all ordinances pertinent thereto, and any license required for the operation of such business must be procured and the fee therefor
required must be paid. (1973 Code § 13-280)
Chapter 19
SCAVENGERS
3-19-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; NUMBER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavenger, or the collection or disposal of animal, human or vegetable refuse, or offal,
without having first secured a permit therefor. Not more than one such permit shall be issued in the village. (1973 Code § 13-294; amd. 2003 Code)
3-19-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; APPROVAL:
Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be made to the village clerk and shall be referred by him to the corporate authorities. No such permit
shall be issued except on order of the corporate authorities. (1973 Code § 13-295; amd. 2003 Code)
3-19-3: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
Any vehicle used by a scavenger in his business shall be watertight and equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the transportation
of refuse and shall have printed on both sides of the vehicle, the name of the business and the phone number thereof. (1973 Code § 13-296; amd. 2003
Code)
3-19-4: VEHICLE OPERATION ON SUNDAY PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle used by a scavenger in his business to be driven over or through any street in the village on a Sunday. (1973 Code
§ 13-296)
Chapter 20
TREE EXPERTS
3-20-1: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of tree removal, tree trimming, tree spraying or tree treatment in the village without first having registered
with the village. (1973 Code § 13-304; amd. 2003 Code)
3-20-2: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
A tree expert who registers with the village, as provided in section 3-20-1 of this chapter, shall provide a certificate of insurance conditioned to indemnify
the village and hold it harmless against any claim for injury or damages caused by the tree trimming, spraying, or removal. (1973 Code § 13-305; amd.
2003 Code)
3-20-3: PERMISSION REQUIRED TO WORK ON PUBLIC TREES:
No tree trimmer or sprayer shall trim or spray any tree on any public parkway or other property owned by the village without the written permission of the
director of public works. (1973 Code § 13-307; amd. 2003 Code)
3-20-4: REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
Any certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked as provided in chapter 1 of this title for repeated violations of any of the
provisions hereof, or of any other ordinance relating to the work done. (1973 Code § 13-309; amd. 2003 Code)
Chapter 21
OUTSIDE SPRAY PAINTING AND SANDBLASTING
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 185/522
3-21-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to engage in a business of outside spray painting or sandblasting in the village without first having obtained a license therefor. (1973
Code § 13-330)
3-21-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring a license under this chapter shall file an application therefor in compliance with the general provisions of this code relating to licenses
and permits. (1973 Code § 13-332)
3-21-3: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for licenses granted under this chapter shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, and the license year shall be
the same as that provided for general business licenses in the village1. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-2009)
3-21-4: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No license shall be issued unless the applicant files with the director of public works evidence of a public liability policy or certificate of insurance in the
amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) conditioned to indemnify the village and hold it harmless against any claim for injury or damages
caused by outside spray painting or sandblasting. (1973 Code § 13-333)
3-21-5: ISSUANCE AND SCOPE OF LICENSE:
A license under this chapter shall be issued upon the payment of a license fee, as provided herein, to the village clerk and shall permit the use of any such
outside spray painting or sandblasting equipment only for the period specified on the license. (1973 Code § 13-334)
Chapter 22
ABOVEGROUND FUEL STORAGE TANKS1
3-22-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to install, erect, construct, operate, use or maintain an aboveground fuel tank for the storage of flammable or combustible liquids
without having first obtained a license therefor. (Ord. 03-3050, 1-13-2003)
3-22-2: LICENSE FEE AND APPLICATION; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
The annual license fee for each license issued under this chapter shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code and application shall
be made in compliance with the general provisions of this code relating to licenses and permits. In addition, no license shall be issued under this chapter
unless the applicant has complied with all of the provisions of this chapter. Each application must be submitted on forms provided by the village. (Ord. 09-
3500, 2-23-2009)
3-22-3: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No license shall be issued unless the applicant files with the village evidence of a public liability policy or certificate of insurance in the minimum amount of
five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) to provide coverage on account of injury to persons, loss of life, or damage arising out of or consequent upon
the installation, erection, construction, operation, use or maintenance of the aboveground fuel storage tank licensed hereunder. (Ord. 03-3050, 1-13-2003)
3-22-4: TANK REQUIREMENTS:
No license shall be issued to permit the installation of an aboveground fuel storage tank for the storage of flammable or combustible liquids unless each of
the following requirements have been satisfied: (Ord. 03-3050, 1-13-2003)
A. State Regulations Adopted: The tank shall meet the standards pertaining to tanks and associated piping set forth in regulations promulgated by the
office of the Illinois state fire marshal as part 160 and all of the sections thereunder and as part 180 and all of sections thereunder, both in chapter 1 in
title 41 in the Illinois administrative code. All of the aforesaid regulations are hereby incorporated by reference. Copies of said regulations are on file in
the office of the fire department for public use and inspection. (2003 Code; amd. Ord. 03-3050, 1-13-2003)
B. Zoning Ordinance Regulations: The tank shall conform to the regulations of the Barrington zoning ordinance and appendix N of the Barrington zoning
ordinance.
C. Fire Code Requirements: The tank shall conform to the requirements of the Barrington fire code. (Ord. 03-3050, 1-13-2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 186/522
D. Digital Data Standards: All submittals to the village and/or to any engineer, architect, surveyor, or other consultant retained by the village as required by
this title shall comply with the village's digital data standards set forth in title 1, chapter 16, "Digital Data Standards", of this code. (Ord. 09-3536, 8-17-
2009)
3-22-5: INSPECTIONS:
For purposes of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, the building official or fire official shall have the authority, at reasonable times, and upon
reasonable oral notice, to enter any premises in the village in or upon which any aboveground fuel storage tank subject to this chapter is located, to
inspect the same, provided, however, that no oral notice shall be required when representatives of the village of Barrington have cause to believe that an
emergency situation requiring a prompt response exists in or around the tank. At least one such on site inspection for each licensed aboveground fuel
storage tank shall be performed during each license year. (Ord. 03-3050, 1-13-2003)
3-22-6: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If an inspection by the village building official or fire official or any other authorized village official reveals that any tank is not installed, maintained, used or
operated in accordance with any of the requirements of section 3-22-4 of this chapter, or if any other provision of this chapter is violated, the village
manager shall immediately suspend the license and if the violation(s) are not corrected within fifteen (15) days of the notice thereof, the village manager
shall immediately revoke the license. Upon the occurrence of a condition causing the license to be suspended, if the condition constitutes an emergency
necessitating emergency action, which emergency action shall include, but not be limited to, the removal of the stored liquid from the tank, the village is
authorized to take remedial action, the cost of which shall be chargeable to the licensee. (Ord. 03-3050, 1-13-2003)
3-22-7: REMOVAL OF TANKS:
If an aboveground tank is not used for a period of one hundred eighty five (185) days, or if a license has been revoked by the village manager, then such
tank must be removed immediately after the revocation of the license and within thirty (30) days of notice that the use of a tank has been discontinued for
one hundred eighty five (185) days. (Ord. 03-3050, 1-13-2003)
Chapter 23
BED AND BREAKFAST ESTABLISHMENTS
3-23-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful in the village for any person, either directly or indirectly, to operate a bed and breakfast establishment without first having obtained a
license to do so. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-2: APPLICATION:
A. Applications for all licenses to operate a bed and breakfast establishment shall be made in writing to the village clerk on forms provided by the clerk's
office in the absence of a provision to the contrary.
1. Each application shall state:
a. The name of the applicant;
b. Whether the applicant is an individual, partnership or corporation; if an individual, the name and the residence (and any business) address of the
applicant; if a partnership, the name and any business and residence address of each partner, including limited partners; if a corporation, the
name, state under which corporation was organized, the names and business and residence addresses of the officers, directors and managers in
charge of any local facility thereof;
c. The permit or license desired;
d. The location or mailing address to be used (if any), and all telephone numbers which may be used;
e. Whether the premises are owned or leased by the applicant; and if leased, the name and residence and business addresses of each owner or part
owner thereof;
f. The time period involved;
g. The activity to be licensed;
h. The fee to be paid; and
i. The number of employees or agents.
2. Each application shall contain such additional information as may be required or may be necessary to provide for the proper guidance of village
officials in the issuance of the license. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-3: PERSONS SUBJECT TO LICENSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 187/522
Every person shall be subject to the requirements for a license if, by himself or through an agent or employee, he holds himself forth as being engaged in
the operation of a bed and breakfast establishment; or solicits patronage therefor; or performs or attempts to perform any such business in the village.
Licenses are not transferable. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-4: INVESTIGATIONS:
A. After an application for a license or permit has been completed by the applicant, investigations and/or inspections are hereby required by the fire
department, the village health official or the applicable health department that provides inspections for the village and the building and zoning officer
before the issuance of such license. The village clerk shall refer the application to the appropriate official(s) for the making of such investigation and/or
inspection. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003; amd. Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
B. The official(s) to whom the application has been referred shall promptly make a report thereon.
C. All investigative and/or inspection reports shall be furnished to the village clerk who shall evaluate the same and seek additional information if required.
D. After consideration of the application and the related investigative reports, if the village clerk determines that the application complies with the code and
all applicable statutes, and if the required fee has been paid, the license shall be issued. If not, the applicant shall be advised that the license has been
denied.
The clerk shall deny a license if it can be determined that the applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading or fraudulent statement of fact in the
application or in any documents required by the village in connection therewith. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-5: LICENSE FEE AND PERIOD OF LICENSE:
A. The administrative fee for the original application for a bed and breakfast establishment license shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1
of this code and the administrative fee for each application for a renewal of such license shall be as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this
code. All fees shall be paid at the time each application is submitted to the village. No application shall be processed without the payment in full of the
applicable fees even if the application is made for a period of less than a full year. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-2009)
B. In order to obtain the license required by the provisions of this chapter, the applicant for such license shall pay to the village clerk (or to the health
department of the inspecting county, as appropriate), the actual cost of the minimum number of required inspections based on the schedule of fees and
of inspections adopted by the appropriate county or the village as the case may be. The foregoing inspection fee shall be in addition to the
administrative fee set forth in subsection A of this section. If the inspection is performed by the health official of the village, the inspection cost shall be
an amount equal to the amount that would have been charged by the county in which the premises upon which the bed and breakfast establishment is
located as if the county had performed the inspection in addition to the administrative fee set forth in subsection A of this section.
In the event that a reinspection is deemed necessary in either county by the applicable county health department and/or by the health official of the
village, the payment of reinspection fees shall be a condition of issuance, reissuance or continuance of the license required. The cost of any and all
reinspections shall be paid by the applicant or holder of the license. For each reinspection required, the applicant or holder of the license shall pay to
the village clerk the amount charged by the appropriate county health department according to the schedule of fees established by that department,
plus an administrative fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. If the reinspection is performed by the health official of the
village, the applicant or holder of the license shall pay to the village clerk an amount equal to the amount that would have been charged by the county
in which the premises upon which the bed and breakfast establishment is located as if the county had performed the reinspection in addition to the
administrative fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each reinspection. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
C. Commencing with May 1, 2003, each license year shall commence on May 1 of each year and shall expire on April 30 of the following year unless an
application is submitted after May 1 for any year (but before April 30 in the following year) in which case the license shall commence when issued but
shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance. Thereafter, licenses may be renewed for successive one year periods. (Ord. 09-3500, 2-23-
2009)
3-23-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
The bed and breakfast establishment license shall be displayed in an open and conspicuous place in the premises to be licensed. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-
2003)
3-23-7: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
No license shall be issued for the operation of a bed and breakfast establishment if the premises and building to be used for this purpose does not fully
comply with all applicable ordinances and regulations of the village and the state of Illinois including, but not limited to, all building and life safety codes
and to the zoning ordinance. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-8: LOCATION:
No license for the operation of a bed and breakfast establishment in the village shall be construed to permit the operation of a bed and breakfast
establishment in more than one location in the village. A separate license shall be required for each location. For the purpose of this chapter "one location"
means that all buildings containing the principal or accessory uses shall be connected or on the same lot or parcel, be operated and managed by the same
person or owner, and that the business be in an establishment with the same classification. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 188/522
3-23-9: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
The location of any licensed bed and breakfast establishment shall not be changed unless an application for each such new location including the
payment of all fees therefor is submitted and approved. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-10: NUISANCE:
Any location used as a bed and breakfast establishment in violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-11: INSPECTIONS:
A. Licensed premises shall be maintained in a clean, safe and lawful manner and shall be inspected by the village periodically, but not less than annually,
to assure compliance with this code and all applicable laws and regulations. It shall be a prior condition of the acceptance of such a license from the
village that the holder agrees to such inspections. It shall be the duty of the licensee or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected to admit,
for the purpose of making the inspection, any officer or employee of the village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection.
B. Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure performance with any ordinance provision or to detect violations
thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected to give, upon official request, to any authorized
officer or employee of the village, samples of such material or commodity for such analysis. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-12: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
A. Any license issued for a bed and breakfast establishment may be suspended for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days by the village manager upon
written notice to the license holder, which notice shall state a basis or charge. The notice shall be served by mailing a copy thereof by regular U.S. mail,
addressed to the licensee at the address of the licensed premises and shall be deemed served on the date of mailing (the "service date") and by
delivering a copy of the notice to the owner of the licensed premises or to any other manager or employee on the licensed premises. The license holder
may request in writing a hearing before the village manager within ten (10) days of the service date. If a written request for a hearing is not made within
ten (10) days of the service date, the village manager may suspend any license for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days for any of the reasons
hereinafter set forth in the provisions of this subsection. Upon receiving a timely written request therefor, the village manager shall conduct the hearing
and may suspend a license for a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days if any of the provisions of this chapter are violated or any employee of the
licensee is engaged in any conduct at licensee's place of business which violates any of the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinances of the
village relating to the license, the licensed premises, or any state law, or where any applicant has committed any fraud, misrepresentation or made a
false statement on an application for a license under this chapter or in any case where the licensee refuses to permit any duly authorized inspector on
behalf of the village to inspect the premises or the operations therein, or the failure or refusal to provide any product sampling or the failure or refusal of
the licensee to pay any fine, penalty or charge owed to the village, or in the event that the licensee would not now qualify for the issuance of a license
or the renewal thereof. The licensee shall be deemed to have actual or constructive knowledge of any violations hereinabove set forth if they occur on
the licensed premises by any person(s) acting as an agent or otherwise receiving compensation. Such license may also be suspended by the village
manager upon the recommendations of the health official that such business is being managed, conducted, or maintained without regard for the public
health or health of patrons or without due regard to proper sanitation or hygiene. The village prosecutor shall present the complaint. The licensee shall
be permitted to be represented by counsel and shall have the right to present any relevant evidence bearing on the alleged violations set forth in the
notice and to cross examine witnesses. A transcript shall be made of the hearing. After the hearing, the village manager shall render a decision
whether to suspend the license holder's license.
Any decision of the village manager to suspend a license may be appealed to the village president by the licensee by a request in writing therefor made
to the village president within ten (10) days of the issuance by the village manager of any order of suspension. The village president shall review the
record of the hearing held before the village manager if any was held or if no hearing was held, the basis for such order of suspension, and based upon
such review shall make a decision to either affirm or reverse the decision of the village manager to suspend the license. If the village president decides
to affirm the decision to suspend the license, he may also modify the term of the suspension provided that in no event shall the suspension exceed
thirty (30) days. Any suspension ordered by the provisions hereof shall be stayed until all administrative appeals made to officials of the village as
provided herein (and not including any appeal of a decision of a village official made to any court of competent jurisdiction) have been concluded. The
decision of the village president shall be final and subject to judicial review only by a court of competent jurisdiction to the extent otherwise provided by
law. (Ord. 12-3693, 6-25-2012)
B. Any license issued for a bed and breakfast establishment may be revoked by the village manager for any of the reasons hereinabove set forth in
subsection A of this section upon written notice to the license holder, which notice shall state a basis or charge. The notice shall be served by mailing a
copy thereof by regular U.S. mail, addressed to the licensee at the address of the licensed premises and shall be deemed served on the date of mailing
(the "service date") and by delivering a copy of the notice to the owner of the licensed premises or to any other manager or employee on the licensed
premises. Within ten (10) days of the service date, the licensee may request a hearing before the village manager. If a written request for a hearing is
not made within ten (10) days of the service date, the village manager shall determine whether or not to revoke any license as hereinafter provided.
Upon receiving a timely request made therefor, the village manager shall conduct a hearing. The village prosecutor shall present the complaint. The
licensee shall be permitted to be represented by counsel and shall have the right to present any relevant evidence bearing on the alleged violations set
forth in the notice and to cross examine witnesses. After the hearing, the village manager shall render a decision whether or not to revoke the license
holder's license. A transcript shall be made of the hearing.
C. The village manager may revoke a license for any of the reasons hereinabove set forth in subsection A of this section.
D. Any decision of the village manager to revoke a license may be appealed to the village president by the licensee by a request in writing therefor made
to the village president within ten (10) days of the issuance by the village manager of any order to revoke a license. The village president shall review
the record of the hearing held before the village manager, if any was held, or if no hearing was held, the basis for such order to revoke and based upon
such review shall make a decision to either affirm or reverse the decision of the village manager to revoke the license. Any order to revoke a license
shall be stayed until all administrative appeals made to officials of the village as provided herein (and not including any appeal of a decision of a village
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 189/522
official made to any court of competent jurisdiction) have been concluded. The decision of the village president shall be final and subject to judicial
review only by a court of competent jurisdiction to the extent otherwise provided by law.
E. Any licensee whose license has been revoked is barred from applying for a new license for a minimum period of one year from the date of revocation.
Any suspension or revocation of the license, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of any other penalties provided for the violation of
other applicable provisions of this chapter or other ordinances of the village. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-13: REVIEW OF DENIAL OF AN APPLICATION FOR A LICENSE:
The denial by the village clerk to issue a license for a bed and breakfast establishment pursuant to an application made therefor shall be subject to review
by the village manager provided that a request for such review is made in writing by the applicant to the village manager within ten (10) days of the
issuance of the written denial of the application. The village manager shall conduct a hearing to review the application submitted to the village by the
applicant, along with any and all investigations and/or any other reports of inspections made and of any other relevant facts and evidence determined. The
applicant may present any relevant evidence in support of his request that the denial of the application be reviewed and reversed. The village manager
shall determine whether the denial of the application shall be affirmed or whether the denial shall be reversed and the application approved. If the village
manager reverses the decision and approves the application, the license applied for shall be issued. The decision of the village manager to affirm the
denial of the application shall be final and subject to judicial review only by a court of competent jurisdiction to the extent otherwise provided by law. (Ord.
03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-14: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
Every person, whether acting as an individual owner, employee of the owner, operator or employee of the operator, or whether acting as a mere agent or
independent contractor for the owner, employee or operator, or acting as a participant or worker in any way directly or indirectly who operates a bed and
breakfast establishment without first obtaining a license or permit and paying a fee to do so from the village or who violates any provision of this chapter
shall be guilty of an ordinance violation and upon a finding of guilty or conviction such person shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate offense or ordinance violation shall be deemed committed on each day
during or upon which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 03-3056, 2-10-2003)
3-23-15: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
BED AND BREAKFAST ESTABLISHMENT: An owner occupied residence providing accommodations for a charge to the public with no more than five (5)
guest units for rent, in operation for more than ten (10) nights in a twelve (12) month period. Only the breakfast meal may be provided to the registered
guests. The service of food to the public for a charge is otherwise prohibited. Bed and breakfast establishments shall not include motels, hotels, boarding
houses, or food service establishments.
