b. A term of incarceration, either periodic or continuous, in a penal institution other than the penitentiary for a period not to exceed three hundred
sixty four (364) days as authorized by reference to the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code.
c. A term of supervision or conditional discharge as authorized by section 1-4-1 of this Village Code and by reference to the Illinois Motor Vehicle
Code and the Illinois Unified Code of Corrections. (Ord. 06-3332, 11-27-2006)
d. Penalty as provided in section 1-14-1 of this Village Code. (Ord. 18-3984, 1-8-2018)
2. It is not intended that any penalty for a violation of this Code exceed that which is permitted by law.
F. Interpretation: To the extent such amendments, modifications and/or additions or any other provisions of this Village Code are inconsistent with any of
the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code herein adopted, the more restrictive and specific regulation shall apply, but otherwise this Village Code shall
be so construed as to favor the effectiveness of the regulations and intent of the Illinois Vehicle Code. (Ord. 06-3332, 11-27-2006)
6-1-2: TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS:
A. Installation And Maintenance Of Traffic Control Devices: The Director of Public Works shall place and maintain traffic control signs, signals and devices
when and as required under the traffic ordinances of the Village to make effective the provisions of said ordinances, and, with the concurrence of the
Corporate Authorities, may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as he may deem necessary and as may be authorized by the
Corporate Authorities to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of the Village, under State law, or to guide or warn traffic. (1973 Code § 14-13; amd.
2003 Code)
B. Designation Of Crosswalks And Safety Zones: The Director of Public Works is hereby authorized:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 237/522
1. To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion
there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as he may deem necessary. (1973 Code § 14-14)
2. To establish safety zones upon resolution of the Corporate Authorities of such kind and character and at such places as they may deem necessary
for the protection of pedestrians. (1973 Code § 14-14; amd. 2003 Code)
C. Designation, Marking Of One-Way Streets: The Director of Public Works is authorized, subject to approval of the Corporate Authorities by resolution or
motion, to designate one-way streets, and he shall erect and maintain appropriate signs giving notice thereof. Signs indicating the direction of lawful
traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. (1973 Code § 14-18; amd. 2003
Code)
D. Authority To Place, Obedience To Turning Markers: The Director of Public Works is authorized to place markings or signs within or adjacent to
intersections indicating the course to be traveled. When authorized markings or signs are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be
traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indicators. (1973 Code § 14-15)
6-1-3: EMERGENCY AND EXPERIMENTAL REGULATIONS:
The Chief of Police is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the Village and to
make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. (1973 Code § 14-12)
6-1-4: VEHICLE LICENSES:
Every owner or operator or lessee of a motor vehicle or motor bicycle who resides within the Village and who desires to have a Village vehicle license or
who desires to make application for a permit to park such vehicle in certain designated commuter parking areas within the Village, the use of which is
restricted to persons residing in the BACOG (Barrington Area Council of Governments) community, shall apply to the Village Clerk for the issuance of a
Village vehicle license. Upon the presentation of an application upon forms designed by the Village Clerk and containing the name and address of the
applicant and upon providing reasonable proof of residency within the Village, the Village Clerk shall, for no fee, issue a license which qualifies the holder
thereof to make application for a permit to park such vehicle in the above described parking areas. (Ord. 99-2788, 4-26-1999; amd. 2003 Code)
6-1-5: REGULATIONS SAVED FROM REPEAL:
All ordinances which establish loading zones, bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands, through streets, one-way streets and alleys, school zones or which
prohibit or limit parking on certain streets, or which regulate turning, or any provision of traffic ordinances of the Village in effect prior to the passage of this
chapter shall remain in force and effect as fully as if this chapter had not been passed. (1973 Code § 14-297)
Chapter 2
ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES
6-2-1: ENFORCEMENT OF PROVISIONS:
The village police department shall enforce the provisions of this title and have the powers and duties enumerated herein. It shall be the duty of the police
department to enforce the street traffic regulations of the village and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the village, to make arrests for
traffic violations, to investigate accidents and to cooperate with other officers of the village in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways
and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out those duties especially imposed upon said police department by this chapter or other ordinances
of the village. (1973 Code §§ 14-2, 14-3)
6-2-2: VIOLATION NOTICES AND COMPLAINTS:
A. Forms: Traffic violation notice forms for notifying violators to appear and answer to charges of violating traffic laws and ordinances, and the
corresponding complaint forms therefor, shall be the uniform traffic ticket and complaint in serially numbered sets using the form required by the court
of venue. The chief of police shall be responsible for the issuance of such books and shall maintain or cause to be maintained a record of every such
book. (1973 Code § 14-298; amd. 2003 Code)
B. Records Kept:
1. Every police officer upon issuing a traffic violation notice to an alleged violator of any provision of the motor vehicle laws of the state or of any traffic
ordinance of the village shall deposit the corresponding traffic violation complaint of said notice with his immediate superior officer who shall cause
the same to be filed in circuit court.
2. The chief of police shall maintain or cause to be maintained in connection with every traffic violation notice issued by a member of the police
department of the village a record of the disposition of the charge.
3. It shall be unlawful and official misconduct for any police officer or other officer or public employee to dispose of a traffic violation notice or copies
thereof, a traffic violation complaint, or the record of the issuance of a traffic violation notice in a manner other than as required in this title. (1973
Code § 14-299)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 238/522
C. Illegal Cancellation: It shall be unlawful for any person to cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic violation notice or complaint in any manner other
than as provided in this title. (1973 Code § 14-300)
6-2-3: PARKING VIOLATIONS:
A. Notice On Illegally Parked Vehicle: Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking and
there is no person in attendance upon such parked vehicle to be arrested or served immediately with a traffic violation notice to appear in court or
administrative notice of violation to answer the charge of such violation, any police officer observing such violation may attach to the vehicle used in
such violation a written administrative notice of violation so that the person in whose name such vehicle is registered may appear in court or before the
village administrative hearing officer at a specified location on a certain day and at a designated courtroom or other specified location to be named in
such notice and answer to the charge of such violation. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the driver of the vehicle to which said notice is
attached, to remove the same from said vehicle.
B. Prima Facie Proof: Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any of the provisions of any ordinance or requirement of this code
prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to
the penalty therefor; provided, however, no person who is the lessor of a vehicle pursuant to a written lease agreement shall be liable for the violation
of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking involving such vehicle during the period of the lease unless such lessor fails to provide the name,
address, and driver's license number of the lessee within sixty (60) days of receipt by such lessor of a request by the village for such information made
within one hundred twenty (120) days after the violation occurred.
C. Vehicle Immobilization:
1. Grounds; Preimmobilization Notice; Placement Of Immobilization Restraint Device: A motor vehicle parked upon any public way (i.e., any publicly
maintained area when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for the purpose of vehicular travel, including, but not limited to, upon any
public street or municipal parking lot) at any time may, by or under the direction of an officer or member of the police department, be immobilized in
such a manner as to prevent its operation if the state registration number of the vehicle is included on the police department's current immobilization
list. A vehicle's state registration number shall be included on the police department's current immobilization list if:
a. The registered owner of the vehicle has accumulated five (5) or more parking violation complaints on one or more vehicles registered in his or her
name or five (5) or more administrative notices of violation(s) on one or more vehicles registered in his or her name, relative to which the
applicable fines are due but unpaid; and
b. At least twenty one (21) days prior to placing the state registration number of the vehicle on the police department's current immobilization list,
notice of impending vehicle immobilization has been sent to the registered owner by, at a minimum, first class mail, postage prepaid, at the
address of the registered owner recorded with the secretary of state or, in the case of a vehicle bearing a registration number of a state other than
Illinois, at the address of the registered owner recorded in that state's registry of motor vehicles. The preimmobilization notice shall state the name
and address of the registered owner, the state registration number of the vehicle, the general nature of the ordinances violated and the parking
ticket numbers and issue dates of the administrative notice of violation. Service of the notice of impending immobilization shall be deemed
complete upon deposit in U.S. mail. The preimmobilization notice shall advise that a person may challenge the validity of the notice of impending
vehicle immobilization by appearing in person at a preimmobilization hearing and submitting evidence to the village administrative hearing officer
or his designee which would conclusively disprove liability, such as, but not limited to, the following:
(1) The person was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle on the date or dates the notices of parking violations were issued;
(2) The fines or penalties for the violations cited in the report were paid; or
(3) The registered owner of the vehicle has not accumulated five (5) or more parking violation complaints on one or more vehicles registered in his
or her name or five (5) or more administrative notices of violation(s) on one or more vehicles registered in his or her name, relative to which the
applicable fines are due but unpaid.
2. Postimmobilization Notice: Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, the officer or employee shall affix to the vehicle a postimmobilization notice in
a conspicuous place. Such notice shall warn that the vehicle is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in its damage. The
notice also shall provide information specifying how release of the immobilizing restraint may be had, and how the registered owner may obtain a
postimmobilization hearing pursuant to this subsection C.
3. Towing And Impoundment: Except where the vehicle is otherwise subject to towing, if the immobilizing restraint has not been released pursuant to
subsection C4 of this section within seventy two (72) hours of its placement, the restraint shall be released and the vehicle towed and impounded.
4. Securing Release Of Vehicle; Preventing Inclusion On Immobilization List: The owner of an immobilized vehicle or other authorized person shall be
permitted to secure release of the vehicle or prevent the inclusion of such vehicle on the police department's current immobilization list by:
a. Paying the immobilization fee and towing fees and storage as specified in subsection C7 of this section; and
b. Taking any one of the following actions:
(1) By paying all fines, penalties, and costs, if any, on the outstanding complaints specified in the preimmobilization notice sent pursuant to
subsection C1b of this section;
(2) By the payment of the fees as required by subsection C7 of this section.
5. Notice Of Impoundment: Within fifteen (15) days after a previously immobilized vehicle has been impounded, notice of impoundment shall be sent by
certified mail, return receipt requested, to the registered owner of the vehicle at the address to which the preimmobilization notice specified in
subsection C1b of this section was mailed. The notice shall state that the owner has the right to a postimmobilization hearing as provided in
subsection C6 of this section, and that if the car is not claimed within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice, the vehicle may be sold or otherwise
disposed of as provided for in this title relative to abandoned vehicles.
6. Postimmobilization Hearing:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 239/522
a. The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall have the right to a postimmobilization hearing to determine whether the immobilization and/or any
subsequent towing was erroneous and/or whether the vehicle was properly included on an immobilization list, if the owner files a written demand
for a hearing with the village administrative adjudication hearing officer or his designee within twenty one (21) days after issuance of the notice of
impoundment specified in subsection C5 of this section or within twenty one (21) days of the immobilization, whichever is later.
b. A postimmobilization hearing shall be conducted before the village administrative adjudication hearing officer within seventy two (72) hours of
receipt of a written demand for hearing unless otherwise mutually agreed by the parties.
c. The failure of an owner to request or to attend a scheduled hearing shall be deemed a waiver of the right to such a hearing.
d. A postimmobilization hearing provided by this subsection C6 shall not determine the validity of or otherwise adjudicate any citation or notice of
parking violation issued relative to the immobilized vehicle.
7. Fees: The fee for immobilization shall be an amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, and the fee for towing subsequent
to immobilization shall be an amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, plus storage charges to date. It shall be unlawful
for the owner of an immobilized and/or impounded vehicle to not pay the fees required by this subsection C7; provided, that no fees shall be
assessed for any immobilization, tow, or storage where the immobilization has been determined to be erroneous pursuant to a hearing. Prior to a
postimmobilization hearing as provided in subsection C6 of this section, the owner may deposit with the village the amounts required by this
subsection C7, together with any storage fees to date, to secure the release of the vehicle if all other requirements for release of the vehicle have
been satisfied, which deposits shall be refundable only if the owner prevails at the subsequent postimmobilization hearing.
8. Record Of Impounded Vehicles; Safety:
a. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to safely keep any vehicle so impounded pursuant to this subsection until such vehicle shall have been
repossessed by the owner or person legally entitled to possession thereof or otherwise disposed of as hereinafter provided for abandoned
vehicles. The chief of police shall cause to be kept an accurate record of:
(1) The description of such vehicle.
(2) The name of the officer from whom such vehicle was received.
(3) The firm employed to tow or deliver such vehicle to the authorized pound.
(4) Name and the location of such authorized pound.
(5) The date and time when received by the authorized pound.
(6) The place where found, seized or taken possession of.
(7) The make and color of car, style of body, kind of power, motor number, serial number, number of cylinders, year built, state license number, if
any, wheel tax license number, if any, equipment and general description of condition.
(8) The name and address of the person redeeming the vehicle.
(9) The date of redemption and the manner and date of disposal of the vehicle in case it shall not be redeemed.
(10) Applicable immobilization, towing and storage charges.
b. These records shall be in form prescribed by the chief of police and shall be kept in the office of the chief of police where they shall be available for
the inspection by any interested party during regular business hours.
9. Right Regarding Violation Charged: Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to deprive any person of the constitutional right to a hearing or trial
as to the violations charged.
D. Notice Of Impending Driver's License Suspension: A notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent to the person liable for failure to pay
any fine or penalty that remains due and owing, or both, on ten (10) or more parking violations. The notice shall state that failure to complete a required
traffic education program or to pay the fine or penalty owing, or both, within forty five (45) days of the notice's date will result in the village's code
hearing department notifying the secretary of state that the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings under the Illinois vehicle code. The
notice shall also state that the person may obtain a photostatic copy of an original ticket imposing a fine or penalty by sending a self-addressed,
stamped envelope to the village's code hearing department along with a request for the photostatic copy. The notice of impending driver's license
suspension shall be sent by first class United States mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the secretary of state or, if any notice to that
address is returned as undeliverable, to the last known address recorded in a United States post office approved database. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-2012)
6-2-4: IMPOUNDMENT AND REDEMPTION OF VEHICLES:
A. Impoundment Authorized: Members of the village police department are hereby authorized to remove a vehicle from any public way to the nearest
village vehicle pound or authorized garage as determined and designated by the chief of police under the following circumstances:
1. When a vehicle upon any public way is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are by
reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal.
2. When any vehicle is left unattended upon any public way and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal
movement of traffic. (1973 Code § 14-303; amd. 2003 Code)
B. Supervision Of Removal; Place Of Impoundment: It shall be the duty of the chief of police to cause every vehicle removed from any public way to be so
removed and conveyed by or under the direction of a member of the police department to an authorized garage. (1973 Code § 14-304)
C. Notice Of Impoundment:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 240/522
1. Notice To Owner: Whenever the department of police has impounded any vehicle as aforesaid, said department shall ascertain from the registration
records of the state or the village the name and address of the owner thereof and shall immediately give or cause to be given notice in writing to such
owner of the fact of such removal and impounding and the reason therefor and of the place to which such vehicle has been removed. (1973 Code
§ 14-307)
2. Notice To Secretary Of State: Whenever the department of police has impounded any vehicle as aforesaid and does not know and is not able to
ascertain the name of the owner, or for any reason is unable to give the notice to the owner as hereinbefore provided, and in the event the vehicle is
not returned to the owner within a period of ten (10) days, then and in that event said department shall immediately send or cause to be sent a
written report of such removal and impounding by mail to the secretary of state. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the
date, time, and place from which removed, the reasons for such removal, and the address of the vehicle pound or authorized garage where the
vehicle is stored. (1973 Code § 14-308)
D. Records Of Impounded Vehicle: It shall be the duty of the chief of police to safely keep any vehicle so impounded until such vehicle shall have been
repossessed by the owner or person legally entitled to possession thereof or otherwise disposed of as hereinafter provided. The chief of police shall
cause to be kept an accurate record of the description of such vehicle, including the name of the officer from whom such vehicle was received, the
officer employed to tow or deliver the same to said authorized garage, the date and time when received, the place where found, seized or taken
possession of, the make and color of car, style or body, kind of power, motor number, serial number, number of cylinders, year built, state license
number, if any, wheel tax license number, if any, equipment and general description of condition, the name and address of the person redeeming said
vehicle, the date of redemption, and the manner and date of disposal of said vehicle in case the same shall not be redeemed, together with the towing
and storage charges. Said record shall be in form prescribed by the chief of police. It shall also be the duty of the chief of police to keep reports of all
such vehicles delivered to him, which reports shall be kept in the office of said chief available for the inspection by any interested party at all reasonable
hours of the day. (1973 Code § 14-306)
E. Redemption Of Impounded Vehicle: Before the owner or person entitled to possession of any legally impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove
the same from the custody of the chief of police, he shall furnish evidence of his identity and ownership of the vehicle and right of possession thereto,
shall sign a receipt for the vehicle, and shall pay a fee to cover the cost of towing or removal to an authorized garage and, in addition thereto, the cost
of storage at a rate for each day or fraction of a day said vehicle is stored therein. (1973 Code § 14-305)
F. Disposition Of Unclaimed Vehicle:
1. Whenever any impounded vehicle shall remain unclaimed by the owner or other person legally entitled to possession thereof for a period of thirty
(30) days from the day such vehicle was impounded, and after notice shall have been given, it shall be the duty of the department of police to sell
such vehicle at public auction to the highest bidder for cash, the time and place of such sale to be published at least once in a newspaper of general
circulation in the village, not less than ten (10) or more than fifteen (15) days from expiration of said thirty (30) days, and he shall also cause a notice
of such sale to be mailed to the secretary of state not less than ten (10) or more than fifteen (15) days from the expiration of said thirty (30) days.
Said notice shall contain a full description of the vehicle to be sold and the time and place of sale; provided, that any such vehicle not sold at the first
sale may be offered for sale and sold at any subsequent sale without further notice or publication. The proceeds of such sale after paying all liens
and deducting all reasonable charges and expenses incurred in receiving, towing, keeping, preparing and giving notices, advertising for sale or
selling or otherwise disposing of such vehicle shall be paid to the village treasurer.
2. No member of the department of police, nor any other employee of the village, directly or indirectly, shall purchase or participate in the bidding for, or
purchase of, any vehicle offered for sale as aforesaid. (1973 Code § 14-309)
6-2-5: EMERGENCY RELOCATION OF VEHICLES:
When any emergency arises necessitating the removal of any vehicle upon any public way, members of the department of police are hereby authorized to
remove or have removed any such vehicle from one location to any other location. (1973 Code § 14-310)
6-2-6: PENALTY:
Every person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this title for which no penalty is specifically provided shall be punished as provided by
section 1-4-1 of this code. (1973 Code § 14-296; amd. Ord. 96-2617, 9-9-1996)
Chapter 3
PARKING REGULATIONS
6-3-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of any regulation prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified or as
indicated on official signs except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police
officer or official traffic control device. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
6-3-2: AUTHORITY TO REGULATE PARKING:
A. Prohibited Parking Places: The board of trustees shall have authority to determine and designate by ordinance or resolution those streets or parts of
streets and other village property upon which parking is prohibited or upon which parking shall be prohibited on one side only.
B. Time Limits On Parking: The board of trustees shall have authority to determine and designate by ordinance or resolution those streets or parts of street
and other village property upon which stopping, standing or parking shall be prohibited within certain hours or permitted for a limited period of time.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 241/522
(Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006; amd. Ord. 15-3864, 10-12-2015)
6-3-3: PARKING PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES:
A. No person shall park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic
control device, in any of the following places:
1. On a sidewalk.
2. In front of a public or private driveway or on any "driveway apron" as that term is defined in section 7-3-1 of this code.
3. Within an intersection.
4. Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
5. On a crosswalk or within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
6. On any unpaved portion of any dedicated right of way or of any public place in the village.
7. Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway.
8. Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet (30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless
the department or the local authorities on highways under their respective jurisdiction indicate a different length by signs or markings.
9. Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade crossing.
10. Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire station and, on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within
seventy five feet (75') of said entrance when properly posted.
11. Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such parking would obstruct traffic.
12. On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge or curb of a street.
13. Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel.
14. Upon any street within twenty feet (20') of any mailbox designed and arranged to permit deposit of mail from vehicles.
15. At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
16. At any curb marked with yellow paint.
17. In any parking place, including, but not limited to, both on street parking and/or any private or public off street parking facility, where such parking
place is specifically reserved by the posting of an official sign, as designated under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-301, unless such vehicle is
bearing registration plates or decals issued to a person with disabilities, as defined by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-159.1, pursuant to 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-616 or 5/11-1301.2, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-609, as evidence that the
vehicle is operated by or for a handicapped person or disabled veteran.
18. In any posted loading zone, except when such vehicle is loading or unloading and in no event for more than thirty (30) minutes at any one time.
19. Within any alley for more than thirty (30) minutes at any one occasion.
20. In any setback or place, whether on private or public property, where parking is otherwise prohibited by this code, the zoning ordinance of the
village or by any separate ordinance adopted under the authority of said zoning ordinance.
21. In excess of that period of time designated by official signs which limit parking at such location to a fixed duration; and no vehicle, after being
parked in such location, shall, within a like period thereafter, be parked within two hundred feet (200') of its original location.
22. Other than in a single designated parking space where lines are marked on the pavement to indicate such parking spaces.
B. No person other than a police officer, as provided in subsection 6-2-4A of this title, shall move a vehicle into any such prohibited area or away from a
curb such distance as is unlawful or start or cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change, or move the levers, brake, starting
device, gears, or other mechanism of a parked motor vehicle to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver thereof, or attempt
to do so. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-2012)
6-3-4: METHOD OF PARKING:
No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement,
and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within twelve inches (12") of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this title. Double
parking is prohibited, provided, however, that where a street has been marked for angle parking by direction of the board of trustees, vehicles shall be
parked at the angle indicated by such marks. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 4061 - PARKING. Go to new ordinance.
6-3-5: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
A. Not To Obstruct Traffic: No person shall park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than fifteen
feet (15') of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic, except on a one-way street.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 242/522
B. Fire Lanes: No person owning, controlling, driving or operating any vehicle shall cause or permit such vehicle to park in any area designated as a "fire
lane", as vehicle parking in such designated areas interferes with access by fire vehicles. Appropriate signs indicating fire lanes and no parking shall be
installed on any area so designated as a fire lane.
C. All Night Parking: In addition to any other restrictions now or hereafter imposed, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any portion of any dedicated
right of way, including, but not limited to, any street, any parkway or tree bank in the village, between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six
o'clock (6:00) A.M., with the exception of the following portions of dedicated rights of way where it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle thereon
between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.:
Cook Street between Main Street and Station Street.
Klingenberg Drive from the Village Commuter Parking Lot 11 to Route 14.
Park Avenue between Main Street and Grove Avenue.
Station Street between Hough Street and Grove Avenue.
Wool Street between Main Street and Klingenberg Drive.
However, notwithstanding the foregoing, the parking prohibitions provided by section 6-3-6, "Parking During Snow Removal Operations", of this chapter
shall be and remain applicable as provided by such section.
D. Near Theaters: The operator of a vehicle shall not park such vehicle on the same side of the street in front of any entrance or exit of any theater building
during the hours such theater is open to the public for the uses permitted therein.
E. Use Of Bus And Taxicab Stands: No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle, other than a bus in a bus stop, bus stand or bus terminal, or other than
a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated by appropriate signs; except, that the driver of a passenger
vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not
interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone.
F. Vehicles With Expired Registration: No person may stop, park, or leave standing upon a public street, highway, or roadway a vehicle upon which is
displayed an Illinois registration plate or plates or registration sticker after the termination of the registration period for which the registration plate or
plates or registration sticker was issued or after the expiration date set under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-414 or 5/3-414.1. Any person violating
this subsection shall be fined as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each offense. Each day on which a violation occurs or
continues shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 12-3682, 4-9-2012)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 4061 - PARKING. Go to new ordinance.
6-3-6: PARKING DURING SNOW REMOVAL OPERATIONS:
A. Parking Prohibitions:
1. No person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any portion of any dedicated right of way, including, but not limited to, any street, any
parkway or any tree bank within the village, at any time after snow begins to fall, and said snow exceeds two inches (2") in depth as determined by
the meteorological service then utilized by the village department of public works, until snow removal operations are completed, except in the village
center business district as depicted on the official zoning map which is a part of the village zoning ordinance.
2. No person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any portion of any dedicated right of way, including, but not limited to, any street, any
parkway or any tree bank, within the village center business district after one o'clock (1:00) A.M. after a snowfall exceeds four inches (4") as
determined by the meteorological service then utilized by the village department of public works, until snow removal operations are completed.
B. Violations; Citations; Vehicles Towed: The chief of the police department and all members thereof assigned to traffic duty are hereby authorized to issue
citations to the owner and/or operator of any car or other vehicle illegally parked in violation of this section and to remove and tow away, or have
removed or towed away by a commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in violation of this section which is impeding snow
removal operations. Vehicles so towed away shall be stored at a location designated by such commercial towing service and shall be restored to the
owner or operator thereof after payment of the expense incurred by the village in removing and storing such vehicles. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
6-3-7: PARKING TRUCKS AND TRAILERS IN RESIDENTIAL ZONES:
Except as otherwise specifically authorized by a permit issued pursuant to this chapter, it shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, or person having
custody of or responsibility for any truck or trailer to park such truck or trailer, or allow such truck or trailer to be parked, on any street or alley in the village
where the zoning classification of property adjacent to said street on either side thereof is zoned R-1 through R-8 for a period longer than two (2) hours,
unless such truck or trailer is actually engaged in loading and unloading for a longer period. Nothing in this section is intended to or shall be construed as
amending any provision of this chapter providing for parking for a lesser period of time or prohibiting parking. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
6-3-8: PARKING FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS:
A. Authority To Designate Spaces: The board of trustees shall have authority to determine and designate by ordinance or resolution those streets or parts
of streets, or those parking spaces in commuter or municipal parking lots upon or in which parking shall be prohibited except as to the motor vehicles of
handicapped persons bearing registration plates issued to a physically handicapped person pursuant to section 3-616 or to a disabled veteran
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 243/522
pursuant to section 3-609 of the Illinois motor vehicle code (Illinois vehicle code) or bearing other appropriate evidence that the vehicle is operated by a
handicapped person. The chief of police shall also have the authority to designate or cause to be designated the location of handicapped parking by
the posting of appropriate signage.
B. Exemptions From Parking Regulations: A motor vehicle bearing registration plates issued to a physically handicapped person pursuant to section 3-616
of the Illinois vehicle code or to a disabled veteran pursuant to section 3-609 of the Illinois vehicle code or a vehicle bearing appropriate evidence that
the vehicle is operated by or for a handicapped person is exempt from all provisions of this chapter or regulations of the village imposing time limits on
parking spaces in any business district and any parking space controlled by a parking meter but otherwise is subject to all such provisions of this
chapter or regulations of the village which prohibit parking in "no stopping" and "no standing" zones in areas requiring any parking permit, in daily fee
automated fare box parking areas, and in employer/employee permit parking areas, in front of or near fire hydrants, fire lanes, driveways, public
building entrances and exits, bus stops, and loading zones, and is prohibited from parking where the motor vehicle constitutes a traffic hazard. Such
motor vehicles shall be moved at the instruction and request of a police officer to a location designated by the police officer.
C. Restrictions Regarding Handicapped Status: Parking privileges granted by this section are strictly limited to the person to whom the special registration
plates were issued and to qualified operators acting under his express direction while the disabled person is present. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
6-3-9: OBEDIENCE TO SIGNS:
Where signs and/or curb markings have been erected upon any street or other village property as authorized herein indicating that parking is prohibited
during designated hours, prohibited for a longer time than is designated, and/or otherwise regulated, no person shall park any vehicle on said street or on
any village property in violation of any such signs or curb markings. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
6-3-10: PAVEMENT MARKING:
For the purpose of designating parking spaces within which a vehicle is permitted to park, the chief of police, or his designee, is authorized to have
markings painted or placed upon pavement so designated for parking purposes. Vehicles must be parked within the lines or markings so established, and
it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle across any such line, or marking, or to park any vehicle in such a position that such vehicle is not parked entirely
within a parking space so designated by such lines or markings. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
6-3-11: SIGNAGE:
The chief of police of the village or his designee is hereby authorized and directed to erect appropriate signs or make appropriate curb markings to give
notice of the establishment of the parking regulations as set forth in this chapter in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and the chief of police
may modify any such signage on a temporary basis as may be required to respond to any emergency or other exigent circumstances. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-
22-2006)
6-3-12: ENFORCEMENT:
A. The police department of the village shall issue a citation or arrest ticket or administrative notice of violation in the case of each motor vehicle parked in
violation of the provisions of this chapter. Such citation or arrest ticket or administrative notice of violation shall be placed upon the motor vehicle and
shall constitute service of a notice to appear in court or before the village's administrative hearing officer, as the case may be, on the owners and
operator thereof. The penalty for any violation of the provisions of this chapter unless otherwise specified shall be as specified from time to time in
section 1-14-1 of this code, provided, however, that penalties for particular violations shall be assessed and may be settled, compromised and paid as
set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code.
B. The village reserves the right to suspend or revoke any village parking permit, through a written determination by the chief of police, or his designee, if
the village obtains or receives information that one or more village parking permits held by any permit holder have been used in a manner inconsistent
with and/or in violation of the provisions of this chapter applicable thereto, provided, however, at least fifteen (15) days prior to the effective date of such
suspension or revocation, the chief of police, or his designee, shall send to the permit holder written notice that the village may suspend or revoke all of
the parking permit(s) of the permit holder in question. If within fifteen (15) days after the date of the notice, the permit holder so requests, then the
village manager, or her designee, shall provide the permit holder with the opportunity to be heard to establish that one or more of the parking permit(s)
in question have not been used in violation of or in a manner inconsistent with the applicable provisions of this chapter. Any suspension or revocation
imposed pursuant to the provisions of this subsection may be applied to all parking permits held by any person or entity which hold multiple parking
permits, including, but not limited to, any employer which holds multiple employer/employee parking permits.
C. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a violation of this code, provided that the fine for such violation may be settled by
prepayment as provided in section 1-14-1 of this code. Nothing contained herein shall prevent the removal and impoundment and/or relocation of any
vehicle parked in violation of this chapter for twenty four (24) hours as provided in subsection 6-2-4A of this title, or for a shorter period of time, when
authorized by the chief of police, or his designee, when he finds that an emergency or other exigent circumstances exist. (Ord. 12-3677, 3-12-2012)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE PARKING LOTS
6-3A-1: SUPERVISION:
All municipal off street parking lots and other areas where village parking permits are required, operated by the village, shall be subject to the supervision
of the chief of police, or such other person as may be designated by the board of trustees, who shall be responsible for and have charge of the operation
of such lots and other areas and shall have control over the places for parking and the method of parking, and means of entrance and exit, including, but
not limited to, the authority to establish temporary and/or experimental regulations to respond to unusual or unexpected circumstances, subject to the right
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 244/522
of the board of trustees to establish additional regulations or modify or rescind any existing regulation(s) relative to said parking areas. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-
22-2006)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 4061 - PARKING. Go to new ordinance.
6-3A-2: METHOD OF PARKING:
The particular method or methods of parking regulation required in and applicable to each separate municipal parking lot, and other areas where village
parking permits are required, shall be as designated from time to time by ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 4061 - PARKING. Go to new ordinance.
6-3A-3: FEES AND HOURS:
Fees for utilizing municipal off street parking lots, and other areas where village parking permits are required, shall be as follows and are required to be
paid for use of any space controlled or covered by a daily fee automated fare box or similar device (hereinafter referred to as a "fare box") or parking
permit, or combination thereof as designated by posted signs.
A. Daily Fee Automated Fare Box:
1. Fee Established; Payment: When a municipal parking lot is controlled by one or more fare boxes, a fee per designated parking space per day as
specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code is required to be paid by depositing in such fare box U.S. currency or by utilizing prepaid
electronic cards as authorized by the village. Said fare boxes shall be placed within the parking lot or within the immediate vicinity thereof at one or
more locations. Immediately after parking the vehicle, said fee shall be deposited into such a fare box for the number corresponding with the number
of the parking space in which said vehicle has been parked.
2. Parking Regulated: Vehicles may only be parked in numbered parking spaces.
3. Hours: Said fee shall be for a period from five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on any day to two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the following day, or any portion of such
period.
B. Parking Permits:
1. Parking Regulations: When a municipal parking lot, or any other area where village parking permits are required, is regulated by a parking permit,
only those vehicles displaying a current and valid permit issued by the village shall be permitted to park in designated parking spaces in the
municipal parking lot, or in such other areas where village parking permits are required, corresponding with the type of parking permit issued by the
village. Notice that parking is by permit only shall be posted at the entrance to such lots or in proximity to other areas where village parking permits
are required.
2. Hours: Parking shall only be allowed by such permit for the period from five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on any day to two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the following
day, or any portion of such period, except in designated overnight parking areas after paying the corresponding fee for a temporary overnight parking
permit, or except as otherwise authorized by another appropriate village parking permit.
3. Fees:
a. Fees Established: A fee is required to be paid for each parking permit issued by the village. The fees for a parking permit shall be as follows,
which fees may be modified from time to time by the corporate authorities of the village:
(1) That amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, per quarter, for a permit for commuter lots on the south side of the
Union Pacific Railroad tracks.
(2) That amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code per quarter, for a permit for commuter lots on the north side of the
Union Pacific right of way.
(3) That amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, per quarter, or that fee as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1
of this code, annually, for a "premium" parking permit which may be used for any lot or other parking area designated by the village for
employer/employee parking.
(4) That amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, per year, for a "discount" parking permit, which may be used as a
discounted employer/employee parking permit for any lot or other parking area designated by the village for such discounted
employer/employee parking.
(5) That amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for a special parking permit for commuter parking lot 22 as described
in subsection 6-3A-7B of this article.
(6) That amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for an "employer/employee seasonal permit" parking permit for lots
10, 13, and 7, and at other designated locations, as described in subsection 6-3A-7A of this article.
(7) That amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for a "temporary guest parking" permit available for purchase by Cook
Street Plaza condominium owners, for parking in the Cook Street Plaza underground garage, as described in subsection 6-3A-7A of this article.
(8) That amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for a "temporary (yellow) overnight parking permit, commuter lot" to
permit overnight parking in the commuter lot for a period not to exceed three (3) consecutive days and nights, as described in subsection 6-3A-
7A of this article.
b. Proration Of Fees; Refunds: The effective date for annual parking permits shall be June 1 of each year. These permits may, however, be
purchased throughout the year, but the fee for parking permits shall not be prorated, with the exception of annual premium permits and permits for
the commuter lots on the south side of the Union Pacific right of way (hereinafter, "south lot commuter parking"). The fee for an annual premium
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 245/522
permit shall be prorated based upon the number of full or partial months remaining to the end of the calendar year, but in no case shall the fee be
less than fifty percent (50%) of the full annual fee for such permit. The fee for a quarterly south lot commuter parking permit shall be prorated on
the basis of the weeks which have already expired in the period based upon thirteen (13) weeks per quarter. Once a permit is issued, no refund
shall be provided upon its return, provided, however, refunds may be made on a pro rata basis as to parking permits for the south lot commuter
parking, but only if the permit for which a refund is sought is resold by the village for the balance of the period for which it was issued.
c. Lost Permits: The fee for the replacement of a lost permit shall be that amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code.
4. Permit Does Not Guarantee Parking: Such permits shall be issued as a convenience to users, and the issuance thereof shall not guarantee the
availability of parking space, which spaces shall be utilized on a first come, first served priority basis.
5. Designated Areas: Permits may only be used in those areas designated by this chapter, or otherwise designated by the village.
6. Display: All parking permits shall be hung on the rearview mirror at all times while the vehicle is parked in a designated parking space or the vehicle
may be ticketed for failure to display the required permit. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 4061 - PARKING. Go to new ordinance.
6-3A-4: PARKING WITHOUT PAYING FEE OR DISPLAYING PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in any parking space owned or operated by the village without paying the fee required for such parking, if any, or
without displaying a current, valid permit, as required by the posted regulations for such space. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
6-3A-5: USE OF SPACES:
A. All vehicles parked in any parking space owned or operated by the village must be parked within the lines as indicated on the pavement and in
conformity with the regulations issued by the board of trustees and/or the chief of police and posted in conspicuous places in or near the parking lot.
B. No vehicle shall be parked in excess of that period of time designated by official signs which limit parking at such location to a fixed duration; and no
vehicle, after being parked in such location, shall, within a like period thereafter, be parked within two hundred feet (200') of its original location.
C. It shall be unlawful to park any truck, bus, or any vehicle that does not fit into the established parking place for one vehicle in any parking space owned
or operated by the village. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 4061 - PARKING. Go to new ordinance.
6-3A-6: DAMAGE TO FARE BOXES:
It shall be unlawful to injure, deface, tamper with, damage, or in any way interfere with or impair any daily fee automated fare box owned or operated by
the village. Without any limitation on the foregoing, it shall be unlawful to deposit or cause to be deposited in any daily fee automated fare box, or similar
device, anything other than United States currency or a prepaid electronic card authorized by the village. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006)
6-3A-7: PARKING LOTS, PARKING AREAS, AND PERMITS DESIGNATED:
A. Definitions And Regulations:
COMMUTER LOTS: Any parking lots designated by the board of trustees where parking is restricted to vehicles displaying commuter lot parking
permits, unless the posted notice in the lot permits parking of vehicles for which a daily fee is paid or other permit parking is allowed. Certain commuter
lots or portions thereof may be restricted to use by residents of the communities that are members of the Barrington area council of governments
("BACOG"), and such restriction shall be duly posted. Certain commuter lots may be specifically designated for reverse commuters who depart from
the village in the evening after five o'clock (5:00) P.M. and return to the village not later than ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on the next day.
CONSTRUCTION ("ORANGE") PERMITS: Parking permits issued by the village to make "on street" parking available for construction workers or
"displaced" employers/employees or homeowners during commercial or residential construction. Such construction permits are available at the village
hall, subject to prior approval by the chief of police or his designee, and subject to the conditions established by the police department in conjunction
with this approval, at the cost of twenty dollars ($20.00) per month.
CUSTOMER CONVENIENCE PARKING: Designated parking areas established by the board of trustees within the village center district where vehicles
may be parked for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes for the purpose of customer convenience only and shall not be used for any other
purpose.
DAILY FEE PARKING: Designated parking areas established by the board of trustees where vehicles are permitted to be parked on a daily basis for a
period of time from five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on any day to two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the following day, or any portion of such period, and a required daily
fee is paid. When any vehicle shall be parked in a daily fee parking space, the owner or operator of such vehicle shall park within the area designated
by the curb and/or pavement marking lines as indicated, for parallel, right angle, or diagonal parking, and upon entering said parking space shall
immediately deposit into the daily fee automated fare box the required amount of United States currency or a prepaid electronic card as authorized by
the village as indicated by instructions on said daily fee automated fare box. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to park within any such daily fee
designated space in any daily fee lot or to fail or neglect to so deposit the required United States currency or a prepaid electronic card as authorized by
the village as specified on the daily fee automated fare box. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or to permit any motor vehicle registered in his
name to be unlawfully parked in any daily fee space.
EMPLOYER/EMPLOYEE DISCOUNT PERMIT: A discount parking permit issued by the village which allows parking only in specified lots 7, 10, 13,
and 21, and only in the areas designated and posted for employer/employee parking. Such discount permits may also be designated as a type "B"
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 246/522
employer/employee permit.
EMPLOYER/EMPLOYEE LOTS AND PARKING AREA: "Permit only" parking areas designated by the board of trustees where vehicles belonging to
eligible employees of eligible employers and eligible employers located within a designated area of the village are permitted to park.
Employer/employee parking permits may be issued by the village in the name of an eligible employee or in the name of an eligible employer. The name
of the employer will be marked on each permit. When issued in the name of the employer, such permits allow the use of that permit by multiple
employees at different times. To be eligible for applying for an employer/employee parking permit, an employer must be located within a designated
area of the village, which maps depicting said designated areas are available for inspection at the village hall and public safety building. For an
employee to qualify for the use of such a permit, that employee's primary employment location must be at an employer location that is eligible to apply
for such a permit, and proof thereof must be presented at the time of the employee's initial application.
Any parking of a vehicle in a lot or other area of parking designated by the board of trustees as employer/employee parking shall be restricted to
parking of vehicles displaying a valid employer/employee parking permit, and such restriction shall be duly posted. Some employer/employee parking
may also include spaces which are designated for either employer/employee permit parking or daily fee parking after nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., or three
(3) hour shopper parking.
EMPLOYER/EMPLOYEE PREMIUM PERMIT: A premium parking permit issued by the village which allows parking in any of the parking lots or spaces
designated by the village for employer/employee parking. Such premium permits may also be designated as type "A" employer/employee permits.
EMPLOYER/EMPLOYEE SEASONAL PERMITS: A parking permit issued by the village for use from November 1 through December 31 of a specified
year ("the seasonal period") that allows parking only in lot 10, lot 13, lot 7 (in the area designated and posted on the west side), lot 21 and at other
locations as designated by the corporate authorities of the village or chief of police. Employer/employee seasonal permits may be purchased by a
village employer for that amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for the seasonal period. Such seasonal permits may also
be designated as a type "C" employer/employee permit.
LOADING ZONE PARKING: Allows a vehicle to be parked within certain designated parking spaces within the village for a period of not to exceed thirty
(30) minutes for the purpose of loading and/or unloading goods or materials.
SHOPPER LOT OR AREAS: Any lot or group of parking spaces designated by the board of trustees where parking space is available free to shoppers
for up to three (3) hours per visit except as may be otherwise determined by ordinance of the village, and as duly posted. Shopper parking lots or areas
may also contain spaces which are designated for and restricted to parking of vehicles displaying valid employer/employee permits.
TEMPORARY GUEST PARKING: Prepaid temporary overnight parking in the Cook Street Plaza underground garage between the hours of nine
o'clock (9:00) P.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. Temporary guest parking permits may be purchased from the village by a Cook Street Plaza condo
owner in packages or lots of ten (10) for that amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code. Each condo owner is limited to fifty
(50) permits, or five (5) packages of ten (10) permits, per calendar year. The permits purchased for each calendar year shall expire on December 31 of
that year.
TEMPORARY OVERNIGHT ("YELLOW") PARKING PERMITS; COMMUTER LOT: Temporary overnight parking permits issued by the village allow
train commuters to leave their vehicle in the commuter parking lot between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. for a period
not to exceed three (3) consecutive days and nights, but in any event, such vehicles must be removed by twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight of the last day
designated on such permit. Such permits shall be purchased from the village in advance of the overnight stay, and all such vehicles shall clearly display
such permit and must be parked in the commuter lot in the area designated by the chief of police for "overnight parking". The cost of such permit shall
be that amount as specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code.
TEMPORARY ("PINK") PARKING PERMITS: Temporary parking permits issued by the village allow parking on certain designated village streets or in
certain village parking lots to accommodate special projects within the village and may be issued in the sole discretion of either the board of trustees or
the chief of police.
VILLAGE FACILITY LOT: Any lot serving a village facility where parking shall be and is hereby restricted to the parking of vehicles of village employees
and of visitors to the building or facility at which the lot is located, except where any parking by permit is specifically authorized by the board of trustees.
VISITOR PARKING PERMITS: A parking permit issued by the village that allows a "visitor" to a local business or institution to park in any of the
employer/employee parking lots or employer/employee designated spaces on the date indicated on the visitor parking permit. Visitor parking permits
may be purchased at least two (2) days in advance by a village employer at the village hall for ten dollars ($10.00) per day. (Ord. 06-3306, 5-22-2006;
amd. Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008; Ord. 15-3835, 5-11-2015)

insureds.

6-3A-8: APPLICATION, GENERAL RESTRICTIONS:
A. Except as otherwise expressly provided herein, no parking shall be permitted in any municipal parking lot between two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) A.M., provided, however, vehicles displaying a valid special parking permit for reverse commuters or temporary overnight parking shall
be permitted to park during this time period, subject to such other special regulations as may be prescribed for those special parking permits. (Ord. 06-
3306, 5-22-2006; amd. Ord. 15-3850, 8-3-2015)

Chapter 4
TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
6-4-1: THROUGH STREETS; REQUIRED STOPS:
A. Placement Of Signs; Operation Of Vehicles: The streets set forth in subsection B of this section are designated as through streets, and stop signs shall
be maintained at all entrances thereto. Every driver of a vehicle approaching a through street shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side
of the intersection to each through street or in the event there is no crosswalk, shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point
nearest the intersecting street where the driver has a view of the approaching traffic on the intersecting street, before entering the intersection, except
when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic control signal; provided, however, that where yield right-of-way signs are maintained in lieu of said
stop signs pursuant to section 6-4-3 of this chapter, every driver at a through street intersection so marked shall be governed by the terms and
provisions contained in said section 6-4-3 of this chapter.

6-4-3: YIELD INTERSECTIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 252/522
A. Placement Of Signs; Operation Of Vehicles: The intersections set forth in subsection B of this section are designated yield right of way intersections.
Yield right of way signs shall be maintained at the appropriate approaches to said intersections, and thereupon, the driver of every vehicle approaching
said sign shall reduce the speed of his vehicle to not more than twenty (20) miles per hour and shall yield the right of way to other vehicles which have
entered the intersecting street either from the right or left or which are approaching so closely on said intersecting street as to constitute an immediate
hazard, but said driver having so yielded may proceed at such time as a safe interval occurs. If a driver is involved in a collision at such intersection or
interferes with the movement of other vehicles after driving past a yield right of way sign, such collision or interference shall be deemed prima facie
evidence of the driver's failure to yield the right of way. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to fail to yield the right of way as hereinafter
provided. (1973 Code § 14-502)

B. Special Speed Limit While Passing Schools:
1. Definitions: For purposes of this subsection, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
SCHOOL: a. A public or private primary or secondary school;
b. A primary or secondary school operated by a religious institution; and
c. A public, private, or religious nursery school.
SCHOOL DAY: A school day shall begin at seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and shall conclude at four o'clock (4:00) P.M.
2. Speed Limit Established: On a school day when schoolchildren are present and so close thereto that a potential hazard exists because of the close
proximity of the motorized traffic, no person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour while passing through a
school zone or while traveling upon any public thoroughfare where children pass going to and from school.
3. Signs Posted: This subsection shall not be applicable unless appropriate signs are posted upon streets wherein the school zone is located. With
regard to the special speed limit while passing schools, the signs shall give proper due warning that a school zone is being approached, and shall
indicate the school zone and the maximum speed limit in effect during school days when schoolchildren are present.
