which is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public right of way without regard to delivery technology, including internet protocol
technology. This definition does not include any video programming provided by a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 USC section 332(d) or
any video programming provided solely as part of, and via, service that enables users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services
offered over the public internet.
VILLAGE: The village of Barrington, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
8-5-2: CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEE IMPOSED:
A. Fee Imposed: A fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable service or video service in the village.
B. Amount Of Fee: The amount of the fee imposed hereby shall be five percent (5%) of the holder's gross revenues.
C. Notice To The Village: The holder shall notify the village at least ten (10) days prior to the date on which the holder begins to offer cable service or video
service in the village.
D. Holder's Liability: The holder shall be liable for and pay the service provider fee to the village. The holder's liability for the fee shall commence on the
first day of the calendar month following thirty (30) days after receipt of the ordinance adopting this chapter by the holder. The ordinance adopting this
chapter shall be sent by mail, postage prepaid, to the address listed on the holder's application notice sent pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/21-401(b)(6) to the village.
E. Payment Date: The payment of the service provider fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, forty five (45) days after the close of the calendar quarter. If
mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the
fee.
F. Exemption: The fee hereby imposed does not apply to existing cable service or video service providers that have an existing franchise agreement with
the village in which a fee is paid.
G. Credit For Other Payments: An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/21-301(c) with credit for prepaid franchise fees under that agreement may deduct the amount of such credit from the fees that operator owes under
subsection B of this section. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
8-5-3: PEG ACCESS SUPPORT FEE IMPOSED:
A. PEG Fee Imposed: A PEG access support fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable service or video service in the village in addition to the
fee imposed pursuant to section 8-5-2 of this chapter.
B. Amount Of Fee: The amount of the PEG access support fee imposed hereby shall be one percent (1%) of the holder's gross revenues or, if greater, the
percentage of gross revenues that incumbent cable operators pay to the village or its designee for PEG access support in the village.
C. Payment: The holder shall pay the PEG access support fee to the village or to the entity designated by the village to manage PEG access. The holder's
liability for the PEG access support fee shall commence on the date set forth in subsection 8-5-2D of this chapter.
D. Payment Due: The payment of the PEG access support fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, forty five (45) days after the close of the calendar quarter.
If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the
fee.
E. Credit For Other Payments: An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-
301(c) shall pay, at the time they would have been due, all monetary payments for PEG access that would have been due during the remaining term of
the agreement had it not been terminated pursuant to that section. All payments made by an incumbent cable operator pursuant to the previous
sentence may be credited against the fees that that operator owes under subsection B of this section. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
8-5-4: APPLICABLE PRINCIPLES:
All determinations and calculations under this chapter shall be made pursuant to generally accepted accounting principles. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
8-5-5: NO IMPACT ON OTHER TAXES DUE FROM HOLDER:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to exempt a holder from any tax that is or may later be imposed by the village, including any tax that is
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 344/522
or may later be required to be paid by or through the holder with respect to cable service or video service. A state issued authorization shall not affect any
requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the village's simplified municipal telecommunications tax or any other tax as it applies to any
telephone service provided by the holder. A state issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the local
unit of government's 911 or E911 fees, taxes or charges. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
8-5-6: AUDITS OF CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER:
A. Audit Requirement: The village will notify the holder of the requirements it imposes on other cable service or video service providers to submit to an
audit of its books and records. The holder shall comply with the same requirements the village imposes on other cable service or video service
providers in its jurisdiction to audit the holder's books and records and to recompute any amounts determined to be payable under the requirements of
the village. If all local franchises between the village and cable operator terminate, the audit requirements shall be those adopted by the village
pursuant to the local government taxpayers' bill of rights act, 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 45/1 et seq. No acceptance of amounts remitted should be
construed as an accord that the amounts are correct.
B. Additional Payments: Any additional amount due after an audit shall be paid within thirty (30) days after the village's submission of an invoice for the
sum. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
8-5-7: LATE FEES/PAYMENTS:
All fees due and payments which are past due shall be governed by the provisions of this code adopted by this village pursuant to the local government
taxpayers' bill of rights act, 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 45/1 et seq., to wit: title 3, chapter 2, article F of this code. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-3-2007)
8-5-8: CABLE AND VIDEO CUSTOMER PROTECTION LAW:
A. Authority: This section is adopted pursuant to the cable and video customer protection law1 authorizing a village to enforce all of the customer service
and privacy protection standards of said section.
B. Purpose: The village desires to enforce the customer service and privacy protection standards with respect to complaints received from residents as
provided by the cable and video customer protection law.
C. Adoption: The regulations of 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/70-501 are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the cable or video
providers offering services within the village's boundaries.
D. Amendments: Any amendment to the cable and video customer protection law that becomes effective after the effective date of this chapter shall be
incorporated into this chapter by reference and shall be applicable to cable or video providers offering services within the municipality's boundaries.
However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this chapter by reference
without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village.
E. Enforcement: The village does hereby pursuant to law declare its intent to enforce all of the customer service and privacy protection standards of the
cable and video protection law with respect to complaints received from residents within the village. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
F. Penalties: The village, pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/70-501(r)(1), does hereby provide for a schedule of penalties for any material breach
of the cable and video protection law by cable or video providers in addition to the penalties provided in the law. The monetary penalties shall apply on
a competitively neutral basis and shall not exceed the amount specified from time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code for each occurrence of a
material breach per customer. (Ord. 09-3495, 2-9-2009)
1. "Material breach" means any substantial failure of a cable or video provider to comply with service quality and other standards specified in any
provision of the law.
2. The village shall give the cable or video provider written notice of any alleged material breaches of the law and allow such provider at least thirty (30)
days from the receipt of the notice to remedy the specified material breach.
3. A material breach, for the purposes of assessing penalties, shall be deemed to occur for each day that a material breach has not been remedied by
the cable or video service provider after the notice in subsection F2 of this section.
G. Customer Credits: The village hereby adopts the schedule of customer credits for violations. Those credits shall be as provided for in the provisions of
220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/70-501(s) and applied on the statement issued to the customer for the next billing cycle following the violation or
following the discovery of the violation. The cable or video provider is responsible for providing the credits and the customer is under no obligation to
request the credit.
H. Effective Date: The provisions of this section shall not take effect until January 1, 2008, as to incumbent cable operators, but otherwise it shall be in full
force and effect from and after its passage, approval and publication as required by law. (Ord. 07-3415, 11-5-2007)
I. Additional Penalty: Except as specifically provided in this chapter, any violation of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine as specified from time to time
in section 1-14-1 of this code, and each day a violation has existed or continues to exist shall be a separate offense. (Ord. 09-3495, 2-9-2009)

Chapter 6
ELECTRICITY AGGREGATION PROGRAM
8-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following definitions:
ACT: The Illinois power agency act, 20 Illinois Compiled Statutes 3855/1-92, as may be amended from time to time.
CUSTOMER: Recipients of residential and small commercial retail electric loads as provided in the act.
ELECTRICITY AGGREGATION PROGRAM: A program pursuant to the act for the aggregation of residential and small commercial retail electric loads
located within the corporate limits of the village that provides customers with the opportunity to opt out of participating in that program as provided in the
act. (Ord. 12-3685, 4-23-2012)
8-6-2: AGGREGATION OF ELECTRICAL LOAD:
A. The corporate authorities of the village are authorized to operate an electricity aggregation program pursuant to the act and for that purpose may solicit
bids and enter into service agreements to facilitate the sale and purchase of electricity and related services and equipment for those loads aggregated
pursuant to the electricity aggregation program as provided in the act.
B. The corporate authorities of the village may exercise the authority to operate the electricity aggregation program jointly with any other municipality or
county and, in combination with two (2) or more municipalities or counties, may initiate a process to jointly authorize the electricity aggregation program
by a majority vote of each particular municipality or county as required by the act. (Ord. 12-3685, 4-23-2012)
8-6-3: OPT OUT PROGRAM:
A. The electricity aggregation program shall operate as an opt out program whereby customers who do not wish to participate in the electricity aggregation
program may opt out pursuant to the act.
B. The village president, or her designee, on behalf of the village, shall fully inform residential customers and small commercial retail customers of the
village in advance, as provided in the act, that customers have the right to opt out of the village electricity aggregation program. The disclosure
provided to the customers shall comply with the requirements of the act and shall prominently state all charges for electricity service to be made and
shall include full disclosure of the cost to obtain service pursuant to 16-103 of the public utilities act1, how to access service, and the fact that service
under section 16-103 of the public utilities act is available to customers without penalty if they are currently receiving service under section 16-103 of
the public utilities act.
C. Upon notification from any customer that the customer wishes to opt out of the electricity aggregation program, that customer shall be excluded from
the electricity aggregation program.
D. Except for those customers who opt out of the electricity aggregation program pursuant to this section and the act, the electricity aggregation program
shall automatically apply for each person owning, occupying, controlling, or using an electrical load center proposed to be aggregated in the corporate
limits of the village. (Ord. 12-3685, 4-23-2012)
8-6-4: ADOPTION OF PLAN OF OPERATION AND GOVERNANCE FOR THE ELECTRICITY AGGREGATION PROGRAM:
A. The corporate authorities of the village, with the assistance from the Illinois power agency as required pursuant to the act, shall develop and approve a
plan of operation and governance for the electricity aggregation program.
B. Before adopting the plan of operation and governance required under this section and the act, the corporate authorities shall hold at least two (2) public
hearings on the proposed plan. Before the first public hearing, the corporate authorities shall publish notice of the hearings once a week for two (2)
consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the village. The notice shall summarize the plan of operation and governance and state the
date, time, and location of each hearing.
C. The plan of operation and governance for the village's electricity aggregation program shall:
1. Provide for universal access to all applicable residential customers and equitable treatment of applicable residential customers,
2. Describe demand management and energy efficiency services to be provided to each class of customers, and
3. Meet any requirements established by law concerning aggregated service offered pursuant to the act. (Ord. 12-3685, 4-23-2012)
8-6-5: SOLICITATION OF BIDS:
The process for soliciting bids for electricity and other related services and awarding proposed agreements for the purchase of electricity and other related
services for the electricity aggregation program shall be conducted pursuant to the act. (Ord. 12-3685, 4-23-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 346/522
Title 9
WATER AND SEWER
Chapter 1
WATER AND SANITARY SYSTEM USE AND SERVICE
9-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this chapter and chapters 2, 3, 4, and 5 of this title shall be as follows:
BUILDING WATER SYSTEM: The water distribution system for any building intended or used for human habitation or occupancy, which is not part of the
village system.
CLARIFICATION OF WORD USAGE: Shall is mandatory; may is permissible.
CURB COCK: A shutoff valve attached to a water service pipe from a water main to a building installed near the curb, which may be operated by a valve
key to start or stop flow in the water supply lines of a building. May be referred to as "curb stop", "buffalo box", "roundway" and "service box".
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
FEDERAL GOVERNMENT:
Administrator: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency.
Federal Act: The federal 1996 safe drinking water acts, as amended.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT:
Approving Authority: The director of public works.
Village: The village of Barrington, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois.
PERSON: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society, institution,
enterprise, governmental agency or other entity.
SERVICE BOX: A water valve box used with corporation or curb cock.
STATE GOVERNMENT:
Director: The director of the Illinois environmental protection agency.
State Act: The Illinois antipollution bond act of 19701.
State Loan: The state of Illinois participation in the financing of the construction of the village system as provided for by the Illinois antipollution bond act
and for making such loans as filed with the secretary of state of the state of Illinois.
TYPES OF CHARGES:
Basic User Charge: The basic assessment levied on all users of the village system.
Capital Improvement Charge: A charge levied on users to improve, extend or reconstruct the village system.
Debt Service Charge: The amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest, principal and coverage of loan outstanding for the village
system.
Local Capital Cost Charge: Charges for costs other than the operation, maintenance and replacement costs of the village system, i.e., debt service and
capital improvement costs.
Replacement: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the
village system to maintain the capacity and performance for which such village system was designed and constructed. The term "operation and
maintenance" includes "replacement".
System Service Charge: The charge levied on all users of the village system facilities. The service charge shall be computed as outlined in chapter 2 of
this title and shall consist of the total of the basic user charge and the local capital cost, if applicable.
Useful Life: The estimated period during which the village system will be operated.
User Charge: A charge levied on all users of the village system for the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement.
Utility Fund: The principal accounting designation for all revenues received in the operation of the village system.
VILLAGE SYSTEM: The combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village, as defined in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-139-1, including, but
not limited to, water supply and distribution facilities, sanitary sewer mains, and sewage collection and treatment facilities, and water mains, storm sewers,
and all appurtenances, extension and improvements determined by the village to be necessary, useful, and/or convenient.
WATER AND ITS CHARACTERISTICS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 347/522
Milligrams Per Liter: A unit of the concentration of water constituent. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters (1,000 ml) of water. It
has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the result of water analysis.
ppm: Parts per million by weight.
pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA division of
laboratories' "Manual Of Laboratory Methods". (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-2: CONNECTION AND PERMIT REQUIRED:
Each building water system shall be supplied by potable water from the village system only; provided, however, that no connection shall be made to such
village system without a permit issued by the director of public works. All industrial, commercial or institutional users of water not served or only partially
served by the village system shall be required to meter its water supply to the same standards, rules and regulations as apply to the village system. (Ord.
08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-3: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Each application for the permit to connect to or disconnect from any public water main which is part of the village system shall be accompanied by a
certificate of insurance covering commercial general liability insurance in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit per
occurrence for bodily injury and property damage, naming the village as an additional insured to hold the village, its officers, employees, and agents,
harmless from any damages and costs which might be caused by accidents. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-4: VILLAGE SYSTEM CONNECTION FEES AND DEPOSIT:
A. Fees Established:
1. Connection fee(s) shall be paid to the village for all new connections to the village system in the amounts specified from time to time in section 1-14-
1 of this code.
2. The foregoing fees or charges shall not be applicable to any connection for a fire sprinkler system as provided in subsection 9-4-5B of this title.
3. An upgrade in the size of the water meter serving any building shall be allowed only after there has been paid to the village the difference between
the respective connection fees. No credit for or reimbursement of connection fees shall be granted for reductions in water meter size.
B. Deposit Established:
1. The village system users ("customers") hereinafter set forth shall be required to deposit with the village an aggregate amount equal to the sum of the
following multiplied by three (3): the applicable combined base water and sewer fees or charges; plus, the average bimonthly usage for the
applicable billing classification multiplied by the current water and sewer flow charges, which amount shall remain on deposit for as long as village
system service is provided.
2. The following customers shall be required to make the deposit provided for in subsection B1 of this section:
a. Any customer whose water service cannot be disconnected at the B-box due to inaccessibility of the B-box or the impact on other customers
serviced by the same B-box; and
b. Any customer who has had a payment history of late payments, a nonpayment and/or a payment by a check which is returned by the bank due to
nonsufficient funds for any village system service.
C. Applicability And Scope Of Connection Fees: The above prescribed connection fees shall be paid for connection of any property within or outside of the
village. As said connection fees or charges are in consideration of the availability and existence of a total combined village system, such fees or
charges shall be in addition to any other fees or charges and/or costs which the owner of property may have to pay or may have paid for the installation
of water and sewer mains to serve his property or by way of any other fees or charges and/or costs which the owner may have to pay to the village to
compensate any other person for water and sewer mains installed in contemplation of serving said owner's property, commonly referred to as
"recapture charges".
D. Fees Not To Affect Written Contracts: The village system connection fees provided for herein shall not affect or repeal any specific written valid
arrangement of the payment of such connection fees or the connection of specific properties. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-5: SUPERVISION OF VILLAGE SYSTEM CONNECTIONS; INSPECTIONS:
All village system connections shall be made under the supervision of the director of public works, and no connection shall be covered until the work has
been inspected and approved by the director of public works, or his designee. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-6: TURN ON OF WATER:
A. Authority To Turn On: No water from the village system shall be turned on for service to any premises by any person except the director of public works
or some other person authorized by him to perform this service.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 348/522
B. Application For Turn On: Application to have water turned on shall be made to the director of public works and shall contain an agreement by the
applicant to abide by and accept all of the provisions of this title as a condition governing the use of the village system by the applicant.
C. Deposit Required: A deposit as provided in section 1-14-1 of this code shall be made with each application to have water turned on, this sum to be
retained by the village to ensure the payment of all bills until all such bills have been paid and the remainder of such deposit, without interest, shall be
refunded to the applicant when service is discontinued, if all bills have been paid. When service to the applicant is discontinued permanently, this
deposit, less any amount still due the Village for service provided by the Village system, shall be refunded without interest to the applicant.
D. Substandard Plumbing: No water shall be turned on for Village system service to a premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the
ordinances of the Village; provided, that water may be turned on temporarily for construction purposes in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions
of this title. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-7: FIRE HYDRANT USE:
A. Permit Required; Emergencies: No person, firm or corporation shall open or draw water from the Village system, including, but not limited to, any Village
fire hydrant or plug, or interfere in any manner therewith without the prior written authorization of the Director of Public Works, or except in the case of a
fire or other similar emergency.
B. Fire Protection Services: The Director of Public Works may issue a permit upon request to any person, firm or corporation to make special connections
with water mains which are part of the Village system in order to obtain a water supply for private hydrants and standpipes for use in the case of fire.
No charge shall be made for such permit or for water used for fire protection purposes, but all such work in connection with such fire protection system
shall be done under the direction of the Director of Public Works. Such private facilities shall be maintained in good working order by the owner of the
premises where they are located, and readily available and open to inspections by the Village at all times. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-8: WATER SERVICE PIPES AND CONNECTIONS:
A. Installation From Shutoff Box To Premises: All water service pipes from the shutoff box to the premises to be served shall be installed by, and at the cost
of, the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. Such installations shall be under the supervision of the Director of Public
Works, or his designee.
B. Piping Specifications: All water service pipes from the main to the meter shall be of a material and size in accordance with the latest version of the
Illinois State Plumbing Code. All fittings and connections shall be uniform in size and shall comply with specifications established by the Corporate
Authorities. In all cases where a service pipe enters a building, it shall be furnished with a stop or valve placed within twelve inches (12") of the inside
wall where the service enters the building between the meter and the wall, and a similar valve shall be placed on the opposite side of the meter within
twelve inches (12") thereof. Such stops or water valves shall have a handle or wrench attached thereto for the purpose of turning same so that the
water may be turned off in case of water leaks in the building. Such stops or valves shall be kept accessible at all times. Any electrical grounding
devices shall only be installed where the service pipe enters the building and before the valve. (Ord. 18-4006, 5-14-2018)
C. Depth: All service pipes shall be buried at least four and one-half feet (41/2') deep in the ground.
D. Repairs From Shutoff Box To Building:
1. All repairs to service pipes from the shutoff box to the building or premises served shall be made by and at the expense of the owners of the building
or premises served.
2. The Village may, in case of emergency, repair any such service pipe, and if this is done, the cost of such repair work shall be reimbursed to the
Village by the owner of the premises served.
3. In the event that a leak or break occurs in that portion of the water service pipe to be maintained by the owner of the premises, the Village may close
the curb stop and discontinue the service of water to the premises until the required repairs have been made by such owner.
4. The Village shall not be liable for any damage caused by leak or break in any water service pipe, or for damage caused by a failure to repair the
same promptly; nor shall the Village be liable for any damage caused by the repair or installation of such pipes or resulting therefrom.
E. Excavations: Excavations for installing water service pipes or repairing the same shall be made in compliance with the ordinances relating to
excavations in streets2.
F. Shutoff Boxes: Shutoff or service boxes shall be placed on every water service pipe and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk line
approximately eight feet (8') from the adjacent property, where this is practicable. Such boxes shall be so located that they are easily accessible, and
shall be protected from frost.
G. Connection With Main: The water service pipe from the main to the shutoff box shall hereafter be installed, subject to approval and inspection by the
director of public works, by and at the expense of the owner of the property or applicant for service. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-9: NEW DEVELOPMENTS; USE OF OR DISCONNECTION FROM MAINS:
A. Definition: For the purpose of this section, "disconnection" means: 1) closing the corporation stop into the water main; 2) removing the roundway and
buffalo box (curb cock and box) in the water service; and 3) accomplishing any restoration work on the property in question.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 349/522
B. Reuse Or Disconnection: When an application for a building or site development permit is made for a property which, prior to the date of the application,
has been connected to the village system, the application must state whether the proposed building or development will use the existing village system
connection, or if new or different water and/or sanitary services and connections are required by any law, ordinance or regulation, or if the applicant,
though not required to, desires new or different water and/or sanitary services and connections. If new or different water and/or sanitary services and
connections are required as aforesaid, or if the applicant desires new or different water and/or sanitary services and connections and such desired
service and connection is approved by the village, then, in each such event, the applicant must disconnect the existing service(s), as provided in this
section, in order to obtain the permit.
C. Responsibility For Disconnection; Inspection: It shall be the responsibility of the applicant for the building or development permit to bear all expenses to
accomplish the disconnection as provided in this section, including the restoration work. The disconnection shall be made only by a licensed plumber
and shall be inspected and approved by the director of public works or his designee before the work is covered.
D. Restrictions On Reuse: Under no circumstances shall any lead water service lines serving said property be reused. All such water service lines shall
either be replaced with type K copper or with other materials which have been approved in writing by the director of public works, or abandoned. (Ord.
08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-10: RESALE OF WATER:
No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the village system's water supply to any premises other than that for which the original
sale has been made, as evidenced by meter installation, except as may be specifically authorized by the director of public works in cases of emergency
use. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-11: TAMPERING OR INTERFERING WITH SYSTEM:
A. Meters: No unauthorized person shall break or tamper with any seal placed by the village upon any meter or other fixture which is part of the village
system. Meters shall be left in the condition as set by the village and shall not be interfered with or tampered with in any manner. No meter shall be
removed, relocated or otherwise disturbed without the permission of the director of public works; except, that duly licensed plumbers making repairs to
frozen services may remove the meter, provided it is immediately delivered to the director of public works for inspection and test, and provided, that a
bond wire is installed prior to the removal. In no case shall a pipe coupling or bypass be installed in the line in place of or around a meter; except, that
in case of a frozen meter, the public works personnel shall make such installation. Any person violating this provision shall, in addition to such fines as
established by this code, be liable to pay an amount estimated by the director of public works to cover the charges for village system service not
recorded by reason of the incorrect or lost registration on the meter.
B. Obstructing Access:
1. No person shall in any manner obstruct the access to any stopcock, hydrant or valve, or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any street,
alley, public ground or place connected with or part of the village system, nor pile or place any lumber, brick or building material or other article, thing
or hindrance whatsoever within twelve feet (12') of the same, or so as to in any manner hinder, delay or obstruct the members of the fire department
in reaching the same and, in addition, it is unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with or obstruct the members of the fire department in
reaching the same.
2. No person shall prevent or deny access to any authorized village employee attempting to read or inspect any meter during normal business hours.
C. Obstructing Flow: It is unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with or obstruct the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water in the
village system, reservoir or plant, or any part thereof, or to injure, deface, remove or display any water main, hydrant, service pipe, meter, shutoff box,
public fountain, valve, engine or building connected with the village system, or well, or to cause, suffer or permit any of said things to be done. (Ord. 08-
3486, 12-15-2008)
9-1-12: VILLAGE SYSTEM SERVICE OUTSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS:
A. No building or other structure shall be connected to the village system unless the parcel of real property on which the building or structure is located is
within the corporate limits of this village. Any exception to the requirement of mandatory annexation as a condition to the provision of service from the
village system shall be subject to the approval of a written agreement between this village and the village in which the real property with the building(s)
or other structure(s) thereon to be served is located and an agreement between this village and the owner of such real property on which the
building(s) or other structure(s) to be connected to the village system is located.
B. Any property outside the corporate limits of the village which is connected to the village system shall be disconnected from the village system upon the
occurrence of any one of the following events:
1. The disconnection of the property from another village without such other village's consent in which the property is located and with which this village
has a written agreement pursuant to which this village has agreed to provide services from the village system to the property;
2. The annexation of the property to another municipality without this village's consent; or
3. Termination or expiration of the written agreement pursuant to which this village has agreed to provide services from the village system.
C. Any property within the corporate limits of the village that is connected to and served by the village system shall be disconnected from the village
system upon disconnection of such property or part thereof from this village unless this village has consented to such disconnection and/or has entered
into a written agreement to provide or continue to provide such service from the village system. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 350/522
Chapter 2
WATER METERS AND VILLAGE SYSTEM SERVICE CHARGES
9-2-1: METERS REQUIRED; CHARGES:
A. Meters Required; Charges Established: All premises using the village system shall be supplied with an adequate water meter approved by the director
of public works and furnished by the village. Except as provided in sections 9-2-5 of this chapter and 9-9-2 of this title, whenever any building
constructed on or after May 9, 1998, contains more than one residential dwelling unit, the owner shall provide a separate water meter for each such
dwelling unit at a location and configuration approved by the director of public works. No meter shall be installed unless there shall first have been paid
to the village the meter charge specified in section 1-14-1 of this code.
B. Review Of Charges; Exemption: The determination of the director of public works as to any water meter charge shall be subject to review by the
corporate authorities at the request of the applicant. The foregoing water meter charges shall not be applicable to water meters for fire sprinkling
systems as provided in subsection 9-4-5B of this title. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-2: SUPERVISION OF AND STANDARDS FOR METER INSTALLATION:
Meters shall be installed under the supervision of the director of public works or his designee in a location that will be accessible for maintenance, reading
and repairs. The standards for installation of meters shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
A. Meters shall not be set in any place where ground or surface water can rise and cover it or otherwise interfere with its operation.
B. Electrical ground wires, when so installed, shall only be connected to the street side of the meter and before the shutoff valve.
C. In all new or remodeling construction, an electrical raceway conduit shall be provided for the physical protection and maintenance of the meter wiring.
This conduit is to be continuous from the remote meter location to the location of the inside meter.
D. A device to permit reading the meter from outside the building shall be installed with each meter. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-3: LOCATION OF METERS:
A. General Requirements:
1. All meters installed in any structure shall be so located so as to permit authorized village employees ready and safe accessibility for the purpose of
reading and maintaining such meters.
2. No building permit shall be issued for the erection or construction of any single-family residential structure or multiple-family residential structure
unless the plans accompanying the application for any such permits show compliance with provisions of this title.
3. In the event that a meter is situated in a location that is inaccessible or difficult to access, the director of public works shall notify the owner in writing
of such condition. If the condition is not remedied in a satisfactory manner at the expense of the owner within thirty (30) days after the date such
notice is sent, the water supply from the village system may be shut off in accordance with the provisions of section 9-2-9 of this chapter, and shall
remain shut off until such condition has been remedied.
B. Large Consumers: Large consumers, including commercial, manufacturing, and office and research establishments, multiple-family dwellings and public
buildings, shall provide unobstructed access to the meter location for ready access during normal working hours. All such water meters and
appurtenant equipment shall become and remain the property of the village upon installation and approval by the director of public works or his
designee. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-4: RESPONSIBILITY FOR METERS; READING AND MAINTENANCE:
A. Meters Furnished By Village: All meters used in connection with the village system shall be furnished by the village and shall be and remain the
property of the village.
B. Cost Of Meters And Repairs: The actual cost to the village of furnishing each meter shall be paid by the person ordering the same. The actual cost of
keeping such meter in repair shall be paid by the person ordering same or by the owner or occupant of the premises as soon as the billing for same is
presented. The person upon whose application any meter is installed or the occupant or owner of the premises where installed shall be liable for any
breakage by freezing or otherwise, or any loss or damage to said meter in any manner except by ordinary use and wear, and the cost of making good
such damage or loss shall be paid by the person upon whose application such meter was installed, or by the occupant or owner of the premises where
installed as soon as the billing for same is presented, and the amount thereof shall be a lien against the premises in which such meter is located to the
same extent and with the same effect as delinquent water charges.
C. Reading Meters: The village manager shall cause to be read every water meter used in the village at such times as are necessary in order that bills
may be sent out at proper times. Reading inside meters shall be required at least once a year.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 351/522
D. Accuracy Of Meters; Tests:
1. Any customer who disputes the accuracy of his meter may request that such meter be tested. Upon payment to the village of a fee, as set forth from
time to time in section 1-14-1 of this code, the disputed meter will be removed by representatives of the village, and in the company of the person so
requesting the testing, the meter will be delivered to a testing facility designated by the village. In the presence of the person so requesting the test,
the meter will be tested in accordance with the American Water Works Association "Standard Practice For Testing Of Meters". If, after such testing,
the meter proves to be within three percent (3%) of being accurate, the fee paid shall be retained by the village to cover the cost of removal, testing
and reinstallation of the meter. If, after such testing, the meter is not accurate within three percent (3%), the meter shall be repaired and replaced at
no cost to the customer, and the testing fee shall be refunded in full. Further, if such testing indicates that the customer has been overcharged for his
utility, then an appropriate adjustment will be made and a credit issued to his account.
2. Except as provided in subsection D1 of this section meters shall be tested and/or replaced at village expense, unless said meter has sustained
damages due to abuse or tampering.
E. Tampering With Meter: No meter shall be removed or otherwise disturbed without having first obtained permission to do so from the director of public
works.
F. Access To Meters For Inspection: In the event the village notifies a customer in writing that their water or sewer meter requires inspection, service,
and/or replacement by the village, and the customer fails to provide the village with all necessary access for such purpose(s) after not less than three
(3) separate written requests for such access sent by regular U.S. mail over a period of not less than sixty (60) days, the water supply to the premises
in question from the village water system and/or the village's sanitary sewer services to such premises may thereafter be shut off unless and until all
necessary access to the premises required by the village for such purposes has been provided. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-5: VILLAGE SYSTEM SERVICE RATES ESTABLISHED:
A. Within Village Limits:
1. Computation: The charge to be paid by every person using water and sanitary sewer service from the village system within the corporate limits of the
village shall be computed bimonthly (once every 2 months) based upon the water meter size (basic village system service charge) and the quantity
of water used (quantity or flow charges).
2. Rates:
a. The rates and charges imposed by this subsection A to be paid by every person using water and sanitary sewer service from the village system
within the corporate limits of the village shall be as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code.
b. Quantity (flow) charges shall be as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code.
3. Master Metering: Any building that has thirty (30) or more residential dwelling units and is substantially constructed after October 1, 2001, shall be
served by either individual meters or a master water meter(s). In those instances that a master water meter is installed, basic village system service
charges shall be based on the size and number of meters that would have been installed assuming the individual metering of the residential dwelling
units and the separate metering of other areas.
B. Outside Village Limits: The charge to be paid by every person using any service from the village system outside the corporate limits of the village is as
set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code.
C. Large Users; Monthly Bills: The village may, but shall not be obligated to, bill on a monthly basis consumers using in excess of one hundred thousand
(100,000) gallons of water during each bimonthly billing period, such monthly billing to be based upon one estimated and a second actual reading.
(Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-6: LIABILITY FOR SERVICE:
The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof, and the user of any service from the village system shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for such
service to such premises, and such service is furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant
and user of such service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-7: USE OF WATER DURING BUILDING CONSTRUCTION:
A. Application For Use; Fee: During construction of any building and before any water is installed as is herein provided, any owner or contractor so
constructing such building may be permitted to use the water supply from the village system by making application therefor and paying the flat fee
prescribed from time to time by the corporate authorities as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code.
B. Restrictions On Use: Any owner or contractor shall use the water supply from the village system only for purposes directly related to the construction of
the building for which a building permit has been issued. Use of the water supply from the village system for other purposes not directly related to
construction of the building, including, but not limited to, landscaping and filling of swimming pools, shall be prohibited.
C. Penalty: Any owner or contractor who violates this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day in which any violation
shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-8: BILLS FOR SERVICE; PENALTY FOR DELINQUENCIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 352/522
Bills for village system service shall be dated and sent on or about the first day of the month succeeding the period for which the service is billed, and such
bills shall be payable not later than fifteen (15) days thereafter. After said fifteen (15) day period, a penalty of ten percent (10%) of the amount of the bill
shall be collected as part of said bill. For convenience in billing, the village may be divided into districts, with a different bimonthly billing period for each
district. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-9: NONPAYMENT OF BILLS; DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
The water supply from the village system and/or sanitary sewer service to the village system may be shut off from any premises for which the bill remains
unpaid twenty (20) days after the due date, or if, in the opinion of the village manager, or his or her designee, the private water and/or sanitary system(s)
and/or service line(s) serving the premises in question present(s) a hazard to the public health and safety; provided, however, that prior to such shutoff, a
written notice shall be mailed or delivered to the person(s) liable for such bill, notifying them of their right to request an administrative hearing before the
village manager or his/her designee within ten (10) days of the date of the notice, and at the hearing, present their objections to such action and/or to
contest a water and/or sewer utility bill. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no notice or hearing as aforesaid shall be required prior to shutoff if the village
manager, or his or her designee, determines that water and/or sanitary system(s) or service lines serving the premises present(s) an immediate hazard to
the public health or safety and/or an emergency related to such premises otherwise exists. The procedures for such administrative hearing shall be as set
forth in section 9-2-10 of this chapter. If such a hearing is requested, the water supply from the village system shall not be shut off until the hearing has
been held and the village manager has made a decision on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing and such written decision has been mailed
by regular U.S. mail, postage prepaid, to the person(s) requesting such hearing and/or to the person(s) liable for the payment of such water and/or sewer
utility bill at issue. When the water supply from the village system has been shut off from a premises or when an employee from the village has responded
to a premises for the purpose of shutting off the water supply but is unable to do so, a "shutoff/reconnection" fee as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code
shall be added to the amount owed and must be paid prior to the turning on of the water supply. An additional fee as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code
shall be charged if the village is requested to restore service outside "normal working hours" which, for the purpose of this section, are defined as Monday
through Friday (except holidays) from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to four o'clock (4:00) P.M. In addition to any reconnection fee required herein, if the water
supply from the village system to any premises was shut off due to nonpayment, prior to reconnection, the village may require a deposit as set forth in
section 1-14-1 of this code. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-10: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS RELATIVE TO UTILITY BILLS; REMEDIES:
A. Rules Of Procedure:
1. An administrative hearing may be held before the village manager to permit the person(s) liable for such bill to contest a water and/or sewer utility
bill. Such a hearing relative to water and/or sewer utility bill may be requested pursuant to section 9-2-9 of this chapter or may be requested by
person(s) liable for a utility account by submitting a written request to the village manager.
2. The person(s) requesting such hearing shall be notified of the time, date, and place of such hearing by the village by electronic communication (email
or equivalent), or by regular U.S. mail if an electronic communication method is not available, not less than seven (7) days prior thereto.
3. No continuance(s) of such a hearing shall be authorized by the village manager, or his or her designee, at such hearing except where absolutely
necessary to protect the right of the parties. The lack of preparation of a party does not constitute cause for a continuance.
4. Such hearings are not a meeting of a public body and, therefore, consistent with the provisions of the Illinois open meetings act, shall be closed to
the public and only the village manager, or his or her designee, the person(s) requesting the hearing, and any persons who are expected to testify
may be physically present or participate electronically in the hearing.
5. Such hearing(s) may be conducted by electronic means, rather than in person, by such means as, without limitation, telephone conference call, if
approved in advance by the village manager, or his or her designee.
6. Person(s) requesting such a hearing may also request in writing, in advance, of the village manager, or his or her designee, that their respective
personal appearance(s) at such hearing, by their physical presence or electronic participation, be waived, and the village manager, or his or her
designee, may, in his or her sole discretion, grant such requested waiver(s), but only if the village manager, or his or her designee, determines that
no party will be placed at a substantial disadvantage at such hearing by reason of a lack of opportunity for cross examination of those person(s) who
will not appear at such hearing.
7. All such administrative hearings shall be recorded and shall culminate in a determination of liability, nonliability, or partial liability made by the village
manager, or his or her designee, who shall consider testimony and/or other evidence of facts without the application of the formal or technical rules of
evidence. At such hearings, the person(s) requesting the hearing and any other person present shall be permitted to submit relevant evidence and
shall have the right to cross examine witnesses. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly relied upon by
reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs.
8. Persons appearing to contest a water and/or sewer utility bill may be represented by counsel at their own expense.
9. The burden of proof at such hearing shall be on the person(s) requesting the hearing to refute the correctness and accuracy of the utility bill at issue,
which shall be presumed to be correct and accurate by a rebuttal presumption. The person(s) contesting a water and/or sewer utility bill shall be
required to meet their burden of proof by a clear preponderance of the evidence.
10. The village manager, upon a determination of liability, nonliability, or partial liability, shall issue a written decision and send a copy to the person(s)
requesting the hearing and to the person(s) liable for payment of the water and/or sewer utility bill at issue.
B. Reduction Of Water Usage Charge: Based on circumstances, facts and evidence made available to the village manager, or his or her designee, at a
hearing to review a water and/or sewer utility bill, or informally without a hearing, may, but shall not be obligated to, authorize, at his or her sole
discretion, a reduction to the water usage charge portions of a utility bill. Neither the village manager, nor his or her designee, shall be authorized to
reduce or adjust water or sewer base facility charges. The village manager, or his or her designee, may, but shall not be obligated to, reduce the water
usage charge portion of the bill by up to a maximum amount that is based upon the customer's annual average usage at the sole discretion of the
village manager, or his or her designee, if all of the conditions precedent listed below are met:
1. The account must be in existence for a minimum period of one year;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 353/522
2. The usage must be at least three (3) times the annual average monthly usage, based on the last twelve (12) month consumption history;
3. The cause of water consumption cannot easily be determined, or would not be readily apparent to the person(s) liable for such utility bill, either
audibly or visibly, and was not the result of any carelessness, negligence, or intentional act(s) of the person(s) liable for such utility bill, or their
employee(s), agent(s), tenant(s), family member(s), or other occupant(s) of the premises serviced by the village system;
4. The person liable for the utility bill has taken any necessary action to correct the cause of the excess consumption of water, as evidenced by a
reduction in their consumption to typical levels; and
5. The village has not granted an adjustment pursuant to this section to the same utility account in the previous three (3) years.
C. Reduction Of Sewer Usage Charge: When all the conditions precedent set forth within subsection B of this section are met for a water usage charge
adjustment, the village manager, or his or her designee, may but shall not be obligated to, at his or her sole discretion, reduce the sewer usage charge
portion of the utility bill by up to a maximum amount that is based upon the customer's annual average monthly usage. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-11: LIEN FOR UNPAID BILLS; FORECLOSURE; COLLECTION:
A. Claim For Lien:
1. Whenever a bill for village system service remains unpaid thirty (30) days after it is due, the village manager shall file with the county recorder of
deeds of Cook County or Lake County (in whichever county the property is situated) a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal
description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges
for village system services provided subsequent to the period covered by the proper village officials, as provided by law.
2. If the consumer of village system service whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises, and the village manager has notice of this, notice
shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address is known to or can be obtained by the village manager, or his/her designee, whenever
such bill remains unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days after it is due.
3. The failure of the village manager to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the
village's right to foreclose the lien for an unpaid bill for village system service.
B. Foreclosure Of Lien:
1. Property subject to a lien for unpaid village system service charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be
applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure, of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the
name of the village.
2. An attorney selected by the village is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings, in the name of the village, in any court having
jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which the bill for village system service has remained unpaid thirty (30) days after it has been
rendered.
C. Collection: The village manager, or his or her designee, shall be and is authorized to utilize the services of private collection agent(s) and/or attorney(s)
which are approved by the board of trustees for the purpose of collecting any bill for village system services which remains unpaid thirty (30) days after
it is due. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-12: ANNUAL REVIEW OF RATES; REVISIONS:
The adequacy of the village system service charge shall be reviewed, not less often than annually, by certified public accountants for the village, in their
annual audit report. The village system service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect changes in debt service or in operation and maintenance
costs, including replacement costs. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
9-2-13: DISPOSITION AND ADMINISTRATION OF REVENUES:
The director of financial services shall receive all revenues from the village system service charges and all other funds and monies incident to the
operation of such system as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in the account of the fund designated as the "utility fund of the village
of Barrington". The director of financial services shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided in article 11, division 129 of the Illinois
municipal code1 and all other laws amendatory thereof and supplementary thereto. (Ord. 15-3837, 6-8-2015)
9-2-14: ACCOUNTS AND RECORDS:
A. System Of Accounts And Records: The director of financial services shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records,
and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the village system and, at regular annual intervals, shall
cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the village system and its utility
fund. (Ord. 15-3837, 6-8-2015)
B. Financial Information On Audit: In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating
expenses of the water and sanitary sewer facilities, including a replacement cost. The financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include
the following:
1. Flow data showing total gallons received at the plants for the current fiscal year.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 354/522
2. Billing data to show number of gallons billed per fiscal year.
3. Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year.
4. Number of users connected to the village system.
5. Number of nonmetered users.
C. Access To Records: The Illinois environmental protection agency or its authorized representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers
and records of the village which are applicable to the village system of user charges for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and
transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the loan agreement and rules or any state loan. (Ord. 12-3672, 2-13-2012)
Chapter 3
WATER-USING AIR CONDITIONERS
9-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated, whenever used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings given to them by this section:
AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM: Any unit or combination of units used for the cooling or dehumidification, or both, of space for human occupancy, supplied
with water through any single customer water pipe connected to the public water system. An air conditioning system using water separately submetered to
a tenant of a building shall be considered a separate system.
SUMMER SEASON: The period of May 1 to September 30 in the same calendar year.
TONS OF CAPACITY: The total number of tons of refrigeration installed on one air conditioning system. For the purposes of this chapter, one compressor
horsepower shall be considered equivalent to one ton of refrigeration.
WATER REGULATING DEVICE: A regulating valve or other device, the purpose of which is to limit the maximum use of water to a predetermined rate.
(Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-3-2: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to install or operate an air conditioning system without complying with the provisions of this chapter or which system is
not equipped as required by the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-3-3: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required: No air conditioning system shall be installed unless a permit for such installation shall first have been secured.
B. Application For Permit: Applications for air conditioning installation permits shall be made to the director of development services, or his or her
designee, and shall include plans and specifications of the proposed installation.
C. Plans And Specifications: No air conditioning installation permit shall be issued until the plans and specifications have been examined and approved by
the director of development services, or his or her designee, and the director of public works as being in compliance with this chapter.
D. Digital Data Standards: All submittals to the village and/or to any engineer, architect, surveyor, or other consultant retained by the village as required by
this chapter shall comply with the village's digital data standards set forth in title 1, chapter 16, "Digital Data Standards", of this code. (Ord. 15-3837, 6-
8-2015)
9-3-4: WATER CHARGES:
A. Charges Established: The charges for water used for an air conditioning system shall be the regular rates for water supplied by the village system
through meters; except, that during the summer season, there shall be paid, in addition, a demand charge as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code per
ton of capacity per season for the total capacity above three (3) tons unless the use of water from the village system for such air conditioning system
shall be limited to a maximum of two-tenths (0.2) gallon per minute per ton of capacity.
B. Payment Of Charges: The demand charges prescribed in this chapter shall be due and payable by May 1 of each year. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-3-5: WATER REGULATING DEVICES REQUIRED:
A. Any air conditioning unit using water from the village system shall be provided with a device approved by the director of public works to prevent
backsiphonage and backflow.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 355/522
B. Any air conditioning unit having three (3) tons of capacity or less must be equipped with a water regulating device to limit the use of water from the
village system not to exceed two (2) gallons per minute per ton of capacity.
C. Any air conditioning unit over three (3) tons' capacity installed prior to December 1, 1956, shall be equipped with a water regulating device to limit the
use of water from the village system to a rate not to exceed two-tenths (0.2) gallon per minute per ton of capacity. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-3-6: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the director of development services, or his or her designee, to enforce the provisions of this chapter, and for such purpose, he or
she shall be permitted to inspect any such air conditioning system at any reasonable hour. He or she shall have authority to require the installation of a
water meter to be furnished by the village at the expense of the owner to measure the amount of water used by any such air conditioning system. (Ord. 15-
3837, 6-8-2015)
Chapter 4
FIRE SPRINKLER SYSTEMS
9-4-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; ISSUANCE:
It shall be unlawful to install any fire sprinkler system, automatic or otherwise, within any building or structure within the village without having first secured
a permit therefor. Such permits may be issued by the building official. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-4-2: APPLICATION:
A. Application To Include Plans: The application for a fire sprinkler system permit shall be accompanied by, or include, plans and specifications in duplicate
showing the location of the proposed system, and all features thereof from the connection with the village water main to the sprinkler heads. Such
applications shall be approved by the director of development services, or his or her designee, and by the director of public works.
B. Digital Data Standards: All submittals to the village and/or to any engineer, architect, surveyor, or other consultant retained by the village as required by
this chapter shall comply with the village's digital data standards set forth in title 1, chapter 16, "Digital Data Standards", of this code. (Ord. 15-3837, 6-
8-2015)
9-4-3: FEES:
The fee for a fire sprinkler system shall be as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code, in addition to such plan review fees as are prescribed by the
Barrington building code. Plan review fees for expert consultants, when required by the code official, shall be as prescribed by the Barrington building
code. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-4-4: STANDARDS ADOPTED:
No fire sprinkler system shall be installed unless it complies with the standards for the installation of fire sprinkler systems published by the national board
of fire underwriters, or its successor, the National Fire Protection Association, and also with this code and all ordinances of the village. The said standards
are hereby adopted as regulations governing the installation of fire sprinkler systems in the village; provided, that wherever in such standards it is recited
that anything must be done to the approval of or subject to the direction of any village official, this shall be construed to give such officer only the discretion
to determine whether the rules and standards established have been complied with, and no such provision shall be construed as giving any officer of the
village discretionary powers as to what such regulations or standards shall be, or power to interpret such regulations or provisions in an arbitrary or
discriminatory manner. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-4-5: ADDITIONAL CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Shutoff Valve And Connection For Fire Hose Required: There shall be a shutoff valve in the fire sprinkler system connection at the street main housed
in a masonry valve vault, and there shall be a service connection suitable for connection with the village fire hose outside the building wall.
B. Check Valve And Bypass Meter: For each fire sprinkler system installed pursuant to this chapter, a detector check valve and bypass meter as approved
by the director of public works shall be installed on each water service line used for fire protection purposes and the actual costs thereof paid for by the
owner or applicant for service. Such water service lines used for fire protection purposes shall not be subject to the water service connection fees or
the meter charges as provided in section 1-14-1 of this code, but no other connections shall be made to such water service lines.
C. Connections With Other Pipes Prohibited: There shall be no connection of any kind between the fire sprinkler system pipes and any other pipes in the
building except for connection with the sprinkler heads. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-4-6: SUPERVISION OF WORK:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 356/522
A. Outside Building: All installation work from the street main to the inside of the building wall shall be done under the supervision of the director of public
works, and the fire sprinkler system shall not be placed within the building until such installation is finished.
B. Inside Building: The director of development services, or his or her designee, shall supervise and inspect the installation of such fire sprinkler system
inside the building. (Ord. 15-3837, 6-8-2015)
Chapter 5
NONDOMESTIC WATER USE, BULK DELIVERIES
9-5-1: APPLICATION FOR TEMPORARY HOOKUP:
A. Applications Generally: Every purchaser of bulk amounts of water for nondomestic purposes such as swimming pools, ice rinks or other purposes
requiring delivery of large quantities of water shall apply to the director of public works to arrange for a temporary hookup to the village water system. In
such application, the purchaser shall specify the specific date and time at which the temporary connection service is requested.
B. Ice Rinks:
1. Property Owner's Permission; Plans: Any person or organization requesting a temporary hookup to provide bulk delivery of water for an ice rink shall
provide the director of public works with the landowner's written permission for construction of the skating pond on his or her property and shall
submit in writing plans for the drainage of such ice rink to the director of public works for his approval.
2. Bond: The director of public works may, at his discretion, require the posting of a cash bond to assure drainage of the ice rink in accordance with the
approved drainage plan for such ice rink. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-5-2: RESPONSIBILITY TO PROVIDE EQUIPMENT:
A. Hydrant Available: For any location serviceable by a fire hydrant, the village will provide all necessary equipment, including a fire hydrant meter, fittings
and hose to measure, in order to deliver the amount of water required.
B. Hydrant Unavailable: For any area not serviceable from a fire hydrant, the purchaser may obtain water from a hydrant at the public works garage. The
purchaser shall provide the necessary vehicle, in which case, to transport the water from such hydrant to the desired site. The village shall not be
responsible for quality and cleanliness of the water beyond the point of delivery into whatever vehicle provided by the purchaser at the public works
garage. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-5-3: SUPERVISION OF TEMPORARY CONNECTIONS:
All temporary connections to fire hydrants for the purposes of supplying bulk amounts of water for nondomestic use shall be made under the supervision of
the director of public works, and he shall determine which hydrant shall be used for such temporary connection. Only village personnel from the
department of public works shall be permitted to operate fire hydrants or to make hookups for such purposes. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-5-4: WATER RATES AND CHARGES FOR NONDOMESTIC PURPOSES:
A. Rates Established:
1. Purchasers That Are Water System Customers: Purchasers receiving water service from the village system shall be charged for the actual amount
of water used at the current rate applicable to their property as established by and as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code. An additional fee as
established by and as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code shall be charged for the cost of the temporary hookup.
2. Purchasers Not Water System Customers: Purchasers not receiving water service from the village system shall deposit in cash with the village an
amount equal to one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the estimated charges as established by and as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code,
based upon the current nonresident rate, plus a service fee as established by and as set forth in section 1-14-1 of this code prior to the establishing
of any temporary hookup. The balance, if any, shall be returned to the purchaser upon payment of the final bill.
B. Determination Of Water Used: The actual amount of water from the village system used shall be determined by the use of the fire hydrant meter, to be
furnished and installed by the village.
C. Additional Charges: The purchaser will be billed for any overtime salaries which must be paid to village personnel by a request for a temporary hookup
at a time outside of regular working hours. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
Chapter 6
CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
9-6-1: PURPOSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 357/522
The purpose of this chapter is as follows:
A. To protect the public water supply system from contamination or pollution by isolating within the customer's water system contaminants or pollutants
which would backflow through the service connection into the public water supply systems.
B. To promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections, actual or potential, between the public or consumer's potable water system and
nonpotable water systems, plumbing fixtures and sources or systems containing substances of unknown or questionable safety.
C. To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross connection control which will prevent the contamination or pollution of the public and
consumer's potable water systems. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-6-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall apply to all premises served by the public potable water supply system of the village. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-6-3: VILLAGE POLICY:
The director of public works shall be responsible for protection of the public water supply system from contamination due to backflow or backsiphonage of
contaminants through the customer's water service connection. The director of public works shall be responsible for causing surveys and investigations to
be made of industrial and other nonresidential accounts served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public
water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two (2) years, or as
often as the director of public works shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least
five (5) years. The installation of an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water supply system. The director of
public works shall give notice to the consumer to install such approved backflow prevention device at each service connection immediately beyond the
water meter. The consumer shall immediately install such approved device or devices at the consumer's own expense. Failure, refusal or inability on the
part of the consumer to install such device or devices shall constitute grounds for discontinuing water service to the premises until such device or devices
have been installed. The consumer shall retain records of installation, maintenance, testing and repair as required in subsection 9-6-9B of this chapter for
a period of at least five (5) years. (Ord. 08-3486, 12-15-2008)
9-6-4: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter:
ASSE: American Society of Sanitary Engineering.
AGENCY: Illinois environmental protection agency.
AIR GAP: The air gap in a water supply system is the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any
pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank or plumbing fixture and the flood level rim of the receptacle.
APPROVED: Accepted or acceptable under an applicable specification stated or cited in this chapter or accepted as suitable for the proposed use.
AUXILIARY WATER SYSTEM: Any water source or system on or available to the premises other than the public water supply system. These auxiliary
waters may include water from another purveyor's public water supply system; fire sprinkler connections or water from a source such as wells, lakes,
ponds, or streams, or process fluids; or used water. These waters may be polluted or contaminated or objectionable or constitute a water source or system
over which the water purveyor does not have control.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than
the intended source of the potable water supply.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Any device, method, or type of construction intended to prevent backflow or backsiphonage into a potable water
system. All devices used for backflow prevention in Illinois must meet the standards of the Illinois plumbing code and the Illinois environmental protection
agency.
BOOSTER PUMP: A mechanical device used to increase domestic water pressure.
CCCDI: Cross connection control device inspector.
COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEM (CWS): A public water supply which is owned or operated by the village of Barrington.
CONSUMER OR CUSTOMER: The owner, official custodian or person in control of any premises supplied by or in any manner connected to a public
water system.
CONSUMER'S WATER SYSTEM: The service connection and any water system located on the customer's premises. A building plumbing system is
considered to be a customer's water system with the exception of the water meter and its connections.
