10-12-6: STREET ADDRESS DISPLAY REQUIRED:
A. For the purposes of this section, an "address for display" is defined as the numerals and/or characters assigned to a specific location in compliance with
this chapter, but does not contain the name of the street or road upon which the structure is located.
B. 1. All numerals in an address for display shall be:
a. Arabic numerals;
b. A minimum of four inches (4") high and one-half inch (1/2") thick; and
c. Of a contrasting color to the surface of the structure on which they are attached.
2. All numerals in an address for display shall be maintained in a clearly legible condition.
C. Address numerals shall be displayed at a location on the property and/or on the structure where readily visible from the primary street or road on which
the structure is addressed.
D. 1. Whenever a building is located more than sixty feet (60') from the street right of way, the street address shall be displayed on a freestanding marker
or on a curb type mailbox that is at or near the front property line.
2. The street address may be located on the building if all of the numerals are visible from the street and if the numerals are increased to a size which
is approved in advance in writing by the director of development services, and/or his designee. (Ord. 15-3836, 6-8-2015)
10-12-7: DISPLAY COMPLIANCE STANDARDS:
A. New Construction: Upon commencement of initial construction of a new structure, a clearly visible freestanding sign or post shall be erected and
maintained in place on the respective lot or parcel until the permanent address numerals are attached to the structure or are otherwise displayed upon
the premises at completion in compliance with this chapter.
B. New Structures: Permanent address numerals for display must be in place and/or affixed to the subject structure(s) at a location which is readily visible
from the primary street or road on which the structure is addressed prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy by the village.
1. a. Single-family and/or two-family residential structures must have the address numerals displayed on:
(1) The structure and/or the premises at a location which is readily visible from the primary street or road on which the structure is addressed in
compliance with this chapter;
(2) The mailbox post when the mailbox is located on the subject property; or
(3) A freestanding post located at the driveway entrance leading to the structure.
b. The address must be of sufficient size to be visible from street right of way.
2. a. Multi-family structures with a common building entrance must have the numeric address of the site or of the individual building displayed on the
premises at or immediately adjacent to the building entrance at a location which is readily visible from the primary street or road on which the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 493/522
structure is addressed.
b. In addition, the individual unit number(s) for each dwelling unit shall be displayed on or immediately adjacent to the entrance door to each such
individual unit.
3. Townhomes/row homes must have the address numerals displayed as follows:
a. If a separate address is assigned to each townhome or row home building, the address numerals for the building shall be displayed on the front of
the subject structure at a location which is readily visible from the primary street or road on which the structure is addressed, and the unit number
for each individual dwelling unit within such building shall be displayed either on or directly adjacent to the entrance door(s) to each such individual
dwelling unit, and/or above the garage door(s) for such individual dwelling unit if it is a front load garage and the garage door faces the street
frontage.
b. If a separate address is assigned to each individual dwelling unit located within a townhome or row home building, the address numerals shall be
displayed at a location which is readily visible from the primary street or road on which the structure is addressed and displayed on, above, or
directly adjacent to the entrance door(s) to each such individual dwelling unit, and/or above the garage door(s) for such individual dwelling unit if it
is a front load garage and the garage door faces the street frontage.
4. a. Commercial, industrial, and/or office structures must have the address displayed either:
(1) On the building face at a location which is readily visible from the primary street or road on which the structure is addressed; or
(2) Upon a post or freestanding sign situated at the driveway or entrance to the property when numbering on the structure is not readily visible
from the street.
b. A mailbox post may be used if the mailbox is situated near the street.
c. In a business complex, each building shall have the numeric address displayed upon:
(1) The building at a location which is readily visible from the primary street or road on which the structure is addressed; and
(2) The suite or unit numbers displayed on the door or near the entrance to each unit.
C. Existing Structures:
1. The following persons are responsible for compliance with this chapter:
a. The resident or current occupant of any dwelling;
b. The owner, manager, or occupant of any business structure; or
c. The owner of any structure that is not occupied.
2. Permanent address numerals shall be attached or otherwise displayed upon the structure or premises within one hundred eighty (180) days of the
adoption of this chapter. (Ord. 15-3836, 6-8-2015)
10-12-8: CHANGES IN THE NAMES OF STREETS AND THE NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS AND LOTS:
Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-80-18, the corporate authorities of the village may regulate the numbering of buildings and lots. No change
in the numbering of buildings and lots shall be effective until thirty (30) days after the applicable election authority having jurisdiction in the area in which
such numbering is changed and the U.S. postal service branch serving that area have been notified by the corporate authority initiating such action of the
change in writing by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. (Ord. 15-3836, 6-8-2015)
10-12-9: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be a violation of this chapter to fail to display the address as prescribed herein, or to display any address not officially assigned. (Ord. 15-3836, 6-8-
2015)

thereto (the "comprehensive plan, as amended") is the official comprehensive plan of the village. This plan may be amended from time to time pursuant to
law without amendment of this code. (Ord. 09-3495, 2-9-2009)

No map or plat of any subdivision presented for record affecting lands within the corporate limits or any contiguous territory outside of and distant not more
than one and one-half (11/2) miles from the corporate limits of the village shall be approved by the corporate authorities or be entitled to record or shall be
valid unless such subdivision complies with such official comprehensive plan. (Ord. 09-3495, 2-9-2009)

Chapter 3
DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS
Title, Purpose, Applicability And Administration
11-3-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be cited and referred to as the VILLAGE OF BARRINGTON DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS and may also be referred to in this code
as the "village of Barrington subdivision regulations". (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-2: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the development of land located within, and within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the
village and the regulations set forth in this chapter are hereby made a part of the official comprehensive plan of the village of Barrington ("the village"), as
may be amended from time to time. This chapter is also intended to provide for the harmonious development of the village and its environs; for the
coordination of streets within new developments with other existing or planned streets; for the dedication and acceptance of land for public use; for the
installation and construction of utilities, roadways and other improvements essential to service the developments; for the dedication and acceptance of
land required for schools, parks, playgrounds, and other public uses; for the preparation of subdivision and other development plans and the procedure for
the submittal thereof to the village and the related public hearing process, approval and recording of plats of subdivision, when required by and in
compliance with the relevant provisions of this code and the Illinois statutes.
The purpose of this chapter is also:
A. To promote and protect the public health, safety, convenience and the general welfare.
B. To facilitate the orderly growth and development of the Village by providing suitable residential, commercial and industrial developments consistent with
the official comprehensive plan.
C. To secure a safe traffic circulation system by having a good relationship between the street system, adjoining developments, and public facilities.
D. To achieve homesites of maximum utility and livability.
E. To ensure adequate provisions for water, drainage, sanitary sewer facilities and other health requirements.
F. To secure adequate provisions for roads, recreational and open space areas, school sites and other public facilities.
G. To facilitate the further resubdivision of large tracts into smaller parcels of land.
H. To preserve the character of the Village and contiguous unincorporated territory.
I. To preserve the ecological system and the environment.
J. To establish standards of design and reasonable procedures for subdivision and resubdivision and other development of land within the Village and
adjacent unincorporated areas which are within the subdivision jurisdiction of the Village.
K. To assist land developers and public officials in processing subdivisions and making other decisions about them.
L. To avoid disturbing areas subject to flooding.
M. To preserve natural vegetation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 496/522
N. To define and limit the powers and duties of the administrative officers and bodies that administer and enforce these regulations.
O. To help enforce the development standards contained in the other applicable ordinances of the Village. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-3: JURISDICTION:
Whenever any subdivision or other development of land shall hereafter occur within the corporate limits of the Village or within one and one-half (11/2)
miles beyond the corporate limits of the Village ("subdivision jurisdiction"), unless otherwise provided by an existing intergovernmental boundary
agreement executed by the Village, the developer thereof or his agent, shall submit to the Village both a preliminary plan therefor and, if applicable, a
preliminary plat of subdivision, and shall thereafter be required to submit a final plan and, if applicable, a final plat of subdivision to the Village. All public
improvements within the corporate limits of the Village and within its subdivision jurisdiction shall be installed in accordance with the design standards and
requirements of this chapter. Said plans and plats, the proposed public improvements, and all procedures relating thereto, shall in all respects, be in
substantial compliance with the regulations set forth herein, provided, however, except any subdivision and/or other development of land lying outside of
the Village and within one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits of the Village, shall also be required to comply with the regulations of the
County in which the property is located whenever said County requirements are more stringent than the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-
2014)
11-3-4: APPLICABILITY:
A. Compliance Required: No landowner may subdivide or plat or otherwise develop any land within the Village or within its subdivision jurisdiction unless
the procedures of this chapter are followed and the requirements of these development regulations are met.
B. Sales Prohibited Prior To Approval Of Final Plat: No owner or agent of the owner of any parcel of land located in a proposed subdivision or other
development shall transfer or sell such parcel before a final plan and, if applicable, a final plat of subdivision has been approved in accordance with the
terms of these regulations.
C. Applicability: These development regulations shall be applicable to:
1. All subdivision of land within the corporate limits of the Village.
2. All resubdivision of land heretofore platted within the corporate limits of the Village, except as otherwise provided in subsection D2 of this section.
3. All subdivision of land and the resubdivision of land heretofore platted within the subdivision jurisdiction of the Village, except where the Village has a
boundary agreement with another municipality or the subdivision jurisdiction of another municipality overlaps the subdivision jurisdiction of the
Village.
a. Boundary agreements between the Village and other municipalities will take precedence in determining the Village's subdivision jurisdiction for
unincorporated areas;
b. If another municipality's subdivision jurisdiction overlaps the subdivision jurisdiction of the Village and there is no boundary agreement that applies,
these development regulations shall be applicable to the territory from the corporate limits of the Village to a line equidistant from its boundary and
the boundary of the other municipality nearest to the Village at any given point on the land.
4. All development other than subdivisions or resubdivisions which affect or relate to the need for public improvements and/or which includes or may
include the installation thereof (present or proposed).
5. Any condominium development, any planned unit development, and any other residential, commercial or industrial building and/or other
development on one (1) or more lots, tracts or parcels of land which affects or relates to the need for public improvements and/or which includes or
may include the installation thereof (present or proposed).
D. Exceptions: These development regulations shall not be applicable to the following situations, consistent with the definition of a "subdivision" as set
forth in this chapter:
1. The division or subdivision of land into parcels or tracts of five (5) acres or more in size which does not involve any new streets or easements of
access and which does not create or increase the need for public improvements (present or future) and/or which includes or may include the
installation thereof.
2. The division of lots or blocks of less than one (1) acre in any recorded subdivision: a) which does not involve any new streets or easements of
access; b) which does not create or increase the need for public improvements (present or future) and/or which includes or may include the
installation thereof; c) which is in the nature of a consolidation of existing lots, parcels, and/or portions of lots or parcels of record; d) which, based
upon a written determination by the Village's Zoning Official, creates only a single zoning lot which is in compliance with the requirements of the
Village of Barrington zoning ordinance or does not create any new or increased nonconformities with respect to the relevant provisions of said zoning
ordinance; and e) further provided that in order to document said consolidation, a plat of consolidation or plat of resubdivision shall be prepared by
an Illinois Registered Land Surveyor and recorded with the applicable County Recorder of Deeds by the owner(s) of the subject property in order to
document this exception and waiver of the respective provisions of these development regulations and pursuant to section 1(c) of the Plat Act1.
3. The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining and contiguous land but excluding any resubdivision of land heretofore
subdivided or platted and which does not create or increase the need for public improvement(s) (present or future) and/or which includes or may
include the installation thereof, and which does not result in the creation of any additional lots, and which does not result in creation of any lots or
parcels which are nonconforming relative to the requirements of this chapter or pursuant to the requirements of the Village of Barrington zoning
ordinance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 497/522
4. The conveyance of parcels of land or interests therein for use as a right-of-way for railroads or other public utility facilities and other pipelines which
does not involve any new streets or easements or access and which does not create or increase the need for public improvements (present or
future) and/or which includes or may include the installation thereof.
5. The conveyance of land owned by a railroad or other public utility which does not involve any new streets or easements of access and which does
not create or increase the need for public improvements (present or future) and/or which includes or may include the installation thereof.
6. The conveyance of land for a road, street, highway or other public purposes or grants or conveyances relating to the dedication of land for public use
or instruments relating to the vacation of land impressed with a public use.
7. Conveyances made to correct descriptions in prior conveyances.
8. The sale or exchange of parcels or tracts of land following the division into no more than two (2) parts of a particular parcel or tract of land existing
on July 17, 1959, and which does not involve any new streets or easements of access and which does not create or increase the need for public
improvements and/or which includes or may include the installation thereof, and which does not result in creation of any lots or parcels which are
nonconforming relative to the requirements of this chapter or pursuant to the requirements of the Village of Barrington zoning ordinance. (Ord. 17-
3929, 2-27-2017)
11-3-5: LEGAL AUTHORITY AND STATUS:
A. Applicable Statutes: This chapter, and the development regulations set forth herein, are adopted pursuant to the legal authority of the Village provided
by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-12-5, 5/11-12-5.1, 5/11-12-6, 5/11-12-7, 5/11-12-8, 5/11-12-9, and 5/11-15-1.
B. Conflict With Other Instruments: In case of conflict between any part of these development regulations and any other valid legal instrument, the most
restrictive provisions shall apply in every case.
C. Minimum Requirements And Interpretation:
1. Minimum Requirements: In their interpretation and application, the provisions of these development regulations shall be held to be the minimum
requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals, convenience and general welfare.
2. Higher Standards Govern: Where the development regulations imposed by any provision of this chapter are either more restrictive or less restrictive
than comparable regulations for the same site imposed by any other provision of this code or any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation
of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements shall govern.
3. Abrogation: This chapter is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant or other private agreement; provided, however, that where the
development regulations of this chapter are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements than any such easements, covenants or
other private agreements, the requirements of this chapter shall govern and prevail. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-6: APPROVALS, INTERPRETATIONS AND EXCEPTIONS:
A. No plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to be recorded in the office of the applicable county recorder of deeds or have any validity, or any
development which constitutes, affects, or is related to the need for public improvements (present or future) and/or includes or may include the
installation thereof, until it shall have received final approval by resolution or ordinance of the corporate authorities of the village in the manner
prescribed by this chapter and the other applicable provisions of this code.
B. No land shall hereafter be subdivided or filed for record, nor any street laid out, nor any public improvements made to the land, nor shall any
development activities commence on the land until the respective final plat of subdivision and/or the related plans for said development, including for
the public improvements which are part thereof, are approved by action of the corporate authorities of the village. This approval must be in writing and
the village's written approval placed on the original of the respective final plat prior to the recording thereof according to the procedure outlined in
section 11-3-27 of this chapter.
C. No lot, tract, parcel of land, or condominium within any such subdivision or within any other development shall be offered for sale, nor shall any sale,
contract for sale, or option be made or given until the final plat therefor and the final plans for the development, if any, shall have been approved in
writing by the corporate authorities of the village.
D. No public improvements shall be installed, nor shall any development activities occur within any such subdivision by any owner or owners or his or their
agent, or by any public service corporation at the request of such owner or owners or their agent until the respective final plat, if any, and also the final
plans for improvements to such subdivision or other development have been the subject of review and a recommendation by the village's plan
commission and approval in writing by the corporate authorities of the village.
E. Where a tract of land is proposed for subdivision that is part of a larger, logical subdivision unit in relation to the village as a whole, the corporate
authorities of the village may cause to be prepared, a possible plan of the entire area for the purpose of providing both the plan commission and the
corporate authorities an aid in evaluating the proposed plat and/or plans.
F. All interpretations of this chapter are reserved to the village's enforcement officer, its plan commission, and finally, to its corporate authorities.
G. The corporate authorities of the village may grant, in writing, variations and/or exceptions as set forth herein where there is sufficient evidence, in its
sole opinion, of hardship caused by topographical conditions, or where any other unique conditions may exist, provided such variations or exceptions
are in substantial compliance with the spirit and intent of the village's official comprehensive plan, as may be amended from time to time.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 498/522
H. Whenever the areas divided into lots containing larger lots, such as, for example, one to three (3) acres, and there are indications that such lots will
eventually be resubdivided or redeveloped into smaller building lots, consideration shall be given to the street and lot arrangement of the original
subdivision so that additional minor streets can be opened which will permit a logical arrangement of future smaller lots. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-7: REVOCATION OF SITE DEVELOPMENT PERMIT:
In addition to imposing any penalties as provided in this chapter and/or as otherwise provided in this code, the village is authorized to suspend and/or
revoke any site development permit issued by the village pursuant to this chapter, for any violation of any of the terms and/or conditions of such permit,
and/or for any violation of the provisions of this chapter, including, but not limited to, activities such as site development in such a manner that is materially
detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to person, property or the environment in the neighborhood and/or surrounding areas, and/or a temporary
suspension of the respective site development permit may be imposed effective immediately upon written notification by any authorized representative of
the village to the person and/or entity to whom the site development permit was issued. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-8: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
A. Violations: Violations of the provisions of this chapter, including, but not limited to, failure to comply with any of the requirements of this chapter, the
other applicable provisions of this code, and/or the terms and/or conditions related to any permit issued by the village, shall be subject to a fine for each
offense.
B. Enforcement: The village employee or agent designated by the village manager shall be the enforcement officer for purposes of this chapter. This
chapter may be enforced by injunction, mandamus, abatement by the village, civil penalties, and/or any other appropriate actions in law or equity.
C. Accumulation Of Violations: Each day that each violation of this chapter exists and/or continues shall be a separate offense for the purposes of the
fines, penalties and/or remedies imposed by and/or available to the village. The accumulation of fines and/or penalties for violations, but not the
obligation for payment of fines and/or penalties imposed by the village for violations already committed, may, at the sole discretion of the village, cease
upon the correction of the respective violation(s).
D. Civil Penalties: All fines and penalties for any violation of this chapter shall be as specified in section 1-14-1 of this code, as such section may be
amended from time to time. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-9: APPEALS:
A. Establishment And Purpose: A process of appeals of the decisions of the enforcement officer is hereby established to provide appropriate checks and
balances on delegated administrative authority.
B. Authority: The corporate authorities of the village shall hear and make final decisions on all applications for appeals of administrative decisions made by
the enforcement officer.
C. Decisions Appealed: Any decisions and/or interpretations of this chapter by the enforcement officer can be appealed.
D. Application: Appeals shall be filed in accordance with the requirements of the application for appeal. Submission materials shall conform to the
requirements as specified on that application. Submission materials shall be forwarded to the corporate authorities of the village for review.
E. Decisions On Appeals: The corporate authorities of the village shall hear and make a final decision on an appeal at its next available, regularly
scheduled village board meeting. Upon conclusion of such a hearing, the corporate authorities of the village shall determine whether or not the permit
shall be suspended or revoked.
F. Limitations On Appeals: A written application for such appeal shall be delivered to the village within thirty (30) days of the respective decision(s) and/or
interpretation(s) appealed from. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-10: EFFECTIVE DATE:
The effective date of this chapter is the date of adoption thereof by the corporate authorities of the village, this date being November 10, 2014. (Ord. 14-
3798, 11-10-2014)
Definitions
11-3-11: DEFINITIONS GENERALLY:
For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms and words are defined and are used in this chapter in that defined context. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-12: WORD USAGE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 499/522
The following rules of word usage apply to the text of this chapter:
A. The particular shall control the general.
B. Words used or defined in one tense or form shall include other tenses or forms.
C. Words in the singular number shall include the plural number. Words in the plural number shall include the singular number.
D. The masculine gender shall include the feminine. The feminine gender shall include the masculine.
E. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary. The word "may" is permissive.
F. The word "person" includes individuals, partnerships, firms, corporations, associations, trusts, and any similar entities or combination of individuals.
G. A "building" or "structure" includes any part thereof.
H. The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for", "designed for", or "occupied by".
I. Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two (2) or more items, conditions, provisions, or events connected by the
conjunction "and", "or" or "either or", the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows:
1. "And" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events shall apply.
2. "Or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events may apply singly or in any combination.
3. "Either or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provision, or events shall apply singly, but not in combination.
J. The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specified examples, but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like
kind or character. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-13: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
ACCEPTED PUBLIC STREET: Any street duly accepted in writing by the corporate authorities of the village for maintenance thereof by the village.
ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER OR ADMINISTRATION AUTHORITY: The village manager or any officer designated by him/her to administer and enforce
this chapter (also see definition of Enforcement Officer).
ALLEY: A strip of land along the side of or in the rear of properties intended to provide access to those properties abutting and/or adjacent to said strip of
land.
APPROVED STREET: Any street, whether public or private, meeting standards or specifications of the village and/or otherwise accepted by the village for
dedication.
BIKE PATH: A designated right of way provided for the specific use of pedestrians and bicycles.
BOARD OR VILLAGE BOARD: See definition of Corporate Authorities.
BUILDING LINE: A line parallel to a lot line set at the closest point of the principal building, excluding allowable obstructions, to such lot line.
BUILDING SETBACK LINE: A building line establishing the minimum allowable distance between a street right of way line or property line and any
structure.
CALIPER: Measurement used for nursery stock. The diameter of a tree trunk as measured six inches (6") above ground line for nursery trees up to and
including four inches (4") in caliper and as measured twelve inches (12") above ground line for nursery trees larger than four inches (4") in caliper.
COMMISSION: Whenever the word "commission" is used in this chapter, it shall be deemed to refer to the plan commission of the village.
COMPREHENSIVE PLAN: The official comprehensive plan, or any geographical or functional part thereof, as adopted and amended from time to time by
the village.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The president and board of trustees of the village.
COUNTY ENGINEER: Chief administrative official of the Lake County division of transportation or Cook County highway department.
CRITICAL ROOT ZONE: That area around a tree as defined by the following calculation: for each inch of tree as measured by the standard dbh method,
one foot (1') of area around the tree in all directions as measured from the base of that tree.
CUL-DE-SAC: A street having one open end and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 500/522
DEVELOP: See definition of Development Or To Develop.
DEVELOPER: The owner, representative or petitioner who proposes to construct, build, use, subdivide, or resubdivide property.
DEVELOPMENT OR TO DEVELOP: Any subdivision, resubdivision, or any other project which includes any construction or installation of site
improvements on a lot or parcel which affects or relates to the need (present or future) for public improvements and/or which includes and/or may include
the installation of such public improvements.
DIAMETER BREAST HEIGHT (dbh): The diameter of a tree measured four and one-half feet (4.5') above the existing ground line.
EASEMENT: A strip of land on or between parcels of land dedicated for use for a specific purpose or purposes, including, but not limited to, use by the
village, public and/or utilities, and/or the general public, usually shown on a plat and/or granted by the property owner by a separate easement document,
which shall be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds for the applicable county.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: For purposes of this chapter, the enforcement officer shall be that village employee or agent designated by the village
manager.
ENGINEER: A professional engineer registered in the state of Illinois.
EYEBROW: A bulblike expansion of a street and the pavement thereof that provides access to lots and serves as a vehicle turnaround.
FRONTAGE, BLOCK: All the property on one side of a street between two (2) intersecting streets (crossing or terminating) measured along the line of the
street, or if the street is dead ended, then all the property abutting on one side between an intersecting street and the dead end of the street.
FRONTAGE, LOT: The length of all of the property of such lot fronting on a street, as measured between side lot lines.
FRONTAGE ROAD: A street, often parallel to and providing access to the adjacent land where direct access to such street is precluded.
FRONTAGE ROAD, REVERSE: A street often parallel to a high volume road and located behind the adjacent buildings, instead of between the buildings
and the major road.
INSPECTOR: The authorized and designated representative of the village manager assigned to make detailed inspection(s) of any or all portions of the
work or material thereof.
KEY TREE: Any tree identified by a qualified arborist as an exceptionally good example of the species, in good to excellent condition, that has a diameter
breast height of twenty four inches (24") or larger and that is a variety of the following species: oak, hickory, walnut, sugar maple, or any other species
listed in the definition of Significant Tree.
LOT: A parcel of subdivided land duly recorded.
MONUMENT AND BENCHMARK SYSTEM: The village of Barrington monument and benchmark system refers to the horizontal control as state plane
coordinates with second order, class II (1:20,000) accuracy and the vertical control as United States geological survey elevations with second order, class
II (1:20,000) accuracy respectively. The control monumentation for the village of Barrington is contained in the "benchmark location exhibits" book as
amended from time to time.
OWNER: Any person having legal or equitable title to the land sought to be subdivided.
PARKWAY: An unpaved strip of land within the right of way of a street between a sidewalk and the back of curb or edge of pavement, or if there is no
sidewalk, between the lot line and the back of curb or edge of pavement.
PEDESTRIANWAY: A right of way, however designated, across or within a block for use by pedestrian traffic, which shall include, but not be limited to,
sidewalks and crosswalks.
PERSON: A firm, association, authority, organization, partnership, company or corporation as well as an individual.
PLAT: A map, drawing, or chart on which the developer's plan of the subdivision is presented and which he submits for approval and intends to record
when in final form.
PLAT, FINAL: The final plat of the subdivision, including, but not limited to, plats of consolidation and plats of resubdivision, or the final plan for a
development, with accompanying material, which is submitted to the village for approval.
PLAT OFFICER: The plat officer for the village shall be the village engineer.
PLAT, PRELIMINARY: A preliminary plat of subdivision or plan with accompanying material, upon which the design for the subdivision is presented, and
submitted to the village for approval, but not recording.
PRELIMINARY PLAN: The drawings and documents described in section 11-3-26 of this chapter.
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT(S): Facilities (present or future) protecting the public health, safety, and welfare, including, but not limited to, public or private
streets, highways, alleys, public grounds, easements for utilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, and/or pedestrianways and/or bicycle paths, streetlights, parks,
playgrounds, school grounds, stormwater drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers and sewage collection and/or treatment facilities.
PUBLIC STREET: All major and minor collector streets and all local streets and cul-de-sacs which are shown on the subdivision plat and dedicated for
public use and accepted by the village or appropriate public body.
PUBLIC TREE: Any tree that is on public property including the dedicated right of way of all roads and streets.
RESERVE STRIP: A strip of land, smaller than a lot, and retained in private ownership as a means of controlling access to land.
RESUBDIVISION: The relocation of property boundaries, or the reallocation of property lines in a recorded subdivision. The vacation of property lines not
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 501/522
accompanied by the relocation of new property lines shall not constitute resubdivision, but rather, a vacation of the subdivision.
RIGHT OF WAY: A strip of land acquired by reservation, dedication, prescription, or condemnation intended to be occupied or occupied by a road, alley,
sidewalk, trail, bicycle path, or similar use(s).
ROAD OR ROADWAY: The paved area within the street right of way, not including private drive aprons.
SIGNIFICANT TREE: Any tree identified by a qualified arborist in good to excellent condition, that has a diameter breast height of twelve inches (12") or
larger and that has a species rating percentage of sixty (60) or greater as listed in the species ratings and appraisal factors for Illinois published by the
International Society Of Arboriculture and is a variety of the following species: black maple, sugar maple, common hackberry, Turkish filbert, cockspur
hawthorn, green ash, thornless honey locust, Kentucky coffee tree, crab apple, douglas fir, callery pear, white oak, swamp white oak, bur oak, chinquapin
oak, English oak, bald cypress, white cedar arborvitae, redmond linden, hedge maple, amur maple, Norway maple, red maple, Ohio buckeye, serviceberry,
river birch, shagbark hickory, American hornbeam, redbud, pagoda dogwood, Washington hawthorn, European beech, ginkgo, eastern red cedar, Norway
spruce, white spruce, Colorado spruce, eastern white pine, hill's oak, pin oak, chestnut oak, red oak, Peking lilac, Japanese lilac, American linden, little
leaf linden, hybrid elm, lacebark elm, common horsechestnut, American beech, tuliptree, saucer magnolia, London planetree, amur chokecherry, or any
other species determined by the village manager, or his designee.
SIGNIFICANT VEGETATION: Indigenous, herbaceous and small woody plants less than twelve inches (12") diameter at breast height, as determined by
the village manager or his designee, that may grow in association with or apart from significant trees, wetlands, or prairie remnants.
SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL SUBDIVISION: A single-family residential subdivision of land includes the division of land for single-family residential
purposes, into two (2) or more lots, sites or parcels and may include the dedication or establishment of a public or private road, highway or street through a
parcel of land.
SITE PLAN: A plan as specified by the village manager or his designee that shows all of the existing features and proposed changes to a development
site.
STREET: A vehicularway, whether public or private, which may also serve for all or part of its width as a way for pedestrian traffic, whether called street,
highway, thoroughfare, parkway, throughway, road, avenue, boulevard, lane, place, alley, mall or otherwise designated.
STREET, ARTERIAL: A continuous roadway through the village linking it to other villages or cities. (See appendix E on file with the village for street
designations.)
STREET, LOCAL: A street that extends block to block and is not continuous. (See appendix E on file with the village for street designations.)
STREET, MAJOR COLLECTOR: A street which connects local and arterial roadways. Not always continuous through the village. (See appendix E on file
with the village for street designations.)
STREET, MINOR COLLECTOR: A street which connects local roadways, usually to major collector streets. Not always continuous through a village or city.
(See appendix E on file with the village for street designations.)
STREET, RIGHT OF WAY: All property dedicated or intended for streets.
STREET WIDTH: The shortest distance between the lines delineating the right of way of a street.
SUBDIVISION: For the purposes of these development regulations, any condominium development, planned unit development, and other residential,
commercial, industrial and/or other development on one or more lots, tracts or parcels of land which affects or relates to the need for public improvements
and/or which includes or may include the installation thereof (present or proposed). For the purpose of these development regulations, a subdivision of
land includes resubdivision, and/or consolidations of land.
SUBDIVISION JURISDICTION: Within, and within one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits of the village, unless otherwise provided by an
intergovernmental boundary agreement executed by the village.
SURVEYOR: A land surveyor registered in the state of Illinois.
TREE: Any self-supporting woody plant together with its root system, growing upon the earth usually with one trunk, or a multistemmed trunk system,
supporting a definitely formed crown.
TREE PRESERVATION: Actions undertaken to preserve and protect trees, including, but not limited to, welling to protect from change in grade, mulching,
root pruning, crown pruning, and construction fencing, in a manner consistent with this chapter, to implement the following objectives:
A. To preserve trees as an important and valuable public resource that contributes significantly to the quality of life and the general welfare of the
village and its citizens;
B. To preserve and enhance the unique character and the physical, historical, and aesthetic environment of the village;
C. To aid in controlling stormwater runoff, stabilizing soil by preventing erosion and sedimentation, and replenishing groundwater supplies;
D. To enhance air quality, in that trees remove carbon dioxide, generate oxygen, and filter air pollutants;
E. To reduce noise, in that trees provide a buffer and screen from the spread of noise;
F. To reduce energy consumption, in that trees provide shade and a windbreak effect;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 502/522
G. To preserve and enhance the habitat and food source for birds and other wildlife; and
H. To protect and increase property values.
TREE PRESERVATION PLAN: A written plan having graphics and text that indicates the methods which are to be used to preserve existing trees during
and after the construction process. The plan will contain all pertinent information as may be required by the village manager, or his designee.
TREE SURVEY: A document having text and graphics that includes the species, size, condition, and location of all live trees on the subject property prior
to any construction activity. The survey will contain a level of detail and other pertinent information as may be required by the village manager or his
designee.
TYPE MAP: A map delineating the types of existing vegetation by dominant species, size and condition.
ZONING OFFICIAL: The person as appointed by the village manager or his designee.
ZONING ORDINANCE: The village of Barrington zoning ordinance, as amended from time to time. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
Subdivision Standards
11-3-14: CHARACTER OF DEVELOPMENT:
The corporate authorities and village manager or his designee shall confer with a developer regarding the type and character of the proposed
development, and, as part of that process, may impose upon the developer certain minimum conditions and restrictions in order to ensure that all of the
proposed structures are built in substantial compliance with all applicable regulations and ordinances of the village, and to ensure that the proposed land
use is in compliance with the village's comprehensive plan, as amended from time to time, in order to maintain the character and value of the proposed
development and of adjoining property. Deed restrictions or covenants may be included to provide for the creation of a property owner's association or
board of trustees for the proper protection and maintenance of the development and the related public and/or private improvements in the future provided,
however, that such deed restrictions or covenants shall not contain reversionary clauses wherein any lot shall return to the developer because of a
violation thereon of the terms of the restrictions or covenants. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-15: BLOCK STANDARDS:
A. The length, width and shape of blocks within the proposed development shall be determined with due regard for the following:
1. Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the needs of the type(s) of use(s) contemplated.
2. Zoning requirements as to lot size and dimensions.
3. Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic.
4. Limitations and opportunities of topography.
B. No block shall exceed one thousand two hundred feet (1,200') in length except where required by unusual topographic conditions, nor shall they be less
than four hundred feet (400') in length. Blocks over six hundred feet (600') may require easements for crosswalks. Crosswalk easements not less than
twenty feet (20') in width shall be provided where deemed necessary by the village manager or his designee at the approximate centers of the blocks.
Additional crosswalks may be required in order to provide safe and convenient pedestrian and/or bicycle access to schools, parks or other destinations
as recommended by the village manager or his designee.
C. Although there is no specific rule concerning the shape of a block, blocks must fit easily into the overall plan of the development, and their design must
show consideration of lot planning, traffic flow and public areas.
D. The plan must show adequate off street areas to provide for parking, loading and/or loading docks, as the case may be, and such other facilities that
may be required to accommodate motor vehicles. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-16: LOT STANDARDS:
A. Lot dimensions and area shall be not less than the lot dimensions and area otherwise required by the applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance, as
may be amended from time to time.
B. All side lot lines shall be at right angles to the straight street lines, or radial to curved street lines unless a variation to this rule will give a better street
and lot plan. Lots with double frontage should be avoided.
C. All lots shall front directly on a publicly dedicated and improved street. Lots adjoining regional arterial and major arterials shall be provided with frontage
roads or front on an interior street and access directly to the arterials shall be prohibited. An indication shall appear on the final plat where access is
prohibited.
D. Lots abutting a regional arterial or major arterial, a railroad, utility right of way or other inharmonious use shall have a width or a depth of forty feet (40')
in excess of the typical interior lot in the same subdivision. A planting screen easement, across which there shall be no right of access, shall be
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 503/522
required on such lots.
E. Where said lots front upon a cul-de-sac or curved road or street having a radius of two hundred feet (200') or less, the minimum width of the frontage at
the lot may be measured at the building line, with the width at the said right of way line to be not less than fifty percent (50%) of the width required, with
said width being measured on the arc of the street right of way line.
F. The area of the street right of way, whether dedicated to the public or a private street or easement for the street purposes shall not be included in
calculating the area of the lot to be in accordance with the minimum lot area requirements of the zoning district in which the lot is located. The lots shall
have a width and a depth entirely adequate to provide necessary yard requirements of the zoning ordinance, as may be amended from time to time.
G. Corner lots shall have extra width sufficient to permit the establishment of front building lines on both the front and the side of the lots adjoining the
streets.
H. Lots upon major highway intersections and at all other acute angle intersections which, in the opinion of the corporate authorities, are likely to be
dangerous to traffic movement shall have a radius of twenty feet (20') at the street corner. On business lots, a chord may be substituted for the circular
arc. Where grade separation structures are proposed at the intersection of major highways, the lots and improvements in the subdivision shall be
arranged so as to make adequate provisions for such structure.
I. Lots abutting a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, shall have additional minimum width or depth as required to provide an adequate building
site and afford the minimum usage area required to provide an adequate building site and afford the minimum usable area required in the zoning
ordinance for front, rear and side yards. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-17: BUILDING LINES:
A. Building lines shall be shown on plans for all subdivisions. Restrictions requiring buildings to be set back to such building lines shall be shown on the
plan which shall also contain a reference that the dimensions thereof were accurate as of the time of recording, but if such building lines are based
upon the zoning ordinance, they may be preempted by later amendments of the zoning ordinance, as it may hereafter be amended from time to time.
B. Building lines for territory outside of the corporate limits of the village, but within the jurisdiction of this chapter, shall conform to the provisions of the
applicable county ordinance, except that in no instance shall the building lines be less than the minimum required by the zoning ordinance for its most
similar zoning classification. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-18: STREETS:
A. Street Plan: The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets, alleys, or other land to be dedicated for public use, shall be
consistent with the comprehensive plan, and the zoning ordinance, as well as with all other applicable ordinances of the village, all as they may be
amended from time to time. A street plan shall be considered in relation to existing and planned streets, to the existing topography, drainage, and
natural features of the site, and to public convenience and safety in relation to the proposed uses of the land.
B. Minimum Street Widths And Design Standards: The minimum widths of rights of way for public streets to be dedicated or minimum parcel width for
private roads to be established after the effective date of this chapter within the village and/or under jurisdiction of this chapter, shall be in substantial
compliance with the following schedule:
TABLE 3.5-A: STREET WIDTHS AND DESIGN STANDARDS
Street Designation
Minimum ROW/
Parcel Width
Minimum Pavement Width
(Back Of Curb To Back Of Curb)
Alley 24 feet 20 feet
Cul-de-sac1 66 feet/100 feet 27 feet/75 feet
Arterial 100 feet 48 feet
Major collector 80 feet 36 feet
Minor collector 66 feet 27 feet
Local 66 feet 27 feet
Note:
1. The first cul-de-sac dimension of the right of way and pavement width standards refer to the neck of the cul-de-sac, the second to the terminals
or bulb of the cul-de-sac.
1. Street Thickness: For street thickness design refer to the bituminous pavement detail in appendix A on file with the village.
2. Road Details: For road details such as minimum horizontal centerline radius and minimum tangent please refer to the latest edition of the "Bureau Of
Local Roads Design Manual" by the state of Illinois department of transportation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 504/522
3. Classification Determination: The village manager, or his designee, shall determine the classification of any and all proposed rights of way upon
review of the proposed development.
4. Local Streets: Local streets shall be laid out that their use by through or high speed traffic will be discouraged.
5. Street Jogs: Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') as measured from the centerline of one street to the
centerline of the other street shall not be permitted.
6. Clear Visibility: Clear visibility, measured along the centerline of the street shall be provided for at least three hundred feet (300') on all major
collector streets, for at least two hundred feet (200') on minor collector streets, and for at least one hundred fifty feet (150') on all other streets.
7. Street Intersections: All street intersections shall be designed to ensure safe traffic flow. Street intersections shall be at right angles. Where unusual
conditions exist, the village manager or his designee may permit intersections of less than ninety degrees (90°) but not less than sixty degrees (60°).
In all cases, street intersections and junctions shall be laid out so as to facilitate the safe flow of traffic. In no case shall two (2) junctions be offset
less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') as measured from the centerline of one street to the centerline of other street.
8. Maximum Length: The maximum length of cul-de-sacs or areas of the development accessed by a single road shall be six hundred feet (600')
measured along the centerline from the furthest extent of the right of way to the centerline of the nearest intersecting street. Each cul-de-sac shall
have a terminus or nearly circular shape with a minimum diameter as specified in table 3.5-A of this section.
9. Eyebrows: Eyebrows shall not be permitted.
10. Half Streets: Half streets shall not be permitted except to complete an existing half street which is dedicated and accepted, or to conform to the
official comprehensive plan of the village of Barrington.
11. Frontage Roads:
a. The complete design for frontage roads, including, but not limited to, specifications and designation for trafficways, driving lanes, paving widths,
thickness, materials, etc., shall be submitted prior to the issuance of building permits.
b. Frontage roads and parking areas shall be constructed in accordance with the design requirements of a local street as specified in table 3.5-A of
this section.
c. Where more than one owner or lessee are to use the same private driveway or parking lot, an easement document satisfactory to the village shall
be recorded which specifies the rights and obligations of the respective parties before approval of the development which will utilize same as
defined herein.
d. A minimum distance between points of ingress and egress may be required where deemed necessary for all property to be subdivided or
otherwise developed is under one ownership on the effective date of this chapter. Where property has frontage on a state or a federal highway, the
spacing and design of the points of ingress and egress to the major highway shall be subject to the approval of the agency having jurisdictional
control of that roadway.
12. Reserve Strips: Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall not be permitted.
13. Street Names: No new street names may be used which will duplicate or be confused with the names of existing streets within the village, the
village's planning jurisdiction. Wherever a new street aligns with an existing street, the existing street name shall be continued to the new portion
thereof.
14. Major Collector: Where a development borders on or contains an existing or proposed major collector street, the corporate authorities may require
a frontage road or reverse frontage road with screen planting contained in a landscape easement which prohibits access. Such landscaped area
shall have a minimum width of ten feet (10') along the rear of the property line; or other treatment as may be adequate to buffer residential properties
and to afford separation of through and local traffic.
15. Land Adjacent To Highways: If the tract of land proposed to be subdivided or otherwise developed, or any part thereof, lies adjacent to one or more
highway(s) over which IDOT and/or a county engineer has jurisdiction and an entrance or entrances are desired from such highway to lots, streets,
roadways, or alleys in such subdivision and/or development, the developer shall submit to the village manager, a written permit from the IDOT or
from the applicable county engineer(s), granting their respective permission to obtain and construct such an entrance or entrances.
16. Development: Wherever a development borders on or contains the right of way of a limited access highway; a railroad; or a utility right of way, a
street may be required approximately parallel to, and on either side of, such right of way for a distance suitable to service such uses as front thereon.
17. Streets On Boundary: Streets shall not be laid out on the boundary of a subdivision and/or other development. Exceptions to this may be permitted
where the village manager or his designee finds that such streets are desirable for further expansion of the village or of the development or where
such streets will be consistent with the layout of the existing street system.
18. Streets Paralleling Boundary: Streets roughly paralleling the subdivision or development boundary shall be located either on that boundary, if
permitted pursuant to one of the exceptions set forth in this subsection B18, or not less than one lot depth from said boundary. Where practical to do
so, streets shall be extended to the subdivision boundary so as to provide for future access to the adjoining property.
C. Street Construction Standards: All streets dedicated or platted after the effective date of this chapter, shall be improved with roadway paving in
accordance with the requirements specified in appendix A on file with the village.
1. Heavily traveled streets in industrial and residential areas shall be considered on an individual basis and pavement designs shall be based on
specific engineering data for each street;
2. All new roadways shall be bordered by portland concrete cement curb designated as state standard B-6.12 concrete curbs in accordance with the
detail specified in appendix A on file with the village.
3. All roadway construction including subgrade, subbase, base course, surface course, curb and gutter, and related work thereto shall be performed in
accordance with the latest edition of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", by the state of Illinois department of
transportation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 505/522
4. Major and minor collector streets shall not have grades in excess of six percent (6%), and all other streets shall not have grades in excess of eight
percent (8%); provided, however, that all streets shall have grades greater than one-half of one percent to provide for positive drainage.
5. Stormwater inlets shall be provided within the roadway improvements at spacing not greater than three hundred feet (300').
6. All curb corners shall have a radii of not less than fifteen feet (15') and at intersections having high traffic volumes, curb corners shall have a radii of
not less than twenty five feet (25').
7. Street name signs of a type approved by the corporate authorities shall be provided at all street intersections.
8. All streets in developments lying within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of Barrington shall be subject to requirements of these
development regulations.
D. Private Roads:
1. Private roads may be permitted at the sole discretion of the corporate authorities of the village. Wherever such private roads are provided, they shall
meet all applicable standards for public roadways.
2. Private roads may be gated at the sole discretion of the corporate authorities. If private roads are gated, such gates shall be fitted with appropriate
access systems compatible with existing village systems, be provided with a knox box entry system and default to an open position in the event of a
power outage.
3. Street name signs for private roads shall designate the roadway as a private road.
4. Wherever private roads are provided, a declaration of covenants shall be recorded against all properties served by the private road. Such covenants
shall state that the private road shall remain private in perpetuity and include provisions for capital reserves for maintenance and replacement of the
private road.
5. Whenever private roads are provided the developer on behalf of the homeowners' association shall enter into an intergovernmental agreement with
the village to permit access and enforcement of all village regulations on the private roads including, but not limited to: parking restrictions, traffic
enforcement and building and property maintenance codes. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-19: PEDESTRIAN AND BICYCLE ACCOMMODATIONS:
A. Developments Within Village: When a development is within the corporate limits of the village, or the subdivision jurisdiction of the village, concrete
sidewalks, having a width of not less than five feet (5'), shall be constructed along both sides of all streets within the public rights of way, irrespective of
whether adjoining section(s) of the sidewalks exist.
B. Pedestrian Accommodations: All pedestrian accommodations hereinafter constructed or repaired shall be in compliance with the latest federal, state
and local accessibility requirements. All accessible ramps locations shall be individually designed and detailed on the final engineering plans. A typical
accessible ramp detail shall not be deemed sufficient to meet this requirement.
C. Bicycle Accommodations: Bicycle accommodations must be installed on or adjoining the development where depicted by the village's bicycle and
pedestrian plan, irrespective of whether adjoining section(s) of the bicycle accommodations exist.
D. Collector Streets In Single-Family Residential Developments: All local and minor collector streets in single-family residential developments shall have
concrete curbs and gutters and sidewalks along both sides of the street, irrespective of whether adjoining sidewalks exist.
E. Sidewalk Construction Standards: The minimum sidewalk thickness shall be at least five inches (5") thick and shall be increased at driveways to seven
inches (7") thick or six inches (6") thick with wire mesh and shall be of class SI portland concrete cement. (See construction detail in appendix A on file
with the village.)
F. Off Street Bike Path Construction Standards: The minimum bike path thickness shall be at least three inches (3") thick three inch (3") asphalt over eight
inches (8") CA-6 stone. (Required width and other construction details shall be pursuant to the AASHTO "Guide For The Development Of Bicycle
Facilities".)
G. On Street Bike Lane Construction Standards: The minimum on street bike lane pavement thickness shall be the same as the roadway on which it is
located. (Required width and other construction details shall be pursuant to the AASHTO "Guide For The Development Of Bicycle Facilities".)
H. Exception: Bicycle accommodation requirements shall not apply to individual single-family lots that do not require replatting or resubdivision of any kind.
(Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-20: STREET LIGHTING:
A. In all subdivisions and/or developments within the corporate limits of the village, a controller based street lighting system shall be provided throughout
the development by the developer. Streetlight standards shall be installed within the street parkways and shall be served by appropriate wiring with
connections to a public power supply. A light standard shall be located at each street intersection, at the turnaround of each cul-de-sac, and elsewhere
at intervals of not more than three hundred feet (300') alternating on both sides of the roadway. Streetlight standards, luminaries, lamps, and wiring
shall be subject to the approval of the corporate authorities. A minimum of one streetlight standard and one streetlight luminaire shall be provided by
the developer to the village for each ten (10) streetlights required to be installed pursuant to this chapter. The developer shall, if requested by the
village, provide a monetary amount equivalent to the developer's cost for said streetlight standard and luminaire to the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 506/522
B. Privately owned property lights may not be substituted for the streetlighting required above. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-21: UTILITIES:
All utilities, whenever possible, shall be public rather than privately developed facilities.
A. Public Utilities: All utilities, including, without limitation, electric, telephone, gas and cable TV lines shall be installed and maintained underground in
public rights of way or in easements provided for those purposes. All care should be taken to avoid disturbing or damage to trees to be preserved when
any utilities are being installed. If the village manager, or his designee, determines that it is not feasible for any utilities or their appurtenant equipment
to be located underground, the developer shall present a screening plan for such aboveground utilities and their appurtenant equipment and a
proposed screening location for the review and approval of the village manager, or his designee, prior to the installation of such utilities, and the
developer shall install and thereafter maintain in good condition such approved screening. Utilities shall be located in rear yards whenever possible.
B. Sewer And Water Supply: Sanitary sewers and water lines shall be installed to comply with specifications set forth in appendix A on file with the village
and shall be connected to the village's public water supply and sanitary sewer systems, in accordance with plans and specifications approved in writing
by the village.
C. Privately Developed Facilities: Where a development is to contain park areas, stormwater detention facilities and/or other improvements which will not
be maintained by existing public agencies, provisions should be made, as part of recorded deed restrictions, for the continuous maintenance,
supervision, operation and reconstruction of such facilities by the lot owners in the development. Said deed restrictions shall be reviewed and approved
in writing by the corporate authorities of the village, or by its designee, as part of its approval of the final plat and/or as final plans and specifications for
the development. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-22: LANDSCAPING AND TREE PRESERVATION:
A. Landscaping: A preliminary landscaping and tree preservation plan and a final landscaping and tree preservation plan shall be required to be submitted
to the village for each development and shall be reviewed and approved in writing by the village as part of both the preliminary and final plans and
specifications for said development prior to the commencement of any site development activities on the subject property. All parkways within the
dedicated rights of way of streets or other public use areas, shall be graded, seeded, or sodded, in a manner approved in writing by the village
manager. Existing features which would add value to a development or to the community as a whole, such as trees, as herein defined, watercourses,
historic spots, and similar irreplaceable assets, shall be preserved in the landscaping design of the development. No trees shall be removed from any
development nor any change of the grade of the land effected until approval of the preliminary plat has been granted. The preliminary plat or plan shall
show the required tree protection plan as herein specified. The preliminary and final plan shall also show the location of all proposed shade trees
required within the street right of way as required by these regulations.
1. Planting Density: For every acre of green space, a minimum of thirty (30) trees shall be planted. A minimum of fifty percent (50%) of the trees will be
deciduous shade trees, twenty percent (20%) will be evergreen trees, and ten percent (10%) ornamental trees. The remaining twenty percent (20%)
may be from any of the three (3) categories and shall be selected and placed in a manner to further enhance the aesthetic and functional aspects of
the site. Shrubs should be added to the plan to provide accent and screening where necessary.
2. Plant Size: The following distribution by size class will be used to ensure adequate size variation:
Deciduous shade trees 3" 60%
3" - 4.5" 20%
4.5" - 6" 20%
Evergreen trees 6' - 8' 75%
8' - 10' 20%
10' + 5%
Ornamental trees:
Tree form 3" - 3.5" 80%
3.5" - 5" 20%
Clump form 5' - 6' 5%
6' - 8' 75%
8' - 10' 20%
3. Street Trees: Street trees shall be planted throughout the entire development, subject to the following requirements:
a. Such trees are to be planted four feet (4') from the sidewalk within the right of way or as approved by the village manager.
b. One tree shall be planted for every thirty feet (30') of frontage on each side of the street or road unless the corporate authorities shall grant a
waiver or exception from such provisions. Such waiver should be granted only if there are existing trees growing along such right of way or on an
abutting property which in the opinion of the corporate authorities comply with these regulations.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 507/522
c. There shall be adequate spacing between existing and proposed trees. Spacing shall be based on the size at maturity using the following
guidelines: large trees shall be planted no closer than forty feet (40') from any other large tree; medium trees shall be planted no closer than thirty
feet (30') from any other medium tree; small trees shall be planted no closer than twenty feet (20') from any other small tree. Trees of differing
classes shall use the average of two (2) spacing requirements to calculate spacing.
d. Trees shall not be planted within five feet (5') of any underground utilities. Trees shall not be planted within fifteen feet (15') of any aboveground
utility.
e. Trees shall not obstruct or interfere with sight distance visibility, traffic control devices and/or vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
f. Trees under utility lines shall be of species that grows no taller than thirty feet zero inches (30'0") at maturity.
g. The new trees to be planted shall consist of not less than two (2) of the following species:

than two inches (2") as measured at a point twelve inches (12") above the ground line. The developer shall certify to the village that said trees are
free from disease and shall guarantee said trees for a period of one year from the date of planting. The trees shall be transplanted stock and the
transplanting thereof shall be completed within two (2) years from the date of approval of the final plat or final plan by the corporate authorities of
the village.
