https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 508/522
4. Maintenance: The key to the long term success of landscaping is the maintenance and replacement of the plant material. The final landscape plan
as approved by the village shall include a comprehensive maintenance plan as a minimum, which shall include mowing, pruning, watering,
cultivating, fertilizing, weed control, and insect and disease control. All plants that die shall be replaced in a timely manner. After installation, all
landscaping shall be maintained in good condition as designed and approved.
5. Exception: Landscaping requirements shall not apply to individual single-family lots that do not require replatting or resubdivision of any kind.
B. Tree Preservation:
1. Tree Preservation Plan:
a. It shall be the public policy of the village to preserve and maintain, to the greatest extent possible, existing trees and significant vegetation within
the village.
b. All proposed developments that are greater than or equal to one-half (1/2) acre in size shall be required to provide a tree preservation plan which
shall:
(1) Designate key trees, significant trees, and significant vegetation as identified during the preparation of the required environmental studies and
site development plans. All key trees, significant trees and significant vegetation must be clearly identified within the required inventory and
shown on all development engineering and site development plans. All key trees, seventy percent (70%) of the significant trees, and sixty
percent (60%) of the significant vegetation shall be preserved.
(2) Include the location of tree protection fencing and the specific actions to be taken to protect each of the preserved trees. These actions may
include crown pruning, root pruning, fertilizing, and mulching.
(3) Provide any additional information pertinent to the site in question, its trees, or their relation to drainage or the other objectives of tree
preservation as set forth in this chapter, as may be required by the village manager or his designee.
2. Tree Protection:
a. All trees and shrubs designated to be preserved shall be fenced prior to the commencement of any work.
b. It shall be the responsibility of the contractor to assemble and install all tree protection devices as described:
(1) Fencing shall be forty eight inch (48") high density polyethylene (HDPE) with a nominal mesh opening of 1.25 inches by 1.25 inches and shall
be colored orange.
(2) Fence posts shall be metal "T" posts at least seventy two inches (72") in length.
(3) Fencing shall be installed at the drip line around all protected trees.
c. No protection device shall be removed without prior approval by an authorized representative of the village.
d. There shall be no construction activity or storage of any material within the enclosure or within the drip line of any tree.
e. All trees to be preserved within the construction zone shall be trimmed and root pruned prior to any construction activity in order to lessen the
impact of construction. The contractor shall be responsible for the proper completion of all trimming and pruning.
f. Where required, all trees shall be welled and protected against change of grade.
g. All trees and shrubs not specifically indicated for removal which are damaged shall be inspected by an authorized representative of the village.
The village will furnish the contractor with an action plan indicating all corrective action to be taken. It shall be the responsibility of the contractor to
complete all necessary remedial action.
h. All trees with a six inch (6") dbh or less and all shrubs not specifically indicated for removal, which are removed or damaged beyond repair, shall
be replaced by the contractor with plant material equivalent in size and species suitable for planting in that location, as determined by an
authorized representative of the village.
i. All trees larger than six inch (6") dbh not specifically indicated for removal, which are removed or damaged beyond repair, shall be replaced by the
contractor with plant material in size and species suitable for planting in that location, as determined by an authorized representative of the village.
Plant material shall be replaced on an inch for inch basis (i.e., one 30-inch dbh tree removed; replaced with six 5-inch trees). No replacement tree
shall have a diameter of less than three inches (3") or more than six inches (6"). In the event space does not allow for the required number of
replacement trees, the remaining trees shall be planted within the village rights of way as designated by an authorized representative of the village.
3. Tree Removal: No trees shall be removed from any development nor any change of the grade of the land effected until approval of the final plat or
final plan has been granted by the corporate authorities of the village.
4. Review: If there are special circumstances relative to a particular development, the applicant may request a review from the village manager, or his
designee. Based on this review, the village manager, or his or her designee, may grant relief from the preservation requirements for key trees,
significant trees, and significant vegetation, up to but not to exceed ten percent (10%). Any key trees, significant trees, or significant vegetation shall
be replaced at the following ratio:
Type Of Tree Or
Plant Required Replacement(s)
Key tree 2 inches of replacement for every 1 inch of removal. The minimum size for replacement trees shall be 6 inches in caliper.
Significant tree 2 inches of replacement for every 1 inch of removal. The minimum size for replacement trees shall be 4 inches in caliper.
Significant
vegetation
2 inches of replacement for every 1 inch of removal.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 509/522
Woody plant
material
The minimum size for replacement woody plant material shall be 11/2 inches in caliper.
Significant
vegetation
2 plants for every 1 plant removed. The minimum size herbaceous plant for replacement herbaceous plant material shall be
material equivalent to the plant removed.
5. Replacement Plantings: All replacement plantings shall be guaranteed for a period of three (3) years. A replacement plan shall be submitted to the
village manager, or his designee, for review and approval prior to the granting of the requested relief.
6. Minimum Requirements: The minimum requirements for tree preservation shall be a tree inventory and location survey for all trees on the property
that are twelve inches (12") dbh and larger and a type map of trees and significant vegetation less than twelve inches (12") dbh. The project design
must show that the project addresses the objectives set forth in the definition of "tree preservation" in section 11-3-13, "Definitions", of this chapter
and preserves significant trees as defined in said section 11-3-13 of this chapter.
7. Payment In Lieu Of Planting: In lieu of installing replacement tree(s), the owner or his designee may compensate the village with a cash payment at
the required replacement value. The replacement value shall be calculated using the following method:
a. The village shall obtain three (3) prices from area landscapers, for the purchase and planting of the required replacement trees.
b. The village shall take the average of those three (3) prices to calculate the replacement value.
c. The village shall invoice the property owner or his designee for the calculated replacement value.
d. The funds collected shall be placed in the current village tree planting budget and used solely for the purpose of purchasing and planting new
trees within the village, including, but not limited to, for the purpose of in arterial and/or tree replacement planting by the village. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-
10-2014)
11-3-23: EASEMENTS:
A. Village Easements: Easements shall be provided for village utility services. They shall be a minimum of fifteen feet (15') wide for any single
underground village utility and a minimum of twenty feet (20') wide for two (2) underground village utilities and be established where practicable at the
rear of each lot and along such other lot lines as to provide continuity of alignment from block to block. Additional easement width may be required to
accommodate unique circumstances including, but not limited to, multiple utilities, large utilities and/or extra deep utilities.
B. Public Utility Easements:
1. Easements shall be provided for public utility services. They shall be a minimum of fifteen feet (15') wide for any single underground public utility and
a minimum of twenty feet (20') wide for two (2) underground public utilities and be established where practicable at the rear of each lot and along
such other lot lines as to provide continuity of alignment from block to block. Additional easement width may be required to accommodate unique
circumstances including, but not limited to, village utilities, multiple utilities, large utilities and/or extra deep utilities.
2. All utility distribution facilities shall be installed underground to the greatest extent possible within easements and/or within dedicated public ways.
Any aboveground boxes shall be located so as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public. In addition, the village may require landscape
screening and/or special access provisions. The installation of such facilities shall be made in compliance with applicable orders, rules, and
regulations, pursuant to the Illinois public utilities act and other applicable provisions of this code.
C. Drainage Easements: When a development is traversed by an established stream, established drainageway, or channel, there shall be provided a
stormwater easement or drainage right of way conforming substantially with the same course of said stream, drainageway or channel. The location,
width, alignment, and improvement of such easement shall be subject to the approval of the corporate authorities provided that such easement shall be
not less than twenty feet (20') in width. Where swale drainage is used in lieu of storm sewers, as may be permitted herein, the easement shall be of
sufficient width to allow future construction of a storm sewer main adequate to carry the ultimate runoff, including, but not limited to, runoff from any
adjacent public way, and/or of the watershed in accordance with the Barrington watershed development ordinance.
D. Combined Easements: Village, public utility, and/or drainage easements may be combined into a single, nonexclusive easement. The location, width,
alignment, and improvement of such easement shall be subject to the approval of the corporate authorities provided that such easement shall be not
less than twenty feet (20') in width.
E. Easement Language: All easements shall be as per the language as specified in appendix D on file with the village, except as otherwise approved by
the corporate authorities of the village, or by their designee. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-24: EXPECTATIONS IN PLANNED DEVELOPMENT:
Whenever a development is developed under the planned development provisions of the zoning ordinance, the corporate authorities may, at its sole
discretion, approve certain variation(s) or exception(s) from the requirements of this chapter relative to the arrangement of the street(s) and lots within the
proposed development, but at the same time protect the health, welfare, safety, and convenience of the potential future residents of the development as
well as the character of surrounding properties and the general welfare of the community. (Ord. 14-3798, 11-10-2014)
11-3-25: DEDICATION OF SCHOOL SITES, PARK, FIRE/RESCUE, AND LIBRARY LANDS, OR CASH CONTRIBUTIONS IN LIEU
THEREOF:
A. Legislative Intent: As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision or of a final plat of a planned development, each subdivider or developer shall
be required to dedicate land for library, park, recreational, fire/rescue and/or school purposes to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents
of the development, or shall be required to make a cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication, or a combination of both, at the option of the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=576 510/522
village with the concurrence of the affected district or districts, which concurrence shall be obtained in writing. However, the corporate authorities of the
village shall make the final determination in this regard. Land dedication sites may be made to the village or to the applicable district at the discretion of
the corporate authorities of the village. The dedications and cash contributions required hereunder shall be made in accordance with the criteria and
formulas herein.
B. Criteria For Requiring School Site Dedications:
1. Requirement And Population Ratio: The ultimate number of students to be generated by a subdivision or planned development shall bear directly on
the amount of land required to be dedicated for school sites. The land dedication requirement shall be determined by obtaining the ratio of: a)
estimated children to be served in each such school classification over the b) maximum recommended number of students to be served in each such
school classification as stated herein, and then applying such ratio to c) the appropriate number of acres for a school site of each such school
classification as stated herein. The product thereof shall be the acres of land deemed needed to have sufficient land for school sites to serve the
estimated increase in number of students for each such school classification.
2. School Classifications And Size Of School Site: These requirements for acreage are based upon a review of available data studies and literature on
the subject, including, but not limited to, information provided by the state superintendent of education and the unique characteristics of the village,
including its general rural character and open spaces, and the desire of the residents to maintain this character and open space in future school
sites. These requirements for acreage shall be presumed as the appropriate acreage requirements and shall be used in calculating any cash in lieu
of land dedication herein unless timely objected to as provided herein. Objections to these acreage requirements for any particular development shall
be made in accordance with subsection Q of this section to the plan commission. Failure to timely object to these acreage requirements in
accordance with subsection Q of this section shall thereafter waive any right to raise an objection at a later time.
School classifications and size of school sites within the village shall be determined in accordance with the following criteria:
